Title: Temporal, Affective, and Embodied Characteristics of Taste Experiences: A Framework for Design
Author list: Marianna Obrist, Rob Comber, Sriram Subramanian, Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, Carlos Velasco, Charles Spence
Author emails: obristmarianna@gmail.com, robert.comber@newcastle.ac.uk, sriram@cs.bris.ac.uk, betina.piqueras-fiszman@psy.ox.ac.uk, carlos.velasco@psy.ox.ac.uk, charles.spence@psy.ox.ac.uk
Abstract: We present rich descriptions of taste experience through an analysis of the diachronic and synchronic experiences of each of the five basic taste qualities: sweet, sour, salt, bitter, and umami. Our findings, based on a combination of user experience evaluation techniques highlight three main themes: temporality, affective reactions, and embodiment. We present the taste characteristics as a framework for design and discuss each taste in order to elucidate the design qualities of individual taste experiences. These findings add a semantic understanding of taste experiences, their temporality enhanced through descriptions of the affective reactions and embodiment that the five basic tastes elicit. These findings are discussed on the basis of established psychological and behavioral phenomena, highlighting the potential for taste-enhanced design.

Title: Opportunities for Odor: Experiences with Smell and Implications for Technology
Author list: Marianna Obrist, Alexandre N Tuch, Kasper Hornbaek
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Department of Psychology, Center for Cognitive Psychology and Methodology
Abstract: Technologies for capturing and generating smell are emerging, and our ability to engineer such technologies and use them in HCI is rapidly developing. Our understanding of how these technologies match the experiences with smell that people have or want to have is surprisingly limited. We therefore investigated the experience of smell and the emotions that accompany it. We collected stories from 439 participants who described personally memorable smell experiences in an online questionnaire. Based on the stories we developed 10 categories of smell experience. We explored the implications of the categories for smell-enhanced technology design by (a) probing participants to envision technologies that match their smell story and (b) having HCI researchers brainstorm technologies using the categories as design stimuli. We discuss how our findings can benefit research on personal memories, momentary and first time experiences, and wellbeing.

Title: History Assisted View Authoring for 3D Models
Author list: Hsiang-Ting Chen, Tovi Grossman, Li-Yi Wei, Ryan Schmidt, BjÃ¶rn Hartmann, George Fitzmaurice, Maneesh Agrawala
Author emails: ht.timchen@gmail.com, tovi.grossman@autodesk.com, liyiwei@stanfordalumni.org, rms@dgp.toronto.edu, bjoern@eecs.berkeley.edu, George.Fitzmaurice@autodesk.com, maneesh@cs.berkeley.edu
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 1 - Ins: JST ERATO Igarashi Design Interface Project
Abstract: 3D modelers often wish to showcase their models for sharing or review purposes. This may consist of generating static viewpoints of the model or authoring animated fly-throughs. Manually creating such views is often tedious and few automatic methods are designed to interactively assist the modelers with the view authoring process. We present a view authoring assistance system that supports the creation of informative view points, view paths, and view surfaces, allowing modelers to author the interactive navigation experience of a model. The key concept of our implementation is to analyze the modelâ€™s workflow history, to infer important regions of the model and representative viewpoints of those areas. An evaluation indicated that the viewpoints generated by our algorithm are comparable to those manually selected by the modeler. In addition, participants of a user study found our system easy to use and effective for authoring viewpoint summaries.

Title: Visualizing Dynamic Networks with Matrix Cubes
Author list: Benjamin Bach, Emmanuel Pietriga, Jean-Daniel Fekete
Abstract: Designing visualizations of dynamic networks is challenging, both because the data sets tend to be complex and because the tasks associated with them are often cognitively demand- ing. We introduce the Matrix Cube, a novel visual representation and navigation model for dynamic networks, inspired by the way people comprehend and manipulate physical cubes. Users can change their perspective on the data by rotating or decomposing the 3D cube. These manipulations can produce a range of different 2D visualizations that emphasize specific aspects of the dynamic network suited to particular analysis tasks. We describe Matrix Cubes and the interactions that can be performed on them in the Cubix system. We then show how two domain experts, an astronomer and a neurologist, used Cubix to explore and report on their own network data.

Title: Scalable Multi-label Annotation
Author list: Jia Deng, Olga Russakovsky, Jonathan Krause, Michael Bernstein, Alex Berg, Li Fei-Fei
Author emails: jiadeng@umich.edu, olga@cs.stanford.edu, jkrause@cs.stanford.edu, msb@cs.stanford.edu, aberg@cs.unc.edu, feifeili@cs.stanford.edu
Abstract: We study strategies for scalable multi-label annotation, or for efficiently acquiring multiple labels from humans for a collection of items. We propose an algorithm that exploits correlation, hierarchy, and sparsity of the label distribution. A case study of labeling 200 objects using 20,000 images demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach. The algorithm results in up to 6x reduction in human computation time compared to the naive method of querying a human annotator for the presence of every object in every image.

Title: TouchTools: Leveraging Familiarity and Skill with Physical Tools to Augment Touch Interaction
Author list: Chris Harrison, Robert Xiao, Julia Schwarz, Scott E. Hudson
Abstract: The average person can skillfully manipulate a plethora of tools, from hammers to tweezers. However, despite this remarkable dexterity, gestures on todayâ€™s touch devices are simplistic, relying primarily on the chording of fingers: one-finger pan, two-finger pinch, four-finger swipe and similar. We propose that touch gesture design be inspired by the manipulation of physical tools from the real world. In this way, we can leverage user familiarity and fluency with such tools to build a rich set of gestures for touch interaction. With only a few minutes of training on a proof-of-concept system, users were able to summon a variety of virtual tools by replicating their corresponding real-world grasps.

Title: Overload is Overloaded: Email in the Age of Gmail
Author list: Catherine Grevet, David Choi, Debra Lauterbach, Eric Gilbert
Abstract: The term email overload has two definitions: receiving a large volume of incoming email, and having emails of different status types (to do, to read, etc). Whittaker and Sidner proposed the latter definition in 1996, noticing that email inboxes were far more complex than simply containing incoming messages. Sixteen years after Whittaker and Sidner, we replicate and extend their work with a qualitative analysis of Googleâ€™s Gmail. We find that email overload, both in terms of volume and of status, is still a problem today. Our contributions are 1) updating the state of email overload, 2) extending our understanding of overload in the context of Gmail and 3) comparing personal with work email accounts: while work email tends to be status overloaded, personal email is also type overloaded. These comparisons between work and personal email suggest new avenues for email research.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We replicated prior work on email overload. We extend this work from the perspective of two email habitats: work and personal email accounts, and expand the definition of email overload.
Summary of Changes: - updated the participant characteristics with more detail (as described in the rebuttal) and gave more information on the location of the interviews for the de-anonymized final version. \  \ - updated the limitations section with an explanation for our small sample size and a more thorough description of our choice of a qualitative study. \  \ - provided more detail for the re-operationalization of Whittaker and Sidner's email management categories. We did not attempt to redefine them, rather we had to find a way to map our Gmail participant along those categories. \  \ - added a paragraph in the discussion about disentangling work and personal email, in some cases they might overlap and we did not look at this in our study. We included the reference to Renaud et al provided by the reviewers.  \  \ - added a sentence about how status overload and type overload may overlap in many cases, though are clearly distinct. \  \ - edited grammatical errors and updated references

Title: Finder Highlights: Field Evaluation and Design of an Augmented File Browser
Author list: Stephen Fitchett, Andy Cockburn, Carl Gutwin
Abstract: Navigating to files through a hierarchy is often a slow, laborious, and repetitive task. Recent lab studies showed that file browser interface augmentations, such as Icon Highlights and Search Directed Navigation, have the potential to reduce file retrieval times. However, for this potential to be realised in actual systems, further study is necessary to address two important issues. First, there are important design and implementation challenges in advancing the research prototypes previously evaluated into complete interactive systems that can be used for real work. Second, it is unknown how real users would employ these systems while engaged in actual work; would the potential performance improvements suggested by the earlier lab studies be realised? We therefore describe the design, implementation, and longitudinal field study evaluation of Finder Highlights, a file browser plugin for the OS X 'Finder' that adds support for Icon Highlights and Search Directed Navigation. Study results confirm that the augmentations are effective in reducing real-world file retrieval times, with retrieval times 13% faster when using Finder Highlights compared to the standard tool (10.6 s versus 12.2 s), while also emphasising important differences between lab and field studies. In summary, the paper strongly suggests that large-scale deployment of interface augmentations to file browsers, particularly Icon Highlights, will have a marked effect in improving users' real-world file retrieval.

Title: Error Related Negativity in Observing Interactive Tasks
Author list: Chi Thanh Vi, Izdihar Jamil, David Coyle, Sriram Subramanian
Abstract: Error Related Negativity is triggered when a user either makes a mistake or the application behaves differently from their expectation. It can also appear while observing another user making a mistake. This paper investigates ERN in collaborative settings where observing another user (the executer) perform a task is typical and then explores its applicability to HCI. We first show that ERN can be detected on signals captured by commodity EEG headsets like an Emotiv headset when observing another person perform a typical multiple-choice reaction time task. We then investigate the anticipation effects by detecting ERN in the time interval when an executer is reaching towards an answer. We show that we can detect this signal with both a clinical EEG device and with an Emotiv headset. Our results show that online single trial detection is possible using both headsets during tasks that are typical of collaborative interactive applications. However there is a trade-off between the detection speed and the quality/prices of the headsets. Based on the results, we discuss and present several HCI scenarios for use of ERN in observing tasks and collaborative settings.

Title: Kickables: Tangibles for Feet
Author list: Dominik Schmidt, Raf Ramakers, Esben Pedersen, Johannes Jasper, Sven KÃ¶hler, Aileen Pohl, Hannes Rantzsch, Andreas Rau, Patrick Schmidt, Christoph Sterz, Yanina Yurchenko, Patrick Baudisch
Author emails: dominik.schmidt@hpi.uni-potsdam.de, raf.ramakers@student.uhasselt.be, esbenwp@diku.dk, johannes.jasper@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, sven.koehler@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, aileen.pohl@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, hannes.rantzsch@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, andreas.rau@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, patrick.schmidt@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, christoph.sterz@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, yanina.yurchenko@student.hpi.uni-potsdam.de, patrick.baudisch@hpi.uni-potsdam.de
Abstract: We introduce the concept of tangibles that users can manipulate with their feet. We call them kickables. Unlike traditional tangibles, kickables allow for very large interaction surfaces as kickables reside on the ground. The main benefit of kickables over other foot-based modalities, such as foot touch, is their strong affordance, which we validate in two user studies. This affordance makes kickables well-suited for walk-up installations, such as tradeshows or museum exhibits.  \  \ We present a custom design as well as five families of standard kickables to help application designers create kickable applications faster. Each family supports multiple standard controls, such as push buttons, switches, dials, and sliders. Each type explores a different design principle, in particular different mechanical constraints. We demonstrate an implementation on our pressure-sensing floor.

Title: Expanding the Input Expressivity of Smartwatches with Physical Pan, Twist, Tilt and Click
Author list: Robert Xiao, Gierad Laput, Chris Harrison
Abstract: Smartwatches promise to bring enhanced convenience to common communication, creation and information retrieval tasks. Due to their prominent placement on the wrist, they must be small and otherwise unobtrusive, which limits the sophistication of interactions we can perform. This problem is particularly acute if the smartwatch relies on a touchscreen for input, as the display is small and our fingers are relatively large. In this work, we propose a complementary input approach: using the watch face as a multi-degree-of-freedom, mechanical interface. We developed a proof of concept smartwatch that supports continuous 2D panning and twist, as well as binary tilt and click. To illustrate the potential of our approach, we developed a series of example applications, many of which are cumbersome â€“ or even impossible â€“ on todayâ€™s smartwatch devices.

Title: Is my Phone Alive? A Large-Scale Study of Shape Change in Handheld Devices Using Videos
Author list: Esben Warming Pedersen, Sriram Subramanian, Kasper HornbÃ_k
Abstract: Shape-changing handheld devices are emerging as research prototypes, but it is unclear how users perceive them and which experiences they engender. The little data we have on user experience is from single prototypes, only covering a small part of the possibilities in shape change. We produce 51 videos of a shape-changing handheld device by systematically varying seven parameters of shape change. In a crowd-sourced study, 187 participants watched the videos and described their experiences using rating scales and free text. We find significant and large differences among parameters of shape change. Shapes that have previously been used for notifications were rated the least urgent; the degree of shape change was found to impact experience more than type of shape change. The experience of shape change was surprisingly complex: hedonic quality were inversely related to urgency, and some shapes were perceived as ugly, yet useful. We discuss how to advance models of shape change and improve research on the experience of shape change.

Title: Expressive Touch: Studying Tapping Force on Tabletops
Author list: Esben Warming Pedersen, Kasper HornbÃ_k
Abstract: This paper investigates usersâ€™ ability to perform force-sensitive tapping and explores its potential as an input modality in touch-based systems. We study force-sensitive tapping using Expressive Touch, a tabletop interface that infers tapping force from the sound waves created by the usersâ€™ finger upon impact. The first part of the paper describes the implementation details of Expressive Touch and shows how existing tabletop interfaces can be augmented to reliably detect tapping force across the entire surface. The second part of the paper reports on the results of three studies of force-sensitive tapping. First, we use a classic psychophysic task to gain insights into participantsâ€™ perception of tapping force (Study 1). Results show that although participants tap with different absolute tapping forces, they have a similar perception of relative tapping force. Second, we investigate participantsâ€™ ability to control tapping force (Study 2) and find that users can produce two force levels with 99% accuracy. For six levels of force, accuracy drops to 58%. Third, we investigate the usability of force tapping by studying participantsâ€™ reactions to seven force-sensitive touch applications (Study 3).

Title: Effects of Display Size and Navigation Type on a Classification Task
Author list: Can Liu, Olivier Chapuis, Michel Beaudouin-Lafon, Eric Lecolinet, Wendy Mackay
Abstract: The advent of ultra-high resolution wall-size displays and their use for complex tasks require a more systematic analysis and deeper understanding of their advantages and drawbacks compared with desktop monitors. While previous work has mostly addressed search, visualization and sense-making tasks, we have designed an abstract classification task that involves explicit data manipulation. Based on our observations of real uses of a wall display, this task represents a large category of applications. We report on a controlled experiment that uses this task to compare physical navigation in front of a wall-size display with virtual navigation using pan-and-zoom on the desktop. Our main finding is a robust interaction effect between display type and task difficulty: while the desktop can be faster than the wall for simple tasks, the wall gains a sizable advantage as the task becomes more difficult. A follow-up study shows that other desktop techniques (overview+detail, lens) do not perform better than pan-and-zoom and are therefore slower than the wall for difficult tasks.

Title: Simplifying Orientation Measurement for Mobile Audio Augmented Reality Applications
Author list: Florian Heller, Aaron KrÃ_mer, Jan Borchers
Abstract: Audio augmented reality systems overlay the physical world with a virtual audio space. \ Today's smartphones provide enough processing power to create the impression of virtual sound sources being located in the real world. \ To achieve this, information about the user's location and orientation is necessary which requires additional hardware. \ In a real-world installation, however, we observed that instead of turning their head to localize sounds, users tend to turn their entire body. \ Therefore, we suggest to simply measure orientation of the user's body --- or even just the mobile device she is holding --- to generate the spatial audio. \  \ To verify this approach, we present two studies:  \ Our first study in examines the user's head, body, and mobile device orientation when moving through an audio augmented reality system in a lab setting. \ Our second study analyzes the user experience in a real-world installation when using head, body, or device orientation to control the audio spatialization. \ We found that when navigating close to sound sources head tracking is necessary, but that it can potentially be replaced by device tracking in larger or more explorative usage scenarios. \ These findings help reduce the technical complexity of mobile audio augmented reality systems (MAARS), and enable their wider dissemination as mobile software-only apps.

Title: Listening to the Forest and its Curators: Lessons Learnt from a Bioacoustic Smartphone Application Deployment
Author list: Stuart Moran, Nadia Pantidi, Tom Rodden, Alan Chamberlain, Chloe Griffiths, Davide Zilli, Geoff Merrett, Alex Rogers
Author emails: stuart.moran@nottingham.ac.uk, Konstantia.Pantidi@nottingham.ac.uk, tom.rodden@nottingham.ac.uk, alan.chamberlain@nottingham.ac.uk, chloe.ena@hotmail.co.uk, dz2v07@ecs.soton.ac.uk, gvm@ecs.soton.ac.uk, acr@ecs.soton.ac.uk
Abstract: Our natural environment is complex and sensitive, and is home to a number of species on the verge of extinction. Surveying is one approach to their preservation, and can be supported by technology. This paper presents the deployment of a smartphone-based citizen science biodiversity application. Our findings from interviews with members of the biodiversity community revealed a tension between the technology and their established working practices. From our experience, we present a series of general guidelines for those designing citizen science apps.

Title: PIM and Personality: What do our Personal File Systems Say About Us?
Author list: Charlotte Massey, Sean TenBrook, Chaconne Tatum, Steve Whittaker
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: University of California at Santa Cruz
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: University of California at Santa Cruz
Abstract: Individual differences are prevalent in personal information management (PIM). There is large variation between individuals in how they structure and retrieve information from personal archives. These differences make it hard to develop general PIM tools. However we know little about the origins of these differences. We present two studies evaluating whether differences arise from personality traits, by exploring whether different personalities structure personal archives differently. The first exploratory study asks participants to identify PIM cues that signal personality traits. While the aim was to identify cues, these cues also proved surprisingly accurate indicators of personality. In a second study, to evaluate these cues, we directly measure relations between structure and traits. We demonstrate that Conscientiousness predicts file organization, particularly PC usersâ€™ desktops. Neurotic people may also keep more desktop files. One implication is that systems might be customized for different personalities. We also advance personality theory, showing that personal digital artifacts signal personality.

We have changed the language throughout the abstract, introduction, study 2, and discussion to emphasize that this work is looking at the relationship between personality and PIM strategies in order to understand and predict PIM strategies (as opposed to predicting personality).   \

Title: Representatively Memorable: Sampling the Right Phrase Set to Get the Text Entry Experiment Right
Author list: Luis A. Leiva, GermÃ¡n Sanchis-Trilles
Abstract: In text entry experiments, memorability is a desired property of the phrases used as stimuli. Unfortunately, to date there is no automated method to achieve this effect. As a result, researchers have to use either manually curated English-only phrase sets or sampling procedures that do not guarantee phrases being memorable. In response to this need, we present a novel sampling method based on two core ideas: a multiple regression model over language-independent features, and the statistical analysis of the corpus from which phrases will be drawn. Our results show that researchers can finally use a method to successfully curate their own stimuli targeting potentially any language or domain. The source code as well as our phrase sets are publicly available.

Title: Smart Photo Selection: Interpret Gaze as Personal Interest
Author list: Tina Walber, Ansgar Scherp, Steffen Staab
Abstract: Manually selecting subsets of photos from large collections in order to present them to friends or colleagues or to print them as photo books can be a tedious task. Today, fully automatic approaches are at hand for supporting users. \ They make use of pixel information extracted from the images, analyze contextual information such as capture time and focal aperture, or use both to determine a proper subset of photos. However, these approaches miss the most important factor in the photo selection process: the user. The goal of our approach is to consider individual interests. By recording and analyzing gaze information from the user's viewing photo collections, we obtain information on user's interests and use this information in the creation of personal photo selections. In a controlled experiment with 33 participants, we show that the selections can be significantly improved over a baseline approach by up to 22% when taking individual viewing behavior into account. We also obtained significantly better results for photos taken at an event participants were involved in compared with photos from another event.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Manually selecting subsets of photos from large collections can be tedious. We show that an automatic approach that includes gaze data improves selections significantly over a baseline approach by 22%.
Summary of Changes: Revision Document #2 for the CHI Submission  \ â€œSmart Photo Selection: Interpret Gaze as Personal Interestâ€ù \ by Tina Walber, Ansgar Scherp, and Steffen Staab  \  \ We thank the anonymous reviewers for their valuable feedback. As requested, we have reworked the document and addressed comments raised by the reviewers. In addition, we have significantly improved the presentation. \  \ Below we respond to the additional comments made by the shepherds.  \  \ Q: Update discussion/conclusion \ A: Thank you for the detailed support for rewriting the discussion/conclusion section. This section was carefully reviewed and large parts were rewritten following your suggested structure. Please see Section â€œDiscussionâ€ù. \  \ Q: Different sites for the study, kind of computer used and mouse setting \ A: We have added a reference to the Section â€œParticipantsâ€ù for explaining why two monitors were used. The rest of the equipment and the experiment setup was the same for both groups. \  \ Q: Personal relevance  \ A: We added some text concerning the personal relevance in the introduction. \  \ Q: Spelling \ A: Thank you for your corrections and suggestions. We have updated the marked points and the whole paper was additionally spell checked by a native speaker. \  \ Q: faces in figures \ A: Each depicted person gave his/her agreement to the depiction. \  \ Q:  Fig 13 -  make clearer or consider removing \ A: For us this seems to be an important finding. It shows, that the results are not very stable and depend on the training set / test set split. We added additional text to the discussion regarding this finding. \  \ --- \  \ Revision Document #1 for the CHI Submission  \ â€œSmart Photo Selection: Interpret Gaze as Personal Interestâ€ù \ by Tina Walber, Ansgar Scherp, and Steffen Staab  \  \ We thank the anonymous reviewers for their valuable feedback. As requested, we have reworked the document and addressed comments raised by the reviewers. In addition, we have significantly improved the presentation. \  \ Below we respond to the meta-review comments as well as further individual reviewer comments: \  \ Question from the Meta-Review  \  \ Q: [â€_] the point of why people select photos.  \ A: We have added related work about the life cycle of photos to the â€œIntroductionâ€ù section. We payed particular attention to the motivation why people conduct photo selections and the relevance of the photo selection task in the life cycle (â€œselecting photos is a frequent taskâ€ù). \  \ Q: [â€_] serious attempt to improve the clarity and presentation of the results section in this paper. The results section is very difficult to digest and follow. [â€_]  \ A: We have reworked the results section. We now distinguish between findings on the user behavior (Section â€œUsers' Photo Viewing and Selection Behaviorâ€ù) and gaze-based selection results (Section â€œGaze Selection Resultsâ€ù). In the preambles of each sections, we give an overview of the presented content. \  \ Q: [â€_] basically the concern is that the authors have overlooked some core work on understanding how people 'enjoy' going through their photo collections (it's not all hard, painful work).  \ A: We have added related work to Section â€œIntroductionâ€ù, showing that the creation of a selection of photos is perceived as â€œcomplex and time consumingâ€ù for normal photo collections, while it could be a pleasure for special occasions. \ In addition, we added to the â€œDiscussionâ€ù section an explanation that gaze data alone will probably not be sufficient to make a â€œperfect selectionâ€ù. But it significantly improves over the state of the art. A photo management application might offer a feature that allows the users to create an (semi-)automatic selection just after viewing a set of photos. \  \ Q: R1 â€“ study setup: [â€_] I did find the experiment section a bit confusing. \ A: We rewrote the procedure section and paid particular attention to presenting the methodology applied in our experiment. We have added a new Figure 2, which illustrates this procedure. In the first step, the subjects are viewing the photos (here and only here we record gaze data). In the subsequent three steps, the subjects are performing three different manual photo selection tasks.  \  \ Q: R2/R3 - Results section/Stats (additional statistical analyses) \ A: We added the requested statistical analyses for the viewing and selection times to the new Section â€œUsers' Photo Viewing and Selection Behaviorâ€ù. In addition, we explain in Sections â€œMaterialsâ€ù and â€œSelection Results for Combined Measuresâ€ù why we used non-parametric tests in the analysis of the Likert scale results. To this end, we have added the results of the pre-tests performed to check the conditions of the parametric tests (see Shapiro-Wilk Test and Mauchly's Test). \   \ Q: R2 - I was wondering about intercorrelations among predictors and potential issues due to collinearity. \ A: We have added the results of the previously conducted pairwise Pearson's correlation tests in Section â€œSelection Results for Combined Measuresâ€ù for excluding strong correlations between the considered measures.  \  \ Q: [â€_] when would this 'free gazing' occur? In short, it's not clear that this is necessarily a good solution to the problem that you are aiming to tackle.     \ A: We have added an answer on this question to the â€œIntroductionâ€ù Section. \  \ Q: Figure 6, there are no labels for the x-axis of the chart. \ A: We have added labels to the x-axis of this chart (please note that Figure 6 is now Figure 7). In addition, we added some comments to the chart for an easier understanding of the depicted data. \  \ Q: Figures 8 and 10 only show numbers corresponding to the selection criteria and measures in the x-axis respectively, which makes it a bit difficult to follow.  \ A: The criteria and measures were added to the x-axis in Figure 8 (now Figure 9) and Figure 10 (now Figure 11). \  \ Q: R2 - Pixel distance vs visual angle: without any information on distance to screen (screen size is mentioned) it becomes difficult to get any idea about the actual visual angles involved.  \ A: We have added information about the visual angle degree for all pixel distances in Sections Procedure and Gaze Analysis. \  \ Q: R2 - Numbering of predictor variables: on page 5, top, variable numbers (14 - 19 & 1 - 13) are not in line with the numbering in Tables 1 & 2.  \ A: This error was fixed. \  \  \ Additional questions from Review 4  \  \ Q: [â€_] I found it hard to believe that an analysis of the 'sharpness' of the image would predict how likely it was that  someone would like the photo. [â€_] I felt that a little more could have been done in the related work section to show how well these measures work, or how popular they are in use. \ A: The sharpness measure is used in the related work for conducting fully-automatic photo selections (e.g., Xiao et al. and Boll et al.). Also Rodden and Wood (CHI 2003) mention technical poorness of photos as selection criteria such as sharpness. \ In addition, our participants rated the photo selection criterium regarding quality (â€œthe photo is clear, not blurry, good exposureâ€ù) as their third most important criteria (out of 9 proposed criteria).  \  \ Q: The analyses of pp. 7/8 seem to be in the wrong order â€“ what we have here is going from a detailed view (pp. 7) back out to a big view (pp. 8). [â€_] \ A: We better explain the order. In the first step, we investigate merely single measures (no machine learning). Only in the second step, we look at the combination of several measures using logistic regression. \  \ Q: The problem is when we come to eye-tracking data [â€_] we learn that it comes down to gaze duration [â€_]. What troubles me though is that this main point is never really articulated very clearly. \ A: We have added a clear statement to the â€œDiscussionâ€ù section. \  \ Q: A bigger concern comes from trying to understand why participants might have looked for longer at photos that were selected. It might be the case that the act of selecting a photo simply requires it to be looked at for longer (i.e., in order to select it with the mouse). [â€_] \ A: We have added a clearer description of the experiment procedure, including a diagram describing the steps (Figure 2, Section â€œProcedureâ€ù). The viewing phase and the phase when selecting the photos are two separate steps. \  \ Additional questions from Review 5 \  \ Q: [â€_] photo selection, particularly selection for other people, is a labour of love. [â€_] I wanted to see a discussion of this, or at least a critical comparison of these different approaches and what the pros and cons are somewhere in the paper.   \ A: We well acknowledge that â€œputting together collections for other people, or even for oneself is a processâ€ù that is also pleasurable and can provide a big personal payoff (see above). Details on this have been added to the â€œIntroductionâ€ù section.  \  \ Q: (Baseline Measures) Are any of these combined measures better than chance (or not)?  \ A: In Section â€œComputing Precision Pâ€ù, we show that the precision results for a random selection would be on average 0.33. Thus, all baseline measures perform better than the baseline approaches, although the difference is small for some measures. The combined baseline measures without gaze data reach a precision of P= 0.365.  \  \ Q: Were the participants themselves at the events in question?   \ A: As described in Section â€œMaterialsâ€ù, we have two photo sets taken at two events of two research groups (one in Europe and one in Northern America). In the experiment, the people participating in these events viewed both photo sets. Thus, while there is one photo set the participants were familiar with (as they participated in the event; called in this context the â€œHome Setâ€ù), the other photo set was unfamiliar to the participants (as it covered events from the other research group; called then â€œForeign Setâ€ù). \  \ Additional questions from Review 1 \  \ Q: When would this browsing [of photos] occur in practice? When photos are imported into the library in the first place? At a later stage? \ A: We have added information on this in the â€œIntroductionâ€ù section. \  \ Additional questions from Review 3 \  \ Q: [â€_] literature about how people make decision on the photo selection. \ A: We have added relevant literature in this area suggested by the reviewers as well as new works discovered by additional literature research. \  \ Q: It would be nice to see how much the performance of the automatic photo selection based â€œONLYâ€ù on the eye gaze information can improve or deteriorate?  \ A: Selection Se is based only on gaze data (see Section â€œSelection Results for Combined Measuresâ€ù and Figure 12). The results are good and comparable to the results combining gaze and baseline measures. \  \  \  \  \  \  \  \

Title: Food Messaging: Using Edible Medium for Social Messaging
Author list: Jun Wei, Xiaojuan Ma, Shengdong Zhao
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: NUS Graduate School for Integrative Sciences and Engineering
Abstract: Food is more than just a means of survival; it is also a form of communication. In this paper, we investigate the potential of food as a social message carrier (a.k.a., food messaging). To investigate how people accept, use, and perceive food messaging, we conducted exploratory interviews, a field study, and follow-up interviews over four weeks in a large information technology (IT) company. We collected 904 messages sent by 343 users. Our results suggest strong acceptance of food messaging as an alternative message channel. Further analysis implies that food messaging embodies characteristics of both text messaging and gifting. It is preferred in close relationships for its evocation of positive emotions. As the first field study on edible social messaging, our empirical findings provide valuable insights into the uniqueness of food as a message carrier and its capabilities to promote greater social bonding.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We presented a series of investigations on the applicability of food as a messaging medium, and provided valuable insights into its uniqueness and capabilities to promote greater social bonding.
Summary of Changes: We would like to first sincerely thank the ACs and reviewers for your thorough and constructive reviews before clarifying your questions and concerns below. \ 1)	Presentation of the methodology  \  \ â€¢	Combined methodology section for exploratory interview and field study (R1, R2)   \ We added a Methodology section and Table 1 on page 3 to summarize the series of studies before describing each research setting. \  \ 2)	Providing details of the methodology \  \ â€¢	Clarification of cost (R1, R2)  \ We added the following sentence on page 4, last paragraph of the section Food Messaging Service: \ "Each message cost about 0.45 USD, which is averaged over the cost of the printer, ink, icing sheets, cookies, and plastic bags."   \  \ â€¢	Justification regarding the office environment (R1, R2) \ We added the following sentence on page 4, paragraph 1 under the section Study Site to emphasize that our attempt was to test with professional people who are less likely to play with it as a toy and with richer varieties of social relationships.  \ "This company has a large base of potential users and fits well with our expected user group (professional, technologically savvy users who are more willing to try new things and less likely to play with it). The companyâ€™s size also enabled us to test the application in a variety of social relationships, and also users with different backgrounds (e.g. engineers, staff, etc)." \  \ â€¢	Transparency to employee's managers and bearing on employee's roles and job (R2); Clarification of the printing / delivery setup (R3) \ We added the following sentence on page 5, last paragraph of the section Food Messaging Service:  \ "With managerial approval, we opened the message pick-up counter in the employeesâ€™ canteen during lunch (12-1pm) and dinner (5:30-6:30pm), so as not to interfere with regular working hours." \ We added the following sentence on page 5, 1st paragraph of the section Data Collection: \ "On average, senders used 6 min. to submit a message and complete the survey online. There were no complaints about the process." \  \ â€¢	Details of food (R3) \ We added the following sentence on page 4, paragraph 2 under the section Food Messaging Service:  \  "The icing sheets, made from starch and sugar, have a sweet taste and a creamy aroma." \  \ â€¢	How long in average did recipient collect their food message (R3, R5) \ We added the following sentence on page 4, paragraph 2 under the section Food Messaging Service: \ "Each message was sealed in a plastic bag and ready for collection within a half day of request receipt. Twice daily, we sent a reminder email indicating the next available collection time and location. Printed food messages were kept up to 10 days for collection before being disregarded." \  \ 3)	Interpretation of the finding  \  \ â€¢	Coding issue and unclear data inclusion for the analysis (R2) \ We added the following sentence on page 5 under the section Coding Process:  \ "In other words, each coder could only assign one subcategory to each message... We computed the agreement on all the messages including the 30 training items at the subcategory level. We did not include the undecided 75 messages in the final analysis, because we decided they might be semantically ambiguous, making it difficult to interpret senders' intentions." \  \ â€¢	Recipients' dealing with the cookies (R3) \ We added the following sentence on page 8, paragraph 3 under the section Impacts of Physical Properties:  \  "Our data show receivers, especially females, opted not to eat food messages immediately. Some even expressed the interest of preserving the message. They first took photos, displayed messages on their desks, or kept them in the refrigerator." \  \  \ â€¢	Whether recipients follow up with the sender after receiving a food message (R3) \ We added the following sentence on page 8, paragraph 6 under the section Impacts of Social and Emotional Properties:  \ "In our data, many users wrote back via food messaging. Interviewees also mentioned using conventional channels (phone calls, online chat) to contact senders, similar to gift giving communication. This suggests food messaging can facilitate social dynamics and rebuild social connections." \  \ â€¢	The question is what "everyday communication" means in the study (R1) \ We added the following sentence on page 2, last paragraph of the section Background and Related Work:  \ "Which includes both practical and emotional communication, according to peopleâ€™s communication needs." \  \ â€¢	Clarify "more easily" (end of Discussion section) (R2) \ We have changed this to "to those they care for, in a fashion that combines traditional gift giving and messaging" to clarify the meaning on Page 9. \  \ 4)	Depth of analysis  \   \ â€¢	More analysis should be done on the motivational factors for using food messaging other than just curiosity (R1). \ We added a Motivation section in the Discussion part on page 9 to illustrate the motivational factors based on food messages' physical and emotional impacts, and people's communication needs, which haven't been satisfied by current messaging methods. (Please see in the paper) \  \ â€¢	Elaborate more on how different types of food may differ in serving communication purposes (R2) \ We added the following sentence on page 10, paragraph 5 under the section Implications for Future Design, combining it with the discussion about Mcluhan's saying:  \ "Every food could carry different meanings based on its color, texture, smell and taste. Chocolate means love and intimacy, while fruit may be translated as health and fresh." \  \ â€¢	Discussion on the impact of Chinese culture on gift-giving within the context of food messaging in this study (R3). More discussion on the differences between gift-giving and sending food messages in this context (R1, R2). \ We added content on page 9, paragraph 2, 3, 4 under the section Implications for Future Design (Please see in the paper) \  \ â€¢	Further discuss the food messaging niche in the world of social messaging and gift giving (R2)  \ We added the following sentences on page 6, paragraph 1 under the section Gender Bias to compare with literatures on gender differences of gift giving. \ "It may also result from the gender differences on attitudes and behaviors of gift giving. It is indicated that, "women are more likely to possess a positive orientation towards gift giving, and they are largely responsible for the practice of giving [32]." \  \ We also added content on page 8, paragraph 1,3,5 under the section Impacts of the Physical Properties (Please see in the paper) \  \ â€¢	Further, explicitly, unpack McLuhan in your discussion rather than just reference him at the end (R2) \ We added more discussion on this point and combined it with interviewee's suggestion that send food message using typical cultural foods on page 10, paragraph 5 under the section Implications for Future Design. (Please see in the paper) \  \ â€¢	More discussion on the "Food goes into body" perspective (R2) \ We added the sentences on page 7, 1st paragraph of Impacts of Physical Properties: \ "Recipients could better sense such emotional expression via consumption of the edible messages. This triggers a multimodal sensational and emotional response and the taste of food nicely complements the meaning of the message [5]. Different type of foods can be combined with different types of messages to create enriched and unique experiences." \  \ â€¢	Limitation of the current service and potential effect of operatorâ€™s access to messages (R5) \ We added the following information on page 10, last paragraph of the section Implications for Future Design.  \ "Although the service in this study did not support 3D printing or full automation of messages delivery, the insights were informative. Our participants did not seem to be concerned about the access of message content by the operator as the content typically does not contain much sensitive information. The privacy concern can be further mitigated when food messaging service becomes further expedited and automated, when mainstream food printers were marketed for use at work and home with higher efficiency. Moreover, a 3D food printer would bring an additional expressive dimension in designing the shape and look of food messages, which can be further investigated in future research." \  \ â€¢	More emphasis on how ingesting a message was different from just reading it (R5) \ We added the following sentence on page 8, paragraph 3 under the section Impacts of Physical Properties:  \  "Digesting the messages also reinforce recipients to memorize the content by heart since they cannot be reprocessed once consumed."  \  \ â€¢	Usage of 2D printer on icing sheets in the study instead of 3D printing on food (R5) \ We addressed this by adding the following sentences to the beginning of the methodology section on page 3 to point out that we have used the Canon 2D food printer.  \ "Concerning the potential issues of robustness, efficiency and operation complexity of our current 3D food printer prototype, we employed the commercially available Canon MG5320 edible printer that is capable of printing edible messages on supreme icing sheets (Figure 2) in the field study." \ It is again mentioned on page 5 when we talk about the apparatus of the field study. \

Title: Is Motion Capture-Based Biomechanical Simulation Valid for HCI Studies? Study and Implications
Author list: Myroslav Bachynskyi, Antti Oulasvirta, Gregorio Palmas, Tino Weinkauf
Abstract: Motion-capture-based biomechanical simulation is a non-invasive analysis method that  yields a rich description of posture, joint, and muscle activity in human movement. The method is presently gaining ground in sports, medicine, and industrial ergonomics, but it also bears great potential for studies in HCI where the physical ergonomics of a design is important. To make the method more broadly accessible, we study its predictive validity for movements and users typical to studies in HCI. We discuss the sources of error in biomechanical simulation and present results from two validation studies conducted with a state-of-the-art system. Study I tested aimed movements ranging from multitouch gestures to dancing, finding out that the critical limiting factor is the size of movement. Study II compared muscle activation predictions to surface-EMG recordings in a 3D pointing task. The data shows medium-to-high validity that is, however, constrained by some characteristics of the movement and the user. \ We draw concrete recommendations to practitioners and discuss challenges to developing the method further.

Title: Pinch-Drag-Flick vs. Spatial Input: Rethinking Zoom & Pan on Mobile Displays
Author list: Martin Spindler, Martin Schuessler, Marcel Martsch, Raimund Dachselt
Abstract: The multi-touch-based pinch to zoom, drag and flick to pan metaphor has gained wide popularity on mobile displays, where it is the paradigm of choice for navigating 2D documents. But is finger-based navigation really the gold standard? In this paper, we present a comprehensive user study with 40 participants, in which we systematically compared the Pinch-Drag-Flick approach with a technique that relies on spatial manipulation, such as lifting a display up/down to zoom. While we solely considered known techniques, we put considerable effort in implementing both input strategies on popular consumer hardware (iPhone, iPad). Our results show that spatial manipulation can significantly outperform traditional Pinch-Drag-Flick. Given the carefully optimized prototypes, we are confident to have found strong arguments that future generations of mobile devices could rely much more on spatial interaction principles.

Title: Prospective Motor Control on Tabletops: Planning Grasp for Multitouch Interaction
Author list: Halla B Olafsdottir, Theophanis Tsandilas, Caroline Appert
Abstract: Substantial amount of research in Psychology has studied how people manipulate objects in the physical world. This work has unveiled that people show strong signs of prospective motor planning, i.e., they choose initial grasps that avoid uncomfortable end postures and facilitate object manipulation. Interactive tabletops allow their users great flexibility in the manipulation of virtual objects but to our knowledge previous work has never examined whether prospective motor control takes place in this context. To test this, we ran three experiments. We systematically studied how users adapt their grasp when asked to translate and rotate virtual objects on a multitouch tabletop. Our results demonstrate that target position and orientation significantly affect the orientation of finger placement on the object. We analyze our results in the light of the most recent model of planning for manipulating physical objects and identify their implications for the design of tabletop interfaces. \

Title: Type-Hover-Swipe in 96 Bytes: A Motion Sensing Mechanical Keyboard
Author list: Stuart Taylor, Cem Keskin, Otmar Hilliges, Shahram Izadi, John Helmes
Abstract: We present a new type of augmented mechanical keyboard, capable of sensing rich and expressive motion gestures performed both on and directly above the device. Our hardware comprises of low-resolution matrix of infrared (IR) proximity sensors interspersed between the keys of a regular mechanical keyboard. This results in coarse but high frame-rate motion data. We extend a machine learning algorithm, traditionally used for static classification only, to robustly support dynamic, temporal gestures. We propose the use of motion signatures a technique that utilizes pairs of motion history images and a random forest based classifier to robustly recognize a large set of motion gestures on and directly above the keyboard. Our technique achieves a mean per-frame classification accuracy of 75.6% in leave-one-subject-out and 89.9% in half-test/half-training cross-validation. We detail our hardware and gesture recognition algorithm, provide performance and accuracy numbers, and demonstrate a large set of gestures designed to be performed with our device. We conclude with qualitative feedback from users, discussion of limitations and areas for future work.

Title: A Comparative Study about Children's and Adults' Perception of Targeted Web Search Engines
Author list: Tatiana Gossen, Juliane HÃ¶bel, Andreas NÃ_rnberger
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: Faculty of Computer Science / Institute of Technical and Business Information Systems / Data and Knowledge Engineering Group
Abstract: In this paper we describe an eye-tracking study where we compare children's and adults' search behavior and perception of search interface elements on search engine results pages (SERPs) during an informational and a navigational search with Google and a search engine for children. Our first results indicate that children employ an exhaustive scanning strategy combined with cued visual jumps. Then they navigate to the next result page and only then modify their query. Adults only scan the first three results, following the F-shaped strategy, and immediately reformulate the query. Children pay less attention to textual summaries and more to thumbnails than adults do. Children take notice of a navigational menu with categories while adults do not.

Title: Show Me the Invisible: Visualizing Hidden Content
Author list: Thomas Geymayer, Markus Steinberger, Alexander Lex, Marc Streit, Dieter Schmalstieg
Abstract: Content on computer screens is often inaccessible to users because it is hidden, e.g., occluded by other windows, outside the viewport, or overlooked. In search tasks, the efficient retrieval of sought content is important. Current software, however, only provides limited support to visualize hidden occurrences and rarely supports search synchronization crossing application boundaries. To remedy this situation, we introduce two novel visualization methods to guide users to hidden content. \ Our first method generates awareness for occluded or out-of-viewport content using see-through visualization. For content that is either outside the screen's viewport or for data sources not opened at all, our second method shows off-screen indicators and an on-demand smart preview. To reduce the chances of overlooking content, we use visual links, i.e., visible edges, to connect the visible content or the visible representations of the hidden content. \ We show the validity of our methods in a user study, which demonstrates that our technique enables a faster localization of hidden content compared to traditional search functionality and thereby assists users in information retrieval tasks.

Title: Perception of Ultrasonic Haptic Feedback on the Hand: Localisation and Apparent Motion
Author list: Graham Wilson, Thomas Carter, Sriram Subramanian, Stephen Brewster
Abstract: Ultrasonic haptic feedback is a promising means of providing tactile sensations in mid-air without encumbering the user with an actuator. However, controlled and rigorous HCI research is needed to understand the basic characteristics of perception of this new feedback medium, and so how best to utilise ultrasonic haptics in an interface. This paper describes two experiments conducted into two fundamental aspects of ultrasonic haptic perception: 1) localisation of a static point and 2) the perception of motion. Understanding these would provide insight into 1) the spatial resolution of an ultrasonic interface and 2) what forms of feedback give the most convincing illusion of movement. Results show an average localisation error of 8.5mm, with higher error along the longitudinal axis. Convincing sensations of motion were produced when travelling longer distances, using longer stimulus durations and stimulating multiple points along the trajectory. Guidelines for feedback design are given.

Title: The Department of Hidden Stories: Playful Digital Storytelling for Children in a Public Library
Author list: Gavin Wood, John Vines, Madeline Balaam, Nick Taylor, Thomas Smith, Clara Crivellaro, Juliana Mensah, Helen Limon, John Challis, Linda Anderson, Adam Clarke, Peter Wright
Author emails: g.wood2@newcastle.ac.uk, john.vines@newcastle.ac.uk, madeline.balaam@ncl.ac.uk, n.x.taylor@dundee.ac.uk, thomas.smith@newcastle.ac.uk, c.crivellaro@ncl.ac.uk, j.mensah@newcastle.ac.uk, helen.limon@newcastle.ac.uk, j.challis@newcastle.ac.uk, linda.anderson@newcastle.ac.uk, amazingcommonpeople@gmail.com, p.c.wright@newcastle.ac.uk
Primary Affiliation 7 - Department/Schoo: Newcastle Centre for the Literary Arts
Primary Affiliation 8 - Department/Schoo: Newcastle Centre for the Literary Arts
Primary Affiliation 9 - Department/Schoo: Newcastle Centre for the Literary Arts
Primary Affiliation 10 - Department/Scho: Newcastle Centre for the Literary Arts
Abstract: We detail the design of the Department of Hidden Stories (DoHS), a mobile-based game to support playful digital storytelling among primary school children in public libraries. Through a process of iterative design in collaboration with library staff and childrenâ€™s writers we designed DoHS to support the potential for playful storytelling through interactions with books. A deployment of DoHS with two classes of 8 to 10 years olds as part of their regular library visits revealed insights related to how to balance the expectations of a child-at-play and the requirement to further develop their creative reading and writing skills. Based on our experiences we recommend that designers create playful digitally based activities that encourage children to explore libraries and experience new interactions with physical books.

Summary of Changes: Changes document for CHI 2013 Paper: \  \ Department of Hidden Stories: The Department of Hidden Stories: Playful Digital Storytelling for Children in a Public Library \  \ Based upon reviewer feedback and our rebuttal, we have made the following alterations to our conditionally accepted paper. \  \ ABSTRACT & INTRODUCTION (p1-2): \ - In both the abstract and introduction (p1) we have emphasized now that DoHS was developed for children and 8 to 10 years of age.  \ - At the end of the introduction (p2), we have included an overview of three main stages of the iterative design process and the workshops that were involved in each. \ - Also at the end of the introduction (p2), we have made more explicit the paperâ€™s contribution as noted in the rebuttal. \  \ PLAY & STORYTELLING (p2-3): \ - We have incorporated the suggested additional and relevant literature by Fails et al, into our literature review on p3. Please note we already included StorySurfer as part of talking about the Interactive Childrenâ€™s Library Project. This was also suggested as additional literature. \  \ DESIGN PROCESS (p3): \ - Although it was not picked up explicitly by the reviewers as something to fix, we felt there was some ambiguity at the start of the DESIGN PROCESS section regarding the purpose of the initial workshop. We have rewritten much of the text on p3 to clarify this. \  \ DEPARTMENT OF HIDDEN STORIES (p5): \ - At the start of p5 we now explain how creating DoHS as a digital game presented clear advantages over the card-based storytelling game that was created for the pilot study. \ - We have also adjusted the flow of the text on this page to forefront the interactive techniques we made us of in the DoHS app before discussing the two game modes. \  \ PILOT STUDY (p4): \ - We have added additional information about the ages of the children participating in the study and how they represented a diverse range of literacy proficiency.  \  \ THE STUDY (p5-6): \ - On p5-6 we have added additional detail to describe the approach of coding the themes into some more detail adding some of the specific themes seen at earlier stages. \  \ CONCLUSION (p9): \ - We acknowledge how the childrenâ€™s reactions may be biased by their involvement in the earlier workshop, and note this as a limitation of the work. However we stress that we were reporting about an iterative design process which lead to digital game, rather than presenting a comparative study between a card-based game and the digital game. We also describe that how we have not over generalised our findings in order to present a rich understanding of the childrenâ€™s behaviors and responses to playing the game. \ - We have briefly mentioned the value our library partners got from the project and how we are performing ongoing work with other libraries. \  \ ADDITIONAL: \ - In response to the accessibility report we have now create alt text for all images in the document and ensured the tables are formatted correctly if a different format of display is used. \ - We have altered the dimensions and contrast of Figure 3 to ensure it is readable both on screen and when printed. \ - The final version has been copy-edited and the text has been tightened throughout to aid reading and avoid repetition. \

Title: Recreating Living Experiences from Past Memories through Virtual Worlds for People with Dementia
Author list: Panote Siriaraya, Chee Siang Ang
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Engineering and Digital Arts
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: School of Engineering and Digital Arts
Abstract: This paper describes a study aimed to understand the use of 3D virtual world (VW) technology to support life engagement for people with dementia in long-term care. Three versions of VW prototypes (reminiscence room, virtual tour and gardening) utilising gestured-base interaction were developed iteratively. These prototypes were tested with older residents (80+) with dementia in care homes and their caregivers. Data collection was based on observations of how the residents and care staff interacted collaboratively with the VW. We discussed in depth the use of VWs in stimulating past memories and how this technology could help enhance their sense of self through various means. We also highlighted key approaches in designing VWs to sustain attention, create ludic experiences and facilitate interaction for older people with dementia.

Author Keywords: 3D virtual worlds; older people; care home; dementia; gesture-based interaction
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We explored how virtual world technology was used by people with dementia and their caregivers in long-term care. Testing and revising prototypes iteratively gave insights related to design issues.
Summary of Changes: We would like to thank the reviewers for the constructive comments. Below are the corrections carried out in response to each of the reviews which have been suggested. All the revised sections were highlighted in green in the main text. \  \ Literature review \  \ 1. Add a 2-3 paragraph section on Caring for People with Dementia where you discuss the variability of dementia, the potential impact, and the Intensive Interaction work mentioned by R4, and mention the pressures on carers highlighted by R4 \ We have expanded the section on dementia and old age. In particular, we have discussed more about the variability of the symptoms and the impact of dementia for those who have the condition. In addition, we have added another paragraph about intensive interaction, the challenge in caring for dementia and the pressures on carers. Please see the highlighted text in page 1 and 2. \  \ 2.  In the Section on Technology in Dementia Care, add a paragraph where you discuss more explicitly how your work relates to work on reminiscence systems such as CIRCA. You need to make the difference between these systems and virtual worlds very clear, and clarify why it is important to study this technology separately, in particular given the clear user interface differences between CIRCA and your virtual worlds \  \ We have added a paragraph within the â€œVirtual worlds and their potential in dementia careâ€ù section (Please see the highlighted text in page 2) to discuss more explicitly how the approach we adopted in our system is different from other previous systems (such as CIRCA). \  \  \ Methodology \  \ 3. Please state at the beginning of the methodology section that the design of the Virtual Worlds evolved iteratively in consultation with carers and based on observations of residents, and provide a table that summarises each iteration of the VW prototype and the main reasons for changing the design. \ We have emphasised that the prototypes emerged iteratively at the first paragraph in the method section (Please see the highlighted text in page 2). We have also added sentences highlighting the key design changes and the motivation for the changes in each iteration. Please refer to table 2 in page 4.  \  \ 4. Please provide an overview table that shows for each of the 8 sessions how many carers were involved, at which care home they took place, and roughly how many residents were involved. \ We have added a table to provide more details about the visits and observation sessions which were carried out (Table 1). We have also provided further clarification in regards to the number of visits and observation sessions and focus group studies carried out. Please refer to the highlighted text in page 2-3 in the method section. \  \ 5. Explain whether the focus groups and interviews had a schedule, or whether they were free, based on observations. \ More information about the interviews and the focus groups has been added to the method section. The interviews were open-ended and usually involve a discussion of the intervieweeâ€™s opinions towards the prototypes, a suggestion on ways to improve it and clarification on some of the observations. The focus groups were structured around discussing the issues (problems etc) encountered in the earlier prototypes (a number of issues that were observed were prepared beforehand and this guided the focus group session) and then discussing ideas to improve them and also a discussion to find the best type of content and activity to use. Please refer to the highlighted text in page 2-3.  \  \ 6. Note how many people conducted the thematic analysis and how the coding evolved and was checked \ We have expanded the section about thematic analysis in the â€œData collection & Analysisâ€ù section to provide more information about how the thematic analysis was carried out. Please refer to the highlighted text in page 3. \  \ 7. When you describe the Virtual Worlds, make sure that you either add the motivation for the changes in each version, or point to the part of the study where that specific iteration is described \ Table 2 in page 4 has been added to highlight the key changes and the motivation for change in each of the iteration. We combined the motivation for change within the table describing the key changes to save space.  \  \ 8. Add a sentence that explains why you did not design for users in wheelchairs - what about users that use Zimmer frames or crutches? \ In the initial prototype, we wanted to utilize the full ability of the Kinect to detect the full range of user interactions (movement in ten joints which included head, neck arm and leg movements) and map them to the virtual worlds. However, it quickly transpired from the observation sessions that apart from exhausting the participants, this also excluded participants in wheelchairs and limited the experience for those who have difficulty in moving (such as those relying on Zimmer frames for movements). As such, the second prototype onwards (Virtual tour and gardening prototypes) utilized only movement from the usersâ€™ arms and hands, thus being more inclusive to residents in wheelchairs. We have added this discussion to the â€œVirtual world prototypesâ€ù section. Please see the highlighted text in page 3. \ As for residents with arm crutches or those having difficulty in moving their arms, this still remains a limitation in systems which use gesture-based interaction. Title: End-Users Publishing Structured Information on the Web: An Observational Study of What, Why, and How
Author list: Edward Benson, David R Karger
Abstract: End-users are accustomed to filtering and browsing styled collections of data \   on professional web sites, but they have few ways to create and publish such \   information architectures for themselves. This paper presents a \   full-lifecycle analysis of the Exhibit framework---an end-user tool which \   provides such functionality---to understand the needs, capabilities, and \   practices of this class of users. We include interviews, as well as analysis \   of over 1,800 visualizations and 200,000 web interactions with these \   visualizations. Our analysis reveals important findings about this user \   population which generalize to the task of providing better end-user \   structured content publication tools.  \

Title: In the Blink of an Eye: Investigating Latency Perception during Stylus Interaction
Author list: Albert Ng, Michelle Annett, Paul Dietz, Anoop Gupta, Walter F Bischof
Abstract: While pen computing has become increasingly more popular, device responsiveness, or latency, still plagues such interaction. Although there have been advances in digitizer technology over the last few years, commercial end-to-end latencies are unfortunately similar to those found with touchscreens, i.e., 65 - 120 milliseconds. We report on a prototype stylus-enabled device, the High Performance Stylus System (HPSS), designed to display latencies as low as one millisecond while users ink or perform dragging tasks.  \  \ To understand the role of latency while inking with a stylus, psychophysical just-noticeable difference experiments were conducted using the HPSS. While participants performed dragging and scribbling tasks, very low levels of latency could be discriminated, i.e., ~1 versus 2 milliseconds while dragging and ~7 versus 40 milliseconds while scribbling. The HPSS and our experimentation have provided further motivation for the implementation of latency saving measures in pen-based hardware and software systems. \

Title: Investigating the Effects of using Biofeedback as Visual Stress Indicator during Video-mediated Collaboration
Author list: Chiew Seng Sean Tan, Kris Luyten, Johannes SchÃ¶ning, Karin Coninx
Abstract: During remote video-mediated assistance, instructors often guide workers through problems and instruct them to perform unfamiliar or complex operations. However, the workers' performance might deteriorate due to stress. We argue that informing biofeedback to the instructor, can improve communication and lead to lower stress. This paper presents a thorough investigation on mental workload and stress perceived by twenty participants, paired up in an instructor-worker scenario, performing remote video-mediated tasks. The interface conditions differ in task, facial and biofeedback communication. Two self-report measures are used to assess mental workload and stress. Results show that pairs reported lower mental workload and stress when instructors are using the biofeedback as compared to using interfaces with facial view. Significant correlations were found on task performance with reducing stress (i.e. increased task engagement and decreased worry) for instructors and declining mental workload (i.e. increased performance) for workers. Our findings provide insights to advance video-mediated interfaces for remote collaborative work.

Title: Personal Tracking as Lived Informatics
Author list: John Rooksby, Mattias Rost, Alistair Morrison, Matthew Chalmers
Abstract: This paper characterises the use of activity trackers as â€œlived informaticsâ€ù. This characterisation is contrasted with other discussions of personal informatics and the quantified self. The paper reports an interview study with activity tracker users. The study found: people do not logically organise, but interweave various activity trackers, sometimes with ostensibly the same functionality; that tracking is often social and collaborative rather than personal; that there are different styles of tracking, including goal driven tracking and documentary tracking; and that tracking information is often used and interpreted with reference to daily or short term goals and decision making. We suggest there will be difficulties in personal informatics if we ignore the way that personal tracking is enmeshed with everyday life and peopleâ€™s outlook on their future.

Title: Gaze Gestures and Haptic Feedback in Mobile Devices
Author list: Jari Kangas, Deepak Akkil, Jussi Rantala, Poika Isokoski, PÃ_ivi Majaranta, Roope Raisamo
Author emails: jari.kangas@uta.fi, deepak.akkil@uta.fi, jussi.e.rantala@uta.fi, poika.isokoski@uta.fi, paivi.majaranta@uta.fi, rr@cs.uta.fi
Abstract: Anticipating the emergence of gaze tracking capable mobile devices, we are investigating the use of gaze as an input modality in handheld mobile devices. We conducted a study of combining gaze gestures with vibrotactile feedback. Gaze gestures were used as an input method in a mobile device and vibrotactile feedback as a new alternative way to give confirmation of interaction events. Our results show that vibrotactile feedback significantly improved the use of gaze gestures. The tasks were completed faster and rated easier and more comfortable when vibrotactile feedback was provided. \

Title: OJAS - Open Source Bi-Directional Inductive Power Link
Author list: Jussi Ville Mikkonen, Ramyah Gowrishankar, Miia Oksanen, Harri Raittinen, Arto Kolinummi
Abstract: We present the design, development and evaluation of a bi-directional inductive power transfer circuit for prototyping purposes in the watt-range. Our device does not require any configuration and is intended for the development of wearable and tangible systems. Our approach allows a bi-directional power flow without any change in the circuit, such that the same circuit can be used for charging and discharging a battery. The contribution of this work is an enabling technology for researchers and practitioners in the fields of Wearable Electronics, Ubiquitous Computing and Human-Computer Interaction interested in exploring new interactions powered by watt-range inductive links. It enables smaller battery sizes, and therefore lighter devices, as the power can be distributed in a way that has not been feasible before. We discuss the motivations, technical details and the workshop evaluating our inductive approach.

Title: Cloudy Forecast: An Exploration of the Factors Underlying Shared Repository Use
Author list: Charlotte Massey, Thomas Lennig, Steve Whittaker
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: University of California at Santa Cruz
Abstract: Many teams are now adopting shared repositories for their work. Such adoption is paradoxical, however, as past research has repeatedly shown major co-organizational barriers; teams cannot agree a common organizational scheme, making it difficult to retrieve information organized by others. Another barrier is email competition; email provides a reliable alternative for distributing files that are then personally organized. To address this paradox, we explored how 27 participants actively using shared repositories overcome these barriers in a qualitative study. We found teams addressed co-organization using 4 strategies. First they create ContentMaps that provide explicit structure to organize shared information. Participants also co-organize using implicit strategies based on task structure, expertise, and tool affordances. Greater shared repository use also leads to a changed role for email. Versioning problems mean email is not used for distributing attachments, instead for task management. We present technical implications suggesting how new tools might be better integrated with email facilitating these continued email uses.

Author Keywords: Shared repositories; co-organization; email competition; ContentMaps; versioning
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We present new findings that contribute better understanding of strategies used to successfully exploit shared repositories for collaboration, in contrast to prior work focusing on problems of co-organization.
Summary of Changes: Change document paper 514 \  \ As requested we have made the changes proposed by the reviewers and agreed in the final post committee reviews \  \ 1.	Novelty: We add material to the abstract, intro and discussion motivating the need to understand how shared repositories are being used successfully. In the intro we describe how prior work exclusively documents problems with shared repositories which fails to explain how and why such repositories are being increasingly adopted. In the discussion we describe these successful strategies we have identified. \   \ 2.	Technical Implications: in the discussion we discuss technical modifications to both email and repositories that could make them easier and more successful for participants to deploy. These include modifications to repositories to include ContentMaps, ContentMaps being standard email templates, automatic implicit indexing and communications information being integrated into repositories.  \   \ 3.	Results and Discussion. We clarify our findings on email, showing that although collaborative tools reduce attachment sharing, they increase overall email traffic with information about task management and alerting. This increased traffic may potentially lead to collaborative messages being overlooked. \  \ 4.	Outstanding empirical questions: we have added to the discussion, questions that arise from our work, including scalability, relations between email and shared repositories, and the role of leadership. \  \ 5.	Minor points: we have also rephrased our findings concerning adoption, â€˜novelâ€™ uses of collaborative tools, and on pages 5 and 7 added details about how ContentMaps serve to co-organize and assist with retrieval.  \  \

Title: Wave to Me: User Identification Using Body Lengths and Natural Gestures
Author list: Eiji Hayashi, Manuel Maas, Jason Hong
Abstract: We introduce a body-based identification system that leverages individual differences in body segment lengths and hand waving gesture patterns. The system identifies users based on a two-second hand waving gesture captured by a Microsoft Kinect. To evaluate our system, we collected 8640 gesture measurements from 75 participants through two lab studies and a field study. In the first lab study, we evaluated the feasibility of our concept and basic properties of features to narrow down the design space. In the second lab study, our system achieved a 1% equal error rate in user identification among seven registered users after two weeks following initial registration. We also found that our system was robust even when lower body segments could not be measured because of occlusions. In the field study, our system achieved 0.5 to 1.6% equal error rates, demonstrating that the system also works well in ecologically valid situations. Lastly, throughout the studies, our participants were positive about the system.

Title: Slide to X: Unlocking the Potential of Smartphone Unlocking
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial Arial,Italic Arial,BoldItalic Helvetica,Bold
Author list: Khai Truong, Thariq Shihipar, Daniel Wigdor
Abstract: Unlock gestures are performed by billions of users across the world multiple times a day. Beyond preventing accidental input on mobile devices, they currently serve little to no other purpose. In this paper, we explore how replacing the regular unlock screen with one that asks the user to perform a simple, optional task, can benefit a wealth of application domains, including data collection, personal-health metrics collection, and human intelligence tasks. We evaluate this concept, which we refer to as Slide to X. Further, we show that people are willing to perform microtasks presented through this interface and continue to do so throughout the day while they visit different locations as part of their daily routines. We then discuss how to implement this concept and demonstrate three applications.
