Title: Show me the Money! An Analysis of Project Updates during Crowdfunding Campaigns
Author list: Anbang Xu, Xiao Yang, Huaming Rao, Wai-Tat Fu, Shih-Wen Huang, Brian P. Bailey
Author emails: xu26@illinois.edu, y-x10@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn, huamingr@illinois.edu, wfu@illinois.edu, wenhuang@cs.washington.edu, bpbailey@illinois.edu
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Nanjing University of Science and Technology
Abstract: Hundreds of thousands of crowdfunding campaigns have been launched, but more than half of them have failed. To better understand the factors affecting campaign outcomes, this paper targets the content and usage patterns of project updatesâ€“communications intended to keep potential funders aware of a campaignâ€™s progress. We analyzed the content and usage patterns of a large corpus of project updates on Kickstarter, one of the largest crowdfunding platforms. Using semantic analysis techniques, we derived a taxonomy of the types of project updates created during campaigns, and found discrepancies between the design intent of a project update and the various uses in practice (e.g. social promotion). The analysis also showed that specific uses of updates had stronger associations with campaign success than the projectâ€™s description. Design implications were formulated from the results to help designers better support various uses of updates in crowdfunding campaigns.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Reports a taxonomy and use patterns of the types of project updates created during crowdfunding campaigns and design implications for improving crowdfunding tools that support update activities.
Summary of Changes: We addressed all the issues acknowledged in the rebuttal, as well as issues raised by the reviewers. \  \ 1) The primary AC and the secondary ACs suggested to address R3â€™ concerns on LDA and the taxonomy. We carefully revised the section ANALYZING UPDATES (RQ1) to address the concerns: \  \ (a) We added two paragraphs to provide a detailed explanation on why and how we apply LDA to our data at the sentence level. For example, we added â€œWe first attempted to perform LDA on the preprocessed text by treating each update as a document. However, we found that the resulting themes had too much overlap (i.e. many themes shared the same words), making the interpretation of the themes difficult. This is a known limitation of standard LDA. An alternative that has been applied in the text mining community is to decompose the document into finer granularities such as the sentence level in order to detect more specific topics and reduce the overlap [15]. Thus, we attempted to apply LDA at the sentence-level (each sentence was treated as a document)â€_â€ù \  \ Also, also the reference about sentence-level LDA [15] was added in the revision. \  \ (b) In order to help readers understand the reliability of the taxonomy, we added a paragraph describing how we performed human coding to examine the reliability of the taxonomy. For example, we added â€œTo verify the reliability of the produced taxonomy, we recruited two people to code a sample of the updates based on the taxonomy. First, the coders received training in which they were introduced to the categories, definitions, and examples in the taxonomy. They then coded updates on a small sample of the data and resolved disagreements. Then, they independently coded a random sample of 200 updates. There was good agreement between the coders and the dictionary-based method derived from the taxonomy with a Fleiss' kappa of 0.77.â€ù \  \ 2) R3 wanted to know about how to decide the order of the blocks in the regression. In the revision, we clearly described how the blocks were added to the regression model and emphasized that the order was not predefined by the authors. For example, in the first paragraph of section ASSOCIATION BETWEEN UPDATES & SUCCESS (RQ2), we added the following sentences: â€œSpecifically, the regression starts with no blocks in the model, tests the addition of each block using Nagelkerke RÂ_, adds the block that improves the model the most, and repeats this process for the remaining blocks. This allowed us to study which blocks were more important for the success of a campaign.â€ù \  \ 3) Based on R2â€™s suggestion, we revised examples in Table 1. For instance, for the New Reward category, we added the example â€œFor any contributions of $20 or more, here are [sic] your new bonus.â€ù Additional, similar revisions will be made to better communicate the taxonomy. For the Reminder category, we added the example â€œLess than 24 hours to go â€_ one last push and one last reminder.â€ù \  \ 4) The secondary AC (R5) and R2 suggested better contextualizing the findings. We cited all the suggested papers and revised the DESIGN IMPLICATIONS section. For example, we added â€œFrequent updates used to solicit support from funders reflect frequent communication used in social media to bridge social capital or gain other benefits [7]. Future work may examine how communication strategies (beyond update themes) in updates affect support from funders, similar to how the language used in online posts affects the likelihood of a reply [6].â€ù \  \ 5) Based on R3â€™s suggestion, we revised the ABSTRACT section to provide details on the findings. \  \ 6) Based on R2â€™s suggestion, we added the definition of â€œsuccessâ€ù on Kickstarter in the INTRODUCTION section. \  \ 7) Based on the secondary AC (R5) and R2â€™s suggestions, we revised Figure 1 to save space. \  \ 8) Based on the secondary AC (R5)â€™s suggestion, we changed "initial, middle, and final phase" to "initial, middle, and final thirds", and changed "Update Representation V.S. Project Representation" to "Update Representation vs. Project Representation". \  \ 9) We fixed the typo in Figure 4 (pointed out by R1).

Title: 3D Printed Interactive Speakers
Author list: Yoshio Ishiguro, Ivan Poupyrev
Abstract: We propose technology for designing and manufacturing interactive 3D printed speakers. With the proposed technol-ogy, sound reproduction can easily be integrated into vari-ous objects at the design stage and little assembly is re-quired. The speaker can take the shape of anything from an abstract spiral to a rubber duck, opening new opportunities in product design. Furthermore, both audible sound and inaudible ultrasound can be produced with the same design, allowing for identifying and tracking 3D printed objects in space using common integrated microphones. The design of 3D printed speakers is based on electrostatic loudspeaker technology first explored in the early 1930s but not broadly applied until now. These speakers are simpler than common electromagnetic speakers, while allowing for sound repro-duction at 60 dB levels with arbitrary directivity ranging from focused to omnidirectional. Our research of 3D printed speakers contributes to the growing body of work exploring functional 3D printing in interactive applications.

Title: Bodies in Motion: Mobility, Presence, and Task Awareness in Telepresence
Author list: Irene Rae, Bilge Mutlu, Leila Takayama
Abstract: Robotic telepresence systems---videoconferencing systems that allow a remote user to drive around in another location---provide an alternative to video-mediated communications as a way of interacting over distances. \ These systems, which are seeing increasing use in business and medical settings, are unique in their ability to grant the remote user the ability to maneuver in a distant location. \ While this mobility promises increased feelings of "being there" for remote users and thus greater support for task collaboration, whether these promises are borne out, providing benefits in task performance, is unknown. \ To better understand the role that mobility plays in shaping the remote user's sense of presence and its potential benefits, we conducted a two-by-two (system mobility: stationary vs. mobile; task demands for mobility: low vs. high) controlled laboratory experiment. \ We asked participants (N=40) to collaborate in a construction task with a confederate via a robotic telepresence system. \ Our results showed that mobility significantly increased the remote user's feelings of presence, particularly in tasks with high mobility requirements, but decreased task performance. Our findings highlight the positive effects of mobility on feelings of "being there," while illustrating the need to design support for effective use of mobility in high-mobility tasks. \

Title: Streaming on Twitch: Fostering Participatory Communities of Play within Live Mixed Media
Author list: William A. Hamilton, Oliver Garretson, Andruid Kerne
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Interface Ecology Lab @ Texas A&M University
Abstract: Previously, video streaming sites were at the fringes of online social media. In the past two years, live streams of video games, on sites such as Twitch.tv, have become very popular. Live streams serve as meeting grounds for player communities. The Twitch streaming medium combines broadcast video with open IRC chat channels. In conjunction with gameplay, viewer participation and community building gain emphasis. Twitch streams range in size and nature, from intimate communities with fifty viewers, to massive broadcasts with tens of thousands. In this paper, we present an ethnographic investigation of the live streaming of video games on Twitch. \  \ We find that Twitch streams act as virtual third places, in which informal communities emerge, socialize, and participate. Over time, stream communities form around shared identities drawn from streams' contents and participants' shared experiences. We describe processes through which stream communities form, the motivations of members, and emergent issues in the medium. Finally, we draw from our findings to derive implications for design of live mixed-media environments to support participatory online communities.

Title: Coding Livecoding
Author list: Benjamin Swift, Michael Martin, Henry Gardner
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Research School of Finance, Actuarial Studies and Applied Statistics
Abstract: Livecoding is an artistic programming practice in which an artist's \ low-level interaction can be observed with sufficiently high \ fidelity to allow for transcription and analysis. This paper \ presents the first reported "coding" of livecoding videos. From an \ identified corpus of videos available on the web, we coded \ performances of two different livecoding artists, recording both the \ (textual) programming edit events and the musical effect of these \ edits. Our analysis includes a novel, transition-matrix \ visualisation of the textual and musical dimensions of this data to \ create a "performer fingerprint". We show how detailed \ transcriptions of livecoding videos can be made which, we hope, will \ provide a foundation for further research into describing and \ understanding livecoding.

Title: The Vocal Chorder - Empowering Opera Singers with a Large Interactive Instrument
Author list: Carl E T Unander-Scharin, Ã…sa J Unander-Scharin, Kristina HÃ¶Ã¶k
Abstract: With The Vocal Chorder, a large interactive instrument to create accompaniment, opera singers can get more power over the performance. The device allows performers to interactively accompany themselves through pushing, leaning on and bending steel wires. The design was guided by the unique needs of the solo-singer, explored through autobiographical design and material explorations, some on stage, and later tested by other singers. We discuss how designing for opera and for the stage requires extraordinary durability and how opera performances can change with a bodily-oriented instrument such as The Vocal Chorder. Through a designerly exploration, we arrived at a device that offered (1) a tool for singers to take control over the rhythmical pace and overall artistic and aesthetic outcome of their performances, (2) an enriched sense of embodiment between their voice and the overall performance; and (3) a means to empower opera singers on stage.

Author Keywords: Opera; Autobiographical design; Interactive instruments; embodiment; empowerment; appropriation
Primary and Additional ACM Classifiers: H.5.m. Information interfaces and presentation (e.g., HCI): Miscellaneous.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: The Vocal Chorder is a large interactive instrument devised to create accompaniment for opera singers. We discuss how designing for opera and for the stage requires extraordinary durability.
Summary of Changes: Dear AC \ We have revised our paper on The Vocal Chorder, trying to take the wishes, suggestions and requests from you into account as much as we could. We decided to play down the claim in the title, and at the same time back up that very claim better within the paper. This we did with more citations by our participants, as well as with additional references (namely the critic David Littlejohn's reasoning on the various ages in opera and the ongoing changes in power structures; followed by Sandgren's dissertation on opera singers and health; as well as a pinch of thinking on the industrial "Fach"-system and it's consequences for contemporary opera singers). \ Furthermore, we extended the parts on how the changes in orchestras throughout the ages have directly inflicted changes in vocal practice.  \ We tried to deepen the parts regarding the actual physical interaction for the singers, and how that changed and transformed their vocal practice. In addition, we did rub up some of the parts on the design itself, trying to deepen them a bit, as well as adding testimony from one of our participants on how her views on her own partaking in the operatic world actually did change as a consequence from participating in our work - all of which is building up to our revised finale/ conclusion.  \ At the end of the day, we kept our references to McCarthy & Wright, as we felt that it situates our thinking and aims quite well. Even though we found many of the suggested additional references inspiring and well-fitting for our paper, we realized that due to lack of additional space as well as due to the already present argumentation in the paper, we had to refrain from them. If you feel that the paper now is blatantly missing any of these, we will of course do a new try to tuck them in.  \ With sincere regards \ The Vocal Chorder Team/ Carl Unander-Scharin  \

Title: A Chair as Ubiquitous Input Device: Exploring Semaphoric Chair Gestures for Focused and Peripheral Interaction
Author list: Kathrin Probst, David Lindlbauer, Michael Haller, Bernhard Schwartz, Andreas Schrempf
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Abstract: During everyday office work we are used to controlling our computers with keyboard and mouse, while the majority of our body remains unchallenged and the physical workspace around us stays largely unattended. Addressing this untapped potential, we explore the concept of turning a flexible office chair into a ubiquitous input device. To facilitate daily desktop work, we propose the utilization of semaphoric chair gestures that can be assigned to specific application functionalities. The exploration of two usage scenarios in the context of focused and peripheral interaction demonstrates high potential of chair gestures as additional input modality for opportunistic, hands-free interaction.

Title: Quantifying Visual Preferences Around the World
Author list: Katharina Reinecke, Krzysztof Gajos
Abstract: Website aesthetics have been recognized as an influential moderator of people's behavior and perception.  \ However, what users perceive as ``good design" is subject to individual preferences, questioning the feasibility of universal design guidelines. To better understand how people's visual preferences differ, we collected 2.4 million ratings of the visual appeal of websites from nearly 40 thousand participants of diverse backgrounds. We address several gaps in the knowledge about design preferences of previously understudied groups. Among other findings, our results show that the level of colorfulness and visual complexity at which visual appeal is highest strongly varies: Females, for example, liked colorful websites more than males. A high education level generally lowers this preference for colorfulness. Russians preferred a lower visual complexity, and Macedonians liked highly colorful designs more than any other country in our dataset. We contribute a computational model and estimates of peak appeal that can be used to support rapid evaluations of website design prototypes for specific target groups.  \

Title: ZWERM: a Modular Component Network Approach for an Urban Participation Game
Author list: Thomas Laureyssens, Tanguy Coenen, Laurence Claeys, Peter Mechant, Johan Criel, Andrew Vande Moere
Author emails: thomas.laureyssens@khlim.be, tanguy.coenen@iminds.be, laurence.claeys@iminds.be, peter.mechant@ugent.be, johan.criel@alcatel-lucent.com, andrew.vandemoere@kuleuven.be
Primary Affiliation 6 - Department/Schoo: Design Lab, Department of Architecture, Urbanism and Planning
Abstract: As information technology is increasingly embedded in our cities, opportunities arise to design novel applications that benefit urban communities. We describe the design and evaluation of ZWERM (Dutch for the term â€˜swarmâ€™), a public game that was specifically designed for augmenting community participation in urban neighborhoods. A network of ten components has been designed, some of which had different interfaces and design approaches: from totem-like Trees for gathering around with RFID cards to playful Sparrows that react on whistle sounds. After implementing the urban game in two city neighborhoods, we investigated the impact of each of these components on their communities. Our insights are useful for the public interaction design of future urban, interactive networks that aim to positively influence community participation and social cohesion.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We describe the design and evaluation of a public game, consisting of networked components, for augmenting community participation in urban neighborhoods.
Summary of Changes: - Clarified Interaction Amplification Framework:  \ The model is unable to predict interaction, but provides a language for comparing placement options, which enables to make such decision more consciously.  \  \ - Added non-participation:  \ The poll showed that a lack of time was the most common reasons for non-participation. Also, interviews revealed that the components and the weather conditions were not suit to the physical needs of elderly.  \ Future focus group sessions with these groups are expected to give insight to their needs and preferences and could become a point of entry into their local community networks. \  \ - Added that participation is not for everyone:  \ Such interventions, although not for everyone (some prefer anonymity), can benefit the community at large [3].  \  \ - Added the design workflow:  \ Such interventions, although not for everyone (some prefer anonymity), can benefit the community at large. \  \ - Clarified the difference between recurring gameplay and Missions:  \ The game featured a set of recurrent game plays, playful physical interventions that could be freely interacted with between 8am and 10pm. These were complemented by small online tasks, such as answering questions, which each player could complete once a week. Additional weekly tangible Missions were conceived by game masters, civil servants with local knowledge and existing local networks with potential players. These missions were chosen to balance between entertainment value, team dynamics and benefit for the neighborhood (PER, REL, EMP), aimed to stimulate community action.  \  \ - Clarified the placement of the Trees: \ They were placed on a central square in the neighborhoods, considering the pedestrian safety norms.  \  \ - Added data on city and neighbourhoods:  \ In 2012, the city had a total of 247.941 inhabitants. T1: 7286 residents, 1040 of ethnic minority and 1461 older than 70. T2: 6958 residents, 899 of ethnic minority and 854 older than 70.  \  \ - Added the potential of users valuing their game additions as their own: \ Potentially, players themselves could design and build their own components and extend the game infrastructure. Valuing game modules as their own could generate very own dynamics. However, it remains a question what the importance is of a binding visual and conceptual metaphor (e.g. the reference to nature in ZWERM), which might be needed for players to perceive a networked project as a unified game.

Title: Utilising Insight Journalism for Community Technology Design
Author list: Nick Taylor, David M Frohlich, Paul Egglestone, Justin Marshall, Jon Rogers, Alicia Blum-Ross, John Mills, Mike Shorter, Patrick Olivier
Author emails: n.x.taylor@dundee.ac.uk, d.frohlich@surrey.ac.uk, pegglestone@uclan.ac.uk, justin.marshall@falmouth.ac.uk, J.Rogers@dundee.ac.uk, a.blum-ross@lse.ac.uk, jmills@uclan.ac.uk, mail@mrshorter.co.uk, p.l.olivier@ncl.ac.uk
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Digital World Research Centre, School of Arts
Primary Affiliation 6 - Institution: London School of Economics and Political Science
Abstract: We describe the process of insight journalism, in which local amateur journalists were used to generate unique insights into the digital needs of a community. We position this as a means for communities to represent themselves to designers, both as a method of designing community technologies and as a first step towards supporting innovation at a local level. To demonstrate insight journalism, we present two case studies of community technologies that were directly inspired, informed and evaluated by journalistic content. Based on this experience, we evaluate the role that insight journalism can play in designing for communities, the particular characteristics that it lends to the design process and how it might be employed to support sustainable community innovation.

Author Keywords: Design; citizen journalism; community; local innovation; participatory design; co-design; ethnography
Thumbnail Image Caption: A citizen journalist interviews a local resident in Preston, UK. Journalism was utilised to inform the design of technologies that responded to the community's needs.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Insight journalism employs local amateur journalists to generate unique insights into the digital needs of a community. This process allows communities to represent themselves to designers developing innovative technologies.
Summary of Changes: -	Emphasised the core contribution â€“ demonstrating that insight journalism can work as a design tool and subsequently examining how it might enable local innovation. This has been added to the introduction, analysis and conclusions. \  \ -	Clarified our motivation and choice of citizen journalism as a tool in the introduction. \  \ -	Added further process details to the method section. Including info about the editorial team, payment for the journalists, timings of different stages, been more precise about the meetings that journalists attended and emphasised the close working relationship and editorial policy between the two.  \  \ -	Changed the ending of the Wayfinder section to reflect a little more on the failure/success of this design. \  \ -	Each analysis sub-section has been tweaked to include discussion of how that particular property might be applicable to local innovation. This has included re-working the first sub-section to be about the responsiveness and reflexivity of the process. \  \ -	Extensively reworked the conclusion to more succinctly summarise the contributions, benefits of the process and next steps in realising true local innovation. \  \ -	Added relevant reference to sustainability in community journalism. \  \ -	Adjusted language around â€˜utilisingâ€™ journalists (but not to utilising the method, which is subtly different). \  \ -	We looked closely at R5â€™s suggestion of cutting down the case studies in favour of a much more detailed method section. However, from our perspective, the design and deployment of these prototypes was the meat of the project. What we want to avoid is being overly prescriptive with how this process should be implemented: our project was complex and fluid and would naturally vary dramatically between different communities and contexts. Instead, we aimed to give concrete examples of how we utilised the journalism in a design process, that others might adapt.

Title: Always Somewhere, Never There: Using Critical Design to Understand Database Interactions
Author list: Melanie Feinberg, Daniel Carter, Julia Bullard
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: The University of Texas at Austin
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: The University of Texas at Austin
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: The University of Texas at Austin
Abstract: Structured databases achieve effective searching and sorting by enacting sharply delineated category boundaries around their contents. While this enables precise retrieval, it also distorts identities that exist between category lines. A choice between Single and Married, for example, blurs distinctions within the Single group: single, perhaps, merely because same-sex marriage is not legal in oneâ€™s locality. Sociologists Susan Leigh Star and Geoffrey Bowker describe such residual states as inevitable byproducts of information systems. To minimize residuality, traditional practice for descriptive metadata seeks to demarcate clear and objective classes. In this study, we use critical design to question this position by creating information collections that foreground the residual, instead of diminishing it. We then interrogate our design experiments with solicited critical responses from invited experts and student designers. Inspired by the anthropologist Tim Ingold, we argue that our experiments illuminate a form of interacting with databases characterized by notions of wayfaring, or inhabiting a space, as opposed to notions of transport, or reaching a known destination. We suggest that the form of coherence that shapes a wayfaring database is enacted through its flow, or fluid integration between structure and content.

We have also added some references to the Conceptual Underpinnings section to clarify linkages between our goals and those of others who propose to use ambiguity, contradiction, plurality, and so on as design resources for HCI>  \  \ We have also made small edits throughout to increase clarity.  \  \ Thank you so much to all the reviewers for the helpful feedback!

Title: Probabilistic Palm Rejection Using Spatiotemporal Touch Features and Iterative Classification
Author list: Julia Schwarz, Robert Xiao, Jennifer Mankoff, Scott Hudson, Chris Harrison
Abstract: Tablet computers are often called upon to emulate classical pen-and-paper input. However, touchscreens typically lack the means to distinguish between legitimate stylus and finger touches and touches with the palm or other parts of the hand. This forces users to rest their palms elsewhere or hover above the screen, resulting in ergonomic and usability problems. We present a probabilistic touch filtering approach that uses the temporal evolution of touch contacts to reject palms. Our system improves upon previous approaches, reducing accidental palm inputs to 0.016 per pen stroke, while correctly passing 98% of stylus inputs.

Title: Design Patterns for Exploring and Prototyping Human-Robot Interactions
Author list: Allison SauppÃ©, Bilge Mutlu
Abstract: Robotic products are envisioned to offer rich interactions in a range of environments. While their specific roles will vary across applications, these products will draw on fundamental building blocks of interaction, such as greeting people, narrating information, providing instructions, and asking and answering questions. In this paper, we explore how such building blocks might serve as interaction design patterns that enable design exploration and prototyping for human-robot interaction. To construct a pattern library, we observed human interactions across different scenarios and identified seven patterns, such as question-answer pairs. We then designed and implemented  Interaction Blocks, a visual authoring environment that enabled prototyping of robot interactions using these patterns. Design sessions with designers and developers demonstrated the promise of using a pattern language for designing robot interactions, confirmed the usability of our authoring environment, and provided insights into future research on tools for human-robot interaction design.

Title: The Personal Cockpit: A Spatial Interface for Effective Task Switching on Head-Worn Displays
Author list: Barrett Ens, Rory Finnegan, Pourang Irani
Abstract: As wearable computing goes mainstream, we must improve the state of interface design to keep users productive with natural-feeling interactions. We present the Personal Cockpit, a solution for mobile multitasking on head-worn displays. We appropriate empty space around the user to situate virtual windows for use with direct input. Through a design-space exploration, we run a series of user studies to fine-tune our layout of the Personal Cockpit. In our final evaluation, we compare our design against two baseline interfaces for switching between everyday mobile applications. This comparison highlights the deficiencies of current view-fixed displays, as the Personal Cockpit provides a 40% improvement in application switching time. We demonstrate of several useful implementations and a discussion of important problems for future implementation of our design on current and near-future wearable devices.

Title: Stewarding a Legacy: Responsibilities and Relationships in the Management of Post-mortem Data
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial,Italic Arial
Author list: Jed R Brubaker, Lynn Dombrowski, Anita M Gilbert, Nafiri Kusumakaulika, Gillian R Hayes
Abstract: This paper extends research on the giving and inheriting of digital artifacts by examining social network site accounts post-mortem. Given the important role that social network sites play in online bereavement practices, we conducted a series of in-depth qualitative interviews to explore issues around inheritance and post-mortem data management of Facebook accounts. We found that participants focused less on ownership of the data, and instead on the duties and potential conflicts associated with maintaining an account post-mortem. Subsequently, we argue for â€œstewardshipâ€ù as an alternative to inheritance for framing post-mortem data management practices. Analysis of post-mortem data management activities highlights how stewards are accountable and responsible to the deceased and various survivors. However, weighing competing responsibilities is complicated by varied relationships with disparate survivors, as well as the inability to consult with the deceased. Based on our findings, we claim that post-mortem solutions need to account for the needs of stewards in addition to those of the deceased and survivors. We suggest that a model of stewardship better accounts for the interpersonal responsibilities that accompany online data than inheritance alone.

Summary of Changes: CHI Revision Report - #590 \  \ The following changes have been made to the document: \  \ Objective, Implications, and Contributions: \ 1.	Text throughout the document has been clarified, in particular the conclusion, to better frame our paper.  \ 2.	We specifically note that this paper does not contribute specific design recommendations, and that this should be done in future research. \ 3.	Following R2, we detailed some of the implications of not addressing the needs of stewards â€“ specifically the challenging position of having to mediate conflicting needs, and the problems this may present for their own mourning. \  \ Methods: \ 1.	We provided the gender breakdown of participants (R2). \ 2.	We explained that remote participants were sent a packet of sketches and were instructed to turn to specific pages during the interview (R2).  \ 3.	We clarified that while the three interviewing authors engaged in the open-coding of the interviews, all authors were involved in the synthesizing analysis that resulted in the final categories (R2). \  \ Related work: \ 1.	The related work identified by R3 was incorporated. \ 2.	In response to R5, more detailed age information was provided about our participants [age 20-50 (M=30.9; SD=10)]. \  \ Legal Issues: \ 1.	In response to R3, we added text to the related work explaining that while legal and policy issues around post-mortem data are evolving, the current study reflects the perspective of would-be-inheritors and demonstrates that inheritance may not be the most appropriate model when designing future services or solutions. \  \ Findings: \ 1.	At times the number of participants is only implied â€“ often with the term â€œmanyâ€ù (R2). We clarified this language throughout the findings with more specific numbers where appropriate.  \  \ Finally, we corrected typos mentioned by the reviewers throughout, along with generally tightening the language in order to make space for the new content. \

Title: Kinect-taped Communication: Using Motion Sensing to Study Gesture Use and Similarity in Face-to-Face and Computer-Mediated Brainstorming
Author list: Hao-Chuan Wang, Chien-Tung Lai
Abstract: One key difference between face-to-face (F2F) communication and computer-mediated communication (CMC) is the availability of visual cues. It is often assumed that the reduction of visibility in audio and video conferencing may negatively impact the use of gesture to communicate, and thus negatively influence other outcomes. In this paper we "Kinect-taped" F2F and CMC communication in brainstorming groups by using motion sensors to record and analyze group membersâ€™ hand movements during communication. We investigate how different media influence gesture use and gestural similarity, and how the use of gesture associates with level of understanding and brainstorming performance. Implications to future research and design are discussed.

Title: Towards Community-Centered Support for Peer-to-Peer Service Exchange: Rethinking the Timebanking Metaphor
Author list: Victoria Bellotti, Sara Cambridge, Karen Hoy, Patrick Shih, Lisa Handalian, Kyungsik Han, John Carroll
Author emails: bellotti@parc.com, smcambridge@gmail.com, karen_hoy@mba.berkeley.edu, patshih@ist.psu.edu, LHandalian@CCA.edu, kuh178@psu.edu, jmcarroll@psu.edu
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Palo Alto Research Center Palo Alto
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: College of Information Sciences and Technology
Primary Affiliation 6 - Department/Schoo: College of Information Sciences and Technology
Primary Affiliation 7 - Department/Schoo: College of Information Sciences and Technology
Abstract: Commercial peer-to-peer service exchange businesses, such as AirBnB, Lyft and TaskRabbit, are expanding rapidly, but their non-profit counterparts are lagging behind. We conducted a field study of the most prominent of these, timebanking; a system in which â€˜time dollarsâ€™ are earned and spent by people providing services for and receiving them from each other. Our study exposed problems with the very metaphor of banking itself, which deter participation. In this paper we discuss how these problems can be tackled with user experience design for systems supporting timebanking. Our design ideas emphasize the personal and social benefits of participation, and avoid such unappealing concepts as debt and neediness that the timebanking metaphor falls afoul of.

Title: Offline Painted Media for Digital Animation Authoring
Author list: Makoto Nakajima, Daisuke Sakamoto, Takeo Igarashi
Abstract: We present an animation creation workflow for integrating offline physical, painted media into the digital authoring of Flash-style animations. Generally, animators create animations with standardized digital authoring software. However, the results tend to lack the individualism or atmosphere of physical media. In contrast, illustrators have skills in painting physical media but have limited experience in animation. To incorporate their skills, we present a workflow that integrates the offline painting and digital animation creation processes in a labor-saving manner. First, a user makes a rough sketch of the visual elements and defines their movements using our digital authoring software with a sketch interface. Then these images are exported to printed pages, and users can paint using offline physical media. Finally, the work is scanned and imported back into the digital content, forming a composite animation that combines digital and physical media. We present an implementation of this system to demonstrate its workflow. We also discuss the advantages of using physical media in digital animations through design evaluations.

Title: In-Your-Face, Yet Unseen? Improving Head-Stabilized Warnings to Reduce Reaction Time
Author list: Felix Lauber, Andreas Butz
Abstract: One unique property of head-mounted displays (HMDs) is that content can easily be displayed at a fixed position within the userâ€™s field of view (head-stabilized). This ensures that critical information (e.g. warnings) is continuously visible and can, in principle, be perceived as quickly as possible. We examined this strategy with a physically and visually distracted driver. We ran two consecutive studies in a driving simulator, comparing different warning visualizations in a head-up display (HUD) and a HMD. In an initial study, we found no significant effects of warning type or display technology on the reaction times. In a second study, after modifying our visualization to include a visual reference marker, we found that with only this minor change, reaction times were significantly lower in the HMD when compared to the HUD. Our insights can help others design better head-stabilized notifications.

Title: How Does Knowing What You Are Looking For Change Visual Search Behavior?
Author list: Duncan Brumby, Anna Cox, Jacqueline Chung, Byron Fernandes
Abstract: When searching a display, users sometimes know what the target is but sometimes do not. It has generally been assumed that for this latter case people must engage in a deeper semantic evaluation of items during the search process. This idea is central to Information Foraging theory. But do people actually spend longer assessing items when engaged in a semantically demanding search task? We investigate this by having participants locate target items in 16-item menus. Participants were either told exactly what to look for (known-item search) or they were told the category that the target belonged to (semantic search). Participants were faster and more accurate at known-item searches. Eye-movement data show that this was because participants were more likely to skip over items when performing known-item searches. Contrary to expectation, we found limited empirical evidence to support the idea that deeper semantic evaluations of items lead to longer gaze durations (this occurred only when items were arranged very close together). This finding is important because it reveals how people adopt different eye gaze strategies depending on the kind of search activity they are engaged in.

Title: The Influence of Emotion on Number Entry Errors
Author list: Paul Cairns, Pratyush Pandab, Christopher Power
Abstract: Given the proliferation of devices like infusion pumps in hospitals, number entry and in particular number entry error is an emerging important concern in HCI. There are clearly design features that could greatly improve accuracy in entering numbers but the context of the task could also play an important role. In particular, the emotional state of a person is known to strongly influence their response to a difficult situation and hence the errors that they make. In this paper, we consider the impact of the emotional state of the user on the accuracy with which people enter numbers. Our experiment shows that participants who are in a more positive emotional state are more accurate. The effect is small but could be very important when considering the potentially highly-charged emotional contexts where many healthcare devices are used. \

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We show that users in a more positive emotional state make fewer errors when entering numbers in a device. This could be an important effect in the healthcare context. \
Summary of Changes: Reviewer 5 asked that we clarify why the negative valence images are less negative than the positive ones are positive. We have done so in the Design section on p2. \  \ R5 also asked that we made the changes stated in our rebuttal. These are detailed as follows. \  \ We needed to make it clear that this study lacked ecological validity because it is a test of the principle that affective state influences number entry error. We have amended the end of the introduction, the aim of the experiment and the conclusions to reflect this emphasis. \  \ There were several issues raised around ecological validity including the use of IAPS, the use of long numbers, the use of a number pad and not other types of interface, the use of touchscreens and the control of typing style to one-finger. The experimental aim now acknowledges that such manipulations affect ecological validity and defers the details to the Discussion section. We noted in the Procedure that one-finger typing was required to remove variability. In the Discussion, we briefly outlined all of the issues and noted our reasons for these choices. We removed discussion of more complex tasks around games and what was reference [11] that supported it. This seemed too specific and narrow given the broader concerns raised by reviewers and also we were restricted in space. Instead we asserted again the in principle nature of the reported work and that these failings would need to be addressed in future work. \  \ There were various issues around the display. We have noted in the Figure that the arrow keys are unused in this study and also asserted that the C key did not cause confusion in terms of commit or clear based on our data. \  \ The ANOVAs were re-done non-parametrically using Mann-Whitney tests (not Wilcoxon as incorrectly stated in the rebuttal) and the boxplot axes were labelled as required by R3. \  \ We have indicated in the Discussion further work is needed to address the issues of ecological validity and that we hope to work with nurses as participants in the near future.  We have also acknowledge that treatment of PTSD is a current concern in nursing. \  \ I cannot get rid of the last (fifth) BLANK page without trashing the two column layout. I trust you can sort that out. \

Title: Interrupted by a Phone Call: Exploring Designs for Lowering the Impact of Call Notifications for Smartphone Users
Author list: Matthias BÃ¶hmer, Christian Lander, Sven Gehring, Duncan Brumby, Antonio KrÃ_ger
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
Abstract: Mobile phones have evolved significantly in recent years from single-purpose communication devices to multi-purpose computing devices. Despite this evolution, the interaction model for how incoming calls are handled has barely changed. Current-generation smartphones still use abrupt full-screen notifications to alert users to incoming calls, demanding a decision to either accept or decline the call. These full-screen notifications forcibly interrupt whatever activity the user was already engaged in. This might be undesirable when the userâ€™s primary task was more important than the incoming call. This paper explores the design space for how smartphones can alert users to incoming calls. We consider designs that allow users to postpone calls and also to multiplex by way of a smaller partial-screen notification. These design alternatives were evaluated in both a small-scale controlled lab study as well as a large-scale naturalistic in-the-wild study. Results show that a multiplex design solution works best because it allows people to continue working on their primary task while being made aware that there is a caller on the line. The contribution of this work is an enhanced interaction design for handling phone calls, and an understanding of how people use it for handling incoming calls.

Title: Broken Display = Broken Interface? The Impact of Display Damage on Smartphone Interaction
Author list: Florian Schaub, Julian Seifert, Frank Honold, Michael MÃ_ller, Enrico Rukzio, Michael Weber
Author emails: florian.schaub@uni-ulm.de, julian.seifert@uni-ulm.de, frank.honold@uni-ulm.de, michael-4.mueller@uni-ulm.de, enrico.rukzio@uni-ulm.de, michael.weber@uni-ulm.de
Abstract: This paper is the first to assess the impact of touchscreen damage on smartphone interaction. We gathered a dataset consisting of 95 closeup images of damaged smartphones and extensive information about a device's usage history, damage severity, and impact on use. 88% of our participants continued to use their damaged smartphone for at least three months; 32% plan to use it for another year or more, mainly due to high repair and replacement costs. From the dataset, we identified three categories of damaged smartphone displays. Reading and text input were most affected.  \ Further interviews (n=11) revealed that users adapt to damage with diverse coping strategies, closely tailored to specific interaction issues. In total, we identified 23 different strategies. Based on our results, we proposed guidelines for interaction design in order to provide a positive user experience when display damage occurs. \

Title: Classifying Driver Workload Using Physiological and  Driving Performance Data: Two Field Studies
Author list: Erin Solovey, Marin Zec, Enrique Abdon Garcia Perez, Bryan Reimer, Bruce Mehler
Abstract: Understanding the driverâ€™s cognitive load is important for evaluating in-vehicle user interfaces. This paper describes experiments to assess machine learning classification algorithms on their ability to automatically identify elevated cognitive workload levels in drivers, leading towards the development of robust tools for automobile user interface evaluation. We look at using both driver performance as well as physiological data. These measures can be collected in real-time and do not interfere with the primary task of driving the vehicle. We report classification accuracies of up to 90% for detecting elevated levels of cognitive load, and show that the inclusion of physiological data leads to higher classification accuracy than vehicle sensor data evaluated alone. Finally, we show results suggesting that models can be built to classify cognitive load across individuals, instead of building individual models for each per-son. By collecting data from drivers in two large field studies on the highway (20 drivers and 99 drivers), this work extends prior work and demonstrates feasibility and potential of such measures for HCI research in vehicles.

We also discussed future work, looking at 0-back and 1-back and cross-task classification.  \ To address the HCI contribution, we made the high level story and motivation and goals clearer (in-vehicle user interface evaluation). \ Finally, we added authors and acknowledgments. \ We did additional polishing as suggested by the reviewers to make the paper clearer.

Title: Choice-Based Preference Elicitation for Collaborative Filtering Recommender Systems
Author list: Benedikt Loepp, Tim Hussein, Juergen Ziegler
Abstract: We present an approach to interactive recommending that combines the advantages of algorithmic techniques with the benefits of user-controlled, interactive exploration in a novel manner. The method extracts latent factors from a matrix of user rating data as commonly used in Collaborative Filtering, and generates dialogs in which the user iteratively chooses between two sets of sample items. Samples are chosen by the system for low and high values of each latent factor considered. The method positions the user in the latent factor space with few interaction steps, and finally selects items near the user position as recommendations. \  \ In a user study, we compare the system with three alternative approaches including manual search and automatic recommending. The results show significant advantages of our approach over the three competing alternatives in 15 out of 24 possible parameter comparisons, in particular with respect to item fit, interaction effort and user control. The findings corroborate our assumption that the proposed method achieves a good trade-off between automated and interactive functions in recommender systems.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We introduce an interactive recommending approach using choice-based preference elicitation based on latent factors. It combines the advantages of algorithmic Collaborative Filtering techniques with the benefits of user-controlled, interactive exploration.
Summary of Changes: As already announced in our rebuttal, we have improved the final version of our paper in accordance with the valuable comments provided by the reviewers. In detail, we made the following changes: \  \ - Since R1 suggested to compare our work with [Zhao et al., 2013], we included this reference in the related work section â€œAutomatic and Interactive Recommender Systemsâ€ù (paragraph 3) and describe its main contribution. \  \ - Due to R2's concerns regarding the benefit of including the popularity-based method in the user study, we have now made the purpose and benefit of including the simple, popularity-based approach as a baseline more explicit (section on evaluation has been modified). We also address the issue of comparing our method with other interactive approaches in the concluding section by discussing their need for additional data, as well as our related plans left for future work. \  \ - According to R2's comments, we rewrote the paragraph below Table 2 to make it more readable. Also, the layout of Table 2 has been improved to make it more perspicuous. In addition, we now introduce the purpose of each table in the preceding paragraph. \  \ - In response to R2, we added some clarifying statements about the need for additional data with respect to the Popularity criterion used in the respective subsection â€œSelection of Appropriate Representativesâ€ù. \  \ - Based on R3's request to see our method applied in other domains, we state in the concluding section that we plan to perform evaluations in other application domains in follow-up studies. Additionally, we now more explicitly motivate our use of the MovieLens dataset which is in widespread use as a reference dataset for evaluating recommender systems (in the â€œSettingâ€ù subsection of the Evaluation section), and point out the generally high level of domain independence of CF-algorithms, which is the main reason why we believe our approach to be well transferable to other domains (in the section â€œConclusions and Outlookâ€ù). \  \ - We extended our concluding section to respond to R3's request for additional timing data explaining in more detail why we concentrated on subjective measurements in this comparative study. We also point out that efficiency-related aspects will be addressed more extensively in future in-depth studies. \  \ - Finally, we have made some minor changes with regard to wording and images in order to improve page layout and print quality.

Title: Together Alone: Motivations for Live-Tweeting a Television Series
Author list: Steven Schirra, Huan Sun, Frank Bentley
Abstract: In this paper, we explore motivations for live-tweeting across a season of a television show. Using the third season of Downton Abbey as a case study, we followed 2,234 live-tweeters from the show's premiere episode to its finale, finding that nearly a third of users returned each week to tweet. Semi-structured interviews with 11 diverse live-tweeters revealed that the decision to live-tweet is dependent upon a variety of personal considerations and social conventions forming around this emerging TV viewing practice. This includes the desire to feel connected to a larger community that is interested in the show. Participants actively sought to protect the user experience of others by following good live-tweeting â€œetiquette,â€ù including limiting their number of posts and censoring content that might spoil the show for others. Over time, live-tweeting helped users build and maintain a network of fellow Downton Abbey viewers with shared interests.

Title: Bigger is not always better: Display Size, Performance, and Task Load during Peephole Map Navigation
Author list: Roman RÃ_dle, Hans-Christian Jetter, Jens MÃ_ller, Harald Reiterer
Abstract: Dynamic peephole navigation is an increasingly popular technique for navigating large information spaces such as maps. Users can view the map through handheld, spatially aware displays that serve as peepholes and navigate the map by moving these displays in physical space. We conducted a controlled experiment of peephole map navigation with 16 participants to better understand the effect of a peepholeâ€™s size on usersâ€™ map navigation behavior, navigation performance, and task load. Simulating different peephole sizes from 4â€_ (smartphone) up to 120â€_ (control condition), we confirmed that larger peepholes significantly improve learning speed, navigation speed, and reduce task load; however, this added benefit diminishes with growing sizes. Our data shows that a relatively small, tablet-sized peephole can serve as a â€œsweet spotâ€ù between peephole size and both user navigation performance and user task load.

Title: Designing Information Savvy Societies: An Introduction to Assessability
Author list: Andrea Forte, Nazanin Andalibi, Thomas Park, Heather Willever-Farr
Abstract: This paper provides first steps toward an empirically grounded design vocabulary for assessable design as an HCI response to the global need for better information literacy skills. We present a framework for synthesizing literatures called the Interdisciplinary Literacy Framework and use it to highlight gaps in our understanding of information literacy that HCI as a field is particularly well suited to fill. We report on two studies that lay a foundation for developing guidelines for assessable information system design. The first is a study of Wikipediansâ€™, librariansâ€™, and laypersonsâ€™ information assessment practices from which we derive two important features of assessable designs: information provenance and stewardship. The second is an experimental study in which we operationalize these concepts in designs and test them using Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk).

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We introduce an empirically grounded design vocabulary for assessable design as an HCI response to the global need for better information literacy skills, using Wikipedia as a testbed.
Summary of Changes: We have integrated the new discussion section that we presented in the rebuttal, which addressed several of reviewers' main concerns. We've made modifications to other sections of the paper at reviewers' suggestion, including the addition of relevant citations in our literature review and specific suggestions for clarifying some of the findings such as modifying our interpretation of a participant quote.  \  \ We tried to further clarify how our research draws on some of the earlier work mentioned by reviewers. We also tried to add more language to suggest that we think our two studies provide a starting point, that this is a first step and that research on other kinds of sites are necessary to further develop our ideas. Some of this language was present in parts of the paper, but we added it in the abstract and tried to make it clearer up front. It's not clear to us how to further further "fix" the fact that an interview study like ours isn't generalizable other than adjusting readers' expectations. Readers familiar with our methods should not be confused, but hopefully it will be much clearer now to all readers that broad generalizability is not the goal. (Rather, generating valid interpretations of participants' practices that can serve as the foundation for an empirically grounded approach to design is the goal.) \  \ In order to fit the new material, we reduced some methodological detail about the diary study, which did not play a large role in the analysis other than informing our interviews. In general, we were able to streamline the text a great deal by simply editing the language and removing superfluous clauses.

Title: The Patchworks Code Editor: Toward Faster Navigation with Less Code Arranging and Fewer Navigation Mistakes
Author list: Austin Z Henley, Scott D Fleming
Abstract: Increasingly, people are faced with navigating large information spaces, and making such navigation efficient is of paramount concern. In this paper, we focus on the problems programmers face in navigating large code bases, and propose a novel code editor, Patchworks, that addresses the problems. In particular, Patchworks leverages two new interface idioms--the patch grid and the ribbon--to help programmers navigate more quickly, make fewer navigation errors, and spend less time arranging their code. To validate Patchworks, we conducted a user study that compared Patchworks to two existing code editors: the traditional file-based editor, Eclipse, and the newer canvas-based editor, Code Bubbles. Our results showed (1) that programmers using Patchworks were able to navigate significantly faster than with Eclipse (and comparably with Code Bubbles), (2) that programmers using Patchworks made significantly fewer navigation errors than with Code Bubbles or Eclipse, and (3) that programmers using Patchworks spent significantly less time arranging their code than with Code Bubbles (and comparably with Eclipse).

Title: Spending Real Money: Purchasing Patterns of Virtual Goods in an Online Social Game
Author list: Donghee Yvette Wohn
Abstract: Researchers have found that â€œsocialâ€ù factors contribute to purchasing intentions of virtual goods in an online social game, but little is known about actual purchasing behavior.  Study 1 examined the relationship between social factors and virtual goods purchasing patterns using large scale data obtained by server logs of an online social game. Exchange of virtual goods and number of friends increased the likelihood of spending real money compared to no spending. However, among those who did spend real money, time spent in the game was the strongest factor associated with of the amount of spending. Study 2 examined purchasing patterns of players who spent real money: high real-money spenders were buying items for visual customization while low spenders were buying consumable items necessary to sustain playing the game.

Title: SurfacePhone: A Mobile Projection Device for Single- and Multiuser Everywhere Tabletop Interaction
Author list: Christian Winkler, Markus LÃ¶chtefeld, David Dobbelstein, Antonio KrÃ_ger, Enrico Rukzio
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)
Abstract: In this paper we present SurfacePhone; a novel configuration of a projector phone which aligns the projector to project onto a physical surface to allow tabletop-like interaction in a mobile setup. The projection is created behind the upright standing phone and is touch and gesture-enabled. Multiple projections can be merged to create shared spaces for multi-user collaboration. We investigate this new setup, starting with the concept that we evaluated with a concept prototype. Furthermore we present our technical prototype, a phone case with \ integrated projector that is fully mobile, open sourced, and allows for the aforementioned \ interaction. We discuss its technical requirements and evaluate the accuracy of interaction in a second user study. We conclude with design guidelines.

Title: An EEG-based Approach for Evaluating Audio Notifications under Ambient Sounds
Author list: Yi-Chieh Lee, Wen-Chieh Lin, Jung-Tai King, Li-Wei Ko, Yu-Ting Huang, Fu-Yin Cherng
Author emails: be341341@gmail.com, wclin@cs.nctu.edu.tw, jtchin2@gmail.com, lwko.leo@gmail.com, tinahuang79@gmail.com, fufu22710@gmail.com
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: Department of Biological Science and Technology
Abstract: Audio notifications are an important means of prompting users of electronic products. Although useful in most environments, audio notifications are ineffective in certain situations, especially against particular auditory backgrounds or when the user is distracted. Several studies have used behavioral performance to evaluate audio notifications, but these studies failed to achieve consistent results due to factors including user subjectivity and environmental differences; thus, a new method and more objective indicators are necessary. In this study, we propose an approach based on electroencephalography (EEG) to evaluate audio notifications by measuring users' auditory perceptual responses (mismatch negativity) and attention shifting (P3a). We demonstrate our approach by applying it to the usability testing of audio notifications in realistic scenarios, such as users performing a major task amid ambient noises. Our results open a new perspective for evaluating the design of the audio notifications.
References: 1. Barrass, S., and Frauenberger, C. A communal map of design in auditory display. In Proc. ICAD (2009). \ 2. Blattner, M. M., Sumikawa, D. A., and Greenberg, R. M. Title: DDF Seeks Same: Sexual Health-Related Language in Online Personal Ads For Men Who Have Sex With Men
Author list: Oliver L Haimson, Jed R Brubaker, Gillian R Hayes
Abstract: The HIV/AIDS crisis of the 1980s fundamentally changed sexual practices of men who have sex with men (MSM) in the U.S., including increased usage of sexual health-related (SHR) language in personal advertisements. Analyzing online personal ads from Craigslist, we found a substantial increase in SHR language, from ~23% in 1988 to over 53% today, echoing continuing concern about rising HIV rates. We argue that SHR language in Craigslist ads can be used as a sensor to provide insight into HIV epidemiology as well as discourse among particular communities. We show a positive significant relationship between prevalence rate of HIV in an adâ€™s location and use of SHR language in that location. Analysis highlights the opportunity for SHR information found in Craigslist personal ads to serve as a data source for HIV prevention research. More broadly, we argue for mining large-scale user-generated content to inform HCI design of health and other systems, and explore use of such data to examine temporal changes in language to facilitate improved user-interface design.

Thumbnail Image Caption: We identify a relationship between HIV prevalence and sexual health-related language in a large personal ads dataset to demonstrate online, publicly-available dataâ€™s potential as a sensor and to inform design.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We identify a relationship between HIV prevalence and sexual health-related language in a large personal ads dataset to demonstrate online, publicly-available dataâ€™s potential as a sensor and to inform design.
Summary of Changes: Many thanks, again, to the reviewers and AC for the thoughtful feedback. We have revised the paper to address reviewer concerns. Changes are outlined below: \  \  \ IMPLICATIONS FOR HCI \ We have brought HCI implications to the forefront of the paper and re-worked the paper to speak to an HCI audience, emphasizing: \  \ 1.	This work is an example of mining user-generated content for secondary purposes (AC). Similar methods and techniques could be used in other domains (e.g., urban or civic informatics). \ 2.	To properly design large-scale health data systems (R1), HCI research must be conducted on the information architecture of such data and its use as a sensor. \ 3.	Codifying large-scale data from Craigslist highlights issues around the timescale of data as a sensor, particularly given evolving language (R2). \  \ We have added content about the evolution of personal ad content over time, noting how differences in SHR language between 1980s personal ads and current Craigslist ads highlight the constant evolution of SHR language (R2). \  \ Additionally, we have added an in-depth discussion section (R3), highlighting implications for design and HCI.  \  \  \ SEXUAL HEALTH DICTIONARY \ We clarified that we intentionally excluded drug related terms to focus the scope of our paper on sexual health, replicate Davidsonâ€™s methods, and compare current levels of SHR language to the 1980s (R2).  \   \ We have corrected the inaccurate description of our methods and clarified that 500 ads in total were coded, 125 by all 4 coders for inter-rater reliability (AC).  \  \  \ RELATED WORK \ We have included the references provided by R1 and R2, and agree that they complement the paper. Thank you for bringing these additional references to our attention! We revised the related work section to focus more on addressing how our research questions relate to the existing literature and fill gaps in HCI research (R3). \  \  \ LIMITATIONS \ We have addressed R5â€™s suggestion to include more information about potential limitations of our research. Specifically, we have added content describing the extent to which Craigslist is representative of the MSM community (AC, R5), address the potential issue of people misrepresenting their HIV status on Craigslist (AC), and discuss the presence of irrelevant ads in our dataset (AC). \  \  \ OTHER CONCERNS \ Additionally, we have addressed the following: \ â€¢	We use less strong language regarding the relationship between HIV concern and prevalence (R1). \ â€¢	We define MSM in the paper body (R3). \ â€¢	We revisited our age group distinctions (R3), clarified Table 4, and mention that public health campaigns in the 90s may have influenced the uniqueness of the 32-37 age group (R3). \ â€¢	We proofread thoroughly to remove repetition (R3). \

Title: A Systematic Review of Quantitative Studies on the Enjoyment of Digital Entertainment Games
Author list: Elisa D. Mekler, Julia Ayumi Bopp, Alexandre N. Tuch, Klaus Opwis
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: Department of Psychology, Center for Cognitive Psychology and Methodology
Abstract: Enjoyment has been identified as a central component of the player experience (PX), but various, overlapping concepts within PX make it difficult to develop valid measures and a common understanding of game enjoyment. We conducted a systematic review of 87 quantitative studies, analyzing different operationalizations and measures of game enjoyment, its determinants, and how these were related to other components of PX, such as flow, presence and immersion. Results suggest that game enjoyment describes the positive cognitive and affective appraisal of the game experience, and may in part be associated with the support of player needs and values. Further, we outline that enjoyment is distinct from flow in that it may occur independently of challenge and cognitive involvement, and argue that enjoyment may be understood as the valence of the player experience. We conclude with a discussion of methodological challenges and point out opportunities for future research on game enjoyment.

Author Keywords: Digital Games; Enjoyment; Player Experience; Flow
Auxiliary Material Descriptive (Read-me: A PDF table containing all the data that was collected for each of the 87 studies that were included in the review. Data consists of aim of the study, measures, results, measuring times, study designs, sample, game genre, duration of gameplay, and if provided, definition of enjoyment
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We conducted a systematic review of 87 quantitative studies, comparing different measures of game enjoyment, as well as how they relate to other player experience components, such as flow.
Summary of Changes: 1.  In the introduction section, we clarify the scope of the paper by highlighting the problem of inconsistent measures in PX research, due to the different conceptualizations and subsequent operationalizations of game enjoyment, hence our focus on quantitative studies. As suggested by R2, we also changed the title and abstract to reflect the reviewâ€™s focus on quantitative studies and digital entertainment games. Consequently, we have revised parts of the discussion and adapted the wording throughout the paper accordingly. \  \ 2. We considerably shortened the method section describing the QUOROM procedure. The current version focuses mostly on the selection criteria. More importantly, we realize that the wording concerning the exclusion of serious games and exergames was rather clumsy in the original version. We agree with AC1 and AC3 that these types of games are and should be designed with enjoyment in mind, and acknowledge this in the paper. Rather, we chose to focus on digital entertainment games, because usually their sole â€œintendedâ€ù goal is enjoyment. As for AR and pervasive games, we could not include them for the sake of manageability and we think it is important to clearly state which types of games were included in the review and which were not. However, we now explicitly list this as a limitation of our review and encourage further research to examine whether our findings extend to serious games, exergames and pervasive games. \  \ 3. The results section was overhauled for improved clarity and readability (e.g., enlarging Table 1). We checked and corrected inconsistencies, and removed any redundancies in the text that were already covered in the tables. Moreover, we clarify what we mean by objective and subjective measures of enjoyment. Lastly, we chose to display only absolute numbers. \  \ 4. The discussion has been revised. In particular, the section on the â€œpositive disposition towards oneselfâ€ù has been completely rewritten. Instead, we elaborate upon the fact that several of the reviewed studies found a relation between need satisfaction and game enjoyment, and that there were some indications that enjoyment is negatively correlated with feelings of guilt. Moreover, we expand upon promising directions for future research, in particular concerning the valence and intensity of the player experience. \  \ 5. Finally, we adjusted Figure 1 to more clearly highlight that flow is also characterized by enjoyment, as suggested by R1. \  \ 6. A supplementary PDF table containing the data collected for all 87 studies is included in the auxiliary materials. \

Title: Don't Forget Your Pill! Designing Effective Medication Reminder Apps That Support Users' Daily Routines
Author list: Katarzyna Stawarz, Anna Cox, Ann Blandford
Abstract: Despite the fact that a third of all cases of unintentional medication non-adherence are caused by simple forgetfulness, the majority of interventions neglect this issue. Even though patients have access to smartphone applications ("apps") designed to help them remember medication, neither their quality nor effectiveness has been evaluated yet. We report the findings of a functionality review of 229 medication reminder apps and a thematic analysis of their 1,012 user reviews. Our research highlights the gap between the theory and practice: while the literature shows that many medication regimens are habitual in nature and the presence of daily routines supports remembering, existing apps rely on timer-based reminders. To address this disparity, we present design requirements for building medication reminders that support the routine aspect of medication-taking and its individual nature, and demonstrate how they could be implemented to move from passive alerts to a smarter memory and routine assistant.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Based on a review of medication reminder apps, we present recommendations for designing smartphone apps that help patients remember their medication and support the creation of medication-taking routines.
Summary of Changes: Based on the Reviewers' comments, we have changed the following sections: \ 1. Introduction: It is now shorter and clearer, with more focus on forgetfulness. \ 2. Use case scenario: We have replaced a gendered example (make-up) with a neutral breakfast. \ 3. Conclusions: We have clarified the generalizability of our approach (it's best suited for simple regimens like oral contraception, but could be also applied to more complex ones and also other behavior change interventions; We made it clear that we are not the first to focus on routines in medication-taking, but the first in this context.

Title: Personas is Applicable â€“ A Study On the Use of Personas In Denmark
Author list: Lene Nielsen, Kira Storgaard Hansen
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Center for Personas Research and - Application
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Center for Personas Research and - Application
Abstract: The persona method is gaining widespread use and support. Many researchers have reported from single cases and novel domains how they have used the method. Few have conducted literature studies in order to identify and discuss the different understandings of the method. Fewer still have reported on ethnographic studies of practice. This paper falls within the last category, reporting on a study on how practitioners in Denmark use the method, and their perceptions of benefits and challenges when using the method. Finally, different casts of personas obtained from the involved companies are analyzed. The findings are compared to reported studies of practice. Contrary to the existing findings the study reports that the method is well integrated into existing practices.
