Author Keywords: Personas; scenarios; application; practice-study
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This study contributes with generalization to current understandings of personas and valuable insights across different lines of businesses into how a large group of practitioners use and perceive personas.
Summary of Changes: Rewriting \ First and foremost the reviews was of great help and in rewriting the paper they helped us realize that we wanted to say too much in the paper, and that there is material for several papers in the one paper we have submitted. We have also looked at the detailed suggestions/problems and corrected these. \  \ This said, we have created a better frame for the paper and a stronger focus. In the next we will go through the different issues raised by the reviewers: \  \ Framing \ As suggested by review 1 we have changed the introduction from a presentation of what the persona method is to an introduction of what we did, why another persona study is needed and what we contribute with. \ In this paper we compare our study to studies that have looked at practice and practitioners.  \  \ Related work \ In the related work section we have tightened how the research in the paper differentiate from the related works and the learning points provided from this current research. \  \ The findings in the literature are collected in sections which makes it easier to understand and, later, to compare the findings from the current study to the literature. Furthermore some findings in the literature on practice are compared to common recommendations to describe how they deviate. \  \ Participants \ As suggested we have created a table of companies and interviewees that participated the table covers: company size and type, type of product, years of personas use, job role of interviewee, and personas examples provided. Instead of adding more to the table, as suggested, we have added an additional table that gives an overview of the findings. \  \ Methodology \ The section on methodology has been completely rewritten to include a section on qualitative studies and how this study relates to the paradigm of qualitative studies. \  \ Review 2 writes â€œLack of test measurement as evidence to validate the findings of the study. The authors need to work out this issue.â€ù  \ Unfortunately Review 2 does not seem to understanding that this study is qualitative in its essence and test measurement, as evidence does not apply to qualitative studies that have other demands to validity such as the ability to follow the arguments and comparing the results to literature. \  \ Findings  \ As mentioned we have created a table of findings that cover persona development, persona creation, personas as a UX method, personas in use and satisfaction with personas.  \ The table provided a structure and helped us prioritise the sections. This made us rewrite most of the section and has helped us to guide the writing in order to make the findings more clear and the text more concise.  \ Persona descriptions \ Unfortunately the persona descriptions are all confidential so we cannot provide any examples or illustrations.  \ We have not changed anything here, but Table 1 includes an overview of how many persona descriptions we have had access to. \ Discussion  \ As mentioned we have introduced what the paper contributes with right at the beginning of the paper. \  \ We have in the discussion taken point of departure in the findings from the existing literature and compare these to the findings in our study. In order to do so we have collected 6 key arguments from the literature that our study is compared to: personas are not used for design, designers do not refer to personas in their discussions, problems with persona descriptions, personas are not created entirely on data, personas are not created at the beginning of the design process, and benefits of the method. \  \ In order to make the text more explicit and clarify the findings we have removed all quotes. This provides an analytic level to the study instead of the story-telling that the reviewers would like to see more of. We find that it provides more meaning to give a common overview instead of reporting from single cases and this furthermore supports the uniqueness of capturing practice across disciplines and industries. \

Title: What If We Ask A Different Question?: Social Inferences Create Product Ratings Faster
Author list: Eric Gilbert
Abstract: Consumer product reviews are the backbone of commerce online. Most commonly, sites ask users for their personal opinions on a product or service. I conjecture, however, that this traditional method of eliciting reviews often invites idiosyncratic viewpoints. In this paper, I present a statistical study examining the differences between traditionally elicited product ratings (i.e., â€œHow do you rate this product?â€ù) and social inference ratings (i.e., â€œHow do you think other people will rate this product?â€ù). In 5 of 6 trials, I find that social inference ratings produce the same aggregate product rating as the one produced via traditionally elicited ratings. In all cases, however, social inferences yield less variance. This is significant because using social inference ratings 1) therefore converges on the true aggregate product rating faster, and 2) is a cheap design intervention on the part of existing sites.

Title: Panopticon as an eLearning Support Search Tool
Author list: James Nicholson, Mark Huber, Daniel Jackson, Patrick Olivier
Abstract: We present an evaluation of Panopticon, a video surrogate system, as an online eLearning support search tool for finding information within video lectures. A comparison was made with a standard video player (YouTube) in two scenarios with two classes of users: revision students and independent learners. Results showed that users of Panopticon were significantly faster at finding information within the lecture videos than users of the YouTube player. It was also found that videos predominantly featuring a talking lecturer took longest to navigate, presenting design implications for lectures to be uploaded to open eLearning platforms.

Title: Monadic Exploration: Seeing the Whole Through Its Parts
Author list: Marian DÃ¶rk, Rob Comber, Martyn Dade-Robertson
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: School of Architecture, Planning, and Landscape, University of Newcastle
Abstract: Monadic exploration is a new approach to interacting with relational information spaces that challenges the distinction between the whole and its parts. Building on the work of sociologists Gabriel Tarde and Bruno Latour we turn to the concept of the monad as a useful lens on online communities and collections that expands the possibility for creating meaning in their navigation. While existing interfaces tend to emphasize either the structure of the whole or details of a part, monadic exploration brings these opposing perspectives closer together in continuous movements between partially overlapping points of view. We present a visualization that reflects a given node's relative position within a network using radial displacements and visual folding. To investigate the potential of monadic exploration we report on an iterative design process of a web-based visualization of a highly cross-referenced book and its six-month deployment.

Title: From Checking On to Checking In: Designing for Low Socio-Economic Status Older Adults
Author list: Ingrid Arreola, Zan Morris, Matthew Francisco, Kay Connelly, Kelly Caine, Ginger White
Author emails: inarreol@indiana.edu, morris22@indiana.edu, francm@indiana.edu, connelly@indiana.edu, caine@clemson.edu, giwhite@indiana.edu
Abstract: In this paper we describe the design evolution of a novel technology that collects and displays presence information to be used in the homes of older adults. The first two iterations, the Ambient Plant and Presence Clock, were designed for higher socio-economic status (SES) older adults, whereas the Check-In Tree was designed for low SES older adults. We describe how feedback from older adult participants drove our design decisions, and give an in-depth account of how the Check-In Tree evolved from concept to a final design ready for in situ deployment.

Summary of Changes: The reviewers R2, R3, R4 commented - â€œConcern that the work in this space is not really novelâ€ù \ -We see the peer-approach as a significant contribution within the space of technologies for aging-in-place. (which R2 & R3 note as novel) \ - This was addressed in the section labeled Socio-Economic Status: \ â€œPrevious work in HCI [e.g., 6, 9] has focused on designing for higher-income older adults. This preceding work emphasizes technologies to support a one-to-one (caregiver-to-older adult) relationship. The low-SES older adults in our study had a much richer ecosystem of family members, service providers and peersâ€_â€ù \ - We agree with R2, R3 and R4 in that the primary novelty of contribution of our work is designing for low-income older adults, whereas previous work in HCI (e.g., Forlizzi et al; Mynatt et al) has focused on designing for higher-income older adults. \  \ The reviewer R4 commented - â€œAuthors have failed to draw out clear and actionable information about what is different about designing for this group, as opposed to adults of higher ES.â€ù  \ - Based on the contextual observations conducted on eight low-income older adults we found that low SES do not have a single informal caregiver and rely on peer groups for their needs. This can be found in section labeled Socio-Economic Status: \ â€œP1: â€œWhen I first moved in, the guy around the corner used to take me to stores and stuff like that, and cash my check. Every time Iâ€™m going to go to the grocery store I get him to go and take me.â€ù \ â€œIn another population (asthma patients), Jeong et al. found that that there is a trend of low-income populations relying more heavily on peers, and in particular a variety of informal caregivers [7].â€ù  \ - This reliance on peer-to-peer interaction drove the design process of the Check-In.  \  \ The reviewer R3 commented - â€œPaper says very little about why lower SES older adults rely more on peer-to-peer interactionâ€ù  \ - This was addressed in the section labeled Checking-In: Check-In Tree: \  â€œOlder adults often devise a check-in system in which they can indicate to a neighbor that they have gotten up in the morning (e.g., turn on/off the porch light) and the neighbor agrees to call if they are not up by a certain time [10]â€_.â€ù \  \ The reviewer  R4 commented â€“ â€œSituating this work more clearly in the literature, and providing clear evidence for how the design was derived for.â€ù \ - We agree, and would like to thank the reviewers (R4, R1, R5) for pointing us to Forlizzi et al., Jeong et al., Rubinstein et al., Rowles et al., and Ylirisku et al. \ - Forlizzi et al. was referenced in the section labeled Evolution of Tree Form \ - Jeong et al. was referenced in the section labeled Socio-Economic Status \ - Rubinstein et al. was referenced in the section labeled Socio-Economic Status \ - Rowles et al. was referenced in the section labeled Checking In: Check In Tree \ - Ylirisku et al. was referenced in the section labeled Evolution of Tree Form \  \ The reviewer R1 commented â€“ â€œThe choice to use a manual switch to try and engage elders seems to discount a number of health issues that come with becoming an elder.â€ù  \ - We agree with R1 that a manual button may have disadvantages, and debated this point extensively during the design process. Ultimately, we chose the manual button to engage the older adult with the tree; this button can easily be replaced with an automatic motion-sensor check-in. \ - This can be found in the discussion: \ â€œAnother important design decision related to mobility was to design all three prototypes to blend in to a homeâ€™s dÃ©cor so that older adults will place them in commonly occupied spaces, such as a living roomâ€_we have designed the tree such that the button interaction can easily be replaced with a motion sensor to automatically â€˜check-inâ€™ an older adult if we find use is low or burdensome.â€ù  \  \ The reviewer R2 commented - â€œIt would be interesting to include quotes to help support the findings.â€ù \ - We agree with R2 that having quotes would help support our findings. We included one quote from the contextual observation we held with older adults. This can be found in the section labeled Socio-Economic Status \ â€œP1: â€˜When I first moved in, the guy around the corner used to take me to stores and stuff like that, and cash my check. Every time Iâ€™m going to go to the grocery store I get him to go and take me.â€™â€ù \  \ The reviewer R4 commented â€“ â€œMinimize drastically the space spent on previously published systems and studies for half of the paper. Use the remaining space to maximize description of your contribution and the new knowledge.â€ù \ - We significantly reduced the sections pertaining to the previous systems (ambient plant and presence clock). In the original submission it was titled â€œRemote Presenceâ€ù however it was renamed to the section titled Checking On: Ambient Plant & Presence Clock.   \  \ - There were other miscellaneous edits made so that we could fit it all to the page limit.

Title: Current and Future Mobile and Wearable Device  Use by People With Visual Impairments
Author list: Hanlu Ye, Meethu Malu, Uran Oh, Leah Findlater
Abstract: With the increasing popularity of mainstream wearable devices, it is critical to assess the accessibility implications of such technologies. For people with visual impairments, who do not always need the visual display of a mobile phone, alternative means of eyes-free wearable interaction are particularly appealing. To explore the potential impacts of such technology, we conducted two studies. The first was an online survey that included 114 participants with visual impairments and 101 sighted participants; we compare the two groups in terms of current device use. The second was an interview and design probe study with 10 participants with visual impairments. Our findings expand on past work to characterize a range of trends in smartphone use and accessibility issues therein. Participants with visual impairments also responded positively to two eyes-free wearable device scenarios: a wristband or ring and a glasses-based device. Discussions on projected use of these devices suggest that small, easily accessible, and discreet wearable input could positively impact the ability of people with visual impairments to access information on the go and to participate in certain social interactions.

Title: Pupil Responses during Discrete Goal-directed Movements
Author list: Xianta Jiang, M Stella Atkins, Geoffrey Tien, Roman Bednarik, Bin Zheng
Abstract: Pupil size is known to correlate with the changes of cognitive task workloads, but how the pupil responds to requirements of basic goal-directed motor tasks involved in human-machine interactions is not yet clear. This work conducted a user study to investigate the pupil dilations during aiming in a tele-operation setting, with the purpose of better understanding how the changes in task requirements are reflected by the changes of pupil size. The task requirements, managed by Fittsâ€™ index of difficulty (ID), i.e. the size and distance apart of the targets, were varied between tasks, and pupil responses to different task IDs were recorded. The results showed that pupil diameter can be employed as an indicator of task requirements in goal-directed movementsâ€”higher task difficulty evoked higher valley to peak pupil dilation, and the peak pupil dilation occurred after a longer delay. These findings contribute to the foundation for developing methods to objectively evaluate interactive task requirements using pupil parameters during goal-directed movements in HCI.

One group of subjects executed bottom up from the easiest task to the hardest task and then back to the easiest task (shown in the upper panel); another group of subjects executed bottom up from hard to easy tasks and then back to the hardest task (lower panel).  A1 to A3 represent the distances between targets and W1 to W3 represent the sizes of the targets of ID1 to ID3.â€ù We also added that the ANOVA results to show no significant ordering effect (Page 4, at the end of Tasks and Procedure) â€œWe did not consider other ordering options like executing from middle difficulty to hardest to easiest, because the ANOVA results showed there was no significant difference in movement time between the two groups, and no interaction effect of ID and group order.â€ù \ Analysis:  \ To clarify the moment of tool-reach, we added a sentence to the end of subsection Identification of moments of tooltip leaving and arriving (Page 5) â€œThe moment of tool-reach detected by the algorithm is the moment that the tool quickly arrives at a position above (but not necessarily touching) the target circle.â€ù \ In responding to R1 and R2â€™s concern with the motivation of the 7s window, we added the sentences (Page 5, at the second paragraph of Pupil data processing and segment extraction) â€œThe 7-second window is motivated by considering the extra movement time (about 1s-2s) before the tool leaves in our study compared with others who noted pupil increases start 1.5s before the stimulus [20, 22, 23] and the pupil continuous to dilate afterwards to a peak value in a few seconds e.g. 3s-window in [22], 4s-window in [23], and 5s-window in [20].â€ù  \ Results: \ Page 5: We deleted the paragraph stating the mean pupil size for baselines were not significantly different, as we combined this paragraph to 13th paragraph to make the paper more concise.  \ â€œThe mean pupil size through a whole trial for all the valid trials is 4.1mm (Â±0.8mm). The mean pupil size at baseline was 3.9mm (Â±1.0mm) for Easy and 4.0mm (Â±1.0mm) for Middle and Hard IDs. There was no significant difference between three IDs in terms of mean pupil size in baselines of the moves in each ID.â€ù \ Regarding R1â€™s concerns about the 17 data points in Figs. 9 and 10, we added the following explanation in the text of the first paragraph in Descriptive analysis (Page 7): â€œFor clarity, error bars are drawn every 400ms rather than drawn for every time sample (at 50Hz).â€ù Also the text â€œthe data is averaged over all 808 valid movements of 69 trials from 12 subjectsâ€ù and â€œThe error bars for 1 std. dev. are drawn every 400ms.â€ù were added to the captions of Figs. 9 and 10. \ Regarding that R1 did not think that the figures illustrated a clear relationship between pupil dilation and difficulty, we expanded the data analysis on the valley to peak pupil dilation and the valley to peak pupil duration, and added four short paragraphs to enhance this evidence. \ (1)	A paragraph at the end of Descriptive analysis (Page 7).  â€œFurthermore, the increase of pupil size from the valley (between 3s and 4s in Fig. 10) to its peak correlates to IDs; the easy task (black curve) increased about 0.13mm (0.07mm at valley to 0.2mm at peak), whereas the middle task (pink curve) increased about 0.18mm (0.02 to 0.2mm). The hardest task (green) had the largest increase of about 0.27mm (-0.01 to 0.26mm). Also, the valley to peak duration can be observed to be different between IDs.â€ù  \ (2)	A paragraph to show the ANOVA results on the increase pupil size and duration from valley to peak in terms three IDs (Page 7, 6th paragraph in the section Statistical analysis). â€œANOVA shows there is significant difference in the pupil size increase from valley to peak between IDs (F(2,805) = 44.754, p < .001). Post Hoc test (Tukey HSD) shows that the mean increase of pupil size from valley to peak is significantly different (p < .001) between Easy (0.3Â±0.2mm), Middle (0.4Â±0.2mm), and Hard ID (0.5Â±0.2mm).â€ù  \ (3)	Another paragraph to show the duration of the pupil dilation from its valley to peak size between IDs is significant (P7, 7th paragraph in Statistical Analysis) â€œANOVA shows there is significant difference in the duration of the pupil dilation from its valley to peak size between IDs (F(2,805) = 91.938, p < .001). Post Hoc test (Tukey HSD) shows that the duration from valley to peak is significantly different (p < .001) between Easy (1.6Â±0.7s), Middle (2.1Â±0.9s), and Hard ID (2.7Â±1.1s).â€ù \ (4)	The 7th paragraph in Discussion (P8). â€œAlthough the peak pupil dilations of Easy and Middle ID show similar amount in Figure 10, the increase of pupil size from valley to peak is significantly different between all three IDs." \ We also improved Fig. 10 by correcting an error in drawing the significance testing bars and changed all the corresponding descriptions (in the third, fourth, and sixth paragraphs in Statistical Analysis in P7, and also 6th paragraph in Discussion).  \ Discussion: \ In responding to R1â€™s suggestion to normalize the movement time by distance, we included a brief summary of our other recently accepted paper showing the pupil responses to either the distance or size of the target changes (Page 8, at the end of the second paragraph in Discussion) â€œAlthough it would be   interesting to see if the differences hold if the movement time is normalized by distance and then compared across the three difficulty levels in this study, we did not do that since our other research [18] showed the pupil dilations and the movement time in goal-directed movements still respect Fittsâ€™ Law by only changing the target distance or target distance.â€ù Plus we have included a reference to that new paper [18]. \ In order to answer the question that whether the pupil diameter change has the ability to measure task requirement in goal-directed movement in real-time for each targeting step alone (R1, R3, R4, and R5), we added a paragraph in Discussion (9th paragraph, Page 8) â€œThe 7s window approach i.e., averaging many repetitive task epochs to show the pattern of pupil size change may not have the ability to measure task requirement in real-time. However some features, such as the valley to peak pupil size dilation, the valley to peak duration, and the latency between the moments of tool-reach and peak pupil size can be employed to classify the task difficulty of each targeting step alone using techniques such as machine learning. The ANOVA results showed that all of these features have strong (p < .001) ability in distinguishing the three difficulty levels of task requirement.â€ù \ As suggested by R5, we expanded the discussion for specific steps needed to apply the presented approach in measuring the task difficulty from pupil diameter changes in real-time in practice, and added three paragraphs in the Discussion (Pages 8-9, 10th, 11th, and 12th paragraphs). â€œFor real-world application, several steps should be carefully considered. First, the critical moment of the movement e.g. the moment the tool/hand starts to move or reach, should be accurately detected as a timing marker of the movement event that the pupil responses to. Usually tool-leave is more promising as a movement event marker than tool-reach since in a complex movement such as surgical tasks [17] the tool may need extra actions at the end of movements such as grasping or releasing an object. One effective and robust way to detect tool-leave and tool-reach is to first find the moment of peak velocity of the tool movement and then search backward and forward to get tool start and reached moments, as presented here.  \ Second, the features of pupil size change should be extracted within a window in the vicinity of the movement start. The window size should be properly defined according to the property of the application, since if the window is too small or too wide, useful pupil information may be excluded, or false pupil information introduced.  \ Third, the baseline of pupil diameter used for deriving each relative pupil diameter change in the window should be carefully chosen. In the present discrete movement study, the selection of the position of the baseline is quite straightforward, i.e. between 2s to 3s before the tool-leave moment, which is near the end of the 10s waiting time and is right before the pupil starts to dilate. However in a real-world motor task where the movements may occur consecutively without a clear waiting time between them, it may be a challenge to select the position of the baseline.â€ù \ In responding to tone down the claim of this approach for other tasks (R1, R4, and R5), we changed 15th paragraph in Discussion to â€œSecond, the method by which we measured the task requirements using pupil diameter in a discrete elementary task, that is the ID-to-pupil mapping in this motor-coordination task, could be further applied to complex tasks which can be decomposed into several elementary tasks [14], and is a subject for future research.â€ù \ We also delete the paragraph originally in Discussion that could be mis-interpreted to claim that the present approach is validated to other physiological responses. â€œSecond, we demonstrated a new way to define the task requirement, using Fittsâ€™ index of difficulty (ID), in goal-directed interactions. This new baseline method can be further validated through evaluation of complementary physiological signals to expand the variety of methods for the measurement of the task workload during goal-directed movements. Our approach is applicable in a variety of situations where accurate estimation of workload is critical, e.g. surgical training and simulation environments.â€ù  (Deleted) \ All other suggestions of the reviewers were included. \

Title: SensaBubble: A Chrono-Sensory Mid-Air Display of Sight and Smell
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial,Italic Times_New_Roman,BoldItalic Arial
Author list: Sue Ann Seah, Diego Martinez Plasencia, Peter Bennett, Abhijit Karnik, Vlad Otrocol, Jarrod Knibbe, Andy Cockburn, Sriram Subramanian
Author emails: s.a.seah@bristol.ac.uk, diego.martinez-plasencia@bristol.ac.uk, peter.bennett@bris.ac.uk, abe.karnik@gmail.com, vo0592@my.bristol.ac.uk, jarrod.knibbe@bristol.ac.uk, andrew.cockburn@canterbury.ac.nz, sriram@cs.bris.ac.uk
Abstract: We present SensaBubble, a chrono-sensory mid-air display system that generates scented bubbles to deliver information to the user via a number of sensory modalities. The system reliably produces single bubbles of specific sizes along a directed path. Each bubble produced by SensaBubble is filled with fog containing a scent relevant to the notification. The chrono-sensory aspect of SensaBubble means that information is presented both temporally and multimodally. Temporal information is enabled through two forms of persistence: firstly, a visual display projected onto the bubble which only endures until it bursts; secondly, a scent released upon the bursting of the bubble slowly disperses and leaves a longer-lasting perceptible trace of the event. We report details of SensaBubbleâ€™s design and implementation, as well as results of technical and user evaluations. We then discuss and demonstrate how SensaBubble can be adapted for use in a wide range of application contexts â€“ from an ambient peripheral display for persistent alerts, to an engaging display for gaming or education.

Title: Coordination of Tilt and Touch in One- and Two-Handed Use
Author list: Theophanis Tsandilas, Caroline Appert, Anastasia Bezerianos, David Bonnet
Abstract: Our goal is to enhance navigation in mobile interfaces with quick command gestures that do not make use of explicit mode-switching actions. TilTouch gestures extend the vocabulary of navigation interfaces by combining motion tilt with directional touch. We consider sixteen directional TilTouch gestures that rely on tilt and touch movements along the four main compass directions. An experiment explores their effectiveness for both one-handed and two-handed use. Results identify the best combinations of TilTouch gestures in terms of performance, motor coordination, and user preferences.

Title: Depth Perception with Gaze-contingent Depth of Field
Author list: Michael Mauderer, Simone Conte, Miguel A Nacenta, Dhanraj Vishwanath
Abstract: Blur in images can create the sensation of depth because it emulates an optical property of the eye; namely, the limited depth of field created by the eye's lens. When the human eye looks at an object, this object appears sharp on the retina, but objects at different distances appear blurred. \ Advances in gaze-tracking technologies enable us to reproduce dynamic depth of field in regular displays, providing an alternative way of conveying depth.  \ In this paper we investigate gaze-contingent depth of field as a method to produce realistic 3D images, and analyze how effectively people can use it to perceive depth.  \ We found that GC DOF increases subjective perceived realism and depth and can contribute to the perception of ordinal depth and distance between objects, but it is limited in its accuracy. \

Title: MixFab: a Mixed-Reality Environment for Personal Fabrication
Author list: Christian Weichel, Manfred Lau, David Kim, Nicolas Villar, Hans Gellersen
Abstract: Personal fabrication machines, such as 3D printers and laser cutters, are becoming increasingly ubiquitous. However, designing objects for fabrication still requires 3D modeling skills, thereby rendering such technologies inaccessible to a wide user-group. \ In this paper, we introduce MixFab, a mixed-reality environment for personal fabrication that lowers the barrier for users to engage in personal fabrication. Users design objects in an immersive augmented reality environment, interact with virtual objects in a direct gestural manner and can introduce existing physical objects effortlessly into their designs. \ We describe the design and implementation of MixFab, a user-defined gesture study that informed this design, show artifacts designed with the system and describe a user study evaluating the system's prototype.

Title: Human Factors of Speed-based Exergame Controllers
Author list: Taiwoo Park, Uichin Lee, Scott MacKenzie, Miri Moon, Inseok Hwang, Junehwa Song
Author emails: twpark@nclab.kaist.ac.kr, uclee@kaist.edu, mack@cse.yorku.ca, miri.moon@nclab.kaist.ac.kr, inseok@nclab.kaist.ac.kr, junesong@nclab.kaist.ac.kr
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 6 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Abstract: Exergame controllers are intended to add fun to monotonous exercise. However, studies on exergame controllers mostly focus on designing new controllers and exploring specific application domains without analyzing human factors, such as performance, comfort, and effort. In this paper, we examine the characteristics of a speed-based exergame controller that bear on human factors related to body movement and exercise. Users performed tasks such as changing and maintaining exercise speed for avatar control while their performance was measured. The exergame controller follows Fittsâ€™ law, but requires longer movement time than a gamepad and Wiimote. As well, resistance force and target speed affect performance. User experience data confirm that the comfort and mental effort are adequate as practical game controllers. The paper concludes with discussion on applying our findings to practical exergame design.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This paper examines the characteristics of a speed-based exergame controller that bear on human factors related to body movement and exercise.
Summary of Changes: We would like to thank the reviewers again for their insightful comments and constructive suggestions. We thoroughly addressed the reviewersâ€™ comments in the revised version, as follows. \  \ Appreciating the comments about the statistics in Table 2 (page 7), we changed the significance threshold of p = .05 into p= .01 throughout the table. With this, questionnaire items 9 (arm fatigue) and 10 (shoulder fatigue) are no longer significant. The supporting text has been adjusted accordingly. \  \ Following R3â€™s suggestion regarding user comfort, we added discussion on user comfort earlier in the paper with the research questions (page 3). We found that this issue is closely related with R2â€™s comment regarding the effect of exercise and physical ability. Therefore, we discussed the above two issues and their relationship. In addition, we revised and extended(?) the discussion on physical ability, such as differences in individual fitness levels, physical efforts of manipulating controllers, and resistance level of the exercise bikes (page 8). \  \ The comment of R3, regarding the block effect on movement time, has been addressed by providing detailed statistical information in page 6. As stated in the rebuttal, there is little difference between the results using the last block only and the results using blocks 6 to 10, in terms of the throughput and Fittsâ€™ law regression. Also, we revised the design of the Study 2, by clarifying the number of trials, as commented by R3. \  \ We clarified that the design of ExerPlanet is a demonstration of our findings from the experiments, not an implementation. As a part of our future works, we plan to evaluate actual user experience of the game as well as to provide a real demonstration soon. \  \ As commented by R5, we clarified the cases of actually implemented speed-based exergames in the Related Work section. The examples in Figure 1 are the games using one-dimensional control, which are highly compatible with speed-based exergame controllers. \  \ We updated the out-of-date reference [14] as suggested by R3, and corrected all the typos and wrong reference numbers throughout the paper. All other comments from the reviewers are addressed respectfully. \  \  \ ---- \  \ minor updates, Jan 13 - fixed figure numbers (3 and 4)

Title: Exploring the Acceptability of Google Glass as an Everyday Assistive Device for People with Parkinsonâ€™s
Author list: Roisin McNaney, John Vines, Daniel Roggen, Madeline Balaam, Pengfei Zhang, Ivan Poliakov, Patrick Olivier
Author emails: r.mcnaney@newcastle.ac.uk, john.vines@ncl.ac.uk, daniel.roggen@ieee.org, madeline.balaam@ncl.ac.uk, pengfei.zhang@ncl.ac.uk, ivan.poliakov@ncl.ac.uk, p.l.olivier@ncl.ac.uk
Abstract: We describe a qualitative study investigating the acceptability of the Google Glass  eyewear computer to people with Parkinsonâ€™s disease (PD). We held a workshop with 5 PD patients and 2 carers exploring perceptions of Glass. This was followed by 5-day field trials of Glass with 4 PD patients, where participants wore the device during everyday activities at home and in public. We report generally positive responses to Glass as a device to instil confidence and safety for this potentially vulnerable group. We also raise concerns related to the potential for Glass to reaffirm dependency on others and stigmatise wearers.

Title: Model of Visual Search and Selection Time in Linear Menus
Author list: Gilles Bailly, Antti Oulasvirta, Duncan Brumby, Andrew Howes
Abstract: This paper presents a novel mathematical model for visual search and selection time in linear menus. Assuming two visual search strategies, serial and directed, and a pointing sub-task, it captures the change of performance with five fac- tors: 1) menu length, 2) menu organization, 3) target posi- tion, 4) absence/presence of target, and 5) practice. The novel aspect is that the model is expressed as probability density distribution of gaze, which allows for deriving total selec- tion time. We present novel data that replicates and extends the Nielsen menu selection paradigm and uses eye-tracking and mouse tracking to confirm model predictions. The same parametrization yielded a high fit to both menu selection time and gaze distributions. The model has the potential to im- prove menu designs by helping designers identify more ef- fective solutions without conducting empirical studies.

Title: Growing Closer on Facebook: Changes in Tie Strength Through Social Network Site Use
Author list: Moira Burke, Robert Kraut
Abstract: Scientists debate whether people grow closer to their friends through social networking sites like Facebook, whether those sites displace more meaningful interaction, or whether they simply reflect existing ties. Combining server log analysis and longitudinal surveys of 3,649 Facebook users reporting on relationships with 26,134 friends, we find that communication on the site is associated with changes in reported relationship closeness, over and above effects attributable to their face-to-face, phone, and email contact. Tie strength increases with both one-on-one communication, such as posts, comments, and messages, and through reading friendsâ€™ broadcasted content, such as status updates and photos. The effect is greater for composed pieces, such as comments, posts, and messages than for â€œone-clickâ€ù actions such as â€œlikes.â€ù Facebook has a greater impact on non-family relationships and ties who do not frequently communicate via other channels.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Longitudinal study of changes in relationship closeness associated with Facebook use, over and above changes from phone, in-person, and email contact.
Summary of Changes: 1. Added descriptive statistics (mean, range) for tie strength measures, and clarified that the sample includes both strong and weak ties, but oversampled strong ties. \  \ 2. Toned down over-reaching claims about paper scope (doesn't cover between-relationship dynamics) and revised sentences that sounded like value judgments (e.g., toned down the last sentence, among others). \  \ 3. Revised the discussion about the difference between alter's broadcasting and ego's passive consumption (clarifying H2 and H3), reframing alter's broadcasts as "unread" rather than simply "undirected" content.  \  \ 4. Created supplementary online materials with all of the additional regressions that had been omitted for space (from the section titled "Facebook Communication with Different Kinds of Ties"). Added a link to those regressions as a footnote. (See http://tinyurl.com/burkechi2014supp). \  \ 5. Minor word-smithing / editing for clarity throughout.

Title: The Implicit Fan Cursor: A Velocity Dependent Area Cursor
Author list: Xiaojun Su, Oscar Kin-Chung Au, Rynson Lau
Abstract: We present the Implicit Fan Cursor (IFC) -- a novel target pointing technique using a cursor with a fan-shape activation area. \ The IFC couples the cursor's activation area with its velocity, i.e., the speed and direction of the mouse motion, behaving like a 2D spotlight cursor at low speed and a circular area cursor at high speed. Thus, it enables the user to precisely acquire distant targets at low speed and easily acquire nearest targets at high speed, without explicit mode switching. This technique minimizes cursor movement, while taking into consideration of the precision of cursor movement at different speeds. It also ensures that only one target is captured at any time. The results of our controlled experiments show that the IFC outperforms the point cursor and the area cursor techniques, particularly in terms of cursor moving distance, and that its performance can be accurately modeled using the Fitts' law.

Title: LinearDragger: a Linear Selector for Target Acquisition on Touch Screens
Author list: Oscar Kin-Chung Au, Xiaojun Su, Rynson Lau
Abstract: Touch input is increasingly popular nowadays, especially for mobile devices such as smartphones and tablet computers. However, the human finger has considerably large fingertip size and finger input is imprecise. As such, acquiring small targets on a touch screen is still a challenging task. In this paper, we present the \\emph{LinearDragger}, a new and integrated one-finger target acquisition technique for small and clustered targets. The proposed method has three advantages. First, it allows users to select targets in dense clustered groups easily with a single touch-drag-release operation. Second, it maps the 2D selection problem into a more precise 1D selection problem, which is independent of the target distribution. Third, it avoids finger occlusion and does not create visual distraction. As a result, it is particularly suitable for applications with dense targets and rich visual elements. Results of our controlled experiments show that when selecting small targets, \\emph{LinearDragger} takes about 70\\% and 30\\% less selection time than target acquisition without using any techniques and with the state-of-the-art target acquisition technique that involves a single touch operation, respectively, while maintaining a reasonable error rate.

The details are as follows. \  \ === Main Concerns === \  \ About result and discussion [R1]: \ As suggested by R1, we have now improved the results and discussion sections of both the preliminary studies and the main study as follows: \ 1)	We have placed the results into separate subsections from the discussions. \ 2)	We have replaced the original Tables 1 and 2 with text description in Preliminary Study 1. We have also combined the tables with similar patterns in the Main Experiment. (See Tables 1 â€“ 4 of the revised paper.) \ 3)	In the result subsection of the Main experiment, we have added detailed description of the post-hoc tests that we have conducted. We updated the presentation of the post-hoc test results using a rank based system, which seems to be much clearer than the original presentation. \  \ About the recruitment and compensation of participants [R4] \ We have added the details about the recruitment and compensation in a Participants subsection of Preliminary Study 1. \  \ About the limitation of our method [R2, R4, R5] \ We have added a Limitations subsection to discuss the limitations of our method (namely, the dependence on prior knowledge of target information, selection of arbitrary screen point, and overriding of the dragging operation) in the Conclusion section of the revised paper. \  \ About the comparison with existing methods [R1] \ As discussed in the rebuttal, TapTap ([21] of the revised paper) involves multiple tapping operations and belongs to a different category of methods. Hence, we did not compare our method with TapTap. Nevertheless, we have added this to the revised paper as a potential future work to conduct a broader range of performance evaluation on all selection operation types. \  \ === Minor Concerns === \  \ About the size of ROI in Preliminary Study 1 [R1] \ We have re-run the user study in Preliminary Study 1 with two smaller ROI sizes. Results show that when the size of the ROI is too small, it is much harder for the participants to specify the ROI so as to include the desired target. Hence, the participants needed to redo the selection, which affected the overall performance. \  \ About implementation details of the main experiment [R5] \ In the main experiment, we have explained the zero escalation time used by Shift and clarified that we had disabled the target expansion feature for LinearDragger in order to provide a fair evaluation. \  \ About the unit of the target sizes [R1] \ We have updated all the numbers to include the measurement unit (in mm). \  \ About precise description in the Abstract [R1] \ In the Abstract, we have added a description on the performance difference between LinearDragger and the state-of-the-art method.  \  \ About additional citation [R2, R3] \ We have added the suggested references ([4], [7] and [13] of the revised paper) to the Introduction section and the Related Work section. \

Title: Now You See Me, Now You Don't - Protecting Smartphone Authentication from Shoulder Surfers
Author list: Alexander De Luca, Marian Harbach, Emanuel von Zezschwitz, Max-Emanuel Maurer, Bernhard Slawik, Heinrich Hussmann, Matthew Smith
Author emails: alexander.de.luca@ifi.lmu.de, harbach@dcsec.uni-hannover.de, emanuel.von.zezschwitz@ifi.lmu.de, max.maurer@ifi.lmu.de, bernhard.slawik@ifi.lmu.de, hussmann@ifi.lmu.de, smith@dcsec.uni-hannover.de
Abstract: In this paper, we present XSide, an authentication mechanism that uses the front and the back of smartphones to enter stroke-based passwords. Users can switch sides during input to minimize the risk of shoulder surfing. We performed a user study (n = 32) to explore how switching sides during authentication affects usability and security of the system. The results indicate that switching the sides increases security while authentication speed stays relatively fast (<= 4 seconds). The paper furthermore provides insights on accuracy of eyes-free input (as used in XSide) and shows how 3D printed prototype cases can improve the back-of-device interaction experience.

Title: Research Through Design Fiction: Narratives in Real and Imaginary Abstracts
Author list: Mark Blythe
Abstract: This paper reflects on the value of prototypes in â€œResearch through Designâ€ù and considers â€œDesign Fictionâ€ù as a development technique. It begins with an analysis of RtD abstracts in the ACM digital library using a corpus query system called Sketch Engine. It identifies an emerging language and structure in academic abstracts on Research through Design. The abstracts frame a problem space, introduce a study, often involving the deployment of a prototype, and conclude with considerations, reflections and discussion. This format is pastiched in a series of design fictions written for the â€œdigital originalsâ€ù project investigating new and emerging forms of reproduction in Art. The fictions take the form of â€œimaginary abstractsâ€ù which summarize findings of papers that have not been written about prototypes that do not exist. It is argued that framing concept designs as fictional studies can provide a space for research focused critique and development.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This paper considers Design Fiction as a tool for Research Through Design and presents â€œimaginary abstractsâ€ù â€“ summaries of papers that have not been written about prototypes that do not exist.
Summary of Changes: I have followed the suggestions of the reviewers and the first AC as promised in my rebuttal.  I have also followed the suggestions of the second AC.  \  \ There are changes throughout to make the argument more clear, add depth to the context and finesse the difference between design fiction and other techniques such as scenarios personas and so on.  The main changes addressing this context are in the introduction, the section on Scenarios and Personas and the discussion though other changes have been made throughout to make the argument more clear. \  \ As indicated in the rebuttal I have shown how the imaginary abstract technique might be applied to other research contexts by adding a new fiction addressing a different topic â€“ the care of ageing populations. A complete imaginary abstract addressing this topic has been added to the section before the discussion.   \  \ As suggested by the second AC I have also added a summary of the research through design abstract analysis as well as several disclaimers setting the tone of the piece as a provocative essay and hopefully mitigating the risk of misinterpretation. These occur at the end of the introduction , the section before the imaginary abstracts and in the paragraph beginning â€œTo be clearâ€ù in the discussion. \  \ The paper has been thoroughly revised in line with all of the comments and suggestions from the reviewers and ACs. These were all extremely helpful and Iâ€™m very grateful to all concerned so thanks again. It is now a much stronger paper.  \

Title: Persuasive Technology for Overcoming Food Cravings and Improving Snack Choices
Author list: Anne Hsu, Jing Yang, Yigit Han Yilmaz, Md Sanaul Haque, Cengiz Can, Ann Blandford
Author emails: anne.hsu@eecs.qmul.ac.uk, iamsherlocker@gmail.com, y.yilmaz@se12.qmul.ac.uk, m.haque@se12.qmul.ac.uk, c.can@qmul.ac.uk, a.blandford@ucl.ac.uk
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science
Primary Affiliation 5 - Department/Schoo: School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science
Abstract: A central challenge in weight management is the difficulty of overcoming desires for excessive and unhealthy food. Yet, studies show that when people are able to resist their desires for unhealthy choices, they experience pride and satisfaction. In order to alleviate the former and support the latter, we designed, implemented and tested a mobile application for improving snacking behavior. Our application delivers a food craving reduction intervention at the moment of need and allows users to track how often they successfully resisted cravings. Our craving reduction intervention is based on recent research that shows that food cravings can be reduced through imagery techniques. We conducted a week-long evaluation of our application, comparing the effectiveness of our application to a basic tracking application. We found that our imagery application significantly reduced both overall snacking and unhealthy snacking compared to a simple snack-tracking application.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: An example of using psychological rewards and costs to inform persuasive technology design for weight management. We designed and tested a mobile app to help users reduce cravings in order to promote healthier snacking habits.
Summary of Changes: Revision report: \ All the content we promised in our response (see below for reference copy) has been provided in the new version of our paper.  We also included additional changes in response to the fifth reviewerâ€™s (AC2â€™s) additional comments, which were not required, but which we felt helped to improve our paper even more. \ These include: \ -Highlighting the novelty of our paper. \ -Removing the quantitative results of the prototype evaluation, which reviewers felt was not informative. \ -Including the results of post-experiment questionnaires regarding consumption of unhealthy snacks. \ -Clarifying the differences and similarities between the full app and the tracker app we used for the control condition and verifying the functional and procedural similarities between the two so that the comparison was valid. \ -Including the effects of usage over time in all of our analyses and using repeated measures statistics. \ -Adding a note saying we also repeated our analyses of Likert scales assuming ordinal data using Wilcoxon rank sum test for equal medians, and all of our analysis results were virtually unchanged. \ -Adding a section summarizing results from our qualitative interview. See section on â€œQualitative Resultsâ€ù. \ -Adding a greatly extended discussion section including more detailed description of why iCrave appeared to be effective, suggested broader benefits of iCrave, open questions and design implications. \ -Explaining that we chose the terminology of â€˜savingsâ€™ because we wanted to encourage the idea that forgoing immediate rewards should allow for greater rewards later, so we called this event a â€˜savingâ€™ of the craving on the app.   \ -Explaining why we chose the 20 minutes interval in which new savings could not be recorded, based on previous research on how long the brain takes to register post-consumption experiences. \ -Clarifying the difference between the prototype lite app and the tracker app used in the control condition. \ -Including summary of results of qualitative interviews of 13 people who had used our lite prototype app for a week. We also interviewed 13 participants and asked them about their experience using the app. To evaluate usability, we had asked how easy/hard they felt the app was to use; they all reported it was very usable. â€˜Very easyâ€™, â€˜simpleâ€™, â€˜convenientâ€™, â€˜very user friendly, I like it very muchâ€™. The main complaints were all centred on the fact that it wasnâ€™t deployed as an app and only as a mobile site. \ Response to reviews were as follows (for reference): \ We thank the reviewers for their supportive and helpful comments. We provide clarifications below. As recommended by reviewers, room for this new material can be made by reducing text on the initial pilot study.   \  \ NOVELTY: Previous lab studies only measured self-reported decrease in craving levels. Subsequent intake was never measured. Our work provides the first support that this method of craving reduction actually reduces consumption.    \  \ DIFFERENCE BETWEEN MAIN VS. LITE APPS: Apps were identical except for the imagery task, vividness rating, and choice of recording â€˜savingsâ€™. This is a difference of 10 seconds and one click. Thus we provide the assurances R2 wanted: the lite app looked exactly like Fig. 1 except that the two center screens were omitted, the â€˜save for laterâ€™ button was not available in the right screen, and the â€˜savedâ€™ tally was not available on the home screen. As with the full iCrave, iCrave lite users were asked to use the button when they experienced a craving and indicate whether they were going to consume a healthy or unhealthy snack before eating. Thus, any biases from reporting consumption beforehand would have applied to both groups.    \  \ ANALYSIS FOR UNDER-REPORTING CONCERNS: We also asked participants at the end of the study how many unhealthy snacks they consumed over the week. These results suggested participants in both conditions under-reported on the apps: participants in both conditions reported more unhealthy snacking in the post-questionnaire than their app usage indicated. However, when we compared unhealthy snack consumption based on post-experiment reports, participants in the main condition still consumed significantly fewer unhealthy snacks, F(1,51)=4.2, p=0.04.   \  \ STATS WITH TIME DEPENDENCE AND REPEATED MEASURES: We have re-analyzed the data using repeated-measures analyses and the fixed effect of time (days into expt) and regressions to observe usage with time as requested. All of our results remain unchanged with the new analyses. Overall usage and healthy snacks consumed did slightly decrease with time. Difference in usage patterns across conditions was marginal to non-significant and doesnâ€™t support any alternative interpretation of our results. Updated stats below:    \  \ Usage: Usage means a user pressed the iCrave button to initiate app use. No sig. effect of condition, p=.39. Sig. effect of time F(6,306)=2.71, p=.014, with marginal interaction p=.09. Plots showed that, while usage varied over days, overall decrease with time was small. OLS-Pooled Errors regression fit to the usage data w/ parameters of condition and time found slope for time was -.048, t(369)=2.8, p=.005. OLS-PE fits to individual conditions found: slope= -.04, t(180)=2.9, p=.004 (for main) and slope=-.05 t(187)=1.69, p=.09 (for lite).    \  \ Unhealthy snacks: Sig. effect of condition F(1,306)=14.5, p=.0004, no effects of time p=.43, and no interaction, p=.29.   \  \ Healthy snacks: no sig. effect of condition p=.27, sig. effect of time F(6,306)=2.37, p=.03, no interaction, p=.5.   \  \ Overall snacks: Sig. effect of condition F(1,306)=9.2, p=.004.  Sig. effect of time F(6,306)=2.36, p=.03. Marginal interaction, p=.092.  As before, OLS-PE regression was fit to the full data with param. of condition and time found time to be -.045, t(369)=2.7, p=.007. Fits to individual conditions separately found time slope=-.039, t(180)=2.8, p=.006 (for main) and slope=-.05 t(187)=1.69, p=.09, (for lite).     \  \ LIKERT: Treating Likert responses as interval data is common practice. However, as R2 suggested, we also re-analyzed our Likert responses assuming ordinal data and used Wilcoxon rank sum test for equal medians. All results and significance values remained virtually the same.   \  \ QUALITATIVE DATA: We did collect data from post-interviews with main iCrave users. Our interviews showed that iCrave caused participants to either no longer want a snack at all, or choose a healthy snack instead. Quotes about using the app include: â€œBefore I wanted a cookie, (after) I felt it was better that I did not eat a cookieâ€ù, â€œthere is a loss of appetiteâ€ù, â€œmakes me feel I donâ€™t want to eat snacksâ€ù, â€œI feel like I can control myselfâ€ù, â€œattraction of snacks is reducedâ€ù.  Quotes for moments when healthy snacks were chosen instead: â€œBefore, I wanted chocolate immediately. (Afterwards) I preferred the vegetable salad.â€ù â€œIt made me prefer healthy food.â€ù â€œI wanted chips, but afterwards, I felt it is better to eat something healthy.â€ù Users felt good about healthier choices: â€œI felt good avoiding the popcorn.â€ù â€œIt was a good feeling to avoid the ice creamâ€ù. â€œI felt happy to change the choice of food so my life can be healthier. However (as shown in our data) there were still occasions where iCrave users chose unhealthy snacks after using the app. Quotes about moments when iCrave didnâ€™t improve snacking include: â€œI felt it could not help me this time.â€ù â€œNothing changed, both before and after using the app I still wanted chicken." \

Title: A Pool of Dreams : Facebook, Politics and the Emergence of a Social Movement
Author list: Clara Crivellaro, Rob Comber, John Bowers, Peter Wright, Patrick Olivier
Abstract: In this paper we present insights from an empirical analysis of data from an emergent social movement primarily located on a Facebook page to contribute understanding of the conduct of everyday politics in social media and through this open up research agendas for HCI. The analysis focuses on how interactions and contributions facilitated the emergence of a collective with political will. We lay out an exploration of the intrinsic relationship between cultural memories, cultural expression and everyday politics and show how diverging voices co-constructed dynamic collectives capable of political action. We look at how interactions through the Facebook page challenge traditional ways for conceiving politics and the political. We outline possible research agendas in the field of everyday politics, which are sensitive to the everyday acts of resistance enclosed in the ordinary.

Summary of Changes: We elaborated on the context of the case study to provide clarity and a better understanding of the timeline of events and the relationship between offline and online actions. We also integrated additional information to further contextualize the case study and clarify the temporal narrative of events. This included timestamps and pseudonyms per quote and links to external websites relating to the case study. Additionally we added a section within the â€˜case studyâ€™ section, which clarifies the focus and limitations of the data analysis. We repurposed a section of the discussion to host explicit links to CHI literature and related fields, pinpointing the contributions the study makes in HCI. We provided conceptual clarifications to enable a better understanding of the theoretical framework informing the analysis.

Title: Haptic Turk: A Motion Platform Based on People
Author list: Lung-Pan Cheng, Patrick LÃ_hne, Pedro Lopes, Christoph Sterz, Patrick Baudisch
Abstract: Motion platforms are used to increase the realism of virtual interaction. Unfortunately, their size and weight is proportional to the size of what they actuate. We present haptic turk, a different approach to motion platforms that is light and mobile. The key idea is to replace motors and mechanical components with humans. All haptic turk setups consist of a player who is supported by one or more turkers. The player enjoys an interactive experience, such as a flight simulation. The motion in the playerâ€™s experience is generated by the turkers who manually lift, tilt, and push the player's limbs or torso. To get the timing and force right, timed motion instructions in a format familiar from rhythm games are displayed on turkersâ€™ mobile devices, which they attach to the playerâ€™s body. We demonstrate a range of installations based on mobile phones, projectors, and head-mounted displays. In our user study, participants rated not only the experience as player as enjoyable (6.1/7), but also the experience as a turker (4.4/7). The approach of leveraging humans allows us to deploy our approach anytime anywhere, as we demonstrate by experimentally deploying at an art festival in the Nevada desert.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: The main contribution of this paper is a new mechanism that creates a motion platform based on humans. With haptic turk, people can enjoy immersive motion experience anytime where there is people.
Summary of Changes: We found some typos and updated our video. \ We fixed typos in Figure 1. "turkers' iPod"->"actuators' iPod" \  \  \ SECOND REVISION \  \ Thanks again. We took your advices and changed as following: \  \ ### 2) real time response \  \ We changed the first paragraph in the limitations section to  \ â€œLimitations of our approach include that it requires multiple people, is tiring, and that human actuators cannot rival a computerized motion platform in terms of responsiveness and reliability. In particular, a real time unpredictable event is difficult to handle in our current system. For example, if players controlling a racing game swerve and hit a wall, this hit is difficult to predict. This makes the event difficult to haptically render by our system, as it does not leave enough time to properly prepare actuators for their action. Haptic turk runs in to similar issues if multiple events become possible at a given moment.â€ù \  \ ### 4b) use of "turkers" \  \ We replaced â€œturkersâ€ù with â€œhuman-actuatorsâ€ù in the Abstract and in the beginning of the Introduction and abbreviated it to â€œactuatorsâ€ù later on. \  \  \ FIRST REVISION \  \ Thank you again for supporting our paper--we know that shepherding means extra work for you and we appreciate it. \  \  \ Here are our changes \  \ ### 1) Re-formulate the paper to put more emphasis of the contribution as \   a specific experience (or a game) and *significantly* less of a generic \   approach/platform for haptics. \  \ We reduced the emphasis on being a generic approach to haptics by \  \ - taking out the interactive force feedback section in the Related Work. \  \ - toning down the statement in the Contribution by dropping this paragraph which was part of the original submission (It used to read "While, at first glance haptic turk may appear to be a video game system, we argue that it is general purpose approach to providing users with physical actuationâ€”is it would normally be administered by motion platforms or similar haptics equipment. This concept extends beyond motion and haptics, as we illustrated using the water and heat special effects in the walkthrough.") \  \ - We replaced "generic haptics" with "motion experience" throughout the paper. \  \  \  \ ### 2) Real-time limitations and potential solutions need to be much more \   prominently discussed (follow R2 suggestions).  \  \ In the limitations section, after "Limitations of our approach include that it requires multiple people, is tiring, and that human turkers cannot rival a computerized motion platform in terms of responsiveness and reliability." \ we added: \ 	"In particular, truly unexpected events, such a driver crashing into a guard rails do not leave enough time to properly prepare turkers for the action. Similarly, if a larger number of events are possible at a given moment, Haptic Turk cannot prepare turkers for all of them, as the â€œbandwidthâ€ù of the Turker display is limited." \  \  \  \ ### 3) For clarity, the revised paper should minimize hinting of being \   similar to crowdsourcing. Specifically, the claim that this system \   crowdsources haptics needs to be removed and I would suggest that the \   authors re-formulate their claims along the lines of suggestions from \   R2 and R5 that this is really a WoZ system. \ AND  \   4) That said, I don't think that all mentions of crowdsourcing need to \   be removed, but I would suggest that you constrain this to a specific \   section which discusses similarities and contrasts to crowdsourcing (or \   even better "friendsourcing" - See Bernstein et al.'s TOCHI paper). For \   the rest of the paper, please restrain from using such terminology,  \   since it definitely confused the readers. \  \ To clarify that we are not crowdsourcing, we removed our related work subsection on crowdsourcing and instead inserted this new one that says that we are different from crowdsourcing and that we share some characteristics with Wizard of Oz. \  \ "Wizard of Oz and Crowdsourcing \ Haptic Turk shares some characteristics with Wizard of Oz systems, such as the aforementioned Turk [18], Researchers use the wizard of oz method to speed up proto-typing [6] and to give users new experiences [7]. \ Haptic Turk is different from crowdsourcing, such as Amazonâ€™s Mechanical Turk (www.mturk.com/mturk), which focus on recruiting workers. However, haptic turk could use crowdsourcing platform such as TaskRabbit (www.taskrabbit.com), CommunitySourcing [13] and Friendsourcing [3] to help recruit turkers." \  \  \ ### 4b) Along those same lines, you should find a different term for  \    â€œturkersâ€ù since that is very evocative of the crowdsourcing  \    solutions today. R5 suggests "wizards", but I leave that decision  \    up to you. \  \ We really want to comply, but are struggling. We ran the term wizards by a bunch of people and it seemed to lead to confusion, as wizards are by definition hidden from the user while especially in the iPhone version turkers were clearly visible at all times. Given that the new version of the paper clarifies the origin of the work, is there any way we can talk you into letting us hold on to the term turkers? \  \  \  \ ### 5) While I'd suggest changing it, the name "Haptic Turk" may be  \   retained. If you opt for keeping the name, the motivation for the  \   name (as outlined in the rebuttal) should be included in the  \   beginning of the paper.  \  \ We did retain the name (thanks for giving us the option) and in the beginning of our introduction we clarified that our use of the name is based on the 18th century chess automatonâ€”The Turk "Haptic turk is a motion platform based on people. Title: Letâ€™s Do It at My Place Instead?  Attitudinal and Behavioral Study of Privacy in Client-Side Personalization
Author list: Alfred Kobsa, Bart P. Knijnenburg, Benjamin Livshits
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences
Abstract: Many users welcome personalized services, but are reluctant to provide the information about themselves that personalization requires. Performing personalization exclusively at the client side (e.g., on oneâ€™s smartphone) may conceptually increase privacy, because no data is sent to a remote provider. But does client-side personalization (CSP) also increase usersâ€™ perception of privacy?  \  \ We developed a causal model of privacy attitudes and behavior in personalization, and validated it in an experiment that contrasted CSP with personalization at three remote providers: Amazon, a fictitious company, and the â€œCloudâ€ù. Participants gave roughly the same amount of personal data and tracking permissions in all four conditions. A structural equation modeling analysis reveals the reasons: CSP raises the fewest privacy concerns, but does not lead in terms of perceived protection nor in resulting self-anticipated satisfaction and thus privacy-related behavior. Encouragingly, we found that adding certain security features to CSP is likely to raise its perceived protection significantly. Our model predicts that CSP will then also sharply improve on all other privacy measures. \

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: It has been claimed that users will perceive client-side personalization as being more "privacy-friendly". We investigate this claim in a behavioral experiment.
Summary of Changes: We made the changes that we had promised, and polished the paper thoroughly: \  \ - We removed one hypothesis and corresponding results, giving us room for the explanations below.  \  \ - We emphasize that the replicated use of our constructs increases their validity. \  \ - We explain in more detail that we contrasted CSP with three remote \ providers instead of just one to obtain more insights on established and \ upcoming comparators. We will mention that a pre-study (N=99) on trust \ perception (single-item) of existing and fictitious Pers providers showed \ that AmPers is a neutral (!) anchor point while Amazon is a positive extreme.  \  \ - We verified that removing any of our subsamples does not change our \ results. Because of this, using multiple samples actually increases the \ robustness of the results. \  \ - We follow R2â€™s advice and omit the effect of question position, \ thereby reducing complexity and gaining space for more explanations. The \ model fit will be unchanged.  \  \ - We explicitly mention that have to rely on their self-anticipated (and not post-usage) \ satisfaction when making disclosure decisions. \ We will rename "satisfaction" to "self-anticipated satisfaction", to avoid confusion. \  \ - We explain: In the trust literature, the standard model is \ tri-partite (Mayer et al. 1995). In privacy studies "perceived \ protection" relates to the sub-construct "benevolence", and turns out to \ be a better predictor for privacy-related attitudes and behaviors, and to \ be more reliably and economically measurable, than the "super-construct" \ trust.  \  \ - We emphasize that perceived protection is provider-specific, and \ thus a) closer in the causal chain to the provider manipulation than \ privacy concerns and satisfaction and b) more likely to interact with \ provider to influence these variables.  \  \ - >R2: Perceived protection is the cheese on the privacy concern mouse trap \ We make this proposition more explicit, crediting the reviewer. \  \ - We applied some linguistic corrections, following the AC's suggestions (usage of "rather")

Title: Taking Part: Role-play in the Design of Therapeutic Systems
Author list: Mark Matthews, Geri Gay, Gavin Doherty
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Trinity College, The University of Dublin
Abstract: Gaining an understanding of user needs is a central component of HCI design approaches such as user-centred design and participatory design. In some settings, such as mental health care, access to end-users is often constrained. This is a particular difficulty given that the experience of those with mental illness can be difficult for researchers to understand, and is further complicated by its associated stigma. In addition, the therapeutic setting is outside the common experience of most people and protected from outside intrusion. Although role-play has been used in varied ways in HCI, rarely has it been defined with sufficient clarity to enable others to deploy it in a nuanced manner. We argue that role-play is particularly suited for use in mental healthcare settings and, when used judiciously, can address some of the difficulties associated with working in this setting. This paper details a range of role-play formats appropriated from therapeutic role-play, drawing upon the HCI and mental health literature, therapist input and our experience of using role-play for a number of purposes at different stages of the development process. We consider how and why role-play can be used to generate empathy, gain understanding of therapy, provide feedback on designs before clinical use and help train therapists in using technology in the treatment room.

Title: The MOY Framework for Collaborative Play Design in Integrated Shared and Private Interactive Spaces
Author list: Wooi Boon Goh, Ming Chen, Cuong Trinh, Jacquelyn Tan, Wei Shou
Abstract: A novel Mine-Ours-Yours (MOY) interaction design framework is proposed for designing collaborative play activities in environments that combine both private and shared interactive spaces. A collaborative game designed on a system that integrates multiple mobile devices with an interactive tabletop was presented to demonstrate the implementation of the proposed MOY framework. Observations from field trials involving two groups of children were used to summarize the collaborative behaviors that are likely to be observed under the different interaction design configurations.

Title: GaussBricks: Magnetic Building Blocks for Constructive Tangible Interactions on Portable Displays
Author list: Rong-Hao Liang, Liwei Chan, Hung-Yu Tseng, Han-Chih Kuo, Da-Yuan Huang, De-Nian Yang, Bing-Yu Chen
Author emails: hyaloid@gmail.com, liwei.name@gmail.com, enlong0705@gmail.com, ejic045440@gmail.com, dayuansmile@gmail.com, dnyang@iis.sinica.edu.tw, robin@ntu.edu.tw
Abstract: This work describes a novel building block system for tangible interaction design, GaussBricks, which enables real-time constructive tangible interactions on portable displays. Given its simplicity, the mechanical design of the magnetic building blocks facilitates the construction of configurable forms. The form constructed by the magnetic building blocks, which are connected by the magnetic joints, allows users to stably manipulate with various elastic force feedback mechanisms. With an analog Hall-sensor grid mounted to its back, a portable display determines the geometrical configuration and detects various user interactions in real time. This work also introduce several methods to enable shape changing, multi-touch input, and display capabilities in the construction. The proposed building block system enriches how individuals interact with the portable displays physically.

Title: Visualization of Personal History for Video Navigation
Author list: Abir Al-Hajri, Gregor Miller, Matthew Fong, Sidney Fels
Abstract: We present an investigation of two different visualizations of video history: Video Timeline and Video Tiles. Video Timeline extends the commonly employed list-based visualization for navigation history by applying size to indicate heuristics and occupying the full screen with a two-sided timeline. Video Tiles visualizes history items in a grid-based layout by following pre-defined templates based on items' heuristics and ordering, utilizing screen space more effectively at the expense of a clearer temporal location. The visualizations are compared against the state-of-the-art method (a filmstrip-based visualization), with ten participants tasked with sharing their previously-seen affective intervals. Our study shows that our visualizations are perceived as intuitive and both outperform and are strongly preferred to the current method. Based on these results, Video Timeline and Video Tiles provide an effective addition to video viewers to help manage the growing quantity of video. They provide users with insight into their navigation patterns, allowing them to quickly find previously-seen intervals, leading to efficient clip sharing, simpler authoring and video summarization.
