Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We propose two designs, Video Timeline and Video Tiles, to visualize and navigate a video space using a personal video history, which could be integrated easily in a video viewer.
Summary of Changes: ïÅ—	R6 comment about not being honest and clear in what has been previously done by us (Interact2013) and how it relates, we have elaborated accordingly:  \  \ In the introduction: \  \ Aside from the commonly employed list-based representation of the visited videos in a reversed chronological order (e.g. YouTube, Netflix), to our knowledge, our previous work [1] was the first that provided a detailed visualization of a single video navigation history. Thus, the goal of this research is to extend the work for multiple-videos history by testing different design layouts that support this activity in a visual manner and allow users to manage their history, and evaluate the benefits this brings. \  \ In the subsection titled: History Record Representation Structure \  \ The principle goal of our interface is to provide efficient access to previously viewed videos, and in particular, the intervals viewed within those videos. We accomplish this by applying our approach, described in [1], where a continuous video history is recorded for the user as they consume video. \  \ In the evaluation section under header titled: List  \  \ The List visualization simply displays the history segments on one vertical strip as shown on the left of Figure 10, where these segments are organized on a reversed chronological order having the last viewed segment at the top of the list. This layout is our previous visualization [1] with the exception of having varied sizes for the thumbnails.  \  \  \ ïÅ—	R6 comment about user study is not clear that it looks at visualizations of multiple video (You claim the difference with this work is that you look at visualization of multiple videos, not just one. Yet, from the user study I doubt this. It is unclear.  The filmstrip view is contextual to the current video. The Video timeline and Video tiles could be either just of the current video, or could be of segments from multiple different videos.  The filmstrip view cannot do this. Therefore to be valid, you can only look at one video at a time. I.e. you would need to load a new video and view only its video timeline or video tiles. So I don't see how this really pushes beyond the single video case.). We address this by explaining in more detail about how single video viewing compares with using the history view that contains multiple videos in the following section5: \  \ Before the subsection titled: Design \  \ We also tested whether these history visualizations performed better than without detailed history where users simply find a video from a grid of previously seen videos (Figure 3) and then search for intervals using the single video's filmstrip (similar to what they would have in an online video website such as YouTube). \  \  \ In the subsection titled: Design \  \ For each clip, participants had to find the corresponding video first using either inter-video history (Figure 6) when one of the proposed visualizations was experimented, or the videos library (Figure 3) when Filmstrip was tested. After finding the video, participants searched for the questioned clip using the provided layout.  \  \  \ ïÅ—	R6 comment about post-hoc tests:  \  \ We explicitly mention the post-hoc analysis in the results and discussions section.  \  \ A post-hoc analysis showed that the filmstrip had significantly more previews and took more time than the other two modes, as we hypothesized.  \  \  \ ïÅ—	 R6 comment â€œWhilst the size of the history thumbnails and what this means is discussed in the video, they aren't mentioned in the textâ€ù \  \ We discuss this in paragraph 5 of the subsection titled: Video Navigation Interface \  \  \ Segment size is determined based on a weight factor which is derived from how often this segment has been viewed and the duration of the segment. For our study we used a weight factor of 75% of the peak view count plus 25% of the duration in minutes (normalized duration is not used to ensure small videos are not biased to a larger size).  \  \  \ ïÅ—	 R6 comment about trying to explain both the pilot and the actual experiment description at the same time was very confusing \  \ The table was removed to reduce the confusion and to provide more space to address the other points. \  \ ïÅ—	R1 comment about not including commercial video services such as Netflix \  \ We have included  comment in the related work along with YouTube as follows: \  \ In the timeline-based visualization, history consists of a linear scrollable list of thumbnails, which appear in reverse chronological order: the most recently visited page is at the top of the list, and clicking on any of these thumbnails (or icons) redirects the user to the corresponding web page. Most web browsers, YouTube, Netflix, Hodgkinson [8] and Girgensohn et. al [6] use this visualization to represent the history of user's visited content as shown in Figure 2(a), where clicking on one of the thumbnails navigates to the corresponding content. \  \  \ ïÅ—	 R1 comment about desktop vs. touch and mobile devices as there was disagreement amongst reviews about this point: \  \ nothing has been added for this \  \ ïÅ—	 R1 comment about laboratory study as there was disagreement amongst reviews about this point: \  \ nothing has been added for this \  \  \ ïÅ—	R3 comment about state the number of participants in the study earlier  \ It has been mentioned in the abstract to emphasize the number. \  \ ïÅ—	R3 comment about including other references such as video search (Matejka et. al (2013) Swifter:) and document navigation work (Cockburn et. al (2006), Faster document navigation with space-filling thumbnails) \  \ Cockburn citation has been included in the second paragraph of the results section: \  \ If the scrolling event is disabled following [4], then thumbnails size will shrink as the history builds up making the thumbnails difficult to identify. As is known with visualization scalability of any system there is a trade off between size and scrolling or zooming needs.  \  \ Matejka citation was not included since we are not discussing video search in the literature, as this does not appear as relevant as the other addition and space is limited. \  \ ïÅ—	R3 comment about repositioning figures: \ We tried to reposition figures so that they are closer to the location when they were first discussed. \

Title: Jump and Shoot! - Prioritizing Primary and Alternative Body Gestures for Intense Gameplay
Author list: Chaklam Silpasuwanchai, Xiangshi Ren
Abstract: Motion gestures enable natural and intuitive input in video games.  However, game gestures designed by developers may not always be the optimal gestures for players. A key challenge in designing appropriate game gestures lies in the interaction-intensive nature of video games, i.e., several actions/commands may need to be executed concurrently using different body parts.  This study analyzes user preferences in game gestures, with the aim of accommodating high interactivity during gameplay.   Two user-elicitation studies were conducted: first, to determine user preferences, participants were asked to define gestures for common game actions/commands; second, to develop effective combined-gestures, participants were asked to define possible game gestures using each body part (one and two hands, one and two legs, head, eyes, and torso).  Our study presents a set of suitable and alternative body parts for common game actions/commands.  We also present some simultaneously applied game gestures that assist interaction in highly interactive game situations (e.g., selecting a weapon with the feet while shooting with the hand).  Interesting design implications are further discussed, e.g., transferability between hand and leg gestures.

Title: Support Matching and Satisfaction in an Online Breast Cancer Support Community
Author list: Tatiana A. Vlahovic, Yi-Chia Wang, Robert E. Kraut, John M. Levine
Abstract: Research suggests that online health support benefits chronically ill users. Their satisfaction might be an indicator that they perceive group interactions as beneficial and a precursor to group commitment. We examined whether receiving emotional and informational support is satisfying in its own right, or whether satisfaction depends on matches between what users sought and what they received.  Two studies collected judgments in a breast cancer support community of support users sought, support they received, and their expressed satisfaction. While receiving emotional or informational support in general positively predicted satisfaction, users expressed less satisfaction when they sought informational support but received emotional support. There was also a tendency for users to express more satisfaction when they sought and received informational support. On the other hand, users were equally satisfied with emotional and informational support after seeking emotional support. Implications for membership commitment and interventions in online support groups are discussed.

Summary of Changes: 01-07-2014 \ We thank our reviewers for their helpful suggestions and provide a brief summary of our revisions below. We re-ran our Heckman analyses for Study 1 and Study 2 with the control variable number of community reply posts between the thread starter userâ€™s first and second post to a thread (Secondary, R3); this control variable significantly influenced satisfaction in a positive direction, and our other findings are mostly similar to our first submission. In our introduction section, we briefly acknowledge U&G Theory as a broad framework for matching, and we explain why we focus on the social support literature (R1). We further clarified our methods and explained why we coded first community replies to thread starter posts (Secondary, R3). In the discussion section, we included more discussion of study limitations (Primary, R1, R3), expanded our implications for design (R2), and made avenues of future work more clear (R3).  \  \ 01-15-2014 \ We further clarified our research questions and methodology in the camera ready version.

Title: CRISP - An Interruption Management Algorithm based on Collaborative Filtering
Author list: Tammar Shrot, Avi Rosenfeld, Jennifer Golbeck, Sarit Kraus
Abstract: Interruptions can have a significant impact on users working to \ complete a task. When people are collaborating, either with other \ users or with systems, coordinating interruptions is an important factor \ in maintaining efficiency and preventing information overload. Computer systems can observe user behavior, model it, and use \ this to optimize the interruptions to minimize disruption. However, \ current techniques often require long training periods that make them \ unsuitable for online collaborative environments where new users frequently participate. \  \ In this paper, we present a novel synthesis between Collaborative \ Filtering methods and machine learning classification algorithms to create a \ fast learning algorithm, CRISP. CRISP exploits the \ similarities between users in order to apply data from known users to new \  users, therefore requiring less information on each \ person. Results from user studies indicate the \ algorithm significantly improves users' performances in completing \ the task and their perception of how long it took to complete each \ task. \

Title: Learning to Fail: Experiencing Public Failure Online Through Crowdfunding
Author list: Michael D Greenberg, Elizabeth M Gerber
Abstract: Online crowdfunding platforms like Kickstarter are gaining attention among novice creatives as an effective platform for funding their ventures and engaging in creative work with others. However, a focus on financial success of crowdfunding has obscured the fact that over 58% of crowdfunding projects fail to achieve their funding goals. This population of failed creatives however, gives us an audience to study public creative failure in an online environment. We draw inspiration from work in organizational behavior on failure, and work in Human Computer Interaction (HCI) on online behavior, to study online public failure. Using a mixed-methods approach with data scraped from Kickstarter and interview data with failed crowdfunding project creators, we answer the following question: What do project creators on crowdfunding platforms learn and change through the process of failing? We find that creators who relaunch their projects succeed 43% of the time, and that most individuals find failure to be a positive experience. We conclude the paper with a series of design implications for future creative platforms where public failure is part of the creative process.

Title: The Turn to Practice in HCI: Towards a Research Agenda
Author list: Kari Kuutti, Liam J Bannon
Abstract: This paper argues that a new paradigm for HCI research, which we label the â€˜practiceâ€™ perspective, has been emerging in recent years. This stands in contrast to the prevailing mainstream HCI paradigm, which we term the â€˜interactionâ€™ perspective.  The â€˜practice turnâ€™, as it has been dubbed in the social sciences, provides a conceptual frame to organize a variety of issues emerging in more recent HCI research. While this approach has been present in certain strands of HCI research for some time, it has not been articulated fully to date. In this paper, we provide a short account of the main tenets of this perspective, and then show how it can illuminate some of the recent debates within HCI. Our argument is one which does not seek to replace extant HCI theories, but rather to provide an alternative, complementary theoretical lens which may illuminate the present confusion among both researchers and practitioners as to the direction of HCI. The paper articulates a set of issues which can help direct HCI research programs, as well as highlighting the potential contribution of the HCI field to this practice approach itself, in terms of a more nuanced understanding of emerging practices.

Title: Structuring the Space: A Study on Enriching Node-Link Diagrams with Visual References
Author list: Basak Alper, Nathalie Henry Riche, Tobias Hollerer
Abstract: Exploring large visualizations that do not fit in the screen raises orientation and navigation challenges. Structuring the space with additional visual references such as grids or contour lines provide spatial landmarks that may help viewers form a mental model of the space. However, previous studies report mixed results regarding their utility. While some evidence showed that grid and other visual embellishments improve memorability, experiments with contour lines suggest otherwise. In this work, we describe an evaluation framework to capture the impact of introducing visual references in node-link diagrams. We present the results of three controlled experiments that deepen our understanding on enriching large visualization spaces with visual structures. In particular, we provide the first tangible evidence that contour lines have significant benefits when navigating large node-link diagrams. \

Title: Multi-Viewer Gesture-Based Interaction for Omni-Directional Video
Author list: Gustavo Rovelo Ruiz, Davy Vanacken, Kris Luyten, Francisco Abad, Emilio Camahort
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Departamento de Sistemas InformÃ¡ticos y ComputaciÃ_n
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: Instituto Universitario de AutomÃ¡tica e InformÃ¡tica Industrial
Primary Affiliation 5 - Department/Schoo: Instituto Universitario de AutomÃ¡tica e InformÃ¡tica Industrial
Abstract: Omni-directional video (ODV) is a novel medium that offers viewers a 360Âº panoramic recording. This type of content will become more common within our living rooms in the near future, seeing that immersive displaying technologies such as 3D television are on the rise. However, little attention has been given to how to interact with ODV content. We present a gesture elicitation study in which we asked users to perform mid-air gestures that they consider to be appropriate for ODV interaction, both for individual as well as collocated settings. We are interested in the gesture variations and adaptations that come forth from individual and collocated usage. To this end, we gathered quantitative and qualitative data by means of observations, motion capture, questionnaires and interviews. This data resulted in a user-defined gesture set for ODV, alongside an in-depth analysis of the variation in gestures we observed during the study.

Summary of Changes: We updated the paper according to the suggestions made by the reviewers before and after the rebuttal. \  \ List of changes: \  \ * GENERAL \   - Corrected typos and inconsistencies throughout the paper. \   - Used the term "control operation" consistently, to clear up some confusion. \  \ * RELATED WORK \   - Fixed mistake in referencing Wobbrock's work. \    \ * METHODOLOGY \   - Explained our reasons for not using a Wizard of Oz and using a CAVE-like setup. \   - Clarified the instructions given to all participants before the experiment. \   - Clarified comfort level of participants during the experiment. \  \ * RESULTS \   - Clarified how and where we used the OptiTrack data. \   - Added analysis of friendship ties for each of the adjustment strategies. \    \ * DISCUSSION \   - Discussed the generalizability of our results. \   - Linked our findings to those of Walter et al. and Hinrichs et al.,  \     and to gestures from related work that are similar to those we observed. \   - Clarified that all sessions were used for the elicitation, not just the last session. \   - No longer attributed spread-and-pinch gesture to previous experience with multi-touch devices. \  \ * CONCLUSIONS \   - Emphasized exploratory nature, highlighted some of the opportunities for future research. \  \ Kind regards, \ The authors \

Title: Finding â€œReal Peopleâ€ù: Trust and Diversity in the Interface Between Professional and Citizen Journalists
Author list: Andrew Garbett, Rob Comber, Paul Egglestone, Maxine Glancy, Patrick Olivier
Abstract: The increase of social media and web blogs has enabled a new generation of citizen journalism to provide new perspectives into local communities. However traditional news organisations are currently struggling to incorporate this new form of journalism into their existing organisational workflow. We present an analysis from 10 interviews with professional journalists and explore the current issues faced by professional journalists when searching for reliable and reputable local news sources as well as the perceived role of citizen journalists within a large news organisation. From this analysis we present a set of design implications for building systems that support interaction between citizen and professional journalists in order to encourage participatory news production and diversify national news perspectives.

Title: Co-constructing Child Personas for Health-Promoting Services with Vulnerable Children
Author list: Pontus WÃ_rnestÃ¥l, Petra Svedberg, Jens Nygren
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Information Science, Computer and Electrical Engineering
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: School of Information Science, Computer and Electrical Engineering
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: School of Social and Health Sciences
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: School of Social and Health Sciences
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: School of Social and Health Sciences
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: School of Social and Health Sciences
Abstract: The availability of health-promoting resources for young children diagnosed with cancer who are transitioning from intensive care to everyday life is limited. In the context of designing digital peer support services for children who are considered vulnerable due to clinical and age-related aspects, there are several challenges that put critical requirements on a user-centered design process.  This paper reports on a new method for co-constructing child-personas that are tailored for developing health-promoting services where empirical data is restricted due to practical and ethical reasons. In particular, we are proposing to focus children design workshop sessions on salutogenesis, and complement this with a pathogenic perspective by interviewing healthcare professionals and parents. We also introduce the use of proxy personas, and redemption scenarios in the form of comicboards, both collaboratively constructed by children and designers through storytelling. By applying four progressive steps of data collection and analysis we arrive at authentic child-personas that can be used to design and develop health-promoting services for children in vulnerable life stages.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We present a new methodology for persona construction that integrates both stakeholder and children co-creational contributions when designing complex personas for health-promoting service design for peer support.

We have based the revision on the rebuttal, and also addressed the post-rebuttal reviews. \  \ 1. Salutogenic design orientation and design practice \ We have clarified how we work with salutogenic and patogenic orientations as a theoretical framework to both structure and guide the design process (Section 2.1 last 10 rows) and how the salutogenic orientation allowed us to approach issues related to DPS that would probably not have arised in a strictly pathogenic orientation (Section 3.1, 2nd paragraph, row 7-8 and 3rd paragraph, rows 4-8), and vice versa (Section 3.2, 2nd paragraph, row 10 and 4th paragraph, rows 1-4). \  \ 2. Linking theory, findings, design practice, and outcomes \ All figures have been translated from Swedish to English. We have also included our second primary persona, â€œJuliaâ€ù (Figure 5), to show a more complete list of outcomes, and thereby show a clearer potential of the results. \  \ We have connected how our theoretical underpinnings in terms of salutogenic and pathogenic orientations are visible and merged in the design deliverables - i.e. the primary personas - and supported by our findings in the stakeholder interviews and design workshops data. In the translated personas, it is clearer which characteristics are derived from the stakeholder interviews (pathogenic, and disease-related aspects), and which parts of the persona are derived from the health-promoting aspects raised in the workshops with the children. This is elaborated on in Section 4 (6th paragraph). \  \ 3. Method \ We have removed the comparison with "traditional" UCD to clarify our process as a development of UCD techniques. (Section 3.2, beginning of 1st and 2nd paragraph.) \  \ We added a more detailed account of the Stakeholder roles (Section 3.2, 3rd paragraph, rows 1-11.) \  \ We have addressed the issue that it can be difficult for readers to understand some of the steps and activities in the design workshops by providing more details on what questions were used by the workshop facilitator for character construction, and how the activities relate to friendship and peer support. (Section 3.3.3, 2nd paragraph, rows 5-8.) \  \ As a final point, we have proof-read and corrected grammatical errors as helpfully pointed out in the post-rebuttal review. \  \ The sum of all above-mentioned revisions and added reflections on our methodology (as supported by additional findings) gives a clearer picture of the value of combining pathogenic and salutogenic orientations for child-persona co-construction in this domain. \  \  \ Kind regards, \ The Authors \

Title: RecoFit: Using a Wearable Sensor to Find, Recognize, and Count Repetitive Exercises
Author list: Dan Morris, T. Scott Saponas, Andrew Guillory, Ilya Kelner
Abstract: Although numerous devices exist to track and share exercise routines based on running and walking, these devices offer limited functionality for strength-training exercises. We introduce RecoFit, a system for automatically tracking repetitive exercises - such as weight training and calisthenics - via an arm-worn inertial sensor. Our goal is to provide real-time and post-workout feedback, with no user-specific training and no intervention during a workout. Toward this end, we address three challenges: (1) segmenting exercise from intermittent non-exercise periods, (2) recognizing which exercise is being performed, and (3) counting repetitions. We present cross-validation results on our training data and results from a study assessing the final system, totaling 114 participants over 146 sessions. We achieve precision and recall greater than 95% in identifying exercise periods, recognition of 99%, 98%, and 96% on circuits of 4, 7, and 13 exercises respectively, and counting that is accurate to Â±1 repetition 93% of the time. These results suggest that our approach enables a new category of fitness tracking devices.

Thumbnail Image Caption: RecoFit automatically finds, recognizes, and counts repetitive exercises via an arm-worn inertial sensor, with no user-specific training and no intervention during a workout.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: RecoFit automatically finds, recognizes, and counts repetitive exercises via an arm-worn inertial sensor, with no user-specific training and no intervention during a workout.
Summary of Changes: In addition to addressing several minor fixes suggested by R2, we made three major changes, listed here with their locations in the paper and the new text. \  \ ** \ Added discussion of Muehlbauer (related work) (requested by reviewers) (page 2, first paragraph): \ The most relevant previous work is that of Muehlbauer et al. [24], who similarly divide the problem into segmentation, recognition, and counting. They achieve 85% segmentation accuracy and 94% recognition accuracy (10 classes) using subject-independent training. We build on this work to improve robustness and accuracy, and we validate RecoFit at a larger scale. Like the present work, their approach to segmentation uses features based on the autocorrelation. However, [24] uses heuristic thresholds for segmentation; RecoFit uses learned segmentation, which we believe is essential to robustness and scalability. [24] identifies sensor placement variation as a key challenge. However, they donâ€™t address this algorithmically; RecoFit introduces dimensionality reduction to allow orientation-invariant analysis. RecoFit adds a deeper approach to repetition counting, addressing orientation-invariance and false peak rejection, which results in higher counting accuracy. Finally, [24] doesnâ€™t address real-time scenarios; we discuss all stages in the context of an online application, identify latency tradeoffs, and include results for online and offline recognition. \  \ ** \ Added discussion of intensive strength-training (discussion) (requested by reviewers) (page 9, first paragraph, subsection called â€œIntensive Strength-Training and Periodicity Breakdownâ€ù): \ One of our core intuitions is our use of self-similarity as a segmentation metric. However, self-similarity may break down in intensive strength-training scenarios. For this reason, more validation of intensive weightlifting is important future work. However, we highlight that we only rely on short-term periodicity: if the 10th repetition is different than the first, segmentation will not suffer, as long as itâ€™s some-what similar to the 9th. This addresses the bulk of cases weâ€™ve observed, where breakdown from fatigue is gradual. Furthermore, our aggregation step allows even a sudden shift in form (such as reversing grip) to be handled gracefully, so long as self-similarity resumes. \ Such scenarios also may yield exercises longer than our 5-second windows. This window is tailored to minimize latency, but one may use longer windows for circuits with slow exercises, or use a short window in the non-exercise state and a longer window when looking for the end of slow exercises.â€ù \  \ ** \ Added discussion of implications for generalized activity recognition (discussion) (requested by reviewers) (page 9, last paragraph, subsection called â€œImplication for Generalized Activity Recognitionâ€ù): \ We conclude our discussion by summarizing three key lessons derived from our work that we believe have implications for sensor-based activity recognition, even outside of the exercise space: \ (1) When analyzing periodic signals, the use of independent learned models for periodicity identification and activity recognition can increase robustness. \ (2) Dimensionality reduction can increase robustness to variation in device placement and behavioral orientation. \ (3) We provide specific novel features to capture self-similarity for human motion applications, relevant to fitness, pedometry, physical therapy, etc. \

Title: OneSpace: Shared Visual Scenes for Active Freeplay
Non-embedded fonts: Arial Times_New_Roman Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman,Italic Helvetica,Bold
Author list: Maayan Cohen, Kody Dillman, Haley MacLeod, Anthony Tang, Seth Hunter
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Ontario College of Art and Design
Abstract: Children engage in free play for emotional, physical and social development; researchers have explored supporting free play between physically remote playmates using videoconferencing tools. We show that the configuration of the video conferencing setup affects play. Specifically, we show that a shared visual scene configuration promotes fundamentally active forms of engaged, co-operative play.

Title: TaggedComments: Promoting and Integrating User Comments in Online Application Tutorials
Author list: Andrea Bunt, Patrick Dubois, Ben Lafreniere, Michael Terry, David Cormack
Abstract: User comments posted to popular online tutorials constitute a rich additional source of information for readers, yet current designs for displaying user comments on tutorial webpages do little to support their use. Instead, comments are separated from the tutorial content they reference and tend to be ordered according to post date. We propose and evaluate the TaggedComments system, a new approach to displaying comments that users post to online tutorials. Using tags supplied by commenters, TaggedComments seeks to enhance the role of user comments by 1) improving their visibility, 2) allowing users to personalize their use of the comments according to their particular information needs, and 3) providing direct access to potentially helpful comments from the tutorial content. A laboratory evaluation with 16 participants shows that, in comparison to the standard comment layout, TaggedComments significantly improves users' subjective impressions of comment utility when interacting with Photoshop tutorials.

Title: Reflection through Design: Immigrant Womenâ€™s Self-Reflection on Managing Health and Wellness
Author list: Deana Brown, Victoria Ayo, Rebecca E Grinter
Abstract: Women comprise nearly half of the immigrant population worldwide and are susceptible to a wider range of health challenges compared to immigrant men. We present the findings of four participatory design sessions with immigrant women from the Caribbean to identify health and wellness challenges they faced and to conceptualize technologies to help them manage these issues. Stress, dietary challenges (specifically obesity), mental health, and domestic abuse, as identified by the women, form the focal themes for the design sessions. Their design approaches emphasized rebuilding the support structure, reducing stressors through entertainment and relaxation and encouraging positive gradational lifestyle changes. In conceiving health and wellness technologies for immigrant women, our work highlights opportunities for HCI to consider the role of others (and who benefits) and to reflect on the role of design and the underlying values and themes designs encompass. Finally, we emphasize how the technologies conceived by these women support rather than replace social solutions to the health and wellness challenges faced by these and other immigrant women.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We present findings from participatory design sessions with Caribbean immigrant women to identify health and wellness challenges they faced and through their designs critically reflect on how technologies can and cannot help to tackle challenges.
Summary of Changes: Based on the reviewers comments we: \  \ Reframed and updated the discussion to critically reflect on the designs and their limitations as well as the limitation of HCI to address the life circumstances of people. Reframed the contributions of the paper (shifting away from design solutions to reflection). Revisited word choices and tone of paper, shifting away from use of 'tradition' and making generalizations about culture.  \  \ Described the women's prior use of technologies to attend to some of the challenges they faced. Addressed the question of "why tech solutions" explaining how some of the tech solutions facilitate rather than compete with social solutions and taking up the question of when not to design (included a section to discuss this). \  \ Shortened participant quotes throughout paper.  \  \ Updated statistics to explicitly say US where previously lacking. \  \ Expanded the methods section to include more participant demographics (and info about the women and their circumstances). Expanded description of the coding process (including examples of low-level codes) and discussed the researchers engagement and familiarity with the women before and after the study. Also explained the researchers agenda before the focus group and how themes arose organically from the focus session. \  \ #### \  \ Updated the section on "Consider the Limits of HCI and Design" to emphasize the findings from our work.

Title: SurfaceLink: Using Inertial and Acoustic Sensing to Enable Multi-Device Interaction on a Surface
Author list: Mayank Goel, Brendan Lee, Md. Tanvir Islam Aumi, Shwetak N Patel, Gaetano Borriello, Stacie Hibino, Bo Begole
Author emails: mayank@cs.washington.edu, lee33@uw.edu, tanvir@uw.edu, shwetak@cs.washington.edu, gaetano@cs.washington.edu, stacie.hibino@sisa.samsung.com, bo@begole.net
Abstract: We present SurfaceLink, a system where users can make natural surface gestures to control association and information transfer among a set of devices that are placed on a mutually shared surface (e.g., a table). SurfaceLink uses a combination of on-device accelerometers, vibration motors, speakers and microphones (and, optionally, an off-device contact microphone for greater sensitivity) to sense gestures performed on the shared surface. In a controlled evaluation with 10 participants, SurfaceLink detected the presence of devices on the same surface with 97.7% accuracy, their relative arrangement  with 89.4% accuracy, and various single- and multi-touch surface gestures with an average accuracy of 90.3%. A usability analysis showed that SurfaceLink has advantages over current multi-device interaction techniques in a number of situations.

Title: Reflection or Action?: How Feedback and Control Affect Location Sharing Decisions
Author list: Sameer Patil, Roman Schlegel, Apu Kapadia, Adam J. Lee
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Helsinki Institite for Information Technology HIIT
Abstract: Owing to the ever-expanding size of social and professional networks, it is becoming cumbersome for individuals to configure information disclosure settings. We used location sharing systems to unpack the nature of discrepancies between a person's disclosure settings and contextual choices. We conducted an experience sampling study (N = 35) to examine various factors contributing to such divergence. We found that immediate feedback about disclosures without any ability to control the disclosures evoked feelings of oversharing. Moreover, deviation from specified settings did not always signal privacy violation; it was just as likely that settings prevented information disclosure considered permissible in situ. We suggest making feedback more actionable or delaying it sufficiently to avoid a knee-jerk reaction. Our findings also make the case for proactive techniques for detecting potential mismatches and recommending adjustments to disclosure settings, as well as selective control when sharing location with socially distant recipients and visiting atypical locations.

Title: Exploring the Usefulness of Finger-Based 3D Gesture Menu Selection
Author list: Arun Kulshreshth, Joseph J LaViola Jr.
Abstract: Counting using one's fingers is a potentially intuitive way to enumerate a list of items and lends itself naturally to gesture-based menu systems. In this paper, we present the results of the first comprehensive study on Finger-Count menus to investigate its usefulness as a viable option for 3D menu selection tasks. Our study compares 3D gesture-based finger counting (Finger Count menus) with two gesture-based menu selection techniques (Hand-n-Hold, Thumbs-Up), derived from existing motion-controlled video game menu selection strategies, as well as 3D Marking menus. We examined selection time, selection accuracy and user preference for all techniques. We also examined the impact of different spatial layouts for menu items and different menu depths. Our results indicate that Finger-Count menus are significantly faster than the other menu techniques we tested and are the most liked by participants. Additionally, we found that while Finger-Count menus and 3D Marking menus have similar selection accuracy, Finger-Count menus are almost twice as fast compared to 3D Marking menus.

Title: Fostering Social Capital in Economically Distressed Communities
Author list: Tawanna R Dillahunt
Abstract: Past Information and Communication Technology (ICT) literature suggests that engaging in meaningful activities with ICTs may be related to socio-economic security, social inclusion, empowerment, and increased social capital. However, we identify a pervasive lack of understanding in existing literature, which raises an important research question: how can we build social capital where little social capital exists? We conducted a preliminary study to explore whether and if so, how, individuals in an economically distressed population with limited social capital use technologies to increase social capital and achieve socio-economic security. We contribute details about barriers affecting social capital (e.g., difficulties finding and making the right connections and an overall lack of trust within communities). We also suggest ways in which ICTs can assist populations that could benefit most from increased social capital and economic security.

Title: Interface Design for Older Adults with Varying Cultural Attitudes toward Uncertainty
Author list: Shathel Haddad, Joanna McGrenere, Claudia Jacova
Abstract: This work reports on the design and evaluation of culturally appropriate technology for older adults. Our design context was Cognitive Testing on a Computer (C-TOC): a self-administered computerized test under development, intended to screen older adults for cognitive impairments. Using theory triangulation of cultural attitudes toward uncertainty, we designed two interfaces (one minimal and one rich) for one C-TOC subtest and hypothesized they would be culturally appropriate for older adult Caucasians and East Asians respectively. We ran an experiment with 36 participants to investigate cultural differences in performance, preference and anxiety. We found that Caucasians preferred the interface with minimal elements (i.e. those essential for the primary task) or had no preference. By contrast, East Asians preferred the rich interface augmented with security and learning support and felt less anxious with it than the minimal.

Title: The Use of Surrounding Visual Context in Handheld AR: Device vs. User Perspective Rendering
Author list: Klen ÄŒopiÄç Pucihar, Paul Coulton, Jason Alexander
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Computing and Communications, Lancaster University
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Imagination, Lancaster Institute for the Contemporary Arts
Abstract: The magic lens paradigm, a commonly used descriptor for handheld Augmented Reality (AR), presents the user with dual views: the augmented view (magic lens) that appears on the device, and the real view of the surroundings (what the user can see around the perimeter of the device). The augmented view is typically implemented by rendering the video captured by the rear-facing camera directly onto the deviceâ€™s screen. This results in dual perspectivesâ€”the real world being captured from the deviceâ€™s perspective rather than the userâ€™s perspective (what an observer would see looking through a transparent glass pane). These differences manifest themselves in misaligned and/or incorrectly scaled transparency resulting in the dual-view problem. \ This paper presents two user studies comparing (a) device-perspective and (b) fixed Point-of-View (POV) user-perspective magic lenses to analyze the effect of the dual-view problem on the use of the surrounding visual context. The results confirm that the dual-view problem, a result of dual perspective, has a significant effect on the use of information from the surrounding visual context. The study also highlights that magnification and not the dual-view problem is the key factor explaining the correlation between magic lens size and the increased intensity of the magic lens type effect. From the results, we derive design guidelines for future magic lenses. \

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Disadvantage of device-perspective over user-perspective rendering in tablet-sized magic lenses is not based on increased effect of the dual-view problem (a consequence of lens size), but on cumulative effect of the dual-view problem and magnification.
Summary of Changes: The final manuscript was changed in line with all suggested changes and clarifications provided in the rebuttal. The summary of changes follows the rebuttal structure and +++highlights+++ which text segments of the final manuscript were modified. \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ =Generalisability to Real-world Scenarios= \ *Mapping Interactions* \ Our work addresses the general class of tabletop-sized AR workspaces using two types of tasks: (a) Cross-context interaction: where the user's hand will cross the borders of the lens and (b) View-merge interaction: where the user must merge the surrounding context and lens view.  \ There are many examples of where these interactions take place. For (a): AR supporting user sketching, e.g. transcribing digital instructions/routes to paper maps or reproducing a digital stencil on paper, and where tangible objects are brought into and out of the augmented view, e.g. AR chess with physical pieces; and for (b): Navigation and route-planning on augmented paper maps, e.g. where virtual routes/landmarks are augmented and the focus+context view still supports navigation decision making, and augmented magazine activities, e.g. the augmented view providing hints to a crossword puzzle. \  \ To clarify how our work translates into these real-world examples we will expand the scenario descriptions in the introduction.  \ ------------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to Figure 1 and the text segments p.1 para.3 and p.2 para.2.+++ \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ *Mapping Tasks* \ Contrived tasks: We specifically chose to conduct a series of tightly constrained experiments in order to effectively evaluate cross-context interaction and view-merging. \  \ Cross-context interaction: was evaluated on a drag-and-drop task forcing users to cross the lens boundary, analogous to the examples described above in (a), where a user's hand commonly crosses the lens border during interaction. \ View-merge: was evaluated in a map navigation task where path following required decision making. Even though the task is artificial, this interaction pattern is analogous to the first AR use case of (b) above. [1] used a similar methodology and so it was deemed appropriate.  \  \ To justify the task design we will enhance the experimental approach section with these explanations and a add reference to [1]. \  \  [1] Oh and Hua, User evaluations on form factors of tangible magic lenses, ISMAR '06. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to text segment p.4 para.9.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ *Restricted FOV* \ This work focusses on tabletop-sized workspaces. We agree that the restricted FOV is problematic when considering outdoor settings, but does not limit the applicability of our results in the evaluated context. We will discuss this in our limitations. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to text segment p.9 para.8.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ *Generalization to Dynamic POV*  \ Yes, we believe our results will generalize from Fixed- to Dynamic-POV user-perspective rendering, as Dynamic-POV does not require users to maintain alignment above the screen (Fig 3e). We will comment on this generalizability in our discussion. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to the text segment p.9 para.6.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ =Magnification Model= \ *Magnification as a Major Factor Limiting Context Merging* \ From Study A, we conclude that surrounding context use is predominantly affected by: (1) the existence of the dual-view problem; and (2) magnification. Study A detected: (1) a significant effect of lens type; (2) a strong interaction between lens type and size; and (3) a limited effect of lens size. Point (2) suggests these two factors are inter-related and we explain them with the magnification model. Which of these two are more important varies depending on the AR use case-an area we list as future work. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to the text segment p.7 para.8.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ *Model Production*  \ The magnification model (Fig 5b) is derived from a theoretical analysis of ideal vs. camera-generated (virtual) transparency. Based on this theoretical model, and the screen size (w), FOV of the camera (alpha), distance to workspace (d'), and a variety of observer distances (d), we generated Fig. 5c to illustrate when magnification and minimization occurs for the devices used in our studies (minimising above 1, magnifying below 1). We then generated Fig 5d to summarise when the magnification advantage occurs. We will clarify these production steps in the 'Magnification Model' section. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to the text segments: p.8 para.2, p.8 para.3, p.8 para.4 and p.8 para.5.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ *Generalization of Guideline Table* \ The design-guideline table can be generalized to any table-top sized AR workspace. To do this, the specific setup parameters are plugged into the model (Fig 5b), in order to produce the equivalent of Fig 5c. The magnification advantage (row 1, Fig 5d) is then derived (minimization provides an advantage, magnification does not), while the second criteria (row 2) is only lens-type dependent. This will be clarified by the changes made to the description of model production. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in modifications to the text segment p.8 para.6.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ =Language= \ While R2 enjoyed reading the paper and R3 acknowledges the good writing style, we agree that the paper does require proof-reading. We have recruited a native speaker who is committed to spending the time to carefully proof-read the entire paper and help us to correct the language issues raised by the reviewers. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++Modified segments: Whilst keeping the content of text intact, small text amendments were made through the manuscript to improve quality of presentation and correct language issues raised by the reviewers.+++ \  \  \  \  \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ =Additions= \ For the additional text, we plan to: remove p.2 par.7, p.3 par.4, and the quote in p.4 par.3; p.4 para.7, 8 and 9 will be summarized into one paragraph as a description is in [9]. \ ----------------------------------------------------------------------- \ +++The above reflects in removal of all text segments listed above. Title: Necessary, Unpleasant, and Disempowering: Reputation Management in the Internet Age
Author list: Allison Woodruff
Abstract: In this paper, we report on a qualitative study of how users manage their reputation online. We focus particularly on people who are bothered by content online about themselves and how they manage reputation damage and repair. We describe how users view reputation management chores as necessary but unpleasant, and how they feel disempowered to repair their online reputation. Participants were unable to identify feasible repair mechanisms and ultimately failed to resolve their problems. Given the current state of dysfunction indicated by our findings, we advocate for increased HCI research attention to this area.

Title: The Lonely Raccoon at the Ball:  Designing for Intimacy, Sociability, and Selfhood
Author list: Jeffrey Bardzell, Shaowen Bardzell, Guo Zhang, Tyler Pace
Abstract: Designing for sociable systems requires, among other abilities, a sensitivity to the meanings, structures, and nuances of technology-mediated experiences that are simultaneously felt by users to be intimate and also social. Such a sensitivity is not easily acquired, and design researchers have recommended the use of social theories to guide designersâ€™ readings of technology-mediated social experiences. We use philosopher Michel Foucaultâ€™s theory of identity (and social power, discourse, sexuality, creativity, and style) known as â€œthe care of the self,â€ù as a scaffold with which to produce a sensitive interpretation of the intimacy (and ex-pert social creative) practices of adult users of the virtual world Second Life (SL). This reading sheds light on several skilled and creative intimacy practices in SL. It also offers a philosophically grounded hermeneutic strategy for designers interested in analyzing intimate experiences.

Title: â€œKid-in-the-Loopâ€ù Content Control:  A Collaborative and Education-oriented Content Filtering Approach
Author list: Yasmeen Hashish, Andrea Bunt, Jim Young
Abstract: We present an approach to content control where parents and children collaboratively configure restrictions and filters, an approach that focuses on education rather than simple rule setting. We conducted an initial exploratory qualitative study with results highlighting the importance that parents place on avoiding inappropriate content. Building on these findings, we designed an initial prototype which allows parents and children to work together to select appropriate applications, providing an opportunity for parents to educate their children on what is appropriate. A second qualitative study with parents and children in the six to eight year-old age group revealed a favorable response to this approach. Our results suggest that parents felt that this approach helped facilitate discussions with their children and made the education more enjoyable and approachable, and that children may have also learned from the interaction. In addition, the approach provided some parents with insights into their childrenâ€™s interests and understanding of their notions of appropriate and inappropriate content.

Summary of Changes: We implemented all the changes we promised in the rebuttal, including improving our framing and background in the introduction based on related work, introducing tablet-relevant examples throughout, improving the explanation of the benefits of our exploratory study, clarifying the filter learning implementation details, softening our language in our final discussion as well as clearly discussing some caveats to our work, and expanding the future work section to highlight limitations in our current paper. \   \ An important element of this is our revisions regarding the "kid in the loop" concept. As discussed in the rebuttal, we agree that with our study design we need to soften our stance on wheter or not children were actually in the loop. In addition to changing the paper title, we have worked hard to soften our claims to the child actually in the loop and our claims to success, although the "kid in the loop" idea is still in the paper. \   \ In addition, we implemented all minor formatting and text changes as requested by reviewers

Title: Stimulating a Blink: Reduction of Eye Fatigue With Visual Stimulus
Author list: Tarik Crnovrsanin, Yang Wang, Kwan-Liu Ma
Abstract: Computers make incredible amounts of information available at our fingertips. As computers become integral parts of our lives, we spend more time staring at computer monitor than ever before, sometimes with negative effects. One major concern is the increasing number of people suffering from Computer Vision Syndrome (CVS). CVS is caused by extensive use of computers, and its symptoms include eye fatigue, frequent headaches, dry eyes, and blurred vision. It is possible to partially alleviate CVS if we can remind users to blink more often. We present a prototype system that uses a camera to monitor a user's blink rate, and when the user has not blinked in a while, the system triggers a blink stimulus. We investigated four different types of eye-blink stimulus: screen blurring, screen flashing, border flashing, and pop-up notifications. Users also rated each stimulus type in terms of effectiveness, intrusiveness, and satisfaction. Results from our user studies show that our stimuli are effective in increasing user blink rate with screen blurring being the best.

Title: Consumed Endurance: A Metric to Quantify Arm Fatigue of Mid-Air Interactions
Author list: Juan David HincapiÃ©-Ramos, Xiang Guo, Paymahn Moghadasian, Pourang P Irani
Abstract: Mid-air interactions are prone to fatigue and lead to a feeling of heaviness in the upper limbs, a condition casually termed as the gorilla-arm effect. Designers have often associated limitations of their mid-air interactions with arm fatigue, but do not possess a quantitative method to assess and therefore mitigate it. In this paper we propose a novel metric, Consumed Endurance (CE), derived from the biomechanical structure of the upper arm and aimed at characterizing the gorilla-arm effect. We present a method to capture CE in a non-intrusive manner using an off-the-shelf camera-based skeleton tracking system, and demonstrate that CE correlates strongly with the Borg CR10 scale of perceived exertion. We show how designers can use CE as a complementary metric for evaluating existing and designing novel mid-air interactions, including tasks with repetitive input such as mid-air text-entry. Finally, we propose a series of guidelines for the design of fatigue-efficient mid-air interfaces.

Title: Sample-Oriented Task-Driven Visualizations: Allowing Users to Make Better, More Confident Decisions
Author list: Nivan Ferreira, Danyel Fisher, Arnd Christian Konig
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Computer Science and Engineering/Polytechnic Institute of New York University/VGC Lab
Abstract: We often use datasets that reflect samples, but many visualization tools treat data as full populations. Uncertain visualizations are good at representing data distributions emerging from samples, but are more limited in allowing users to carry out decision tasks. This is because tasks that are simple on a traditional chart (e.g. â€œcompare two barsâ€ù) become a complex probabilistic task on a chart with uncertainty. We present guidelines for creating visual annotations for solving tasks with uncertainty, and an implementation that addresses five core tasks on a bar chart. A preliminary user study shows promising results: that users have a justified confidence in their answers with our system.

Summary of Changes: We thank the shepherd and all the reviewers for all the useful comments. In the following we describe how the points raised by the shepherd were addressed in our paper. \ We take the first two points out of order: \ 2. How have you broadened and clarified the expert/non-expert issues in this paper and address the R1 point that experts "can go ahead and read error bars." \ Several times (page 1,2,9, and 11 in the draft of 12/24) we point out that even experts who use statistics in their research have difficulty understanding confidence intervals. The common rule of thumbâ€”looking for confidence interval overlapâ€”doesnâ€™t actually do what experts think it does. We outsource the heavy lifting on this to Cumming [6,7] and Belia et al [3], whose titleâ€”â€œResearchers misunderstand confidence intervals and standard error barsâ€ùâ€” says it all.  \ Similarly, it is almost impossible to â€˜read error barsâ€™ for questions like ordering and sequencing. Figure 3, which illustrates the ranked list, is a great example.  We do not specifically criticize the notion of â€œreading the error barsâ€ù, but we do instead point out that users can read our visualization directly. We would be happy to add in an explicit comment to that effect.  \ As we briefly discuss in the â€œDiscussion & Future Workâ€ù section, we expect that our principles and similar visualization/interaction techniques would be very helpful in analysis using more complex visualizationsâ€”ones where reading the error bars may not be possible.  \  \ 1. The authors have argued that the audience are "analysts familiar with confidence intervals and basic statistics" which is why this is a relevant and representative test audience. While this reduced the score from one reviewer the authors need to describe how they have framed this paper specifically for this audience. \ 	As described in the previous answer, in several places in the paper we try to motivate the target audience by using the argument that even experts have problems fully understanding confidence intervals.  We think that this is a strong motivation for our work. We added an explicit comment in the first paragraph of section â€œThe Design of Sample-Based Visualizationsâ€ù that states that this target population guided our design. In several places in the paper, we have used the term â€œdata analystsâ€ù instead of â€œusersâ€ù to denote individuals of our target population, we believe that this emphasizes our target population throughout the paper. Finally, we improved the discussion of user population in the evaluation section.  \ In our study we used people with at least basic statistics training and experience in data analysis because these are our target audience. (As R1 notes, these techniques might also be useful for people who are not as familiar with statistics). Previous work, such as Belia et al, also examine researchers who use statistics in their regular work. A future study could try to explore the impact of our annotations in this field. \ We hope that our modifications help make this point more clearly.  \  \ 3. How have the issues of the analysis of data in this study raised by the 2AC been addressed  \ The 2AC raises several questions: \ Our choice of using CS students was addressed above, in our discussion of expert vs non-expert, and our target audience. \ We address more about the â€˜narrow scope of the studyâ€™ and the claim that â€œactual Analysis is shallowâ€ù in the next question. \  \ 4. How have the authors addressed that fact that the evaluation is shallow and lacks quantitative detail? \ We have modified the evaluation to first, discuss the qualitative results. We see these as the main contribution, as they help drive our future work and allow us to know that we are on the right track. We have broken out the accuracy chart by sample size to illustrate how accuracy changes with sample size. We could do the same with confidence, but have not in this draft. We have justified the use of the Kruskal-Wallis test (beginning of â€œQuantitative Resultsâ€ù section), and generally of using non-parametric tests.  \ We would be happy to discuss additional quantitative detail that would better illustrate our results. \ The 2AC also writes, " My concern is if the evaluation as carried out can be trusted, and we can take confidence in the modest claims that the authors make in the paper. " We sympathize with the ACâ€™s concern: in a small study like this, it is difficult to make quantitative claims. By emphasizing the qualitative results we sawâ€”both good and badâ€”we feel that we better illustrate the bounds of what we learned from the study.  \  \ 5. Clearly detail how you have addressed the typographical and presentational concerns of the reviewers. \ Weâ€™ve fixed numerous typos, including those pointed out by the reviewers. In particular: \ -	Reviewer 1: \ o	â€œ[The study] has many typographic errors and is less clear than the rest of the paper.â€ù Fixed. \ -	Reviewer 2 has four specific text changes; fixed. \ -	Reviewer 3: \ o	Asks clarification for Table 1: we changed the format of the table to make it more easily understandable and also made the link to text made clearer.  \ o	Figure 8: ordering of confidence will be repaired.  \ o	â€œIn theory, the sample size should not matter.â€ù The sample size WAS shown to users, in the top-right of the instrument; we have clarified the caption on Figure 5 and in the text to explain that. In particular, we also made comments about the effect of showing it to users in our qualitative results. \ o	Assorted textual notes: fixed. \ -	Shepherd: Figure 7 added to represent multiple difficulty levels. Simplified and shrunk to show percentages rather than line counts. \ -	Changed language throughout for consistency: we always speak of a â€œRankedâ€ù list (and never a Top-K); we speak of "annotations" instead of "enhancements". \

Title: Emerging Sites of HCI Innovation: Hackerspaces, Hardware Startups & Incubators
Author list: Silvia Lindtner, Garnet Hertz, Paul Dourish
Abstract: In this paper, we discuss how a flourishing scene of DIY makers is turning visions of tangible and ubiquitous computing into products. Drawing on long-term multi-sited ethnographic research and active participation in DIY making, we provide insights into the social, material, and economic processes that undergird this transition from prototypes to products. The contribution of this paper is three-fold. First, we show how DIY maker practice is illustrative of a broader â€œreturn toâ€ù and interest in physical materials. This has implications for HCI research that investigates questions of materiality. Second, we shed light on how hackerspaces and hardware start-ups are experimenting with new models of manufacturing and entrepreneurship. We argue that we have to take seriously these maker practices, not just as hobbyist or leisure practice, but as a professionalizing field functioning in parallel to research and industry labs. Finally, we end with reflections on the role of HCI researchers and designers as DIY making emerges as a site of HCI innovation. We argue that HCI is positioned to provide critical reflection, paired with a sensibility for materials, tools and design methods.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This paper contributes to HCI's understanding of making cultures by providing in-depth insights from long-term ethnographic research and participation in DIY making and its intersections with entrepreneurialism and start-up culture.
Summary of Changes: We have added clarity to the definitions of our key terms: \ We have worked through the whole paper and filled in the gaps where key terms such as making and open hardware were not yet defined. We have also moved definitions of hackerspaces, making, and arduino, etc. more up front in the paper. We have added a definition of what we mean by open hardware, referencing http://www.oshwa.org/definition/: â€œtangible artifacts â€” machines, devices, or other physical things â€” whose design has been released to the public in such a way that anyone can make, modify, distribute, and use those things.â€ù  \  \ We have updated the methods section: \ We have added more details about our fieldsites and how we gathered data at each. This includes details about  participant observation, number of interviews, and processes of data gathering as a whole. \  \ We have also made granular changes to the discussion, reflecting our reviewers' recommendations to elaborate how DIY making practices are diverse and range across different genres and disciplines. We have also edited and renamed the section "amateur expertise" (to "beyond amateur expertise") to make more clear to the reader how DIY making is already functioning as a site of research and development. \  \ Finally, we weaved through the whole paper to make more clear what the take-aways for HCI can be. In the introduction and discussion sections, in particular, we added sentences that draw out more specifically what HCI's role can be in making culture, e.g. collaboration and partnerships with hackerspaces and start-ups to develop new curricula and programs.

Title: Understanding Digital and Material Social Communications for Older Adults
Author list: Alexis Hope, Ted Schwaba, Anne Marie Piper
Abstract: Online technologies are promising for helping older adults maintain social connectedness, particularly with younger people, yet many older adults resist or participate minimally in the mainstream technologies used by younger members of their social network. We present results from an interview study involving 22 older adults (age 71-92) to understand communication preferences and values related to social media. Seniors articulate many concerns with online social media, including the time required for legitimate participation, the loss of deeper communication, content irrelevance, and privacy. Additionally, older adults engage in social practices that could be supported by online social technologies, but they rarely use such tools. The theme of material social communications emerges from our data, and we examine this in context of online social media. We conclude with design considerations for the development of social media for older adults, and as part of this we describe the notion of bridging technologies as a framework for intergenerational communication design.

Title: Imperceptible Depth Shifts for Touch Interaction with Stereoscopic Objects
Author list: Dimitar Valkov, Alexander Giesler, Klaus Hinrichs
Abstract: While touch technology has proven its usability for 2D interaction and has already become a standard input modality for many devices, the challenges to exploit its applicability with stereoscopically rendered content have barely been studied. \ In this paper we exploit the properties of the visual perception to allow users to touch stereoscopically displayed objects when the input is constrained to a 2D surface. \ Therefore, we have extended and generalized recent evaluations on the user's ability to discriminate small induced object shifts while reaching out to touch a virtual object, and we propose a practical interaction technique, the attracting shift technique, suitable for numerous application scenarios where shallow depth interaction is sufficient. \ In addition, our results indicate that slight object shifts during touch interaction make the virtual scene appear perceptually more stable compared to a static scene.  \ As a consequence, applications have to manipulate the virtual objects to make them appear static for the user.

Title: Using Asymmetric Cores to Reduce Power Consumption for Interactive Devices with Bi-stable Displays
Author list: Jaeyeon Kihm, FranÃ§ois GuimbretiÃ¨re, Julia Karl, Rajit Manohar
Abstract: Low power â€œhelperâ€ù cores have been increasingly included on application processors to accomplish low intensity tasks such as music playing and motion sensing with minimum energy consumption. Recently, GuimbretiÃ¨re et al. [1] demonstrated that such helper cores can also be used to execute simple user interface tasks. We revisit this approach by implementing a similar system on an off-the-shelf application processor (TI OMAP4). Our study shows that in the case of high event rate interactions (pen inking and virtual keyboard), significant battery life gains (Ã—1.7 and Ã—2.3 respectively) can be achieved with the helper core executing the interface. Having the helper core only dis-patch input events incurs a 18% penalty relative to the maximum savings rate, but allows for simplified deployment since it merely requires a change in toolkit infrastructure.

Title: Faster Command Selection on Tablets with FastTap
Author list: Carl Gutwin, Andy Cockburn, Joey Scarr, Sylvain Malacria, Scott C Olson
Abstract: Touch-based tablet UIs provide few shortcut mechanisms for rapid command selection; as a result, command selection on tablets often requires slow traversal of menus. We developed a new selection technique for multi-touch tablets, called FastTap, that uses thumb-and-finger touches to show and choose from a spatially-stable grid-based overlay interface. FastTap allows novices to view and inspect the full interface, but once item locations are known, FastTap allows people to select commands with a single quick thumb-and-finger tap. The interface helps users develop expertise, since the motor actions carried out as a novice rehearse the expert behavior. A controlled study showed that FastTap was significantly faster (by 33% per selection overall) than marking menus, both for novices and experts, and without reduction in accuracy or subjective preference. Our work introduces a new and efficient selection mechanism that supports rapid command execution on touch tablets, for both novices and experts.

Thumbnail Image Caption: Introduces FastTap, a rapid-access multi-touch command selection technique that supports the transition to expertise. Demonstrates that FastTap provide faster interaction than marking menus, and examines their usability in real tasks.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Introduces FastTap, a rapid-access multi-touch command selection technique that supports the transition to expertise. Demonstrates that FastTap provide faster interaction than marking menus, and examines their usability in real tasks.
Summary of Changes: We have substantially revised the paper to address all of the concerns raised by the committee, and to add the material indicated in the author rebuttal. In particular: \ - we have added extensive text to cover and discuss additional related work and to set our contribution into the context of other systems. The suggested references have been added (Wu and Balakrishnan \ 2003, Kin et al. 2011, Wagner 2012), and all of these works play a role in the related work section and the discussion. We have also increased the detail given to the CommandMap technique which forms the basis for the FastTap method. \ - we have added substantially to the study section to clarify our study design and the implementation of the experimental conditions. We have added text to explain our design choices in the implementation of the Marking Menu (particularly the use of the two-level hierarchy and the use of the invocation button), and have clarified our procedure and analysis for the experiment. \ - we have added text to acknowledge that our experiment is a limited and initial examination of the ideas behind FastTap, and we have toned down our claims throughout the paper (text has been changed in the Introduction, the Study section, the Discussion, and the Conclusion).  \ - we have added a new section to the Discussion to address the issue of scalability of FastTap versus menu-based approaches. We consider the likely performance of FastTap and Marking Menus as command sets increase in size, and we acknowledge that our experiment was carried out with a relatively small command set. \ - we have revised several locations of the paper to avoid the confusion about "expert and novice modes" (since there are only modes of behaviour with the interface, not modes in the interface itself.  \ - we have done a full editing revision to address and improve on a number of additional issues mentioned in the reviews, and to carry out edits that improve clarity and reduce repetition. \

Title: Reading Critical Designs:  Supporting Reasoned Interpretations of Critical Design
Author list: Jeffrey Bardzell, Shaowen Bardzell, Erik Stolterman
Abstract: Critical Design has emerged as an important concept in HCI research and practice. Yet researchers have noted that its uptake has been limited by certain lacks of intellectual infrastructureâ€”theories, methodologies, canons and exemplars, and a community of practice. We argue that one way to create this infrastructure is to cultivate a community adept at readingâ€”that is, critically interpreting and making reasoned judgments aboutâ€”critical designs. We propose an approach to developing close readings of critical designs, which are both evidence-based and carefully reasoned. The approach highlights analytical units of analysis, the relevance of design languages and social norms, and the analytical contemplation of critical aspects of a design. It is intended to be relatively easy to learn, to try out, and to teach, in the hopes of inviting more members of the HCI community to engage in this practice. We exemplify the approach with readings of two critical designs and reflect on different ways that a design might serve a critical purpose or offer a critical argument about design, society, and the future. \
