Author Keywords: Critical design; criticism; design theory; interpretation; art
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We offer an approach to support the teaching and learning of how to "read" (i.e., critically interpret and make judgments about) critical designs.
Summary of Changes: Lots of changes based on the reviews.  \  \ 1. Reworked the whole paper to make it clearer that its primary audience are competent designers and design researchers who lack a certain literacy understanding critical designs \  \ 2. Reworked the introduction in particular, as follows: \ -- Shortened the general problematization of CD in HCI and refocused it more explicitly around the problem of a lack of a community of practice (in HCI) for CD, a lack of curated lists of exemplars, categorizations, norms, etc.  \ -- Argued that all of the above would be improved if more in the community were able to critically read, interpret, and make defensible judgments about critical designs. \ -- Situated our contribution as follows: we offer a critical interpretive approach to support more people in HCI learning how to do this (and also teaching others how to do it) \ -- Introduced a critical design (Amisha Gadani's "Porcupine Dress" from her "Defensive Dresses" collection) and sketched out several different kinds of readings (e.g., as art, as a fashion item, as design proposal/argument) to demonstrate how different hermeneutic communities of practice can and will diversely read a design like this, ultimately to motivate the question: "What sorts of categorizations, associations, questions, insights, norms, judgments, etc., should be part of a critical designerâ€™s hermeneutic toolkit?" \ -- Drastically shortened the earlier section on "epistemological underpinnings" and so forth (per the reviewers), making room for much of the above \  \ 3. The middle section had only minimal revisions \ -- The section where we present the framework had fewer concerns from the reviewers and accordingly we revised it more lightly \ -- One criticism was that we said that a critical design was first some other kind of design (e.g., blood bag radio is a radio, drift table is a table), and a reviewer objected that that was too narrow. We clarified this in two ways: (1) we emphasized that a critical design is constructed out of one or more everyday designs (i.e., not just one); and (2) we emphasized that critical design is constructed out of one more everyday design languages (in other words, rather than saying that blood bag radio is a radio, we said that blood bag radio is partly constructed out of the design language of radios). We believe this is more precise than the earlier formulation and also avoids the over-simplified understanding that one of the reviewers inferred from the way we had written it earlier. \  \ 4. The discussion had some more significant revisions \ -- The Wii example was removed altogether \ -- The "really critical designs" section was removed altogether \ -- This left the reading of Blood Bag Radio as the Discussion, which we thought was good since it seemed to be everyone's favorite part of the paper. \ -- Accordingly we expanded our reading of Blood Bag Radio \ -- And we fleshed out the section at the very end contrasting Blood Bag Radio with Drift Table as a way of showing that designs can successfully critical in different ways. To that we added Porcupine Dress (as a way to help tie up the paper), and we also offered a list of some very different ways that a critical design can offer a critical design argument.  \  \ 5 Throughout the paper: \ -- We changed the term "assessment" to "reading," "critical interpretation," "making judgments" or left it alone as "assessment" to more precisely reflect the practice we were referring to \ -- Sought to unify the paper by ensuring that the discussion reflected the problems set forth in the introduction and that the approach presented in the middle really did in fact serve the purpose we said it would \ -- Added images (and secured permissions to do so) of two designs, to facilitate understanding (Blood Bag Radio by Dunne and Raby and Porcupine Dress by Amisha Gadani) \  \ As a result of all of this, we think that the paper is structurally much simpler, offers a far more straightforward argument than the submitted version, and does a much better job of talking about critical designs, rather than talking about talking about critical designs. We thank the ACs and the committee for taking a chance on this. Between the decision and this submission, we also consulted with a design expert in the field to help ensure that our revision strategy really addressed the issues and didn't merely band-aid over them. We feel much better about this version of the paper and hope that we have done justice to the reviews and guidance that we received.

Title: Interaction on the Edge: Offset Sensing for Small Devices
Author list: Ian Oakley, DoYoung Lee
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Design and Human Engineering
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology
Abstract: The touch screen interaction paradigm, currently dominant in mobile devices, begins to fail when very small systems are considered. Specifically, "fat fingers", a term referring to the fact that users' extremities physically obstruct their view of screen content and feedback, become particularly problematic. This paper presents a novel solution for this issue based on sensing touches to the perpendicular edges of a device featuring a front-mounted screen. The use of such offset contact points ensures that both a userâ€™s fingers and the device screen remain clearly in view throughout a targeting operation. The configuration also supports a range of novel interaction scenarios based on the touch, grip and grasp patterns it affords. To explore the viability of this concept, this paper describes EdgeTouch, a small (6 cm) hardware prototype instantiating this multi-touch functionality. User studies characterizing targeting performance, typical user grasps and exploring input affordances are presented. The results show that targets of 7.5-22.5 degrees in angular size are acquired in 1.25-1.75 seconds and with accuracy rates of 3%-18%, promising results considering the small form factor of the device. Furthermore, grasps made with between two and five fingers are robustly identifiable. Finally, we characterize the types of input users envisage performing with EdgeTouch, and report occurrence rates for key interactions such as taps, holds, strokes and multi-touch and compound input. The paper concludes with a discussion of the interaction scenarios enabled by offset sensing.

Title: Estimating County Health Statistics with Twitter
Author list: Aron Culotta
Abstract: Understanding the relationships among environment, behavior, and health is a \ core concern of public health researchers. While a number of recent studies \ have investigated the use of social media to track infectious diseases such as \ influenza, little work has been done to determine if other health concerns can \ be inferred. In this paper, we present a large-scale study of 27 \ health-related statistics, including obesity, health insurance coverage, \ access to healthy foods, and teen birth rates. We perform a linguistic \ analysis of the Twitter activity in the top 100 most populous counties in the \ U.S., and find a significant correlation with 6 of the 27 health \ statistics. When compared to traditional models based on demographic variables \ alone, we find that augmenting models with Twitter-derived information \ improves predictive accuracy for 20 of 27 statistics, suggesting that this new \ methodology can complement existing approaches.

Title: Upvoting Hurricane Sandy: Event-Based News Production Processes on a Social News Site
Author list: Alex Leavitt, Joshua Clark
Abstract: This paper uses the case of Hurricane Sandy and redditâ€™s topical community (subreddit) /r/sandy to examine the production and curation of news content around events on a social news site. Through qualitative analysis, we provide a coded topology of produced content and describe how types of networked gatekeeping impact the framing of a crisis situation. This study also examines, through quantitative modeling, what kind of information becomes negotiated and voted as relevant. We suggest that highly scored content shared in a social news setting focused more on human-interest media and perspective-based citizen journalism than professional news reports. We conclude by discussing how the mechanisms of social news sites conflict with the social norms and culture of reddit to produce differing expectations around news.

Title: Highlighting Interventions and User Differences: Informing Adaptive Information Visualization Support
Author list: Giuseppe Carenini, Cristina Conati, Enamul Hoque, Ben Steichen, Dereck J Toker, James T Enns
Author emails: carenini@cs.ubc.ca, conati@cs.ubc.ca, enamul@cs.ubc.ca, steichen@cs.ubc.ca, dtoker@cs.ubc.ca, jenns@psych.ubc.ca
Abstract: There is increasing evidence that the effectiveness of information visualization techniques can be impacted by the particular needs and abilities of each user. This suggests that it is important to investigate information visualization systems that can dynamically adapt to each user. In this paper, we address the question of how to adapt. In particular, we present a study to evaluate a variety of visual prompts, called â€˜interventionsâ€™, that can be performed on a visualization to help users process it.  Our results show that some of the tested interventions perform better than a condition in which no intervention is provided, both in terms of task performance as well as subjective user ratings. We also discuss findings on how intervention effectiveness is influenced by individual differences and task complexity.

Title: Investigating the Feasibility of Extracting Tool Demonstrations from In-Situ Video Content
Author list: Ben Lafreniere, Tovi Grossman, Justin Matejka, George Fitzmaurice
Abstract: Short video demonstrations are effective resources for helping users to learn tools in feature-rich software. However manually creating demonstrations for the hundreds (or thousands) of individual features in these programs would be impractical. In this paper, we investigate the potential for identifying good tool demonstrations from within screen recordings of users performing real-world tasks. Using an instrumented image-editing application, we collected workflow video content and log data from actual end users. We then developed a heuristic for identifying demonstration clips, and had the quality of a sample set of clips evaluated by both domain experts and end users. This multi-step approach allowed us to characterize the quality of â€œnaturally occurringâ€ù tool demonstrations, and to derive a list of good and bad features of these videos. Finally, we conducted an initial investigation into using machine learning techniques to distinguish between good and bad demonstrations.

Title: Share your View: Impact of Co-Navigation Support and Status Composition in Collaborative Online Shopping
Author list: Yanzhen Yue, Xiaojuan Ma, Zhenhui Jiang
Abstract: Collaborative online shopping, an emerging paradigm in e-commerce, allows remote shoppers to extend purchase-oriented social interactions into the digital environment. Online vendors have been experimenting ways to facilitate this activity. However, more research needs to be done on identifying what feature can create a pleasing shopping experience and ultimately encourage spending. In this paper, we present an exploration of the impact of co-navigation supports, including location cue, split screen, and shared view, on the experiences and performance of 60 co-shopper dyads. We also studied if status composition of shopping companions played a role in this process. By analyzing about 1800 minutes of eye-tracking data, video footages, and web logs, we found that split screen encouraged more diverse product search, shared view enabled better coordination, and location cue was the least distracting. Co-buyers achieved better factual and inference understanding, though buyer-advisor dyads were more likely to stay together.

Author Keywords: Collaborative Online Shopping; co-navigation; location cue; split screen; shared view; status composition; co-buyers; buyer-advisor; eye-tracking
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This paper presents an eye-tracking-based exploration of the impact of co-navigation supports, including location cue, split screen, and shared view, on the experiences and performance of collaborative online shoppers.
Summary of Changes: We thank all the reviewers for their helpful comments. We have addressed the comments in the paper as follows. \  \ 1. Address the difference between co-buyer and buyer-advisor and its link to the hypotheses (R2) \ We have revised the paper accordingly to address this comment (Page 3).  \ We would argue that people with different status in a co-shopping group would have different decision responsibilities and commitment. In a co-buyer dyad, both individuals have equal decision responsibility. Whereas in a buyer/advisor dyad, only the buyer makes decisions, and the advisor merely provides suggestions for the buyerâ€™s consideration. In a word, co-buyer and buyer/advisor dyads have different status composition, and thus differ in information contribution, knowledge influence, and responsibility distribution. This further leads to different requirements of coordination and consensus. In a status-heterogeneous group (buyer/advisor), information contribution and knowledge influence are not equal. While for group with equal status (co-buyers), both parties share the responsibility to establish the knowledge base for further information provision and discussion. This may result in discrepancy between the levels of mutual understanding achieved by members of different status. Thus, we proposed H4 from the perspective of status composition heterogeneity. \  \ 2. Incorporate more recent work on awareness systems (R2) \ We have revised the paper and added more relevant references accordingly (Page 3).  \ For example, we incorporated the suggested papers (Morris et al. 2008 on SearchTogether, Paul and Morris 2009 on CoSense, etc.) as well as other recent work, such as, co-browsing dynamic web pages (Lowet and Goergen, 2009) and visualizations influence on synchronous remote collaboration (Balakrishnan et al. 2008) among others. \  \ 3. Define â€œdistractionâ€ù and â€œdistraction by actionâ€ù (R2) \ We have revised the paper to make more elaboration on this point (Page 4).  \ We would argue that distraction refers to the divided attention caused by tasks unrelated to the subjectâ€™s primary goal (Baron 1986). In general, distraction can be caused by many types of external stimuli. In this paper, different co-navigation systems involve different levels of visual awareness. Although visual awareness can help establish visual common ground, it also leads to different levels of distraction if forced visual exposures of oneâ€™s partnersâ€™ actions interfere with oneâ€™s own information processing. As a result, group members may often step into one anotherâ€™s way, driving shopping partnersâ€™ attention away from tasks related to their primary goal (e.g. information processing), distractions and even interruptions may occur. Hence, we focused on distraction by action, which is defined as the distraction caused by shopping partnersâ€™ actions, such as scrolling, cursor movement, page switch, etc.  \ To measure how well co-shoppers can concentrate on their own task at hand in a given co-navigation mode, we counted the number of â€œdistraction by actionâ€ù by analyzing the eye-tracking data. \  \ 4. The affordances of different technologies and how they relate (R1) \ We have made more elaboration to explain each of the technologies and how they relate to each other (Page 2).  \ We argue that these tools adopt different mechanisms to support collaborative navigation. Location cue allows users to navigate separately in their own browsers with a small clickable visual location indicator, providing high autonomy in browsing but low synchronicity in awareness of each otherâ€™s actions; whereas shared view keeps collaborators on the same page all the time but sacrifices the ability to act on their own, leading to high synchronicity but low autonomy. Split screen is somewhat in the middle along both dimensions. It provides a personal screen and a reference screen to monitor the partnersâ€™ behaviors, which leads to higher synchronicity than location cue but lower synchronicity and higher autonomy than shared view. \  \ 5. The combination of hypotheses on products viewed, time on site and search scope (R1) \ We have revised the paper to clarify this point (Page 3). Specifically, time on site and number of products viewed are leading metrics widely applied by both researchers and practitioners for e-commerce sales. We combined products viewed, time on site and search scope into one hypothesis, as they are related to each other, and as a whole could imply a general view of how consumers interact with the website itself in co-shopping. \  \ 6. Explain the last two paragraphs of â€œSplit Screen Encourages More Separate Product Searchâ€ù (R3) \ We have revised the paper accordingly to clarify the last two paragraphs (Page 7).  \ These two paragraphs aimed to explain the different findings concerning subjective measurements and objective measurements. The objective results showed that split screen led to a bigger search scope than location cue, while the subjective results indicated no significant difference between the two.  \ We have revised and elaborated as follows: the actual search scope with location cue, compared to that with split screen, was constrained by the decreased readiness to exchange individual search results. However, the subjective results show no difference between these two conditions. It suggests that co-shoppers appreciated the search autonomy provided by location cue and split screen, and thus â€œperceivedâ€ù that both methods enabled wider search. In other words, the effect of â€œillusion of controlâ€ù may make users overestimate their search performance.  \  \ 7. Clarify hotel selection (R1), give a summary of results (R3) and improve figures (R1, R3) \ We have clarified how the hotels were selected (Page 5), provided a summary of the results at the end (Page 9) and improved the figures to make them clearer. \ Specifically, for hotel selection, the hotels used in the study are real hotels extracted from an existing hotel booking website (i.e. tripadvisor.com). We have also provided a summary of results (as shown in Table 1) in the revision. \  \

Title: Understanding Physical Activity through 3D Printed Material Artifacts
Author list: Rohit Ashok Khot, Larissa Hjorth, Florian 'Floyd' Mueller
Abstract: In this paper, we advocate a novel approach of representing physical activity in the form of material artifacts. By designing such material representations, we aim to understand what these artifacts might offer in terms of reflecting upon physical activity. For example, what types of affect do material artifacts, representing onesâ€™ physical activity create for the user? In order to advance this understanding, we designed a system called SweatAtoms that transforms the physical activity data based on heart rate into 3D printed material artifacts. We conducted an â€œin the wild studyâ€ù by deploying our system in six households where participants were experiencing five different material representations of their physical activity for a period of two weeks each. We found that the material artifacts made participants more conscious about their involvement in physical activity and illustrated different levels of engagement with the artifacts. Along with reporting the gained insights from the deployments, we offer reflections on designing material representations for physical activity. We hope that our work will inspire designers to consider new possibilities afforded by digital fabrication to support userâ€™s experience with physical activity by utilizing interactive technologies at our disposal.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: The paper contributes first conceptual understanding of the relationship between material representations and physical activity. \ Our work will inspire designers to consider new possibilities afforded by digital fabrication to support userâ€™s experience with physical activity.
Summary of Changes: We would like to gratefully thank the reviewers for their detailed feedback, which we have taken to heart in order to improve the paper. Below we have listed the changes made, categorized by section and generally listed by occurrence in the paper. We have tried to address the reviewersâ€™ concerns to the best of our abilities and provided additional details where data and page limit allowed us to do. Instead we stressed more on sensing technology and digital fabrication in the introduction.  It required shifting of paragraphs and addition of supporting lines.  \ R4 also suggested us to tone down the design goal, which we did by adding the following line to the end of introduction: â€œAlthough invoking behavioral change was of general interest to us, we focused primarily on eliciting richer reflections on physical activity and understanding the impact material artifacts, representing oneâ€™s physical activity, can have for a user.â€ù We also adjusted the lines: "as a result, design and hci researchers are no considering the role of materiality" and "this argument is well supported" as suggested by R4. \  \ Related work \ R2 wanted an elaboration on the connection between digital fabrication and physical activity, so we added a subsection â€œrethinking visualization of physical activityâ€ù at the end of related work section, explaining the connection between the two, which motivated this work. \  \ SweatAtoms: Proposed system \ R1 needed more details on the design process, so we revamped the design process to reflect hypothesis behind the choices. Title: Unraveling Abstinence and Relapse: Smoking Cessation Reflected in Social Media
Author list: Elizabeth L. Murnane, Scott Counts
Abstract: Analysis of smokers' posts and behaviors on Twitter reveals factors impacting abstinence and relapse during cessation attempts. Combining automatic and crowdsourced techniques, we detect users trying to quit smoking and analyze tweet and network data from a sample of 653 individuals over a two-year window of quitting. Guided by theory and practice, we derive behavioral, social, and emotional measures to compare users who abstain and relapse. We also examine the cessation process, demonstrating that Twitter can help chronicle how some people go about quitting. Among other results, we show that those who fail in their smoking cessation are far heavier posters and use relatively less positive language, while those who succeed are more social in both network ties and in directed communication. We conclude with insights on how intelligent intervention systems can harness these signals to provide tailored behavior change support.

Author Keywords: Smoking; cessation; health; behavior; social media; Twitter
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We study the behavior-change process of smoking-cessation by leveraging longitudinal data from Twitter. Finding behavioral, social, and emotional differences between abstinence vs. relapse, we provide implications for designing technology-based interventions.
Summary of Changes: We elaborate on the Transtheoretical Model of Behavior Change, give additional information about our sample, and improve captions/keys for figures. We also remove any over-generalizations and excessive qualifiers, and we provide an expanded Technological Interventions section as well as a more detailed Conclusion in order to highlight our research's relevance to CHI and better explain its contributions.

Title: Presstures: Exploring Pressure-Sensitive Multi-Touch Gestures on Trackpads
Author list: Christian Rendl, Patrick Greindl, Kathrin Probst, Martin Behrens, Michael Haller
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
Abstract: In this paper, we present Presstures, an extension to current multi-touch operations that enriches common multi-finger gestures with pressure information. By using the initially applied pressure level for implicit mode switching, a gesture can be enhanced with different functionalities to enlarge the interaction space for multi-touch. To evaluate the feasibility of our concept, we conducted an experiment, which indicates good human sensorimotor skills for performing multi-touch gestures with a few number of pressure levels and without any additional feedback. Based on the experimental results, we discuss implications for the design of pressure-sensitive multi-touch gestures, and propose application scenarios that make optimal use of our concept.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Presstures enrich current multi-touch gestures with pressure information. Gestures can be overloaded with different functionalities by applying different initial pressure levels.
Summary of Changes: 1.	INTRODUCTION \  \ â€¢	We will re-write the introduction to clearly point out the contribution of our paper, which consists in: \ - (1) studying the human sensorimotor feasibilities to control a given number of pressure levels (i.e., light-strong resp. light-medium-strong) for three commonly used multi-touch gestures (i.e., pinch, scroll, stretch) without visual feedback \ - (2) referring implications from the study results (i.e., individual perception of pressure, good feasibility for two pressure levels, limited feasibility for three pressure levels) \ - (3) and proposing exemplary interaction concepts from the study results (i.e., content scrolling vs. window snapping, text indentation vs. text enumeration) \ â€¢	In particular, we will clarify that our feasibility study was deliberately performed without any feedback (on pressure intensity) or hints (whether the applied pressure was correctly recognized).  Referring to existing research in the field, we will point out that our goal was to explore the limits of pressure input without VF, in order to isolate the effect of using pressure as mode switching technique. \ â€¢	Furthermore, we will point out that our concept should be seen as alternative to other existing mode-switching techniques (like in Y. Li et al. 2005). Nevertheless, we believe that it might be easier to memorize common gestures overloaded with different pressure levels, as they are more similar to the original gestures (e.g. Pinching) compared to completely new gestures. Especially if the meaning of gestures is extended in a comprehensible way. \ â€¢	Along with these changes, we will add and discuss the following references: \ - GÃ¡bor BlaskÃ_, Steven Feiner, â€œSingle-Handed Interaction Techniques for Multiple Pressure-Sensitive Stripsâ€ù, CHI'04 (=> similar approach, but no study on user capabilities) \ - Y Li, K Hinckley, Z Guan, JA Landay, â€œExperimental analysis of mode switching techniques in pen-based user interfacesâ€ù, CHI'05 (=> alternative mode-switching techniques) \ - Wilson, G. A. (2013). â€œUsing pressure input and thermal feedback to broaden haptic interaction with mobile devicesâ€ù, Doctoral dissertation, University of Glasgow (=> extensive overview about human pressure sensing capabilities & pressure research in general). \ - Shi, K., Irani, P., Gustafson, S., & Subramanian, S. (2008). â€œPressureFish: a method to improve control of discrete pressure-based inputâ€ù (=> non-linear pressure thresholds). \ â€¢	The Abstract of the paper will be revised accordingly. \  \ 2.	CONCEPT \ We state more clearly that ForceDrag by Heo & Lee was an important basis for our work and that it is an extension of their single finger concept to multi-touch gestures. In contrast to their work, with our concept no explicit selection of the pressure level is needed. \  \ 3.	USER STUDY \ To provide a more clear overview of the feasibility study, we will re-structure the study chapter into three sections: \ - (1) Common study features (i.e., setup, hardware,â€_) \ - (2) Experiment 1: study design, results \ - (3) Experiment 2: study design, results \ Moreover, we will only present the study design & results in these sections, and discuss implications of the results within a newly created â€œDiscussionâ€ù section. \  \ â€ƒ \ 4.	DISCUSSION & LIMITATIONS \  \ â€¢	This new section will replace the â€œDesign recommendationsâ€ù section. \ â€¢	In that section we want to discuss the limitations and implications of our results more extensively and honest. \ â€¢	We will state clearly that accuracy for two pressure levels are OK, while three pressure levels are not suitable, as executing â€œmediumâ€ù pressure was problematic for most study participants. This could be due do different factors: On the one side that itâ€™s simply not possible with human sensorimotor skills or that currently available hardware cannot measure it exactly enough. \ â€¢	That we expect serious learning effects, like stated in [7]. Also playing the piano shows human capabilities to learn to apply different levels of pressure accurately. \ â€¢	That we observed relative dependencies between the trials, so if e.g. the user had three times the â€œHigh Pressureâ€ù condition, a â€œLow Pressureâ€ù condition was moderately higher as it initially was. \ â€¢	That our threshold algorithm might not be optimal: We took the averages from the training phase, but it might make sense to choose non-linear thresholds (like proposed in PressureFish). \  \ 5.	APPLICATIONS \  \ â€¢	Weâ€™ll state that three pressure levels without feedback is not suitable. Two possibilities: Either adding a feedback modality, which would give our concept of course much better accuracy rates, or designing interactions where two pressure levels are enough and make perfectly sense. \ â€¢	The application part itself will be shortened heavily by cutting down the explanations since figures, captions and descriptions are somehow redundant at the moment. \  \ 6.	CONCLUSION \  \ â€¢	Analogous to the introduction and discussion chapters, the conclusion will be revised. \  \ 7.	FUTURE WORK \ We will point out some interesting points to be covered in future work, which include:  \ â€¢	 investigating whether individual differences in pressure can be addressed in practical usage (referring to the per-user calibration limitation of the study) \ â€¢	conducting a similar feasibility study with different hardware (referring to possible hardware limitations) or a larger number of participants (referring to highly variable error rates) \

Title: Predictors of Life Satisfaction based on Daily Activities from Mobile Sensor Data
Author list: Onur YÃ_rÃ_ten, Jiyong Zhang, Pearl Pu
Abstract: In recent years much research work has been dedicated to detecting user activity patterns \ from sensor data such as location, movement and proximity. However, how daily activities are \ correlated to people's happiness (such as their satisfaction from work \ and social lives) is not well explored. In this work, we propose an approach to investigate the relationship between users' daily activity patterns and their life satisfaction level. \ From a well-known longitudinal dataset collected by \ mobile devices, we extract various activity features through location \ and proximity information, and compute the entropies of these data to \ capture the regularities of the behavioral patterns of the \ participants. We then perform component analysis and structural \ equation modeling to identify key behavior contributors to \ self-reported satisfaction scores. Our results show that our \ analytical procedure can identify meaningful assumptions of causality between activities and satisfaction.  \ Particularly, keeping regularity in daily activities can significantly improve the life satisfaction.

Title: 28 Frames Later: Predicting Screen Touches From Back-of-Device Grip Changes
Author list: Mohammad Faizuddin Mohd Noor, Andrew Ramsay, Stephen Hughes, Simon Rogers, John Williamson, Roderick Murray-Smith
Author emails: m.bin-md-noor.1@research.gla.ac.uk, andrew.ramsay@glasgow.ac.uk, stephenahughes@gmail.com, Simon.Rogers@Glasgow.ac.uk, JohnH.Williamson@glasgow.ac.uk, Roderick.Murray-Smith@glasgow.ac.uk
Abstract: We demonstrate that front-of-screen targeting on mobile phones can be predicted from back-of-device grip manipulations. Using simple, low-resolution capacitive touch sensors placed around a standard phone, we outline a machine learning approach to modelling the grip modulation and inferring front-of-screen touch targets. We experimentally demonstrate that grip is a remarkably good predictor of touch, and we can predict touch position 200ms before contact with an accuracy of 18mm.

Title: Choice Overload in Search Engine Use?
Author list: Pawitra Chiravirakul, Stephen J Payne
Abstract: Search engines typically return so many results that choosing from the list might be predicted to suffer from the effects of â€œchoice overloadâ€ù.  Preliminary work has reported just such an effect [12]. In this paper a series of three experiments was conducted to investigate the choice overload effect in search engine use. Participants were given search tasks and presented with either six or twenty-four returns to choose from. The results revealed that the choice behaviour was strongly influenced by the ranking of returns, and that choice satisfaction was affected by the number of options and the decision time. The main results, from the third experiment, showed that large sets of options yielded a positive effect on participantsâ€™ satisfaction when they made a decision without time limit. When time was more strongly constrained, choices from small sets led to relatively higher satisfaction. Our studies show how user satisfaction with found information can be affected by processing strategies that are influenced by search engine design features.

Title: Sticker Circuits: A New Technique for Constructing Prototype Physical Interfaces
Author list: Steve Hodges, Nicolas Villar, Nicholas Chen, Tushar Chugh, Jie Qi, Diana Nowacka, Yoshihiro Kawahara
Author emails: shodges@microsoft.com, nvillar@microsoft.com, nchen@microsoft.com, tchugh@microsoft.com, jieqi@mit.edu, d.nowacka@ncl.ac.uk, kawahara@akg.t.u-tokyo.ac.jp
Abstract: We present a novel approach to the construction of electronic prototypes which can support a variety of interactive devices. Our technique, which we call circuit stickers, involves adhering physical interface elements such as LEDs, sounders, buttons and sensors onto a cheap and easy-to-make substrate which provides electrical connectivity. This assembly may include control electronics and a battery for standalone operation, or it can be interfaced to a microcontroller or PC. In this paper we illustrate different points in the design space and demonstrate the technical feasibility of our approach. We have found circuit stickers to be versatile and low-cost, supporting quick and easy construction of physically flexible interactive prototypes. Building extra copies of a device is straightforward. We believe this technology has potential for design exploration, research proto-typing, education and for hobbyist projects.

Title: Understanding Finger Input Above Desktop Devices
Author list: Chat Wacharamanotham, Kashyap Todi, Marty Pye, Jan Borchers
Abstract: Using the space above desktop input devices adds a rich new input channel to desktop interaction. Input in this elevated layer has been previously used to modify the granularity of a 2D slider, navigate layers of a 3D body scan above a multitouch table and access vertically stacked menus. \ However, designing these interactions is challenging because the lack of haptic and direct visual feedback easily leads to input errors. For bare finger input, the user's fingers needs to reliably enter and stay inside the interactive layer, and engagement techniques such as midair clicking have to be disambiguated from leaving the layer. These issues have been addressed for interactions in which users operate other devices in midair, but there is little guidance for the design of bare finger input in this space. \  \ In this paper, we present the results of two user studies that inform the design of finger input above desktop devices. Our studies show that 2 cm is the minimum thickness of the above-surface volume that users can reliably remain within. We found that when accessing midair layers, users do not automatically move to the same height. To address this, we introduce a technique that dynamically determines the height at which the layer is placed, depending on the velocity profile of the user's initial finger movement into midair. Finally, we propose a technique that reliably distinguishes clicking from homing movements, based on the user's hand shape. We structure the presentation of our findings using Buxton's three-state input model, adding additional states and transitions for above-surface interactions.

Title: Metaphone: Machine Aesthetics Meets Interaction Design
Author list: Vygandas Simbelis, Anders Lundstrom, Kristina Hook, Jordi Solsona Belenguer, Vincent Lewandowski
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: KTH â€“ Royal Institute of Technology
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: KTH â€“ Royal Institute of Technology
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: KTH â€“ Royal Institute of Technology
Abstract: Through our art project, Metaphone, we explored a particular form of aesthetics referred to in the arts tradition as machine aesthetics. The Metaphone machine collects the participantâ€™s bio-data, Galvanic Skin Response (GSR) and Heart Rate (HR), creating a process of movement, painting and sound. The machine behaves in machine-like, aesthetically evocative ways: a shaft on two large wheels rotates on the floor, carrying paint that is dripped onto a large sheet of aquarelle paper on the floor according to bio-sensor data. A soundscape rhythmically follows the bio-sensor data, but also has its own machine-like sounds. Six commentators were invited to interact with the machine. They reported a strangely relaxing atmosphere induced by the machine. Based on these experiences we discuss how different art styles can help to describe aesthetics in interaction design generally, and how machine aesthetics in particular can be used to create interesting, sustained, stylistically coherent interactions.

We removed some unimportant sentences and several images, also put some images in to one line to provide space for our changes and added discussion. \ We have discussed the broader field of the topic with some extra research around and put more references to interaction design and interactive arts - like somaesthetics, ambiguity, bio-data based approaches, defamiliarization, etc. We have explained the importance of art styles as well as several examples of intermediate-level design knowledge together with strong concepts, experiential qualities, ultimate particular, etc. And we formulated what impact and influence come from such project as Metaphone and which properties could be used for interaction design as well as what kind of experiences will be created with such designs. \ We have clarified the commentators part as from the beginning we were not clear enough, but we have now explained it in more detail. We have added many of interactive art examples from Khut, Benford and others. We feel proud of such result and thankful for great collaboration with our reviewers.

Title: Passhint: Memorable and Secure Authentication
Author list: Soumyadeb Chowdhury, Ron Poet, Lewis Mackenzie
Abstract: People find it difficult to remember multiple alphanumeric as well as graphical passwords. We propose a Passhint authentication system (PHAS), where the users have to choose four images and create hints for each one of them in order to register a new password. During authentication, they have to recognize only the target images, which are displayed with their corresponding hints, among collections of 15 decoy images, in a four step process. A usability study was conducted with 40 subjects. They created 1 Mikon, 1 doodle, 1 art and 1 object password and then recalled each password after a period of two weeks (without any practice sessions). The results demonstrated that the memorability of multiple passwords in PHAS is better than in existing Graphical authentication systems (GASs). Although the registration time is high, authentication time for successful attempts is either equivalent to or less than the time reported for previous GASs. A guessability study conducted with the same subjects revealed that art passwords are the least guessable, followed by Mikon, doodle and objects in that order. The results strongly suggest the use of art passwords in PHAS, which would offer usable as well as secure authentication. The preliminary results indicate that PHAS has solved the memorability problem with multiple passwords. We propose two new features that could enhance the security offered by PHAS, but the usability of these features would need to be tested before they could be adopted in practice.

Title: Sensing a Live Audience
Author list: Chen Wang, Erik Geelhoed, Phil Stenton, Pablo Cesar
Abstract: Psychophysiological measurement has the potential to play an important role in audience research. Currently, such research is still in its infancy and it usually involves collecting data in the laboratory, where during each experimental session one individual watches a video recording of a performance. We extend the experimental paradigm by simultaneously measuring Galvanic Skin Response (GSR) of a group of participants during a live performance. GSR data were synchronized with video footage of performers and audience. In conjunction with questionnaire data, this enabled us to identify a strongly correlated main group of participants, describe the nature of their theatre experience and map out a minute-by-minute unfolding of the performance in terms of psycho-physiological engagement. The benefits of our approach are twofold. It provides a robust and accurate mechanism for assessing a performance. Moreover, our infrastructure can enable, in the future, real-time feedback from remote audiences for online performances.

Title: Cognitively Inspired Task Design to Improve User Performance on Crowdsourcing Platforms
Author list: Harini Alagarai Sampath, Rajeev Rajeshuni, Bipin Indurkhya
Abstract: Recent research in human computation has focused on improving the quality of work done by crowd workers on crowdsourcing platforms. Multiple approaches have been adopted like filtering crowd workers through qualification tasks, and aggregating responses from multiple crowd workers to obtain consensus. We investigate here how improving the presentation of the task itself by using cognitively inspired features affects the performance of crowd workers. We illustrate this with a case-study for the task of extracting text from scanned images. We generated six task-presentation designs by modifying two parameters - visual saliency of the target fields and working memory requirements - and conducted experiments on Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT) and with an eye-tracker in the lab setting. Our results identify which task-design parameters (e.g. highlighting target fields) result in improved performance, and which ones do not (e.g. reducing the number of distractors). In conclusion, we claim that the use of cognitively inspired features for task design is a powerful technique for maximizing the performance of crowd workers.

Title: Digitally Driven: How Location Based Services Impact the Work Practices of London Bus Drivers
Author list: Gary Pritchard, John Vines, Pam Briggs, Lisa Thomas, Patrick Olivier
Abstract: This paper examines how an occupational group has adapted to the demands of working with a Location Based Service (LBS). Instead of following a rigid timetable, Londonâ€™s bus drivers are now required to maintain an equal distance between the bus in front and the one behind. Our qualitative study employs ethnographic fieldwork and in-depth semi-structured interviews to elicit driversâ€™ perspectives of the new system and show how it has modified their driving and general work conditions. We explore how passengers influence the movement of the bus and how the technology frames bus driversâ€™ relationships to their managers and commuters. This work contributes to our understanding of the impact of LBS in the workplace and shows how technological imperatives can be established that cause unanticipated consequences and gradually undermine human relationships.

Title: Brain Points: A Growth Mindset Incentive Structure Boosts Persistence in an Educational Game
Author list: Eleanor O'Rourke, Kyla Haimovitz, Christy Ballweber, Carol Dweck, Zoran Popovic
Abstract: There is great interest in leveraging video games to improve student engagement and motivation. However, educational games are not uniformly effective, and little is known about how in-game rewards affect children's learning-related behavior. In this work, we argue that educational games can be improved by fundamentally changing their incentive structures to promote the growth mindset, or the belief that intelligence is malleable. We present "brain points," a system that encourages the development of growth mindset behaviors by directly incentivizing effort, use of strategy, and incremental progress. Through a study of 15,000 children, we show that the "brain points" system encourages more low-performing students to persist in the educational game Refraction when compared to a control, and increases overall time played, strategy use, and perseverance after challenge. We believe that this growth mindset incentive structure has great potential in many educational environments.

Title: Effects of Simultaneous and Sequential Work Structures on Distributed Collaborative Interdependent Tasks
Author list: Paul AndrÃ©, Robert Kraut, Aniket Kittur
Abstract: Distributed online groups have great potential for generating interdependent and complex products like encyclopedia articles or product design. However, coordinating multiple group members to work together effectively while minimizing process losses remains an open challenge. We conducted an experiment comparing the effectiveness of two coordination strategies (simultaneous vs. sequential work) on a complex creative task as the number of group members increased. Our results indicate that, contrary to prior work, a sequential work structure was more effective than a simultaneous work structure as the size of the group increased. A mediation analysis suggests that social processes such as territoriality partially accounts for these results. A follow up experiment giving workers specific roles mitigated the detrimental effects of the simultaneous work structure. These results have implications for small group theory and crowdsourcing research.

Title: Crowd Storage: Storing Information on Existing Memories
Author list: Jeffrey P Bigham, Walter S Lasecki
Abstract: This paper introduces the concept of crowd storage, the idea that digital files can be stored and retrieved later from the memories of people in the crowd. Similar to human memory, crowd storage is ephemeral, which means that storage is temporary and the quality of the stored information degrades over time. Crowd storage may be preferred over storing information directly in the cloud, or when it is desirable for information to degrade inline with normal human memories. To explore and validate this idea, we created WeStore, a system that stores and then later retrieves digital files in the existing memories of crowd workers. WeStore does not store information directly, but rather encrypts the files using details of the existing memories elicited from individuals within the crowd as cryptographic keys. The fidelity of the retrieved information is tied to how well the crowd remembers the details of the memories they provided. We demonstrate that crowd storage is feasible using an existing crowd marketplace (Amazon Mechanical Turk), explore design considerations important for building systems that use crowd storage, and outline ideas for future research in this area.

Title: Investigating the Long-Term Use of Exergames in the Home with Elderly Fallers
Author list: Stephen Uzor, Lynne Baillie
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Interactive and Trustworthy Technologies  Research Group
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Interactive and Trustworthy Technologies  Research Group
Abstract: Rehabilitation has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of falling in older adults. However, low adherence to rehabilitation exercises in the home means that seniors often do not get the therapy that they require. We propose that the use of tailored exergames could encourage adherence to falls rehabilitation in the home, as exergames have proved successful in clinical settings. We describe the results from the first known study to investigate the long-term (12 weeks) use of exergames, designed in close collaboration with elderly users, for falls rehabilitation in the home. Our findings suggest that there is an untapped potential of exergames for home rehabilitation use, as our findings show that there was better adherence to exercise in participants who used the exergames, versus those who used standard care. Finally, we make recommendations for designers, on the design of exergames for the rehabilitation of seniors.

Title: SmartVoice: A Presentation Support System For Overcoming the Language Barrier
Author list: Xiang Li, Jun Rekimoto
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Interfaculty Initiative in Information Studies of The univ of Tokyo
Abstract: In most cases, speeches or presentations at an international event are required to be given in a common language (e.g. English). However, for people who are not proficient in that common language, delivering presentations fluently is very difficult. Simultaneous translation seems to be a solution, but besides its high cost, simultaneous translation undermines the nature of the presentation by substituting the real voice of the lecturer as well as his/her emotions. In this paper, we propose "SmartVoice", a presentation support system, which aims to overcome language barriers. By tracking the lip motion of the lecturer, SmartVoice controls the playback of the narration, which is a sound data prepared in advance or created automatically using a voice synthesizer. SmartVoice also controls the intonation of the sound based on the position and shape of the lecturer's mouth. As the lecturer can talk at his/her own pace with the voice automatically following, it appears as if he/she talks in his/her own voice. In our user evaluation, we confirmed that audiences find it difficult to distinguish between the narration generated by SmartVoice and that by a real voice. We also discuss the possibility of applying SmartVoice to fields other than multi-language presentation support, such as Automated Dialogue Replacement and language study.

Title: Supporting Learners in Collecting and Exploring Data from Immersive Simulations in Collective Inquiry
Author list: Michelle Lui, Alex Kuhn, Alisa Acosta, Chris Quintana, James D. Slotta
Abstract: Digitally augmented physical spaces (e.g., smart classrooms) offer opportunities to engage students in novel and potentially transformative learning experiences. This paper presents an immersive rainforest simulation and collective inquiry activity where students collect observational data from the environment and explore their peersâ€™ data through large visualizations displays and on personal mobile devices. Two iterations of the design were tested, which resulted in higher quality student explanations constructed. Images were found to be an important source of evidence for the explanations, more so than text-only evidence. We also found that patterns of collective ideas influenced student performance, and that visualizations, as ambient or plenary displays, supported both teacher and students in reviewing patterns of collected data.

Title: Movement-Based Game Guidelines
Author list: Florian Mueller, Katherine Isbister
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Polytechnic Institute of New York University
Abstract: Movement-based digital games are becoming increasingly popular, yet there is limited comprehensive guidance on how to design these games. We present a set of guidelines for movement-based game design that has emerged from our research-based game development practice. These guidelines have been examined and refined by 14 movement-based game design experts with experience in the academic, independent and commercial game development domains. We contextualize the guidelines using current findings about movement-based game and interaction design, taken from both published research papers and game design venues. Our primary contribution is a body of generative intermediate-level knowledge in the design research tradition that is readily accessible and actionable for the design of future movement-based games.

Thumbnail Image Caption: 10 concrete guidelines, validated by experts, for the design of movement-based games to aid designers in creating engaging games involving bodily action.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: 10 concrete guidelines, validated by experts, for the design of movement-based games to aid designers in creating engaging games involving bodily action.
Summary of Changes: List of changes \ Paper 1183 â€“ Movement-Based Game Guidelines \  \ To the reviewers \ We would like to gratefully thank the reviewers for their detailed feedback, which we have taken to heart in order to improve the paper. Below we have listed the changes made, categorized by section in the rebuttal. We have tried to address the reviewersâ€™ concerns to the best of our abilities and have provided additional details where page limits allowed us to do. We thank the reviewers for their contributions. \  \  \ GUIDELINES: CAPTURING A WIDE RANGE OF GAMES YET SPECIFIC \  \ Reviewersâ€™ feedback:	 \ R1 asks (which was echoed by the AC) if some of the guidelines might be different for different player target groups, game types or game genres. \  \ Changes done: \ We added a section explaining the following: \ * We see our 10 guidelines only as a starting point, i.e. there could be more, going into more specific player target groups, game types and game genres. \ * We acknowledge that our current guidelines are trying to capture a range of games and players while providing concrete advice, i.e. we were aiming to be broad while specific. We mentioned how by proposing guidelines researchers must engage in a constant balancing act between being too specific and too general, a challenge expressed previously by work on interaction patterns (one of our inspirations [Borchers, J.O. A pattern approach to interaction design. AI & SOCIETY, 15 (4). (2001), 359-376]). \ * We added that engaging in this balancing act has distinct advantages and potential pitfalls for researchers (such as the guidelines being useful for a wide range of game ideas, yet not concrete enough for practitioners to use). \ * We explained how we aimed to hit the â€œsweet spotâ€ù between being too broad (and therefore not applicable and useful for practitioners) and too specific (and therefore resulting in guidance that practitioners do not read) based on our over 20 years of experience.  \  \ More specifically, we noted R1â€™s comment on how some of our guidelines, such as â€œSupport self-expressionâ€ù could benefit from mentioning goals from different game types, for example games that aim to train specific muscle groups. In response, we added this to our DOs and DONâ€™Ts. \  \ These amendments should clarify our objective for the guidelines to be useful for a wide range of games while also being specific enough and easily presentable in a practitioner-friendly format.  \  \ DETAILED METHOD \ Reviewersâ€™ feedback: \ R1 and R3 requested more detail about our method for generating the guidelines. \  \ Changes done: \ We added the following: \ * an articulation of the structure we engaged in for the two discussion rounds  \ * more details on how we arrived at the guidelines when we worked face-to-face and how we worked on the guidelines after that, in our respective labs, communicating over the internet . \  \ HEADINGS FOLLOWING GUIDELINES AND RELATED WORK \ Reviewersâ€™ feedback: \ R1 and R4 asked about the separation between â€œGuidelinesâ€ù, â€œDOs and DONâ€™Tsâ€ù and â€œAcademic reasoningâ€ù.  \  \ Changes done: \ We added transition statements between them, detailing their interrelationship, and replaced the term â€œAcademic reasoningâ€ù in order to better highlight the focus of the associated section on the underlying scientific basis behind each guideline. We also used this section to incorporate a discussion on the relationship of our work to the guidelines and taxonomies of movement-based games suggested by R1, R3. Furthermore, we added how this paperâ€™s guidelines relate to one of our own game taxonomies that we have previously published [Taxonomy of Exertion Games, OzCHIâ€™08].  \  \ MAKING SPACE TO PROVIDE MORE GAME DETAILS \ Reviewersâ€™ feedback: \ R1 and R2 suggested ways to make space. \  \ Changes done: \ In order to make space for the above amendments we trimmed down the section â€œFeedback from the expertsâ€ù as suggested by R1 and R2.  \  \

Title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Physical Shape-Change for In-pocket Mobile Device Notifications
Author list: Panteleimon Dimitriadis, Jason Alexander
Abstract: Audio and vibrotactile output are the standard mechanisms mobile devices use to attract their ownerâ€™s attention. Yet in busy and noisy environments, or when the user is physically active, these channels sometimes fail. Recent work has explored the use of physical shape-change as an additional method for conveying notifications when the device is in-hand or viewable. However, we do not yet understand the effectiveness of physical shape-change as a method for communicating in-pocket notifications. This paper presents three robustly implemented, mobile-device sized shape-changing devices, and two user studies to evaluate their effectiveness at conveying notifications. The studies reveal that (1) different types and configurations of shape-change convey different levels of urgency and; (2) fast pulsing shape-changing notifications are missed less often and recognised more quickly than the standard slower vibration pulse rates of a mobile device.

Title: Under Pressure: Sensing Stress of Computer Users
Author list: Javier Hernandez, Pablo Paredes, Asta Roseway, Mary Czerwinski
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department
Abstract: Recognizing when computer users are stressed can help reduce their frustration and prevent a large variety of negative health conditions associated with chronic stress. However, measuring stress non-invasively and continuously at work remains an open challenge. This work explores the possibility of using a pressure-sensitive keyboard and a capacitive mouse to discriminate between stressful and relaxed conditions in a laboratory study. During a 30 minute session, 24 participants performed several computerized tasks consisting of expressive writing, text transcription, and mouse clicking. During the stressful conditions, the large majority of the participants showed significantly increased typing pressure (>79% of the participants) and more contact with the surface of the mouse (75% of the participants). We discuss the potential implications of this work and provide recommendations for future work.

Summary of Changes: List of changes:  \  \ Background Research \ - Emphasize how our study differs from previous studies and highlight our contribution (use of pressure-sensitive keyboard and capacitive mouse in the context of stress measurement). \ - Correct typo highlighted by reviewer 2 ("studied in various areas such AS biometric authentication") \  \ Experiment Tasks \ - Rename title of the section to Experimental Tasks \ - Highlight the different types of stress elicited by the different tasks (exposure to a stressing environment, stressors elicited from within the user by remembering a stressful moment and spillover of stress during mouse clicking) \ - Correct typo during the explanation of the mouse clicking task ("three distances x three widths x TEN repetitions") \  \ Protocol \ - Explicitly mention that there were four different task orderings and how they relate to Figure 3. \ - Emphasize that the ordering of the keyboard tasks were counterbalanced for different participants and remained constant for the same participant. Furthermore, we plan to add few more arrows on Figure 3 to clarify that each participant performed one of the four task orderings. \ - Mention that the 2-minute relaxing clip was selected and tested during a pilot study. \  \ Did the tasks elicit the intended emotions? \ - Remove the last sentence of the second paragraph ("Therefore, self-reported stress was") \ - Increase font size of Figure 5. \  \ How is typing pressure affected by stress? \ - Emphasize that two of the participants showed less (although not significant) typing pressure during the transcription task. \ - Emphasize that one participant showed significantly less typing pressure during the expressive writing task. When analyzing the response of this participant during the stressed condition, s/he described a sad experience which may have caused the decreased of pressure. \ - Emphasize that the ordering effect only occurred in one of the four tasks orderings and that it similarly affected both stressed and relaxed conditions (decreasing the pressure values). Also, emphasize that even though there was an ordering effect, the differences between the two conditions were consistent with the differences of the other tasks orderings (more typing pressure during the stressed condition) \ - Mention that a longer relaxing clip longer could have addressed the ordering effect. \  \ How is mouse capacitance affected by stress? \ - Emphasize that all the participants showed significantly different readings between the two conditions. \ - Emphasize that even though a large majority of the participants (75%) showed significantly larger amount of contact with the mouse during the stressed condition, there were still 25% of participants who showed significantly less contact. This finding highlights that different people respond differently to stress and the importance of considering person-specific models to provide more accurate measurements. \ - Mention that there may be other underlying reasons explaining how an increase of stress may lead to an increase of pressure (e.g., change of body language, typing more aggressively) \ - Emphasize that the amount of interactions (typing velocity) was not significantly different between the two conditions. \  \ How much data is required to differentiate between the stressed and relaxed conditions? \ - Rename subsection to "How much data is required to differentiate between stressed and relaxed conditions at any point in time?" \ - Provide more information about the context of the question (development of a real-time classifier that needs to analyze information over certain periods of time to make predictions) \ - Emphasize that the x-axis of Figure 8 is normalized and, therefore, the curves of the two typing tasks are more different than they seem. \  \ Discussion \ - Emphasize the importance of individual differences when developing methods for automatic measurement of stress. Individual differences can be seen on the range of values of each participant (shown in Figure 6) and the different types of responses observed during the mouse clicking task. \ - Emphasize that 25% of the participants handled the mouse with less contact during the stressed condition. \  \ Conclusions \ - Emphasize that we found significant differences between the two conditions and that most of the participants showed increased typing pressure and mouse contact during our experiment. \  - Incorporate correction of review 2 ("we show THAT stress influences keystroke pressure") \

Title: Wrigglo: Shape-Changing Peripheral for Interpersonal Mobile Communication
Author list: Joohee Park, Young-Woo Park, Tek-Jin Nam
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: CIDR Lab, Department of Industrial Design
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: CIDR Lab, Department of Industrial Design
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: CIDR Lab, Department of Industrial Design
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Abstract: We introduce Wrigglo, a shape-changing smart phone peripheral that allows pairs of users to share wriggling movements with one another. Attached to a smart phone, Wrigglo captures the senderâ€™s motions and activates the receiverâ€™s Wrigglo which repeats the motion simultaneously. The result of our in-lab use observation with twelve couples showed that Wrigglo supported emotional and functional roles of body gestures and postures, creating vocabularies related to the motion of specific body parts and, to some extent, reflected the connected userâ€™s presence through the deviceâ€™s movement. Through its peripheral anthropomorphization, Wrigglo can deliver new forms of telepresence by embodied posturing and gesturing in mobile communication.

Title: Doing the Laundry with Agents: a Field Trial of a Future Smart Energy System in the Home
Author list: Enrico Costanza, Joel E Fischer, James A Colley, Tom A Rodden, Sarvapali D Ramchurn, Nicholas R Jennings
Author emails: ec@ecs.soton.ac.uk, jef@cs.nott.ac.uk, jzc@cs.nott.ac.uk, tar@Cs.Nott.AC.UK, sdr1@soton.ac.uk, nrj@ecs.soton.ac.uk
Abstract: Future energy systems that rely on renewable energy may bring about a radical shift in how we use energy in our homes. We developed and prototyped a future scenario with highly variable, real-time electricity prices due to a grid that mainly relies on renewables. We designed and deployed an agent-based interactive system that enables users to effectively operate the washing machine in this scenario. The system is used to book timeslots of washing machine use so that the agent can help to minimize the cost of a wash by charging a battery at times when electricity is cheap. We carried out a deployment in 10 households in order to uncover the socio-technical challenges around integrating new technologies into everyday routines. The findings reveal tensions that arise when deploying a rationalistic system to manage contingently and socially organized domestic practices. We discuss the trade-offs between utility and convenience inherent in smart grid applications; and illustrate how certain design choices position applications along this spectrum. \

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Deployment of prototype real-time pricing infrastructure in peopleâ€™s homes reveals tensions between social organization of practices and rationalistic system design assumptions. Discusses design trade-offs between economic utility and user convenience.
Summary of Changes: We thank the ACs for their useful comments to improve the paper. We have thoroughly revised our paper according to these over the past few weeks.  \  \ In addition to edits throughout the paper for typos, clarity of language, formatting and consistency of terminology coherent with what we promised in the rebuttal, we have addressed the ACsâ€™ 6 main points from the final reviews as follows: \  \ - to address point 1 ("Clarify the vision and premise from the very outset of the paper"), we edited the introduction (page 1) to introduce the Agent B system earlier, clarify the dynamic pricing scenario and our prototyping approach, clarify the aim to reveal tension that arise when deploying a rationalistic booking system into peopleâ€™s everyday lives, and emphasise the paperâ€™s contributions.  \  \ - to address point 2 ("Get to the data and analysis earlier in the paper.."), we shortened the scenario and system descriptions (pages 3 and 4), so that the study description starts on page 4 \  \ - to address point 3 ("Improve the depth and synthesis of analysis.."), we shortened and removed a number of the interviews quotes (pages 6 and 7) and added summary paragraphs at the end of each of the analysis subsections (also pages 6 and 7); we also added "from automatic interaction logs" to the "system usage" subsection heading (page 5), to clarify where the data reported on here comes from; and added the thematic analysis reference [4] \  \ - to address point 4 ("..laundry as a rational and planned activity, versus laundry as negotiated.."), we extended the discussion, particularly the subsection â€œThe Booking System as a Contingent Resourceâ€ù, including new references [22, 33, 34], and a new subsection "Trading Utility for Convenience?" at the end of the discussion (page 8) \  \ - to address point 5 ("backgrounding agency"), we reduced the subsection "the hidden appearance of agency" (was on page 9) to a single paragraph edited for clarity, and we renamed it to "Orienting to the Agency of Agent B". We followed the ACâ€™s suggestion and removed the section "Putting agents in the infrastructure"  (used to be on page 9). \  \ - to address point 6 ("future designs" and "future directions") we added the section "design for smart grid applications" (page 9); this section draws implications from the extended discussion on the tensions between everyday contingencies and the rationalistic booking system; thus offering design considerations that follow directly from our findings, and suggesting avenues for future HCI research. We also added a summarizing conclusion section.  \  \ Overall, we have made more edits than this changelog can reflect given the space limitations. Our goal was to focus the contribution of the paper, particularly engaging with the tensions raised by introducing a rationalistic booking system into the contingent organisation of domestic practices.  \

Title: Evaluation of Hear-Through Sound Localization
Author list: Georgios Marentakis, Rudolfs Liepins
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Institute for Electronic Music and Acoustics
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Institute for Electronic Music and Acoustics
Abstract: Listening and interacting with audio commonly relies on using earphones which limit the ability of users to perceive their auditory environment. Earphone sets that integrate miniature microphones on their exterior can, however, be used to hear-through the auditory environment. We present an evaluation study in which sound localization when wearing such a hear-through system is compared to normal earphones, open headphones and unblocked ears. Although  localization performance is improved compared to open headphones, we find that it is compromised in comparison to listening without earphones because confusions of sound direction increase and localization judgment distributions are more dispersed and show a weaker correlation to the test directions. The implications of the results to human computer interaction and possible improvements to hear-through system design are discussed.

Title: Remote Handshaking: Touch Enhances Video-Mediated Social Telepresence
Author list: Hideyuki Nakanishi, Kazuaki Tanaka, Yuya Wada
Abstract: Since past studies on haptic and visual communication have tended to be isolated from each other, it has remained unclear whether a touch channel can still enrich mediated communication where video and audio channels are already available. To clarify this, we analyzed remote handshaking in which a robot hand that was attached just under a videoconferencing terminalâ€™s display moved according to the opening and closing motion of a conversation partnerâ€™s hand. Combining touch and video channels raises a question as to whether the partnerâ€™s action of touching a haptic device should be visible to the user. If it can be invisible, the action may be unnecessary, and a unilaterally controlled device may be enough to establish an effective touch channel. Our analysis revealed that the feeling of being close to the partner can be enhanced by mutual touch in which the partnerâ€™s action needs to occur but should be invisible.

Title: Conductor: Enabling and Understanding Cross-Device Interaction
Non-embedded fonts: Arial-BoldMT TimesNewRomanPS-BoldMT TimesNewRomanPSMT TimesNewRomanPS-ItalicMT Verdana TimesNewRomanPS-BoldItalicMT ArialMT Arial-BoldItalicMT
Author list: Peter Hamilton, Daniel Wigdor
Abstract: The proliferation of inexpensive connected devices has created a situation where a person, at any given moment, is surrounded by interactive computers. Despite this fact, there are very few means by which a user may take advantage of this large number of screens. We present Conductor, a prototype framework which serves as an exemplar for the construction of cross-device applications. We present a series of interaction methods by which users can easily share information, chain tasks across devices, and manage sessions across devices. We also present a cross-device usage scenario which utilizes several cross-device applications built within our prototype framework. We also describe a user study, which helped us to understand how users will take advantage of a large number of devices in support of performance of a sense making task.

Title: Improving Machine Translation by Showing Two Outputs
Author list: Bin Xu, Ge Gao, Susan Fussell, Dan Cosley
Abstract: We propose to improve real-time communication between people who do not share a common language by foregrounding potential problems in machine translation. We developed a prototype chat tool that displays two parallel translations of each chat turn, with the thought that comparing the translations might both highlight problems and provide resources for resolving them. We conducted a user study to investigate how people use and like such an interface compared to a standard one-translation interface. On balance, users preferred two translations to one, using them to both notice differences and infer meaning from uncertain translations, with no increase in workload. This suggests that this interface may help improve cross-lingual communication in practical applications and lays the groundwork for a larger design space around systems that highlight possible errors to support communication.

Title: Mechanical Force Redistribution: Enabling Seamless, Large-Format, High-Accuracy Surface Interaction
Author list: Alex Grau, Charles Hendee, John-Ross Rizzo, Ken Perlin
Abstract: We present Mechanical Force Redistribution (MFR): a method of sensing which creates an anti-aliased image of forces applied to a surface. This technique mechanically focuses the force from a surface onto adjacent discrete forcels (force sensing cells) by way of protrusions (small bumps or pegs), allowing for high-accuracy interpolation between adjacent discrete forcels. MFR works with any force transducing technique or material, including force variable resistive inks, piezoelectric materials and capacitive force plates. MFR sensors can be tiled such that the signal is continuous across contiguous tiles. By minimizing active materials and computational complexity, MFR makes large-format interactive walls, collaborative tabletops and high-resolution floor tiles possible and economically feasible.

Title: PrintSense: A Versatile Sensing Technique to Support Multimodal Flexible Surface Interaction
Author list: Nan-Wei Gong, JÃ_rgen Steimle, Simon Olberding, Steve Hodges, Nicholas Gillian, Yoshihiro Kawahara, Joseph A Paradiso
Author emails: nanwei@media.mit.edu, jsteimle@mpi-inf.mpg.de, solberdi@mpi-inf.mpg.de, shodges@microsoft.com, ngillian@media.mit.edu, kawahara@akg.t.u-tokyo.ac.jp, joep@media.mit.edu
Abstract: We present a multimodal on-surface and near-surface sensing technique for planar, curved and flexible surfaces. Our technique leverages temporal multiplexing of signals coming from a universal interdigitated electrode design, which is printed as a single conductive layer on a flexible substrate. It supports sensing of touch and proximity in-put, and moreover is capable of capturing several levels of pressure and flexing. We leverage recent developments in conductive inkjet printing as a way to prototype electrode patterns, and combine this with our hardware module for supporting the full range of sensing methods. As the tech-nique is low-cost and easy to implement, it is particularly well-suited for prototyping touch- and hover-based user interfaces, including curved and deformable ones.

Title: Measuring Operator Anticipatory Inputs in Response to Time-delay for Teleoperated Human-robot Interfaces
Author list: Jonathan Bidwell, Alexandra Holloway, Scott Davidoff
Abstract: Many tasks call for efficient user interaction under time delayâ€”controlling space instruments, piloting remote aircraft and operating search and rescue robots. In this paper we identify an underexplored design opportunity for building robotic teleoperation user interfaces following an evaluation of operator performance during a time-delayed robotic arm block-stacking task in twenty-two participants. More delay resulted in greater operator hesitation and a decreased ratio of active to inactive input. This ratio can serve as a useful proxy for measuring an operatorâ€™s ability to anticipate the outcome of their control inputs before receiving delayed visual feedback. High anticipatory input ratio (AIR) scores indicate times when robot operators enter commands before waiting for visual feedback. Low AIR scores highlight when operators must wait for visual feedback before continuing. We used this measurement to help us identify particular sub-tasks where operators would likely benefit from additional support.
