Thumbnail Image Caption: Ensemble Metatone making improvised music on touch screens with percussion-inspired gestures. This paper examines the vocabulary of gestures they developed in rehearsal and performance.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This paper examines a vocabulary of expressive gestures and musical interactions with touch-screen devices invented by a group of percussionists in free-improvised performance.
Summary of Changes: Our final note contains the revisions that we suggested in our rebuttal and in response to the general comments of the secondary reviewer. \  \ In the first paragraph of the Introduction, we have drawn more attention to the takeaways of our research for others. We think that the vocabulary of gestures we discovered would be useful for designers creating new musical touch-screen interfaces or for musicians composing with them.  We make it clear that by discovering new gestures we are addressing limitations of mainstream music apps which mostly use "virtual keyboard" paradigms.  \  \ In the second paragraph of the Introduction we clarify that the gestures that emerged in our research are quite different to those already in the literature and have added a reference [12] (Wobbrock et al) for comparison. Our gestures are generally two handed and contain many touches over a number of seconds to create sustained musical gestures. \  \ Similar changes were made in the second and fourth paragraphs of the conclusion where we suggest future uses for our research in developing more expressive musical apps, composing music with current apps or training other musicians and students. We state that our research shows that expressive gestures can be used to expand the power of musical touch-screen apps and create compelling performances. \  \ In the first paragraph of "Designing Tablet Instruments", we have added that although many tablet computers might be suitable for developing musical apps we chose the iPad due to its widespread adoption and established computer music development frameworks. \  \ To avoid confusion about the duration of interviews and rehearsals in the data corpus we have used #H#M#S notation in Table 1 as suggested by ISO standards rather than #:#:#. Typos and small corrections have been addressed throughout the note.

Title: Online Public Communications by Police & Fire Services during the 2012 Hurricane Sandy
Author list: Amanda L. Hughes, Lise A. St. Denis, Leysia Palen, Kenneth M. Anderson
Abstract: Social media and other online communication tools are a subject of great interest in mass emergency response. Members of the public are turning to these solutions to seek and offer emergency information. Emergency responders are working to determine what social media policies should be in terms of their â€œpublic informationâ€ù functions. We report on the online communications from all the coastal fire and police departments within a 100 mile radius of Hurricane Sandyâ€™s US landfall. Across four types of online communication media, we collected data from 840 fire and police departments. Findings indicate that few departments used these online channels in their Sandy response efforts, and that communications differed between fire and police departments and across media type. However, among the highly engaged departments, there is evidence that they bend and adapt policies about what constitutes appropriate public communication in the face of emergency demands; therefore, we propose that flexibility is important in considering future emergency online communication policy. We conclude with design recommendations for making online communication media more â€œlistenableâ€ù for both emergency managers and members of the public.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This study examines how the police and fire departments most affected by Hurricane Sandy used (or did not use) online media to communicate with the public during the event.
Summary of Changes: Thank you for your considered and incisive comments. As we reread the paper alongside reviewer feedback, we saw that weakness in the Discussion (all reviewersâ€™ primary concern) could be traced back to earlier analytical and structural issues in the middle of the paper. Our changes follow the claims we made in our rebuttal document, and so are restated and elaborated here. \  \ In correcting the paper, we made many revision passes. We redid some analyses. With the middle analytical material better presented and more extensively discussed, we reworked the last section of the paper so that it is more pointed and tied to the data. Here we describe 1) the rework of the problematic analysis and 2) a summative outline of how that affected each section of the paper, including the better articulated results. \  \ MAJOR CHANGE THAT SNAPPED THINGS INTO PLACE: The Discussionâ€™s weakness largely stemmed from how we presented the results section about online engagement in the middle of the paper. Though our data coding was extensive, the collapsed â€œengagementâ€ù score obscured meaningful interpretation, as reviewers also observed (R2, R3 and R4). With distance, we could see it as we think you did---our readers hoped that the Discussion would resolve some undone analytical interpretation. We have unpacked the engagement score, which opened up the ability to discuss its meaning there. \  \ THE â€œENGAGEMENT SCOREâ€ù REWORK: We discarded the overall engagement score and revisited the 5-point activity score used to originally code for engagement. We carefully combined some categories to simplify distinctions between levels of use. Our new coding scheme includes 3 levels of engagement: INACTIVE (no or low use), NON-SANDY ACTIVE (had accounts but not used for Sandy), and SANDY ACTIVE (accounts used for Sandy). This simplification allowed us to restructure the Online Engagement section to present better visualizations of use across departments and across media. We present those new results and the resulting changes below. \  \ INTRODUCTION: No Changes \  \ STUDY SITE AND DATA COLLECTION: We describe the new simplified coding scheme. \  \ QUANTITATIVE DESCRIPTIONS OF USE: This is the same, except we improved the discussion about websites, clarifying that they were used primarily to locate information about other online presence, and clearly treat it as such over the remainder of the paper. It is hard to know if some Sandy information from websites had been deleted and when, and so we separated that from the subsequent engagement analysis. \  \ ONLINE ENGAGEMENT: The section now begins by describing levels of engagement across online type. Results show that Facebook had the highest level of Sandy engagement (25%), followed by Twitter (7%), then Nixle (4%). Next, we describe levels of engagement by department. Based on the highest level of engagement they reached, departments are categorized as Inactive (46%), Non-Sandy Active (25%), or Sandy Active (29%). Within the Active categories we report how many media types each department used (1-3) in each engagement category type: Non-Sandy Active (used 1: 88%, used 2: 11%, used all 3: 1%) & Sandy Active (used 1:78%, used 2:19%,  used all 3: 3%). Results indicate that of those who were Sandy-Active, the majority (78%) only used 1 medium. Discussion then shifts to describing each engagement category and the reasons for different levels of use (such as lack of time & resources), as well as possible reasons for variability within each category. This reworked section adds strength and clarity to the analysis and overall offerings. It better motivates the transition into the next section. \  \ HIGH-ENGAGEMENT IS A SITUATED PRACTICE: Shortened & simplified the intro \  \ DISCUSSION (now an extended â€œCONCLUSIONâ€ù): Because we now have lengthier discussion closer to the data reporting, we reconfigured this section into an extended Conclusion. We begin by summarizing analyses. Next we now have a short discussion of implications for procedures & policy, followed by a discussion around how online communications provide a sense of transparency to emergency service work, as well as greater public accountability. We then add a new subsection around design implications from this research and future work, which specifically addresses concerns from R3 & R4. This discussion includes recommendations for making social media streams more â€œlistenableâ€ù for on-the-ground emergency managers, as well as more trackable to help better organize Q&A on the fly. These become researchable design propositions that we think are important for the crisis informatics community to take up. Discussion around future work includes insight about the relationship between a departmentâ€™s desire to communicate online (by virtue of establishing accounts and audience following during non-disaster times) and their (in)ability to act on those relationships when personnel resources become taxed during disaster. This is supported by unreported data in other studies of practitioners, and their deep concerns about creating versus maintaining a following when times are the worst. \  \ Throughout this concluding section we made efforts to ensure that our claims were supported by the data in the paper (R2) and that the discussion reflects a more balanced reporting of the data, instead of focusing  just on the activities of the highly engaged departments. \  \ OTHER ISSUES ADDRESSED: Reviewers noted several descriptive issues throughout the paperâ€”which we have addressed in our revisionâ€”where typos appeared (e.g. â€œhow and howâ€ù instead of â€œhow and whyâ€ù), the text was confusing (e.g. our  â€ùcomparison of how often officials replied directly to posts on Facebook vs. Twitterâ€ù), or terms were not clear (e.g. use of the terms â€œbulletin boardâ€ù and â€œpostsâ€ù).  R3 would like to see the role of different fire and police department staff in public outreach expanded upon. However, our approach in this study was to report on the â€œpublic communicationsâ€ù of these departments; these communications appear to members of the public as communications from the department as a single entity because no distinction is made (or given) as to who sent the communication within the departmentâ€™s organization. We feel this suggestion would complicate reporting and analysis, as well as confuse the reader. Further, the topic of who actually handles public communications across online media within fire and police departments requires study of its own, as it often varies by department. Therefore, we feel that implementation of this suggestion is beyond the scope of the paper and would be best addressed in an expanded journal article or as future research. \  \ R3 pointed to several limitations of the data collected in the study. We describe these limitations throughout the revised paper (mostly close to the relevant data reporting) and we also offer areas of research that need further investigation. \  \ We again thank you for your attention and advice and we hope you find the changes we have made satisfactory!  \  \ Amanda L. Hughes \ Lise A. St. Denis \ Leysia Palen \ Kenneth M. Anderson \

Title: NewsViews: An Automated Pipeline for Creating Custom Geovisualizations for News
Author list: Tong Gao, Jessica Hullman, Eytan Adar, Brent Hecht, Nicholas Diakopoulos
Abstract: Interactive visualizations add rich, data-based context to online news articles. Geographic maps are currently the most prevalent form of these visualizations. Unfortunately, designers capable of producing high-quality, customized geovisualizations are scarce. We present NewsViews, a novel automated news visualization system that generates interactive, annotated maps without requiring professional designers. NewsViewsâ€™ maps support trend identification and data comparisons relevant to a given news article. The NewsViews system leverages text mining to identify key concepts and locations discussed in articles (as well as potential annotations), an extensive repository of â€œfoundâ€ù databases, and techniques adapted from cartography to identify and create visually â€œinterestingâ€ù thematic maps. In this work, we develop and evaluate key criteria in automatic, annotated, map generation and experimentally validate the key features for successful representations (e.g., relevance to context, variable selection, â€œinterestingnessâ€ù of representation and annotation quality).

Title: Effects of Implicit Sharing in Collaborative Analysis
Author list: Nitesh Goyal, Gilly Leshed, Dan Cosley, Susan R. Fussell
Abstract: When crime analysts collaborate to solve crime cases, they need to share insights in order to connect the clues, identify a pattern, and attribute the crime to the right culprit. We designed a collaborative analysis tool to explore the value of implicitly sharing insights and notes, without requiring analysts to explicitly push information or request it from each other. In an experiment, pairs of remote individuals played the role of crime analysts solving a set of serial killer crimes with both partners having some, but not all, relevant clues. When implicit sharing of notes was available, participants remembered more clues related to detecting the serial killer, and they perceived the tool as more useful compared to when implicit sharing was not available.

Author Keywords: Implicit sharing; collaborative analysis; sensemaking
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Presents a study of implicit vs. explicit information sharing in a collaborative crime solving task; provides insights for designs of new collaborative analysis tools
Summary of Changes: I made the following changes as requested by Lisa M. Tolles: \  \ 1. Updated the license \ 2. Verified with Susan R. Fussell. It stays with R. \ 3. Non-Justified the Section head \ 4. Fixed the widow line on Page 6 by adjusting one of the paragraphs before. \  \ Thanks. \  \ Comments for AC \ --------- \  \ These changes have been accepted by our shepherd. The Shepherd said that we did a good job integrating more literature into the paper, situating our experiment in the context of other similar work. She also like thee explanation of the distinction between choosing explicitly to share information with one's collaborator, vs. the implicit sharing that took place in our experiment. No further revisions were necessary. . \  \ Please find below the outline of the changes we made based on the suggestions made by you and other reviewers: \  \ 1. The related work section must be revised to include a review of literature similar to Convertino et al. (2011); Reviewer 6 provides some additional suggestions of other papers in this area.  \  \ Pages 2-3 (background) \  \ We discuss Convertino et al. (2011) and few other works as suggested in relation to our work in reasoning the hypotheses. We also refer to these papers in defining the measures (pages 5-6), and in connection to our findings (pages 6-7) and the discussion (page 8). \  \ We decided to not refer to the body of literature about visualizations and feedback such as Bachour et al., CHI 2009, DiMicco and colleagues (CSCW 2004, HCI 2007), and Bergstrom and Karahalios, CHI 2007 (suggested by R6). These papers are typically oriented around the problem of balancing team membersâ€™ contributions to a conversation, which is not central to our current work. \  \ 2. The paper must clarify how the concept of "implicit sharing" is different from (or similar to) concepts like "knowledge sharing" and "awareness" from earlier work.  \  \ Pages 1-2 (background) \  \ We define â€œimplicit sharingâ€ù as automatic sharing of analysis insights. It is a type of the more general â€œknowledge sharingâ€ù, which was shown to be beneficial for improving awareness and common ground. However, not all knowledge sharing is implicit. For instance Convertino et al. (2011) designed knowledge sharing as an explicit act of copying pieces of information from a private space to a public space.   \  \ 3. The paper must be more clear about the contribution. What is new about this experiment -- what have we learned from this that we did not know before? How important is what we have learned?  \  \ Pages 2 (background) & 9 (conclusion) \  \ Our work stands out among other papers about collaborative analysis tools that evaluated their tools as a whole, ran informal studies, or did not evaluate their tools at all. Our contribution is understanding the effects of a specific design feature â€“ implicit sharing of insights using digital post-it notes â€“ in a controlled lab experiment on the process and outcomes of a collaborative analysis task. The results of our study can help clarify the benefits and costs of adding a specific design feature to collaborative analysis tools. \  \  4. Finally, while it may be difficult given the space constraints, try to make these revisions suggested in your rebuttal: \  \ - discuss the limitations, including potential disadvantages of implicit sharing \  \ - strengthen the argument about the ways in which the experiment task resembles real-world problems, and discuss what you think generalizes about these results and what aspects might not  \  \ Page 8 (limitations & generalization) \  \ We explain the problem of balancing a lab study against the real-world scope of analysis tasks. Our study was designed to simulate boundaries around access to data sources and could generalize to cases where such boundaries exist. However, there could be other design choices around sharing in general and implicit sharing in particular, and contextual factors might limit the benefits of our design of implicit sharing, such as organizational policies around what analysts are allowed to write in shared notes. \  \ Finally, as promised in the rebuttal, we strengthened the design implications to better connect our quantitative and qualitative findings with concrete design directions (p. 8-9). We also fixed some typos and tightened our paper by removing the redundancies. \  \

Title: Dynamic Difficulty Using Brain Metrics of Workload
Author list: Daniel Afergan, Evan M Peck, Erin T Solovey, Andrew Jenkins, Samuel W Hincks, Eli T Brown, Remco Chang, Robert J.K. Jacob
Author emails: afergan@gmail.com, evanpeck@gmail.com, erin@cs.drexel.edu, aj.jenkins123@gmail.com, samhincks@gmail.com, eli.t.brown@gmail.com, remco@cs.tufts.edu, jacob@cs.tufts.edu
Abstract: Dynamic difficulty adjustments can be used in human-computer systems in order to improve user engagement and performance. In this paper, we use functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) to obtain passive brain sensing data and detect extended periods of boredom or overload. From these physiological signals, we can adapt a simulation in order to optimize workload in real-time, which allows the system to better fit the task to the user from moment to moment. To demonstrate this idea, we ran a laboratory study in which participants performed path planning for multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in a simulation. Based on their state, we varied the difficulty of the task by adding or removing UAVs and found that we were able to decrease errors by 35% over a baseline condition. Our results show that we can use fNIRS brain sensing to detect task difficulty in real-time and construct an interface that improves user performance through dynamic difficulty adjustment.

Title: Kinetica: Naturalistic Multi-touch Data Visualization
Author list: Jeffrey M Rzeszotarski, Aniket Kittur
Abstract: Over the last several years there has been an explosion of powerful, affordable, multi-touch devices. This provides an outstanding opportunity for novel data visualization techniques that leverage new interaction methods and minimize their barriers to entry. In this paper we describe an approach for multivariate data visualization that uses physics-based affordances that are easy to intuit, constraints that are easy to apply and visualize, and a consistent view as data is manipulated in order to promote data exploration and interrogation. We provide a framework for exploring this problem space, and an example proof of concept system called Kinetica. We describe the results of a user study that suggest users of Kinetica were able to explore multiple dimensions of data at once, identify outliers, and discover trends with minimal training.

Title: Expanding Touch Input Vocabulary  by Using Consecutive Distant Taps
Author list: Seongkook Heo, Jiseong Gu, Geehyuk Lee
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: KAIST (Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology)
Abstract: In recent years, touch screens have emerged and matured as the main input interface for mobile and tablet computers calling for extended touch input possibilities. In this paper, we explore the use of consecutive distant taps to expand the touch screen input vocabulary. We analyzed time intervals and distances between consecutive taps during common applications on a tablet and verified that consecutive distant taps can be used conflict-free with existing touch gestures. We designed the two interaction techniques Ta-tap and Ta-Ta-tap that utilize consecutive distant taps. Ta-tap uses two consecutive distant taps to invoke alternative touch operations for multi-touch emulation, whereas Ta-Ta-tap uses a series of consecutive distant taps to define a spatial gesture. We verified the feasibility of both interaction techniques through a series of experiments and a user study. The high recognition rate of Ta-tap and Ta-Ta-tap gestures, the few conflicts with existing gestures, and the positive feedback from the participants assert the potential of consecutive distant taps as a new design space to enrich touch screen interactions.

Title: Supporting Treatment of People Living with HIV / AIDS in Resource Limited Settings with IVRs
Author list: Anirudha Joshi, Mandar Rane, Debjani Roy, Nagraj Emmadi, Padma Srinivasan, N Kumarasamy, Sanjay Pujari, Davidson Solomon, Rashmi Rodrigues, DG Saple, Kamalika Sen, Els Veldeman, Romain Rutten
Author emails: anirudha@iitb.ac.in, mrane@iitb.ac.in, debjanir@gmail.com, nagrajmumba@gmail.com, padma.srinivasan90@gmail.com, kumarasamy@yrgcare.org, sanjaypujari@gmail.com, drdavidsonsolomon@rediffmail.com, rashmijr@gmail.com, clinic@drsaple.com, ksen@grameenfoundation.in, EVELDEMA@its.jnj.com, RRUTTEN@its.jnj.com
Abstract: We developed an interactive voice response (IVR) system called TAMA (Treatment Advice by Mobile Alerts) that provides treatment support to people living with HIV / AIDS (PLHA) in developing countries, who are on antiret-roviral therapy (ART). We deployed TAMA with 54 PLHA in 5 HIV clinics in India for a period of 12 weeks. During the study, we gathered feedback about TAMAâ€™s design and usage. Additionally, we conducted detailed qualitative in-terviews and analysed usage logs. We found that TAMA was usable and viable in the real life settings of PLHA and it had many desirable effects on their treatment adherence. We developed insights that inform the design of TAMA and some of these can be generalised to design of other long-term, frequent-use IVR applications for users in developing countries in the healthcare domain and beyond.

Title: Wearables and Chairables: Inclusive Design of Mobile Input and Output Techniques for Power Wheelchair Users
Author list: Patrick Carrington, Amy Hurst, Shaun K Kane
Abstract: Power wheelchair users often use and carry multiple mobile computing devices. Many power wheelchair users have some upper body motor impairment that can make using these devices difficult. We believe that mobile device accessibility could be improved through designs that take into account usersâ€™ functional abilities and take advantage of available space around the wheelchair itself. In this paper we present findings from multiple design sessions and interviews with 13 power wheelchair users and 30 clinicians, exploring the placement and form factor possibilities for input and output on a power wheelchair. We found that many power wheelchair users could benefit from chairable technology that is designed to work within the workspace of the wheelchair, whether worn on the body or mounted on he wheelchair frame. We present participantsâ€™ preferences for chairable input and output devices, and identify possible design configurations for wearable and chairable devices.

Title: Structured Labeling for Facilitating Concept Evolution in Machine Learning
Author list: Todd Kulesza, Saleema Amershi, Rich Caruana, Danyel Fisher, Denis Charles
Abstract: Labeling data is a seemingly simple task required for training many machine learning systems, but is actually fraught with problems. This paper introduces the notion of concept evolution, the changing nature of a person's underlying concept (the abstract notion of the target class a person is labeling for, e.g., spam email, travel related web pages) which can result in inconsistent labels and thus be detrimental to machine learning. We introduce two structured labeling solutions, a novel technique we propose for helping people define and refine their concept in a consistent manner as they label. Through a series of five experiments, including a controlled lab study, we illustrate the impact and dynamics of concept evolution in practice and show that structured labeling helps people label more consistently in the presence of concept evolution than traditional labeling.

Title: More Than Touch: Understanding How People Use Skin as an Input Surface for Mobile Computing
Author list: Martin Weigel, Vikram Mehta, JÃ_rgen Steimle
Abstract: This paper contributes results from an empirical study of on-skin input, an emerging technique for controlling mobile devices. Skin is fundamentally different from off-body touch surfaces, opening up a new and largely unexplored interaction space. We investigate characteristics of the various skin-specific input modalities, analyze what kinds of gestures are performed on skin, and study what are preferred input locations. Our main findings show that (1) users intuitively leverage the properties of skin for a wide range of more expressive commands than on conventional touch surfaces; (2) established multi-touch gestures can be transferred to on-skin input; (3) physically uncomfortable modalities are deliberately used for irreversible commands and expressing negative emotions; and (4) the forearm and the hand are the most preferred locations on the upper limb for on-skin input. We detail on usersâ€™ mental models and contribute a first consolidated set of on-skin gestures. Our findings provide guidance for developers of future sensors as well as for designers of future applications of on-skin input.

Title: Expert Voices in Echo Chambers: Effects of Source Expertise Indicators on Exposure to Diverse Opinions
Author list: Q. Vera Liao, Wai-Tat Fu
Abstract: We studied how a source expertise indicator impacted usersâ€™ information seeking behavior when using a system aggregating diverse opinions, and how it interacted with a source position indicator to shape usersâ€™ selectivity of information. We found that, for both attitude consistent and inconsistent information, the expertise indicator increased the selection of sources indicated to have high expertise and decreased that of low expertise. Moreover, when both source expertise and position indicators were present, usersâ€™ selective exposure tendency, i.e., preferential selection of attitude consistent sources over inconsistent ones, decreased among expert sources. Moreover, we found that the expertise indicator could serve the purpose of encouraging common ground seeking with different others by increasing the agreement with, and perceived expertise of inconsistent sources indicated to be experts. Design implications for moderating selective exposure by highlighting the utility of dissonant information were discussed.

Title: Extracting References Between Text and Charts via Crowdsourcing
Author list: Nicholas Kong, Marti A Hearst, Maneesh Agrawala
Abstract: News articles, reports, blog posts and academic papers often include \ graphical charts that serve to visually reinforce arguments presented \ in the text. \ To help readers better understand the relation between the text and \ the chart, we present a crowdsourcing pipeline to extract the \ references between them. Specifically, we give crowd workers \ paragraph-chart pairs and ask them to select text phrases as well as \ the corresponding visual marks in the chart. \ We then apply \ automated clustering and merging techniques to unify the  \ references generated by multiple workers into a single set. \ Comparing the crowdsourced references to a set of gold standard \ references using a distance measure based on the F1 score, we find \ that the average distance between the raw set of references produced \ by a single worker and the gold standard is 0.54 (out of a \ max of 1.0).  When we apply clustering and merging techniques the \ average distance between the unified set of references and the gold \ standard reduces to 0.39; an improvement of 27%. \ We conclude with an interactive document viewing application that uses the \ extracted references; readers can select phrases in the \ text and the system highlights the related marks in the chart.

Title: Direct Drawing on 3D Shapes with Automated Camera Control
Author list: Michael Ortega, Thomas Vincent
Abstract: We present ACCD, an interaction technique that allows direct drawing of long curves on 3D shapes with a tablet display over both multiple depth layers and multiple viewpoints. ACCD reduces the number of explicit viewpoint manipulations by combining self-occlusion management and automated camera control. As such it enables drawing on occluded faces but also around a 3D shape while keeping a constant drawing precision. Our experimental results indicates the efficacy of ACCD over conventional techniques.

Title: MouStress: Detecting Stress from Mouse Motion
Author list: David Sun, John Canny, Pablo Paredes
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department
Abstract: Stress causes and exacerbates many physiological and mental \ health problems. Routine and unobtrusive monitoring of \ stress would enable a variety of treatments, from break-taking \ to calming exercises. It may also be a valuable tool for assessing \ effects (frustration, difficulty) of using interfaces or \ applications. Custom sensing hardware is a poor option, because \ of the need to buy/wear/use it continuously, even before \ stress-related problems are evident. Here we explore stress \ measurement from common computer mouse operations. We \ use a simple model of arm-hand dynamics that captures muscle \ stiffness during mouse movement. We show that the \ within-subject mouse-derived stress measure is quite strong, \ even compared to concurrent physiological sensor measurements. \ While our study used fixed mouse tasks, the stress signal \ was still strong even when averaged across widely varying \ task geometries. We argue that mouse sensing â€œin the wildâ€ù \ may be feasible, by analyzing frequently-performed operations \ of particular geometries.

Title: Diversity for Design: A Framework for Involving Neurodiverse Children in the Technology Design Process
Author list: Laura Benton, Asimina Vasalou, Rilla Khaled, Hilary Johnson, Daniel Gooch
Abstract: The neurodiversity movement seeks to positively reframe certain neurological conditions, such as autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and dyslexia, by concentrating on their strengths. In recent years, neurodiverse children have increasingly been involved in the technology design process, but the design approaches adopted have focused mostly on overcoming difficulties of working with these children, leaving their strengths untapped. We present a new participatory design (PD) framework, Diversity for Design (D4D), which provides guidance for technology designers working with neurodiverse children in establishing PD methods that capitalize on childrenâ€™s strengths and also support potential difficulties. We present two case studies of use of the D4D framework, involving children with ASD and dyslexia, showing how it informed the development and refinement of PD methods tailored to these populations. In addition, we show how to apply the D4D framework to other neurodiverse populations.

Summary of Changes: Summary of Changes \  \ 1.	R2 and R4 requested that we clarify why we used the term framework and not method. This has been clarified in the last paragraph in section â€˜D4D: A Framework for Neurodiversity in PDâ€™ which states: \ â€œWe intentionally employ the term framework, as opposed to method or tool, as the term reflects the necessary flexibility D4D provides designers in developing methods appropriate to their specific context and constraints, whereas method implies more rigidity and precise replication. In considering designersâ€™ agency and need for flexibility in conducting design research, the D4D framework guides them in tailoring their PD methods to enable the participation of neurodiverse populations. â€œ  \  \ 2.	R3 questions how D4D innovates over the TEACCH approach. We have clarified this within the Discussion section, making our specific contribution of adapting the original TEACCH framework clearer within the first paragraph, which states: \ â€œOur contribution is not in developing a novel PD method, as many of the features we identified in our neurodiverse PD methods are not novel. Rather it is the adaptation of the TEACCH education principles as a design framework that scaffolds designers in the creation of new PD methods for children with a range of neurodiverse conditions, guiding them to identify the specific combination of PD features most appropriate for their target population. The implications of our work are three-fold.â€ù \  \ 3.	R3 was concerned about the provision of evidence about certain claims and wanted a deeper analysis of fewer points of the framework. We have therefore re-written the third paragraph of our Practice-Informed PD: one-to-one workshops section, to ensure our findings were not over-stated, which now states:  \ â€œHowever, once we changed our protocol to incorporate example ideas and partially completed interface designs, children were able to expand on the ideas given, and in some cases generate their own idea(s) where previously they had been unable to do so.â€œ \ We have also included some of the questions raised by R3 within the fifth paragraph of the discussion section, which states: \ â€œAs systematically evaluating the outcomes of this framework is beyond the scope of this work, it would be valuable if designers using D4D evaluated and reported on the outcomes of their methods with different populations; potentially considering the quantity, quality and/or novelty of ideas generated using their method.â€ù \  \ 4.	R1 suggests that we should be more specific about how attention to the specific strengths is deployed. We have therefore added in a section about the strengths of children with ASD within the third paragraph of the Theoretically-informed PD section, which states: \ â€œChildren with ASD often have exceptional knowledge or skills in areas related to their special interests [22] and therefore integrating these into the design process allows them to contribute their knowledge/skills. â€œ \  \ 5.	Both R1 and R4 raise concerns about the balance between the positive and negative within the paper. To address this point, we have added in the characteristic difficulties associated with the neurodiverse conditions within Table 1.  \  \ 6.	R1 also requests for the role of the designer to be defined and clarified within the paper. We have clarified that one of the researchers undertook the role of an interaction designer within the case studies as requested by R1 within the first paragraph of the Practice-informed PD sections for both case studies. \  \ 8.	We have briefly indicated the design activities that the children are more suited to participating in, as mentioned by R1, within the first paragraph of the Discussion section, which states: \ â€œWe found that children were most suited to contributing ideas and evaluating different design options. However, as some children also had extensive technical knowledge/skills, they additionally had the potential to contribute towards assessing technical feasibility and developing design prototypes.â€ù \  \ 9.	We have reordered the Introduction as advised by R2 and switched the first two paragraphs. \  \ 10.	R2 suggested moving the worked example of the framework for ADHD to earlier in the paper and we have a created a new section before the Discussion section called Adapting the D4D Framework and included this example here. \  \ 11.	R1 recommended that the attention points in small caps be organised into a checklist style table, but as these already corresponded to the boxes within the D4D framework (Figs 2 + 3) we have instead numbered the points in the text and the associated boxes in the figures to highlight this correspondence. \  \ 12.	R1 highlights the link with the work of Van Rijn, we have therefore referenced this work in the final paragraph of the paper, which states: \ â€œThis draws parallels with the work of Van Rijn [25] who highlights the challenges of designers working with â€˜extremeâ€™ user groups they share little in common with, and how insights from designing with one particular group can actually contribute to an understanding of how to design for any user group.â€œ \  \ 13.	R5 suggests parallels with the Harder et al. paper from Design Issues and the concept of â€˜designing forâ€™ versus â€˜designing withâ€™, which we have referenced this work in the first paragraph of the Discussion section, which states: \ â€œFurthermore, within PD, participants can play multiple roles, at various levels of involvement [17]. Title: Design Tactics for Authentic Interactive Fiction: Insights from Alternate Reality Game Designers
Author list: Elizabeth Bonsignore, Vicki Moulder, Carman Neustaedter, Derek Hansen, kari kraus kraus, Allison Druin
Author emails: ebonsign@umd.edu, vmoulder@sfu.ca, carman_neustaedter@sfu.ca, dlhansen@byu.edu, karimkraus@gmail.com, allisond@umiacs.umd.edu
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: Ira A. Fulton College of Engineering and Technology, Brigham Young University
Abstract: This paper presents insights from designers of Alternate Reality Games (ARGs) regarding the design tactics they employ to integrate participatory storytelling and â€œauthentic fictionâ€ù into the transmedia experiences they create. Our approach was motivated by recent efforts in HCI to more closely align the development of interaction design theory to the craft knowledge and experiences of designers themselves. The resulting insights enhance our understanding of design approaches that a diverse group of ARG producers follow to create interactive, participatory narratives. We outline narrative-specific themes to support designers who craft similar interactive experiences.

Title: â€œHealthifyingâ€ù Exergames: Improving Health Outcomes through Intentional Priming
Author list: Frank X. Chen, Abby C. King, Eric B. Hekler
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: School of Nutrition and Health Promotion
Abstract: Exergames, video game systems that require exertion and interaction, have been rising in popularity in the past years. However, research on popular exergames shows mixed health benefits, potentially due to minimal energy expenditure and decreasing use over time. This paper presents a 2x2 experimental study (N = 44), using a popular exergame, where we vary the framing of intention (i.e., â€œGameplayâ€ù or â€œExerciseâ€ù) and feedback (i.e., â€œHealthâ€ù or â€œNo healthâ€ù) to explore their single and interactive impacts on perceived exertion, objectively measured energy expenditure, affect, and duration of usage in a single session. Our study showed that participants primed with exercise used the system significantly longer than those primed with game play (M = 49.2 Â±2.0 min versus M = 39.3 Â±2.0 min). We discuss our results and possible design implications based on our single-session experiment. We conclude with a discussion on the potential impact of focusing on â€œhealthifyingâ€ù exergamesâ€”highlighting an exergamesâ€™ dual purpose as both a game and exerciseâ€”as opposed to gamifying health behaviors.

Title: Photo Sharing of the Subject, by the Owner, for the Viewer â€“ Examining the Subjectâ€™s Preference
Author list: Auk Kim, Gahgene Gweon
Abstract: Photo sharing activities on social networking sites concern not only the person sharing the information (owner) and the person receiving the information (viewer) but also the person who is in the photo (subject). In our exploratory lab study, we asked 29 participants about their comfort level in allowing a photo owner to share a picture containing both the participant (subject) and the owner. Our results show that the photo subject feels more comfortable in sharing a photo when i) the â€œcloseness between the subject and the owner (SO closeness)â€ù is higher, and ii) the â€œcloseness between the subject and the viewer (SV closeness)â€ù is higher. In addition, we observed that both SV and SO closeness are important in determining the subjectâ€™s picture sharing preference level.

Title: Being Senior and ICT: A Study of Seniors Using ICT in China
Author list: Yuling Sun, Xianghua Ding, Silvia Lindtner, Tun Lu, Ning Gu
Abstract: System design for seniors often focuses on the decline of their biological capabilities and social connectedness. This approach has been challenged as too simplistic to capture what it really means to be senior. This paper presents a qualitative study of 17 seniors in urban China (age ranging from 50s to 70s), who have adopted and incorporated ICT into their daily lives. Findings from this study show that the ways in which seniors attend to ICT are not simply shaped by changes in health or other wellbeing, but also by their life attitudes, value systems, relationships to younger generations as well as historical specifics during their coming of age. This paper contributes by showing that 1) what it means to be senior is shaped from within a whole social ecology of past and current experiences, values and interactions; 2) senior identities are not fixed, but continuously negotiated, articulated and enacted through ICT; 3) social interaction and access of technologies are highly intertwined.

Title: ThumbReels: Query Sensitive Web Video Previews Based on Temporal, Crowdsourced, Semantic Tagging
Author list: Barnaby Craggs, Myles Kilgallon Scott, Jason Alexander
Abstract: During online search, the user's expectations often differ from those of the  author. This is known as the `intention gap' and is particularly problematic when searching for and discriminating between online video content. An author uses description and meta-data tags to label their content, but often cannot predict alternate interpretations or appropriations of their work. To address this intention gap, we present ThumbReels, a concept for query-sensitive video previews generated from crowdsourced, temporally defined semantic tagging. Further, we supply an open-source tool that supports on-the-fly temporal tagging of videos, whose output can be used for later search queries. A first user study validates the tool and concept. We then present a second study that shows participants found ThumbReels to better represent search terms than contemporary preview techniques.

Title: Walk this Way: Musically Guided Walking Experiences
Author list: Adrian Hazzard, Steve Benford, Gary Burnett
Abstract: Musical soundtracks will be important features of future locative experiences from tours to games. We present a study designed to uncover potential relationships between higher-level musical structures such as harmony, melody, timbre, dynamic intensity and punctuation and usersâ€™ spatial experiences. We observed twenty-two participants exploring an open field while listening to four contrasting musical compositions, and then interviewed them afterwards. We report their different approaches to interpreting the music, strategies for mapping zones, choice of stopping destinations, and their awareness and appreciation of the music. Our discussion of these findings in relation to the literature leads us to propose six initial principles to guide the composition of mobile and locative soundtracks, and also to articulate a three-layer framework of global, regional and local attachment to help guide the attachment of musical features to different regions within a locative experience.

Title: Designing For Movement: Evaluating Computational Models using LMA Effort Qualities
Author list: Diego Silang Maranan, Sarah Fdili Alaoui, Thecla Schiphorst, Philippe Pasquier, Pattarawut Subyen
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Art and Technology
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Arts and Technology
Abstract: While single-accelerometers are a common consumer embedded sensors, their use in representing movement data as an intelligent resource remains scarce. Accelerometers have been used in movement recognition systems, but rarely to assess expressive qualities of movement. We present a prototype of wearable system for the real-time detection and classification of movement quality using acceleration data. The system applies Laban Movement Analysis (LMA) to recognize Laban Effort qualities from acceleration input using a Machine Learning software that generates classifications in real time. Existing LMA-recognition systems rely on motion capture data and video data, and can only be deployed in controlled settings. Our single-accelerometer system is portable and can be used under a wide range of environmental conditions. We evaluate the performance of the system, present two applications using the system in the digital arts and discuss future directions.

Summary of Changes: Revision report of submission #1579:  \ Designing For Movement: Evaluating Computational Models using LMA Effort Qualities \  \ We would like to thank the Meta-reviewer and all the reviewers for their positive and encouraging remarks and for their suggestions and critiques.  We report hereafter on the modifications that we made in preparation for final submission of our paper.  \  \ 1) As suggested by the Meta-reviewer, we added a sentence in the introduction (paragraph 2, page 2) about the "handing over" feature of our system: "The advantage of using accelerometers is that they are small and thus highly portable, and can be used under a wide range of environmental conditions including interactive installations targeting general public audience, interactive performances or mobile applications. In such conditions, a compelling feature of single-accelerometer systems is their pervasive ability to pragmatically 'hand over' interaction capability between users. Our approach to selecting single-accelerometer systems emphasizes the often precarious and critical temporal transactions between users. Interaction designers may trade-off the recognition accuracy from multiple accelerometers systems for the ease and simple handing over of one accelerometer between users. This is a key pervasive feature for Art settings, as well as mobile device uses." \  \ 2) We addressed the issue of the motivation of our work in regards of the use of a single-accelerometer by adding a first sentence in the Abstract, and a full paragraph in the Introduction (paragraph 2, page 2). \  \ 3) We indicated at the end section of our paper the benefits of our approach and its potential for application areas. Title: VacuumTouch: Attractive Force Feedback Interface for Haptic Interactive Surface using Air Suction
Author list: Taku Hachisu, masaaki fukumoto
Abstract: We present VacuumTouch, a novel haptic interface architecture for touch screens that provides attractive force feedback to the userâ€™s finger. VacuumTouch consists of an air pump and solenoid air valves that connect to the surface of the touch screen and suck the air above the surface where the userâ€™s finger makes contact. VacuumTouch does not require the user to hold or attach additional devices to provide the attractive force, which allows for easy interaction with the surface. This paper introduces the implementation of the VacuumTouch architecture and some applications for enhancement of the graphical user interface, namely a suction button, a suction slider, and a suction dial. The quantitative evaluation was conducted with the suction dial and showed that the attractive force provided by VacuumTouch improved the performance of the dial menu interface and its potential effects. At the end of this paper, we discuss the current prototypeâ€™s advantages and limitations, as well as possible improvements and potential capabilities.

Title: ISSE: An Interactive Source Separation Editor
Non-embedded fonts: Times-Roman Helvetica Helvetica-BoldOblique Helvetica Helvetica-BoldOblique Helvetica Helvetica-BoldOblique Helvetica Helvetica-BoldOblique Helvetica Helvetica-BoldOblique
Author list: Nicholas J Bryan, Gautham J Mysore, Ge Wang
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics
Abstract: Traditional audio editing tools do not facilitate the task of separating a single mixture recording (e.g. pop song) into its respective sources (e.g. drums, vocal, etc.).  Such ability, however, would be very useful for a wide variety of audio applications such as music remixing, audio denoising, and audio-based forensics. To address this issue, we present ISSE--an interactive source separation editor.  ISSE is a new open-source, freely available, and cross-platform audio editing tool that enables a user to perform  source separation by painting on time-frequency visualizations of sound, resulting in an interactive machine learning system.  The system brings to life our previously proposed interaction paradigm and separation algorithm that learns from user-feedback to perform separation. For evaluation, we conducted user studies and compared results between inexperienced and expert users.  For a variety of real-world tasks, we found that inexperienced users can achieve good separation quality with minimal instruction and expert users can achieve state-of-the-art separation quality.

Title: DemoWiz: Re-Performing Software Demonstrations for a Live Presentation
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial Times_New_Roman,BoldItalic Arial,Italic
Author list: Pei-Yu Chi, Bongshin Lee, Steven Drucker
Abstract: Showing a live software demonstration during a talk can be engaging, but it is often not easy: presenters may struggle with (or worry about) unexpected software crashes and encounter issues such as mismatched screen resolutions or faulty network connectivity. Furthermore, it can be difficult to recall the steps to show while talking and operating the system all at the same time. An alternative is to present with pre-recorded screencast videos. It is, however, challenging to precisely match the narration to the video when using existing video players. We introduce DemoWiz, a video presentation system that provides an increased awareness of upcoming actions through glanceable visualizations. DemoWiz supports better control of timing by overlaying visual cues and enabling lightweight editing. A user study shows that our design significantly improves the presentersâ€™ perceived ease of narration and timing compared to a system without visualizations that was similar to a standard playback control. Furthermore, nine (out of ten) participants preferred DemoWiz over the standard playback control with the last expressing no preference.

Title: The Routines and Needs of Grandparents and Parents for Grandparent-Grandchild Conversations Over Distance
Author list: Azadeh Forghani, Carman Neustaedter
Abstract: A variety of systems have been designed to support communication between distance-separated grandparents and grandchildren. Yet there are few studies of the actual conversational routines of these groups as well as the social challenges that might arise as a result of technology usage. To address this gap, we conducted an interview and diary study that explores the conversational practices of distance-separated grandparents and young grandchildren (aged 3-10) from the perspective of the grandparents and parents of the children. Our results describe the focus of grandparent-grandchild conversations and show that grandparent-grandchild communication is not without its challenges: grandparents sometimes feel self-conscious, perceive that parents or children will be annoyed if they ask too many questions, and do not want to interfere too much in their grandchildrenâ€™s lives. The implication is that designs should attempt to support the conversation routines and needs of grandparents and grandchildren while attempting to mitigate the social challenges.

Title: Smart Subtitles for Vocabulary Learning
Author list: Geza Kovacs, Robert C Miller
Abstract: Language learners often use subtitled videos to help them learn. However, standard subtitles are geared more towards comprehension than vocabulary learning, as translations are nonliteral and are provided only for phrases, not vocabulary. This paper presents Smart Subtitles, which are interactive subtitles tailored towards vocabulary learning. Smart Subtitles can be automatically generated from common video sources such as subtitled DVDs. They provide features such as vocabulary definitions on hover, and \ dialog-based video navigation. In our pilot study with intermediate learners studying Chinese, participants correctly defined over twice as many new words in a post-viewing vocabulary test when they used Smart Subtitles, compared to dual Chinese-English subtitles. Learners spent the same amount of time watching clips with each tool, and enjoyed viewing videos with Smart Subtitles as much as with dual subtitles. Learners understood videos equally well using either tool, as indicated by self-assessments \ and independent evaluations of their summaries.

Title: i-dentity: Innominate Movement Representation as Engaging Game Element
Author list: Jayden Garner, Gavin Wood, Sebastiaan Pijnappel, Martin Murer, Florian Mueller
Abstract: Movement-based digital games typically make it clear whose movement representation belongs to which player. In contrast, we argue that selectively concealing whose movement controls which representation can facilitate engaging play experiences. We call this â€œinnominate movement representationâ€ù and explore this opportunity through our game â€œi-dentityâ€ù, where players have to guess who makes everyoneâ€™s controller light up based on his/her movements. Our work reveals five dimensions for the design of innominate movement representation: concealing the association between movement and representation; number of represented movements; number of players with representations; location of representation in relation to the body and technical attributes of representation. We also present five strategies for how innominate representation can be embedded into a play experience. With our work we hope to expand the range of digital movement games.

Author Keywords: Movement representation; ambiguity; digital play; game design; engagement; social play; entertainment
Thumbnail Image Caption: Presents a new interaction technique for digital game design, where representation of players' actions is made ambiguous to facilitate engaging experiences.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Presents a new interaction technique for digital game design, where representation of players' actions is made ambiguous to facilitate engaging experiences.
Summary of Changes: List of changes \ Paper 1626 â€“ i-dentity: Innominate Movement Representation as Engaging Game Element \  \ To the reviewers \ We would like to gratefully thank the reviewers for their detailed feedback, which we have taken to heart in order to improve the paper. Below we have listed the changes made, categorized by section and generally listed by occurrence in the paper. We have tried to address the reviewersâ€™ concerns to the best of our abilities and provided additional details where data and page limit allowed us to do. We thank the reviewers for their consideration. \  \ ABSTRACT \ Updated dimension 2 name change accordingly. \  \ INTRODUCTION \ No changes. \  \ RELATED WORK \ 1) R5 wanted resources on ambiguous design and indirect sensor mappings to position our work. \  \ Changes done: We added a couple of lines to discuss ambiguity in HCI, explaining the position of our work in relation to existing work on ambiguity as follows: â€œ Gaver et al.â€™s work [8] shows how incorporating ambiguity into the design of interactive systems can have intriguing, mysterious, and delightful outcomes, such as the ambiguity of using indirect sensor mappings of embodied interaction (e.g. [1]), unconventional mappings for reflection on the unexpected (e.g. [24]), or exploring the interpretive space of embodied and situated aspects of interaction that results in physical play facilitating discovery (e.g. [29]). Thus, we were inspired to extend the notion of ambiguous interaction design to the representation of movement to uncover whether having an unclear relationship between movement and representation can facilitate engaging play experiences.â€ù \  \ 2) R4 suggested Marquez et al.â€™s work on effect of technological support on player judgment in body games. \  \ Changes done: We added this near the end of the related work section as follows: â€œTechnological support for such types of physical play experiences is minimal, with an often-increased reliance on player judgement (e.g. [17]).â€ù \  \ USING INNOMINATE MOVEMENT REPRESENTATION AS A DIGITAL GAME ELEMENT \ No changes. \  \ STUDY \ 1) R4 desired explanation on specifics of number of rounds & people who played at each venue. \  \ Changes done: We added the following lines to the â€œparticipantsâ€ù subsection: â€œ8 rounds were played at each venue, at a total of 4 venues, with each venue having between 5-7 participants. Overall, this meant the game was played 32 times during our study.â€ù \  \ 2) R4 asked about the players selecting roles during the study. \  \ Changes done: We added the following lines to the â€œprocedureâ€ù subsection: â€œWe ensured everyone played every role in the game, so that all players could reflect on these roles during the interviews. Our encouragement to play every role is obviously not present in non-study contexts; however, we believe the benefit of our approach of having everyone play each role gave us the advantage of a diverse range of feedback.â€ù \  \ 3) R4 asked about the rigor that went into the process of extracting findings from the data. \  \ Changes done: We added the following to â€œdata gathering and analysisâ€ù: â€œFirstly, the primary author watched all video recordings of people playing i-dentity. The author took notes while watching all of the gameplay recordings 3 times as suggested by grounded theory [28]. Secondly, the author watched the video recordings of the interviews 3 times. Again, the author took notes. Finally, the primary author went back and watched the video recordings of people playing i-dentity to check with the notes taken during the interview recordings. After each stage of this process, the primary author gathered with the other authors to discuss the notes taken. At these meetings, interim analysis results were presented and debated. This helped to develop and refine findings. We used an open-ended process of rapid reflection [21] to discuss ideas and concepts that had emerged. The findings emerging from the data were heavily questioned, debated and discussed. \  \ The resulting higher-level concepts were discussed amongst the group and then presented to 10 games researchers to gather feedback. The outcome was subsequently checked with 8 of the study participants (those who where available, so a selection bias might have occurred), refined and reviewed again by the authors.â€ù \  \ FINDINGS \ No changes. \  \ DESIGN DIMENSIONS \ 1) R5 requested our work to incorporate existing resources on ambiguous design and indirect mappings. \  \ Changes done: We added the following to Dimension 1 to better situate our work by integrating the resources suggested by R5: â€œWhile most movement-based systems are designed using a direct mapping of the playersâ€™ movements to digital representations, i-dentity extends the notion of ambiguous design to show how this mapping can be purposely obscured to facilitate an engaging play experience. This rather unconventional method of mapping input to output reminds us of Rogers et al.â€™s Snark system [24] that uses ambient technologies to explore the concept of the unexpected to foster reflection. Similarly, Gaver et al.â€™s work on ambiguous design [8] suggests benefits of employing ambiguity in mappings between input and output when designing interactive systems, with an example being Antle et al.â€™s whole-body system [1], which deploys ambiguous design through indirect mappings of embodied interaction. We extend this thinking to game design and showed with i-dentity some benefits to having movements conceal associations between movement and representation.â€ù \  \ 2) R1 found Dimension 2 was confusing due to the mixing up of sensors and representations. \  \ Changes done: We edited our title to more clearly communicate Dimension 2 to: â€œNumber of Represented Movementsâ€ù. We also edited the description of dimension 2 to the following: â€œOur second dimension looks at the extent to which designers adjust the number of represented vs. non-represented movements. The two poles of this dimension are made up of either having one playerâ€™s movement represented on one end or having multiple playersâ€™ movements represented on the other. Although we opted for a single playerâ€™s sensed movement representation to be copied across to other playersâ€™ controllers (Fig.18), designs could alternatively represent all players in a system and just be unclear as to who is controlling which representation. Prior work has shown how multiplayer movement-based games use interactive technology to enable rich social play [12] and this can occur by giving players shared control of one representation (e.g. [11]). We now describe different options designers have for mapping input to output by having either one movement representation or multiple movements represented.â€ù \  \ The dimension 2.1 and 2.2 names were changed to reflect the dimension 2 edits to the following: â€œDimension 2.1: One movement representedâ€ù and â€œDimension 2.2: Multiple movements representedâ€ù. \  \ Furthermore, we added Fig. 18 to help better illustrate this design concept. \  \ DESIGN STRATEGIES \ No changes. \  \ EXTENDING THE APPLICATION OF INNOMINATE MOVEMENT REPRESENTATION IN GAME DESIGN \ 1) All reviewers wanted to know how innominate movement representation could be applied to games outside of i-dentity. \  \ Changes done: We added a new section titled â€œExtending the Application of Innominate Movement Representation in Game Designâ€ù. This section details practical game ideas of using our innominate mechanic in various â€˜application domainsâ€™, with descriptions of these proposed games under the following subsections: â€œExtending innominate representations through shared avatar control to facilitate social playâ€ù, â€œUsing innominate representations could be useful to foster awareness of physical activity while addressing privacy concernsâ€ù, â€œExtending innominate gameplay through orientation of bodies in relation to a screen as engaging elementâ€ù, and â€œExtending innominate interaction design with alternate input methods while facilitating knowledge of own and anotherâ€™s bodyâ€ù. \  \ CONCLUSION \ No changes. \  \ REFERENCES \ References were updated accordingly.

Title: TouchSense: Expanding Touchscreen Input Vocabulary Using Different Areas of Users' Finger Pads
Author list: Da-Yuan Huang, Ming-Chang Tsai, Ying-Chao Tung, Min-Lun Tsai, Yen-Ting Yeh, Liwei Chan, Yi-Ping Hung, Mike Y. Chen
Author emails: dayuansmile@gmail.com, cknomber1@gmail.com, tony61507@gmail.com, tsai.danny602@gmail.com, allenyeh1105@gmail.com, liwei.name@gmail.com, hung@csie.ntu.edu.tw, mikechen@csie.ntu.edu.tw
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 6 - Dep: Research Center for Information Technology Innovation (CITI)
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 7 - Dep: Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 8 - Dep: Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia
Abstract: We present TouchSense, which provides additional touchscreen input vocabulary by distinguishing the areas of usersâ€™ finger pads contacting the touchscreen. It requires minimal touch input area and minimal movement, making it especially ideal for wearable devices such as smart watches and smart glasses. For example, users of a calculator application on a smart watch could tap normally to enter numbers, and tap with the right side of their fingers to enter the operators (e.g. +, -, =). Results from two human-factor studies showed that users could tap a touchscreen with five or more distinct areas of their finger pads. Also, they were able to tap with more distinct areas closer to their fingertips. We developed a TouchSense smart watch prototype using inertial measurement sensors, and developed two example applications: a calculator and a text editor. We also collected user feedback via an explorative study.

Summary of Changes: According to the reviewersâ€™ comments and rebuttals, we have done the following improvements for the final version of our paper: \  \ 1. Title: Gifting Personal Interpretations in Galleries
Author list: Lesley Fosh, Steve Benford, Stuart Reeves, Boriana Koleva
Abstract: The designers of mobile guides for museums and galleries face three major challenges: fostering rich interpretation, delivering deep personalization, and enabling a coherent social visit. We propose an approach to tackling all three simultaneously by inviting visitors to design an interpretation that is specifically tailored for a friend or loved one that they then experience together. We describe a trial of this approach at a contemporary art gallery, revealing how visitors designed personal and sometimes provocative experiences for people they knew well. We reveal how pairs of visitors negotiated these experiences together, showing how our approach could deliver intense experiences for both, but also required them to manage social risk. By interpreting our findings through the lens of â€˜gift givingâ€™ we shed new light on ongoing explorations of interpretation, personalization and social visiting within HCI.

Thumbnail Image Caption: Participants P1.a and P1.b using a personalized interactive experience in a gallery. P1.a (left) designed and gifted the experience for P1.b (right) and they are carrying it out together.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We invited visitors to design and gift personalized interpretations for a partner which they experienced together, to address the challenges of interpretation, personalization and social visiting in museums and galleries.
Summary of Changes: Rebuttal \  \ In our rebuttal we proposed to expand our introduction to include a review of the background literature on museum engagement within HCI. We have incorporated this within the existing structure around the challenges of â€˜Interpretationâ€™, â€˜Personalizationâ€™ and â€˜Socializationâ€™, referring to previous work we found most relevant to our own and the challenges we aim to address with our approach. We include a reference to Laaksolahti et al.â€™s work on the Lega system for sharing responses socially, and return to this in our discussion where we reflect on the differences (see â€˜How gift giving shapes socializationâ€™). \  \ We also proposed to expand on the implications of how our technique might be used in practice, including who it might be used by and how the approach could be streamlined for more practical use. In our final version, we have extended our â€˜Conclusionsâ€™ section to include â€˜Design Implicationsâ€™. Here we discuss the kinds of visitors we think might benefit most from our approach and why they might invest the time and effort required. We also point to the future challenge of delivering the approach at scale, such as how our design workshops could be replaced with an online service that could allow visitors to create and download experiences prior to their visit. \  \ We noted in our rebuttal that we needed to emphasise how our approach responds to recent trends in museum interpretation. We refer to Whitehead (2012) and Simon (2010) in our introduction to emphasise how it is becoming common for museums and galleries to invite visitors to engage with multiple interpretations or to create and share their own content around objects. \  \ Finally we proposed to clarify our position that the moments of discomfort experienced by our participants could be highly rewarding whilst not being typically pleasant. We come to this in our discussion, pointing out that cultural experiences with contemporary art can often be challenging, and refer to Benford et al.â€™s work which argues that there can be benefits to moments of discomfort in cultural experiences.  \  \ Discussion at PC Meeting \  \ We thank the PC members for the additional feedback and have incorporated the suggested changes as follows: \  \ The first point from the PC meeting asked us to talk more about how the experiences were constructed. We have responded firstly by including practical details of the design workshops in our â€˜Approachâ€™ section â€“ the specific resources available and examples of questions asked to participants to elicit ideas. Secondly, in our â€˜Findingsâ€™ section (â€˜An overview of the designsâ€™) we added details of how participants came to their design choices and where participants deviated from the experience template. Finally, we reiterate in our conclusions that by working with a predefined template, our participants were able to successfully design personalized experiences. \  \ The second point was that we should strengthen the motivation for our work. We have addressed this in our introduction by referring to recent trends in museum interpretation and the challenge of designing for the deceptive notion of an â€˜averageâ€™ visitor. We also point to the potential benefits of the approach in the penultimate paragraph of our introduction â€“ that our approach might address the issues of interpretation, personalization and socialization in an integrated way, and could lead to intense and personally meaningful engagement with cultural artifacts. \  \ The third point from the PC discussion was that we should be more reflective on what was learned from the study. To address this, we extended our â€˜Conclusionsâ€™ section to include â€˜Design Implicationsâ€™. Here we reflect on the kinds of visitors we think might benefit most from our approach and why. We return to reflect on the social risk inherent in some of the experiences designed, and consider how this could be mitigated in situations where the experience becomes problematic. We also reflect on future challenges, such as how our design workshops might be replaced with an online service and how experiences could be re-used or adapted. \  \ The final point asked us to describe the methodology used to analyse the data. We added a paragraph on â€˜Analysisâ€™ under â€˜Approachâ€™ which describes how we built a rich case study of each pair of participantsâ€™ engagement with our experience from start to finish, and particularly how we adopted an ethnographic approach to analyzing video data.  \  \ To accommodate the additional material we have removed what was previously Figure 1, a visual representation of one participantâ€™s design overlaid on the gallery floorplan. We also reduced the descriptions in Examples 1, 2 and 3. \

Title: Transient and Transitional States: Pressure as an Auxiliary Input Modality for Bimanual Interaction
Author list: Ross McLachlan, Daniel Boland, Stephen Brewster
Abstract: A novel investigation of pressure input is presented where it is characterised as a transient modality, one that has a natural inverse, bounce-back and a state that only persists during interaction. Three empirical studies are described that evaluate pressure for use as a non-dominant hand input modality, where the ability to target and maintain pressure while simultaneously performing a dominant-hand targeting task is investigated. Pressure accuracy was high (93%) and the impact on dominant-hand targeting was low. Mean pressure accuracy when selecting targets by releasing pressure was also high (89%) as was selecting targets by applying pressure from a non-zero starting point (94.4%). The ability to accurately maintain pressure over time was better with larger target pressures. Example applications and design guidelines are presented that enable designers to exploit the transient properties of pressure input in interaction design.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: A novel investigation of pressure input is presented where it is characterised as a transient modality, with three empirical studies to evaluate control in the context of bimanual interaction.
Summary of Changes: New Updates. \  \  \ * Explicitly focusing the work on the utility as opposed to the efficiency of pressure in the discussion works great.  However, I feel that this sentiment should be foreshadowed by a similar statement in the introduction under the "why pressure?" subsection. \  \  \ Added a statement in the last paragraph of the Why Pressure? Section.  \  \  \  \ * Seeing that you have space, I would also suggest you include the posture aspect as one of you early design constraints.  If you leave them to the end of the paper, they look more like accidents rather than design decisions/delimitations. \  \ Added in ref in opening para of introduction. \  \  \ * Eliminate page numbers for the final draft? \  \ Done. \  \  \  \ * The elimination of paragraph spacing in the introduction has caused awful typesetting on the first page.  Suggest you fix this.  \  \ Done. \  \  \ * Please order all multiple citations in ascending order; on page 3, there are three instances of "[20, 21, 13]", which should be "[13, 20, 21]".  Please check all other multiple citations as well. \ Done.  \  \  \ * You have an orphaned heading on the second page ("Background") as well as the fifth page ("Moving"), and there are quite a few widows in general throughout the paper.  For the sake of aesthetics, please try to clean this up.  \  \ Done. \  \  \ =========================================================== \  \ 1. Acknowledgment of the impact of posture. The experiment only \       tested a person sitting down and resting the tablet on their \       legs, but what about standing and walking? The authors will need \       to spend some space discussing the ecological validity and \       utility of their technique in such settings. \  \ This point was addressed by making clear that use in the home, and primarily while seated on the bed or couch, was the motivation for the work and that the results and guidelines are only applicable to this context. A reference was added ([10] in the paper) to support the claim that both the couch and bed are extremely common places for people to use such devices.  \  \  \ 2. A reasonable argument for the utility of pressure selection \       compared to standard touch. What is the overall utility of this \       idea? As the 2AC points out, a user can perform 3-5 taps in the \       time it takes to target a specific pressure. Is this more than a \       theoretical exercise, but one that has real-world utility? We are \       looking for a balanced discussion that acknowledges many of the \       limitations of this idea. \  \ A discussion of this point was included in the General Discussion section. We acknowledge the potential shortcoming of our technique, though state that pressure input has an inherent reversibility (the transient property) that could be useful in design. We state that future work will explore this trade-off between tapping efficiency and transient pressure using realistic applications.  \  \  \  \ 3. Eliminate the Media Navigation example application.  Both the 1AC \       and 2AC took issue with the vagueness of many of the \       applications, and this one in particular seemed rather \       far-fetched. This will also free up some space for other \       improvements. \  \ This example was removed and the Maps example was expanded slightly to include more scenarios. \  \  \  4. Update the design guidelines given the above caveats. These \       guidelines do not take into account the above comments on utility \       in terms of posture as well as selection time compared to taps. \       The authors may need to add additional design guidelines. \  \  \ We felt that with the new emphasis placed on the context as addressed in point 1, which was also stressed in a new sentence prior to the presentation of the guidelines, that they accurately reflect how well users can control pressure and what kind of interactions this could enable. The guidelines state nothing about efficiency (as compared to taps, for instance) but simply state how to use pressure to take advantage of what we call the transient properties. Our definition of transience focuses of reversibility and not efficiency and we feel they accurately reflect what we consider to be the best way to include transient pressure, as we currently understand it, into an interface. We are willing to work on this before the final deadline if necessary. \  \  \  \  5. Improvements in writing, spelling, and any missing references. \       Several reviewers complained about the sloppy state of the work, \       and fixing all of these issues is a clear condition for \       acceptance. \  \  \ The missing reference was added and the grammar, spelling and presentation was tidied up.

Title: Research on Research: Design Research at the Margins: Academia, Industry and End-Users
Author list: Juri Dachtera, Dave Randall, Volker Wulf
Abstract: Design research processes often take place in publicly funded projects. Besides designers and users, public funding increasingly requires industry partners to participate in such projects. We present empirical insights from a joint research project in order to assess the claims connected with such funding structures and to report on challenges for design research within them. We identify three themes of conflict between academic and industry partners and elaborate on the sources of them. The presentation of our results builds on the distinction between 'academia' and 'industry', which is frequently applied by political funding agencies. The analysis of the respective stakeholders' actual interests, however, will prove such a dichotomy to be misleading and simplistic.
