Title: Long Tail TV revisited: From ordinary camera phone use to Pro-Am video production
Author list: Oskar Juhlin, Arvid EngstrÃ¶m, Elin Ã–nnevall
Abstract: Pro-Am live video producers broadcast events on a regular basis. They are here selected for an ethnographic study since their continuous content generation can teach us something of what it takes for amateurs, who currently struggle with mastering the video medium, to become proficient producers. We learn from media theory that Pro-Ams are distinguished from professionals in terms of inherent skills and identities, and have therefore focused on these characteristics. We add to this research by showing on-going challenges that the former face in their production, i.e. how their learning practices, such as learning through instructions, are situated and related to particular settings. Learning and development of skills were done as organizations, rather than as individuals. Furthermore, the recurrent nature of both events and broadcasts appears to be an important condition for establishing the terms needed to carry out a production, and to learn the skills of a producer. This understanding may explain in part why accounts in previous research, of single users struggling with the affordances of live video, point to such diffiÂ¬culties in mastering the medium. The findings guide design to better support activities contiguous with the set-up of the production, rather than the broadcast per se.

Title: Let's Kick It: How to Stop Wasting the Bottom Third of your Large Screen Display
Author list: Ricardo Jota, Pedro Lopes, Daniel Wigdor, Joaquim A P Jorge
Abstract: Large-scale touch surfaces have been widely studied in literature and adopted for public installations such as interactive billboards. However, current designs do not take into consideration that touching the interactive surface at different heights is not the same; for body-height displays, the bottom portion of the screen is within easier reach of the foot than the hand. We explore the design space of foot input on vertical surfaces, and propose three distinct interaction modalities: hand, foot tapping, and foot gesturing. Our design exploration pays particular attention to areas of the touch surface that were previously overlooked: out of handâ€™s reach and close to the floor. We instantiate our design space with a working prototype of an interactive surface, in which we are able to distinguish between finger and foot tapping and extend the input area beyond the bottom of the display to support foot gestures.
References: 1. Augsten, T., Kaefer, K., Meusel, R., Fetzer, C., Kanitz, D., Stoff, T., Becker, T., Holz, C., and Baudisch, P. Title: A User Study of Different Gameplay Visualizations
Author list: Simone Kriglstein, GÃ_nter Wallner, Margit Pohl
Abstract: With the rising interest in multiplayer gaming, gameplay statistics have become an increasingly important aspect of the overall game experience for many players. As a part of this trend, visualizations have gained great popularity among players, in particular heatmaps since they allow them to reenact the course of a game and to develop new strategies. In this paper we report results of a user study conducted with 29 players (i) to investigate how players use heatmaps and two further graphical representations that use clustering algorithms to interpret gameplay and (ii) to assess the three representations in regard to time efficiency, correctness, suitability, and player preference. Our results show that heatmaps were mainly used to detect hot spots while the cluster representations proved useful to compare variables, allowing the players to uncover relationships between them and in turn allowing a deeper insight into the gameplay data.

Title: Performativity in Sustainable Interaction:  The Case of Seasonal Grocery Shopping in EcoFriends
Author list: Maria Normark, Jakob Tholander
Abstract: The EcoFriends application was developed as an attempt to support grocery shopping adjusted to vegetablesâ€™ seasonality through a performative approach to interaction and interactive applications. The design aimed at critical reflection and inspiration among users, rather than achieving a certain kind of persuasion. This guided the practical design to be modelled around open-endedness and social voices to challenge ideas and points of view. We argue that research addressing design for interactions about value-laden concepts such as sustainable action need to find ways of supporting various knowledge discourses, by distinguishing between performative and representational technologies. The approach allowed us to identify a number of design challenges regarding interactive technology and interaction design in relation to aspects of knowledge and truth, trust, negotiation and responsibility.

Title: Tensions in Scaling-up Community Social Media: A Multi-Neighborhood Study of Nextdoor
Author list: Christina Masden, Catherine Grevet, Rebecca Grinter, Eric Gilbert, W. Keith Edwards
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Computing and GVU Center
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Computing and GVU Center
Primary Affiliation 3 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Computing and GVU Center
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Computing and GVU Center
Primary Affiliation 5 - Department/Schoo: School of Interactive Computing and GVU Center
Abstract: This paper presents a study of Nextdoor, a social media system designed to support local neighborhoods. While not the first system designed to support community engagement, Nextdoor has a number of attributes that make it distinct. Our study, across three communities in a major U.S. city, illustrates that Nextdoor inhabits an already-rich ecosystem of community-oriented social media, but is being appropriated by its users for use in different ways than these existing media. Nextdoor also raises tensions in how it defines the boundaries of neighborhoods, and in the privacy issues it raises among its users.

Title: A Gaze-preserving Situated Multiview Telepresence System
Author list: ye pan, Anthony Steed
Abstract: Gaze, attention, and eye contact are important aspects of face to face communication, but some subtleties can be lost in videoconferencing because participants look at a single planar image of the remote user. We propose a low-cost cylindrical videoconferencing system that preserves gaze direction by providing perspective-correct images for multiple viewpoints around a conference table. We accomplish this by using an array of cameras to capture a remote person, and an array of projectors to present the camera images onto a cylindrical screen. The cylindrical screen reflects each image to a narrow viewing zone. The use of such a situated display allows participants to see the remote person from multiple viewing directions. We compare our system to three alternative display configurations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our system by showing it allows multiple participants to simultaneously tell where the remote person is placing their gaze.

Title: A Smartphone-based Sensing Platform to Model Aggressive Driving Behaviors
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial,Italic Arial Helvetica,Bold
Author list: Jin-Hyuk Hong, Ben Margines, Anind K. Dey
Abstract: Driving aggressively increases the risk of accidents. Assessing a personâ€™s driving style is a useful way to guide aggressive drivers toward having safer driving behaviors. A number of studies have investigated driving style, but they often rely on the use of self-reports or simulators, which are not suitable for the real-time, continuous, automated assessment and feedback on the road. In order to understand and model aggressive driving style, we construct an in-vehicle sensing platform that uses a smartphone instead of using heavyweight, expensive systems. Utilizing additional cheap sensors, our sensing platform can collect useful information about vehicle movement, maneuvering and steering wheel movement. We use this data and apply machine learning to build a driver model that evaluates driversâ€™ driving styles based on a number of driving-related features. From a naturalistic data collection from 22 drivers for 3 weeks, we analyzed the characteristics of drivers who have an aggressive driving style. Our model classified those drivers with an accuracy of 90.5% (violation-class) and 81% (questionnaire-class). We describe how, in future work, our model can be used to provide real-time feedback to drivers using only their current smartphone.

Title: Easy Does It:  More Usable CAPTCHAs
Author list: Elie Bursztein, Angelique Moscicki, Celine Fabry, Steven Bethard, John C. Mitchell, Dan Jurafsky
Author emails: elieb@google.com, moscicki@google.com, celine@celine.im, bethard@stanford.edu, jcm@stanford.edu, jurafsky@stanford.edu
Abstract: Websites present users with puzzles called CAPTCHAs to curb abuse caused by computer algorithms masquerading as people.  While CAPTCHAs are generally effective at stopping abuse, they might impair website usability if they are not properly designed. \  \ In this paper we describe how we designed two new CAPTCHA schemes for Google that focus on maximizing usability. We began by running an evaluation on Amazon Mechanical Turk with over 27,000 respondents to test the usability of different feature combinations. Then we studied user preferences using Google's consumer survey infrastructure. Finally, drawing on the insights gleaned during those studies, we tested our new captcha schemes first on Mechanical Turk and then on a fraction of production traffic.  The resulting scheme is now an integral part of our production system and is served to millions of users.  Our scheme achieved a 95.3\\% human accuracy, a 6.7\\%

Title: Understanding Sustained Community Engagement: A Case Study in Heritage Preservation in Rural Argentina
Author list: Mara Balestrini, Jon Bird, Paul Marshall, Alberto Zaro, Yvonne Rogers
Abstract: HCI projects are increasingly evaluating technologies in the wild, which typically involves working with communities over extended periods, often with the goal of effecting sustainable change. However, there are few descriptions of projects that have been successful in the long-term. In this paper we investigate what factors are important for developing long lasting community ICT interventions. We do this by analysing a successful action research project and provide five recommendations for facilitating sustained community engagement. CrowdMemo aimed to preserve local heritage in a town in rural Argentina and the project was set up so that it could be continued by the community once researchers had left. Participants created videos about personal memories of the town and over 600 people attended the premiere where they were first screened. The impact has not just been short-term and there has been sustained engagement with the project by stakeholders in the town and wider region: the local school integrated digital storytelling into its curriculum; the approach has been adopted by two nearby towns; and the project has influenced regional government educational policy.

Thumbnail Image Caption: A young student making a CrowdMemo microdocumentary.
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We investigate what factors are important for developing long-lasting community ICT interventions. We analyse CrowdMemo, a successful action research project, and provide five recommendations for facilitating sustained community engagement.
Summary of Changes: We have better positioned our study within the existing work by:  \ i. expanding the literature review to include other participatory and community projects, such as Cassiar (R5) and Blacksburg Electronic Village (R4); intergenerational storytelling (R1, R5); and the TOCHI special issue on â€œThe Turn To The Wildâ€ù. We have taken on board R1â€™s suggestion to better describe how CrowdMemo (CM) builds on existing action research, in particular the work of Hayes, Crabtree and Chamberlain. In order to make space to reference this work, we have removed figures 3 and 4. \  \ We have clarified the research contribution in 3 ways: \  \ a. By better showing how our work extends Taylor et al.â€™s Best Paper from CHIâ€™13, which identified the research challenges involved in sustaining community engagement with technology prototypes. We have restructured the introduction to expand on our description of Taylor et al.â€™s research along with other studies that have addressed the problem of sustained engagement in community ICT interventions. We have restructured the discussion where we now propose a set of five recommendations for facilitating sustained community engagement and extend Taylor et al.â€™s findings. \  \ b. We have clarified that â€œthis paper is much more than simply a case studyâ€ù (R4) by better explaining that it analyses an ICT intervention to investigate an important HCI research issue, namely, how to bring about sustained community engagement. We have highlighted that a significant contribution is how our project facilitated appropriation and we have provided more details on how the Ministry of Education evaluated CM.  \  \ c. We have restructured the paper. In the abstract we have signposted the research question, clarified our method and summarised the contribution. Following R1â€™s suggestions, we have rewritten the discussion in order to remove all new findings and include the five main recommendations for sustainable ICT interventions, along with the discussion of limitations (R4). We have discussed each recommendation and signposted how it builds on related literature. We have written a new conclusion section that shows how our recommendations answer the research question signposted in the abstract and introduction. \  \ Following R2's recommendation, we have signposted the quotes showing the importance of the intergenerational engagement for the participants. \  \ In response to R1â€™s concerns, we have provided more method information (e.g. 22 interviews were carried out). Following R6â€™s recommendation, we have provided more information about our action research approach and explained that we have conducted one action research cycle and that this paper is part of the reflection stage. Furthermore, we have described what some participants considered to be a limitation of the project, namely, the â€œshort duration of the training phaseâ€ù. \  \ Finally, we have corrected all typos, a paragraph repetition and two missing references highlighted by R2. \

Title: Towards Accurate and Practical Predictive Models of Active-Vision-Based Visual Search
Author list: David Kieras, Anthony Hornof
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Dept. of Computer Science and Information Science
Abstract: Being able to predict the performance of interface designs using models of human cognition and performance is a long-standing goal of HCI research. This paper presents recent advances in cognitive modeling which permit increasingly realistic and accurate predictions for visual human-computer interaction tasks such as icon search by incorporating an â€œactive visionâ€ù approach which emphasizes eye movements to visual features based on the availability of features in relationship to the point of gaze. A high fidelity model of a classic visual search task demonstrates the value of incorporating visual acuity functions into models of visual performance. The features captured by the high-fidelity model are then used to formulate a model simple enough for practical use, which is then implemented in an easy-to-use GLEAN modeling tool. Easy-to-use predictive models for complex visual search are thus feasible and should be further developed.

Author Keywords: Cognitive architecture; GOMS; human performance modeling; visual acuity; visual search
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: A cognitive architecture model for how long it takes to find icons on a display enables more accurate predictions of task performance from an easy-to-use GOMS-based tool.
Summary of Changes: Page numbers refer to the just-submitted pdf version.  \  \ In order to add some of the required material, we removed and tightened up material as follows: \  \ P. 1. We eliminated the duplicated paragraph pointed out by the reviewers. \  \ P. 2. We shortened the discussion of Williams's estimate of reaction times. \  \ P. 5. We tightened up the description of the availability functions in the model. \  \ References - we eliminated a few redundant ones and added additional ones, including the previous presentation of a subset of the modeling results pointed out by one of the reviewers, and an additional real-world reference. \  \ In several other places, we've tightened up the discussion, taking into account some of the other remarks by the reviewers as well as the specific issues called out by the meta-review. \  \ Below are how we addressed the meta-review issues, re-ordered to group related items together, our original rebuttal material is included, followed by a final version changes. \ ------- \  \  2) Assumptions about the priority scheme (see R1). \  \ The paper could mention earlier attempts to fit more complex models in which production rules try to match each possible combination of properties to pick the object with the largest number of sought-for properties. However, because the color is usually the critical property involved in the choice of next fixation, including these other match combinations did not have much effect. So the priority scheme just makes the model simpler to implement while having very little effect on the choice of next object to fixate. However, the similarity between the priority scheme and the acuity functions is a point of confusion that could be alleviated. Thanks for pointing this out! \ ------- \ The "Task Strategy" section on P. 6 was revised to include this explanation for how the priority scheme reflects the acuity functions. \ ------- \  4) What was exactly the parameter fitting process (R2)? \  \ We can explain that this was a manually conducted iterative search in which the acuity function parameters and the retention time were adjusted to maximize the goodness of fit to the data.The quadratic shape and relative spread of the acuity functions for different properties are based on results in the literature in visual perception - for example, color is more visible than shape with greater eccentricity, and larger objects can be recognized better than smaller in the periphery. These differences in availability are strong at larger eccentricities, as primarily determined by the quadratic coefficient. So the other parameters of the acuity functions were kept constant to simplify the search.  \ ------- \ Brief explanations were inserted where needed, starting on P. 5 with the introductory paragraph under THE EPIC MODEL, and in the explanation of fitting the parameters of the acuity functions and persistence parameter. \ ------- \  5) What is the stopping criterion (Yes/No)? (R2) \  \ The flowchart shows two interacting parallel threads of processing. The decision to continue is No if the other thread has shut down the processing by finding a match; otherwise this thread runs at the same time. We will consider a better label for this box - such as "Still Searching?" and clarify the two parallel thread representation. \ ------- \ We revised Fig. 8 and P. 6 to be more clear about about the parallel threads and the stopping criterion in the task strategy. \ ------- \ ------- \ We added a section on P. 7 subheaded "Generality of the strategy and obtained parameter values" which addresses the following issues: \ ------- \ 1) The persistence parameter was set to 9 seconds. How can this parameter \  be determined for other tasks and contexts? (R1) \  \ The value of this parameter should apply to similar displays and tasks; a shorter persistence is suggested by other work cited for very sparse displays. There are interesting contingent-display eye tracking studies of natural scenes that yield retention times similar to this value. So how it might differ for other display/task combinations requires additional experiments and modeling. We can add a recommendation that the parameter value should be applied only to similar displays and tasks. \ ------- \ We also clarified the determination of this parameter value (P. 4). \ ------- \  3) Attribution of results to acuity functions, persistence time, and task \  strategy (see R1). \  \ If any of these three are substantially different, the model fails to fit some aspect of the data. The paper could briefly summarize what each of these contributes. \ ------- \ This is summarized in the new section. \ ------- \  6) Can you describe real-world tasks where the model can be applied to? \  (R2) \  \ We could mention that tasks with many color- and shape-coded icons are common in military HCI settings such as modern computer-driven displays of radar data, and can try to insert some additional citations where readers can see what these are like.  \   \ ------- \ Our revised introduction (P. 1) highlights the real-world issues using the iPhone icon example better, and the new P. 7 section refers to military radar displays. \ ------- \  7) Does the model generalize? (R3) This question is related to some of \  the previous questions. \  \ We can be explicit that the model strategy and processing should generalize to visual search tasks in which the visual field lacks overall structure to guide the search and the target object has to be located based on its visual features.  \  \ ------- \ The P. 7 section is explicit about the scope of the model strategy and parameter values. \ ------- \  8) Are the statistics robust? Can you add error bars and what will they \  show us? (R3) \  \ Williams conducted a truly heroic study for his time, but because he did not report his data fully, trying to add confidence intervals would be "guestimating" only; we felt it was better to simply state the problem and assert the high reliability of the data (due to the reported very large sample sizes). For example, based on the data reported in his paper, for the proportion (0.6) of fixations on the matching color in the Color-only cue condition, the guestimated 95% binomial confidence interval ranges from 0.591 to 0.609. Such error bars are too small to visible on the graphs. We could attempt to convey something of this to justify why they aren't shown. \  \ With regard to the reliability of the model predictions, we should say that trial runs were done to determine the Monte-Carlo run size required for stable predictions. EPIC models that predict mean performance are typically not set to randomly sample component parameters about their mean values, but rather restrict the random variation to sources that are unavoidable in the task (e.g. where the target object happens to be located) or that are theoretically critical such as the perceptual noise in the acuity function. Thus the predictions are stable at relatively small run sizes; error bars around them would be so small as to be redundant.  \ ------- \ Because of the space limitations, we couldn't say as much as we provided in the rebuttal. On P. 3 we've tried to provide a very brief explanation of why the Williams data is reliable, namely that each proportion is based on thousands of fixations.  On P. 6 we've indicated that the number of Monte-Carlo trials was adequate to produce stable predictions. \

Title: MisTable: Reach-through Personal Screens for Tabletops
Author list: Diego Martinez Plasencia, Edward Joyce, Sriram Subramanian
Abstract: We present MisTable, a tabletop system that combines a conventional horizontal interactive surface with personal screens between the user and the tabletop surface. These personal screens, built using fog, are both see-through and reach-through. Being see-through provides direct line of sight of the personal screen and the elements behind it on the tabletop. Being reach-through allows the user to switch from interacting with the personal screen to reaching through it to interact with the tabletop or the space above it. The personal screen allows a range of customisations and novel interactions such as presenting 2D personal contents on the screen, 3D contents above the tabletop or augmenting and relighting tangible objects differently for each user. Besides, having a personal screen for each user allows us to customize the view of each of them according to their identity or preferences. Finally, the personal screens preserve all well-established tabletop interaction techniques like touch and tangible interactions. We explore the challenges in building such a reach-through system through a proof-of-concept implementation and discuss the possibilities afforded by the system.

Title: Combining Think-aloud and Physiological Data to Understand Video Game Experiences
Author list: Chek Tien Tan, Tuck Wah Leong, Songjia Shen
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Interaction Design and Human Practice Lab
Abstract: Think-aloud protocols are commonly used to evaluate player experiences of video games but suffer from a lack of objectivity and timeliness. On the other hand, quantitative captures of physiological data are effective; providing detailed, unbiased and continuous responses of players, but lack contexts for interpretation. This paper documents how both approaches could be used together in practice by comparing video-cued retrospective think-aloud data and physiological data collected during a video gameplay experiment. We observed that many interesting physiological responses did not feature in participants' think-aloud data, and conversely, reports of interesting experiences were sometimes not observed in the collected physiological data. Through learnings from our experiment, we present some of the challenges when combining these approaches and offer some guidelines as to how qualitative and quantitative data can be used together  to gain deeper insights into player experiences.

Title: Juxtapoze: Supporting Serendipity and Creative Expression in Clipart Compositions
Author list: William Benjamin, Senthil Chandrasegaran, Devarajan Ramanujan, Niklas Elmqvist, SVN Vishwanathan, Karthik Ramani
Author emails: benjamin.william@gmail.com, senthil@purdue.edu, dramanuj@purdue.edu, elm@purdue.edu, vishy@purdue.edu, ramani@purdue.edu
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: School of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Abstract: Juxtapoze is a clipart composition workflow that supports \   creative expression and serendipitous discoveries in the shape \   domain. \   We achieve creative expression by supporting a workflow of \   searching, editing, and composing: \   the user queries the shape database using strokes, selects the \   desired search result, and finally modifies the selected image \   before composing it into the overall drawing. \   Serendipitous discovery of shapes is facilitated by allowing \   multiple exploration channels, such as doodles, shape filtering, and \   relaxed search. \   Results from a qualitative evaluation show that Juxtapoze makes \   the process of creating image compositions enjoyable and supports \   creative expression and serendipity.

Title: The Last Meter: Blind Visual Guidance to a Target
Author list: Roberto Manduchi, James M Coughlan
Abstract: Smartphone apps can use object recognition software to provide information to blind or low vision users about objects in the visual environment. A crucial challenge for these users is aiming the camera properly to take a well-framed picture of the desired target object. We investigate the effects of two fundamental constraints of object recognition â€“ frame rate and camera field of view â€“ on a blind personâ€™s ability to use an object recognition smartphone app. The app was used by 18 blind participants to find visual targets beyond armâ€™s reach and approach them to within 30 cm. While we expected that a faster frame rate or wider camera field of view should always improve search performance, our experimental results show that in many cases increasing the field of view does not help, and may even hurt, performance. These results have important implications for the design of object recognition systems for blind users.

Title: Establishing Design Guidelines in Interactive Exercise Gaming: Preliminary Data from Two Posing Studies
Author list: Monica Zaczynski, Anthony Whitehead
Abstract: Interactive gaming has demonstrated promise as a low-cost, at-home training and fitness instruction alternative. Gaming systems offer convenience and the ability to provide enhanced reporting and progress data if body measurement information is collected effectively. However, commercially available systems today are designed primarily for entertainment and as a result, the quality of instruction delivery and level of involvement may not meet the needs of a user performing a disciplined activity. \  \ This paper will look at adapting for occlusion and lack of visibility; learning and orientation; and providing feedback in an effort to determine if there is an ideal visual demonstration delivery that maximizes pose understanding and user self-efficacy, determine whether supplementary modalities are important for instruction, and determine if there is an ideal feedback delivery that promotes pose comprehension, confidence and motivation.  This information can provide a guideline for designing clear and supportive, interactive training systems that can engage users, prevent injury and help maintain fitness. \

Some reference to literature on rehabilitation gaming still exists as background and support literature. \  \ (in reference to R1 comments - point 2) We have included a limitations section that includes acknowledgement and discussion of the limited sample size. Additionally we acknowledge that design guidelines may not be statistically supported but have demonstrated some qualitative interest and are put forward as a foundational guideline for future research (in reference to R1 comments - point 3).  \  \ (in reference to R2 comments - point 2) We have clarified the differences between hardware and software throughout the paper to better identify where the issues lie i.e. a particular game vs. the system itself. \  \ (in reference to R2 comments - point 3) We have clarified the language used to describe orientation and 'sense of self' in Study 1.  \  \ (in reference to R2 comments - point 4) we replaced test 1 and 2 with study 1 and 2. \  \ (in reference to R2 comments - point 5) Errors in figure referencing and typos were edited.

Title: â€œMy religious aunt asked why I was trying to sell her viagraâ€ù: Experiences with account hijacking
Author list: Richard Shay, Iulia Ion, Robert W. Reeder, Sunny Consolvo
Abstract: With so much of our lives digital, online, and not entirely under our control, we risk losing access to our communications, reputation, and data. Recent years have brought a rash of high-profile account compromises, but account hijacking is not limited to high-profile accounts. In this paper, we report results of a survey about peopleâ€™s experiences with and attitudes toward account hijacking. The problem is widespread; 30% of our 294 participants had an email or social networking account accessed by an unauthorized party. Five themes emerged from our results: (1) compromised accounts are often valuable to victims, (2) attackers are mostly unknown, but sometimes known, to victims, (3) users acknowledge some responsibility for keeping their accounts secure, (4) usersâ€™ understanding of important security measures is incomplete, and (5) harm from account hijacking is concrete and emotional. We discuss implications for designing security mechanisms to improve chances for user adoption.

Title: A Low-cost Transparent Electric Field Sensor for 3D Interaction on Mobile Devices
Author list: Mathieu Le Goc, Stuart Taylor, Shahram Izadi, Cem Keskin
Abstract: We contribute a thin, transparent, and low-cost design for \ electric field sensing, allowing for 3D finger and hand tracking \ and gestures on mobile devices. Our approach requires no \ direct instrumentation of the hand or body, and is non-optical, \ allowing for a compact form-factor that is resilient to ambient \ illumination. Our simple driver electronics are based on an \ off-the-shelf chip that removes the need for building custom \ analog electronics. We describe the design of our transparent \ electrode array, and present a machine learning algorithm \ for mapping from signal measurements at the receivers to \ 3D positions. We demonstrate non-contact motion gestures, \ and precise 3D hand and finger localization. We conclude by \ discussing limitations and future work.

Title: Breakdown, Obsolescence and Reuse:  HCI and The Art of Repair
Author list: Steven J Jackson, Laewoo Kang
Abstract: This paper describes an integrated program of theoretical, ethnographic, and building work meant to explore post-humanist alternatives to questions around HCI creativity and design. We review recent theories in the humanities, social sciences, and HCI that argue for different ways of framing the relationship between human agents and the object world around them. We then describe a program of ethnographic work with artists who feature found and broken technologies as central methods and topics of work. Finally, we describe an installation and self-study project of our own, â€œScale,â€ù that extends these lines of analysis through collaborative acts of building with broken and discarded technologies. We argue that such integrated programs of work offer one useful model for leveraging the theoretical, ethnographic and material dimensions of HCI work; and that the distinct â€œpropensitiesâ€ù of found and broken objects can challenge and extend HCI notions of creativity and design itself.

Title: An Assistive Robotic Table for Older and Post-Stroke  Adults: Results from Participatory Design and   Evaluation Activities with Clinical Staff
Author list: Anthony L Threatt, Jessica Merino, Keith Evan Green, Johnell O Brooks, Ian Walker, Stan Healy
Author emails: anthont@clemson.edu, jmerino@clemson.edu, kegreen@clemson.edu, jobrook@clemson.edu, iwalker@clemson.edu, shealy@ghs.org
Primary Affiliation 5 - Department/Schoo: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Abstract: An inevitable new frontier for the CHI community is the development of complex, larger-scale, cyber-physical artifacts where advancements in design, computing and robotics converge. Presented here is a design exemplar: the Assistive, Robotic Table (ART), the key component of our envisioned home+ suite of networked, robotic furnishings for hospitals and homes, promoting wellbeing and independent living. We begin with the motivations for ART, and present our iterative, five-phase, participatory design-and-evaluation process involving clinicians at a rehabilitation hospital, focusing here on the final usability study. From our wide-ranging design-research activities, which may be characterized as research through design, we found ART to be promising but also challenging. As a design exemplar, ART offers invaluable lessons to the CHI community as it comes to design larger-scale, cyber-physical artifacts cultivating interactions across people and their surroundings that define places of social, cultural and psychological significance.

Title: DoDo Game, a Color Vision Deficiency Screening Test for Young children
Author list: Linh Chi Nguyen, Ellen Yi-Luen Do, Audrey Chia, Yuan Wang, Henry Been-Lirn Duh
Abstract: This paper presents â€œDoDoâ€™s Catching Adventure,â€ù a new color vision deficient screening test for young children. Early detection of color blindness among children is useful for parents and teachers to better understand childrenâ€™s needs, to overcome difficulties in learning, and for life and career planning. Unfortunately, current color screening tests are not designed for young children; most require more advanced verbal or cognitive skills. DoDo game has taken a new approach by embedding game elements into a color vision screening test. A user study conducted at Singapore National Eye Centre on twenty-eight children, identified fourteen as Red-Green deficient subjects as did by Ishihara screening test, showed that DoDo was adequately effective in identifying Red-Green color vision deficiency and comparable to two current gold standard colorblind tests, Ishihara and D15.

Title: FloodLight: 3D Silhouette Sensing for High-Precision Input On and Above Physical Surfaces
Author list: David Kim, Shahram Izadi, Jakub Dostal, Christoph Rhemann, Cem Keskin, Christopher Zach, Jamie Shotton, Timothy Large, Steven Bathiche, Matthias Niessner, D. Alex Butler, Sean Ryan Fanello, Vivek Pradeep
Author emails: davidkim@microsoft.com, shahrami@microsoft.com, jd67@st-andrews.ac.uk, chrheman@microsoft.com, cemke@microsoft.com, chzach@microsoft.com, jamiesho@microsoft.com, tlarge@microsoft.com, stevieb@microsoft.com, niessner@cs.stanford.edu, dab@microsoft.com, sean.fanello@iit.it, vpradeep@microsoft.com
Abstract: We present FloodLight, a new vision-based system for accurately \ sensing the 3D silhouettes of hands, styluses, and \ other objects, as they interact on and above physical surfaces. \ Our setup is simple, cheap, and easily reproducible, comprising \ of two infrared cameras, diffuse infrared LEDs, and any \ off-the-shelf retro-reflective material. The retro-reflector aids \ image segmentation, creating a strong contrast between the \ surface and any object in proximity. A new highly efficient \ stereo matching algorithm precisely estimates the 3D contours \ of interacting objects and the retro-reflective surfaces. \ A novel pipeline enables 3D finger, hand and object tracking, \ as well as gesture recognition, purely using these 3D \ contours. We demonstrate high-precision sensing, allowing \ robust disambiguation between a finger or stylus touching, \ pressing or interacting above the surface. This allows many interactive \ scenarios that seamlessly mix together freehand 3D \ interactions with touch, pressure and stylus input. As shown, \ these rich modalities of input are enabled on and above any \ retro-reflective surface, including custom â€œphysical widgetsâ€ù \ fabricated by users. We compare our system with Kinect and \ Leap Motion, and conclude with limitations and future work.

Title: The Role of Interactive Biclusters in Sensemaking
Author list: Maoyuan Sun, Lauren Bradel, Chris North, Naren Ramakrishnan
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Abstract: Visual exploration of relationships within large, textual datasets is an important aid for human sensemaking. By understanding computed, structural relationships between entities of different types (e.g., people and locations), users can leverage domain expertise and intuition to determine the importance and relevance of these relationships for tasks, such as intelligence analysis. Biclusters are a potentially desirable method to facilitate this, because they reveal coordinated relationships that can represent meaningful relationships. Bixplorer, a visual analytics prototype, supports interactive exploration of textual datasets in a spatial workspace with biclusters. In this paper, we present results of a study that analyzes how users interact with biclusters to solve an intelligence analysis problem using Bixplorer. We found that biclusters played four principal roles in the analytical process: an effective starting point for analysis, a revealer of two levels of connections, an indicator of potentially important entities, and a useful label for clusters of organized information.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This note presents four important roles of interactive biclusters in Bixplorer, a visual analytics prototype, for solving human sensemaking tasks such as intelligence analysis.
Summary of Changes: In our final version, we have made the following changes based on suggestion from the reviewers. \   \ 1) Based on R1â€™s concern that we did not clearly describe the system and its usage scenario, we add a new subsection in Introduction titled Bixplorer, where we gives a brief introduction about the system (design considerations, interaction features and the user interface), and presents an example of the typical usage scenario in Bixplorer to illustrate how analysts can make hypotheses based on the spatially organized information in the workspace. \     \ 2) Considering R1â€™s post rebuttal comments with respect to time stamps, we change the fourth column in Table 1 to â€œRelevance of the 1st doc opened before / after users opening their 1st biclusterâ€ù, which clearly demonstrates that 11 of the 13 users, considered for log analysis, were directed to relevant documents by the first bicluster they opened in their workspaces. The time stamps indicates that for most users this happened in the beginning of their analysis. We also add a discussion that we did not give users instructions on any particular analytical approach, so the differences of the timestamp resulted from the preference of users on where to start their analysis. Besides, we switch the position of the second and the third column in Table 1, which follows the time sequence that how many documents were opened in the workspace before users opened their first bicluster, and when users opened their first bicluster.  \  \ 3) Based on R2â€™s concern that we did not discuss user performance in this study, we add a new column in Table 1, which shows the number of attack identified by users in this study, and discuss user performance in the first paragraph of Result section.  \  \ 4) To clarify the confusion about the rate of non-uniform biclusters (72%) raised by R3, we add a discussion that the rate of non-uniform biclusters (72%) is not a parameter that we manually set in Bixplorer. For the Crescent dataset, the number of non-uniform biclusters found by Bixplorer happens to be 72% of the total number of biclusters found. This rate in 10 usersâ€™ workspace is higher than 72%, which indicates that users preferred non-uniform over uniform biclusters in their analysis. \  \ 5) Based on R4â€™s concern that our last two claims (claim 3 & 4) relied on anecdotal data, we clarify the quantitative data mentioned above to support our claim 3, and add new quantitative data (7 of 13 usersâ€™ final workspaces had spatial layouts similar to that shown in Figure 3, and 6 of these 7 users mentioned that biclusters provided the labeling capability to assist their analysis) to support our claim 4. \  \ 6) Based on R2â€™s suggestion about improving readability of figures, we fix all three figures in our paper by changing background color to white and increasing text size. \  \ 7) Considering R2â€™s question what the difference is between this paper and our previous paper about Bixplorer, we add a brief discussion about the preliminary results of the user study in our previous Bixplorer paper to help address the difference between this paper and our previous paper. \  \ 8) Based on our AC's suggestion, we have made all suggested changes to improve the readability of our paper. \

Title: Printing Teddy Bears: A Technique for 3D Printing of Soft Interactive Objects
Non-embedded fonts: Times_New_Roman Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial Arial,Italic
Author list: Scott Hudson
Abstract: This paper considers the design, construction, and example use of a new type of 3D printer which fabricates three-dimensional objects from soft fibers (wool and wool blend yarn).  This printer allows the substantial advantages of additive manufacturing techniques (including rapid turn-around prototyping of physical objects and support for high levels of customization and configuration) to be employed with a new class of material.  This material is a form of loose felt formed when fibers from an incoming feed of yarn are entangled with the fibers in layers below it.  The resulting objects recreate the geometric forms specified in the solid models which specify them, but are soft and flexible â€“ somewhat reminiscent in character to hand knitted materials.  This extends 3D printing from typically hard and precise forms into a new set of forms which embody a different aesthetic of soft and imprecise objects, and provides a new capability for researchers to explore the use of this class of materials in interactive devices.

Title: FOCUS: Enhancing Childrenâ€™s Engagement in Reading by Using Contextual BCI Training Sessions
Author list: Jin Huang, Chun Yu, Yuntao Wang, Yuhang Zhao, Siqi Liu, Chou Mo, Jie Liu, Lie Zhang, Yuanchun Shi
Author emails: huangjin8808@gmail.com, yc2pcg@gmail.com, w.yuntaosea@gmail.com, zhaoyh630@gmail.com, lsqgonna@gmail.com, mochou9211@gmail.com, liujiejesse@gmail.com, zhlie@tsinghua.edu.cn, shiyc@tsinghua.edu.cn

Primary Affiliation 7 - Department/Schoo: Department of Computer Science and Technology
Primary Affiliation 8 - Department/Schoo: Department of Information Art and Design
Primary Affiliation 9 - Department/Schoo: Department of Computer Science and Technology
Abstract: Reading is an important aspect of a childâ€™s development. Reading outcome is heavily dependent on the level of engagement while reading. In this paper, we present FOCUS, an EEG-augmented reading system which monitors a childâ€™s engagement level in real time, and provides contextual BCI training sessions to improve a childâ€™s reading engagement. A laboratory experiment was conducted to assess the validity of the system. Results showed that FOCUS could significantly improve engagement in terms of both EEG-based measurement and teachersâ€™ subjective measure on the reading outcome.

Finally, we asked two native English speakers for helping us to proofread it.   \  \ With respect to the particularly emphasized points, we made the following changes:  \ 1) We describe using O1 and O2 to measure engagement in FOCUS section, and clarify it further in LIMITATION section that what we measure is actually visual engagement, which is supposed to be highly correlated with reading engagement.  \ 2) We explain the difference between our commercial EEG device and Pope's medical EEG device that medical devices have more available electrode sensors, but are much more expensive and complicated to use.  \ 3) LIMITATION section is added, which discusses the limitation of EEG-based device in measuring engagement and the content-related BCI training sessions.  \ 4) We explain the design of four lessons and BCI training sessions in more detail in the [EXPERIMENT-Design of lessons and BCI training sessions] section.  \ 5) We give a detailed description of "Recall Task" and "Quiz Task" in the [EXPERIMENT-Procedure] section. \

Title: Paddle: Highly Deformable Mobile Devices with Physical Controls
Author list: Raf Ramakers, Johannes SchÃ¶ning, Kris Luyten
Abstract: We present the concept of highly deformable mobile devices that can be transformed into various special-purpose controls in order to bring physical controls to mobile devices. Physical controls have the advantage of exploiting people's innate abilities for manipulating physical objects in the real world. We designed and implemented a prototype, called Paddle, to demonstrate our concept. Additionally, we explore the interaction techniques enabled by this concept and conduct an in-depth study to evaluate our transformable physical controls. Our findings show that these physical controls provide several benefits over traditional touch interaction techniques commonly used on mobile devices.

Title: Understanding Procedural Content Generation: A Design-Centric Analysis of the Role of PCG in Games
Author list: Gillian Smith
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: College of Computer Science, College of Arts, Media, and Design
Abstract: Games that use procedural content generation (PCG) do so in a wide variety of ways and for different reasons. One of the most common reasons cited by PCG system creators and game designers is improving replayabilityâ€”by providing a means for automatically creating near-infinite amounts of content, the player can come back and replay the game and refine her strategies over a long period. However, this notion of replayability is both overly broad and incomplete as a motivation. This paper contributes an analytical framework and associated common vocabulary for understanding the role of PCG in games from a design standpoint, with an aim of unpacking some of the broad justifications for PCG use in games, and bringing together technical concerns in designing PCG systems with design concerns related to creating engaging playable experiences.

Title: Between Theory and Practice: Bridging Concepts in HCI research
Author list: Peter Dalsgaard, Christian Dindler
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 1 - Dep: Centre for Advanced Visualization and Interactin (CAVI)
Abstract: We present the notion of â€˜bridging conceptsâ€™ as a particular form of intermediary knowledge in HCI research, residing between theory and practice. We argue that bridging concepts address the challenge of facilitating exchange between theory and practice in HCI, and we compare it to other intermediary forms of knowledge such as strong concepts and conceptual constructs. We propose that bridging concepts have three defining constituents: a theoretical foundation, a set of design articulations and a range of exemplars that demonstrate the scope and potential of their application. These constituents specify how bridging concepts, as a form of knowledge, are accountable to both theory and practice. We present an analysis of the concept of â€˜peepholesâ€™ as an example of a bridging concept aimed at spurring user curiosity and engagement.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Main contributions:  \ 1) presentation and discussion of bridging concepts as an intermediary form of knowledge in HCI research \ 2) the development of â€˜peepholesâ€™ as a particular instance of bridging concepts.
Summary of Changes: In accordance with the reviews and subsequent discussions with our shepherd, we have done the following: \  \ - We have made â€œBridging Conceptsâ€ù the main contribution of the paper. - This has been the main objective of our revision, and it should be reflected throughout the paper. As a consequence, we have also changed the title of the paper. Peepholes now serve an auxilliary role in the paper as an extended example of bridging concepts.  \  \ - We have articulated how bridging concepts are different from strong concepts.  As part of the revision, the sections introducing and positioning the notion of bridging concepts have been extended. This has also given room to better outline how it is related to other concepts. We have dedicated the most space to positioning it in relation to strong concepts and conceptual constructs, but also brought in other intermediary level concepts, e.g. Koskinenâ€™s labs, Zimmermanâ€™s framing constructs, Bowersâ€™ annotated portfolios, and Alexanderâ€™s patterns. \   \ - We have added a section with two further examples of concepts we consider to embody the characteristics of bridging concepts, namely affordances and perceptual crossing from the work of Deckers. We have also added sections in the discussion about how other concepts, e.g. touchpoints from service design, may be developed to function as bridging concepts. \  \ We have furthermore incorporated the final comments from the shepherd: \  \ - The section on conceptual constructs has been expanded. \ - The differences between conceptual constructs and strong concepts have been clarified, the notion of bridging concepts has been positioned more strongly in relation to these concepts, and the relevance of bridging concepts made clear. \ - Minor issues, e.g. in relation to the notion of Labs, have been addressed. \ - Further information has been added to the sections on related work to better account for the origin and intent of the contributions mentioned. \ - The analysis of peepholes has been shortened. \

Title: Exploring Affective Communication Through Variable-Friction Surface Haptics
Author list: Joseph Mullenbach, Craig Shultz, J. Edward Colgate, Anne Marie Piper
Abstract: This paper explores the use of variable friction surface haptics enabled by the TPad Tablet to support affective communication between pairs of users. We introduce three haptic applications for the TPad Tablet (text messaging, image sharing, and virtual touch) and evaluate the applications with 24 users, including intimate couples and strangers. Participants used haptics to communicate literal texture, denote action within a scene, convey emotional information, highlight content, express and engage in physical playfulness, and to provide oneâ€™s partner with an experience or sensation. We conclude that users readily associate haptics with emotional expression and that the intimacy of touch in the contexts we study is best suited for communications with close social partners.

Title: Sweet Home: Understanding Diabetes Management via a Chinese Online Community
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,BoldItalic Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial Arial,Italic Helvetica,Bold
Author list: Xiaomu Zhou, Si Sun, Jiang Yang
Abstract: China has overtaken India and the U.S. as host to the largest diabetic population in the world. Many problems exist in the Chinese healthcare system and very small number of diabetes patients receives treatment. Our paper reports on a case study through the lens of an online diabetes patient community, Sweet Home. We conducted participant observations, text analysis, and interviews, to understand the health management of patients at Sweet Home. Our findings reveal that patientsâ€™ understanding of diabetes, their choice of treatments, their routine management, and their interactions with others (in the physical world) and among themselves (in the online world) are influenced by many factors: belief in traditional Chinese versus western medicine, cultural and social norms regarding social eating and drinking, conflicts over self-images, and responses to comments and pressures of coworkers. That is, social context may significantly affect patientsâ€™ behaviors and each individual patientâ€™s actions may also help reshape the social context. We draw out implications for how our society as a whole may respond to these issues, from the perspective of public health, education, and information technology design.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Our study shows how diabetes patients navigate conflicting pressures to treat their conditions in social and cultural context. Results draw from the largest online diabetes community in China, Sweet Home.
Summary of Changes: We appreciate our 1AC and 2ACâ€™s specific advice and instructions for revising the paper. We accordingly made the following changes.  \  \ 1. We added methods details into the paper, as explained in our rebuttal.  \  \ 2. We rewrote certain paragraph (p1, last paragraph) and revised a number of sentences throughout that previously read over-claiming (e.g. using â€œpatients in our studyâ€ù to replace â€œpatientsâ€ù in general), and we also added two explicit sentences to acknowledge the *limitation* of this study in Conclusion. We made it clear that our study only investigated Sweet Home patients, providing some insights into the diabetes management in the specific social and cultural context, and we do not claim to understand the entire populations.  \  \ 3. We added a few sentences throughout, and one specific paragraph, the last paragraph in Conclusion to highlight our contributions to HCI. \    \ 4. We removed the explicit interpretation of Structuration Theory within the paper (page 7). However, our discussion on observed diabetic practices (as well as other similar studies) is indeed influenced by understanding the focus of this theory, i.e., the mutual constitution and impact of social context and (individual) human actions; therefore we keep this specific reference only in the end, to acknowledge the intellectual influence. (Note, we tried first to include how we used the Theory specifically. However, due to the page limit, we had to cut significant amount of empirical materials. Considering the nature of conference paper, we decided to keep our rich empirical findings for this paper. We would like to add more discussion on our theoretical contributions in our future journal article from this study. Regardless, we are willing to make changes if 1AC thinks itâ€™s necessary to provide further clarification at certain places.) \  \ 5. We made English annotations to the Figure on p3, adding translations to the main structure of webpage and content of the example post, as one of the reviewer asked. \  \ 6. We also made some writing changes in Literature review; and in design implications to make the information flow more smoothly. We also highlighted the importance of publication health awareness in Chinese society. \  \  \

Title: The influence of controllers on immersion in mobile games
Author list: Paul Cairns, Jing Li, Wendy Wang, A. Imran Nordin
Abstract: The controls for digital games understandably have an important \ part in building up the gaming experiences that people \ have. Whilst there is substantial work on innovative controllers \ for consoles, like the XBox Kinect, relatively little \ has been done to understand the effect of the different control \ mechanisms that can be used to play games on mobile devices like smartphones. A well-defined framework of naturalness has emerged as potentially useful concept in area of game controllers. This paper reports two experiments that look at how the naturalness of the game controls influences the experience of immersion in mobile games. It seems that where there is an a prior natural mapping, this will improve immersion in the game but in the absence of a prior mapping, naturalness alone is not sufficient to account for immersion. This opens up the need for a more thorough investigation of this area.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Gaming experience may improve with more natural controllers. This paper shows, with two experiments, that based on an existing typology, more naturalness does not make games more immersive. \
Summary of Changes: The summary update of the review process was that we should make the changes as proposed in the rebuttal and also address R3â€™s criticism more deeply. We report here the revisions we have made accordingly. \  \ R3 had concerns in relation to naturalness which was also raised in the rebuttal and they also raised the issue of direct manipulation being more relevant. \  \ We altered the emphasis of the introduction, particularly the last two paragraphs to emphasise the use of Skalski et al.â€™s notion of naturalness as the focus of the work done. This change is reflected in the abstract. In the section Controllers and Gaming Experience, Skalski et al. is discussed and we have added a list of the four levels of naturalness that are identified there and emphasised this focus in the last paragraph of that section. The experimental aims are more clearly couched in terms of the naturalness framework and the mapping to each type of naturalness made explicit in the discussion of the games in each experimental method. \  \ R3 suggested we consider direct manipulation as relevant in interpreting the results of experiment 2 rather than naturalness. We hope the clarifications made on naturalness would now make it clear what we meant by naturalness and why we interpreted things that way. Also, all games more or less have direct manipulation as understood in Shneidermanâ€™s original formulation (with the exception of reversibility of actions usually) and there is no distinction to be made between the interaction styles in this formulation. However, instrumental interaction does have similarities with the concerns we raise and so we have added a paragraph to discuss those though it raises more issues than it solves. \  \ The issue (R1) of using other scales like the GEQ was addressed by introducing a new second paragraph of the second section,  noting that the popular GEQ and PENS scales are not publically available and in the GEQâ€™s case, not validated. This supplements the discussion of our choice to focus on immersion that was already in the paper. \  \ We have made it clear that we chose casual games as they suit an experimental approach but in the final conclusions we note that this is a limitation of this work that ought to be addressed through further work.  The varitions in experimental set up between experiments, specifically use of incentives and the playing durations, are justified in the participants and procedure sections of the second experiment, respectively. \  \ In both experiments when describing the games used, we have better explained the control styles including a figure in experiment 2 and discussed how in both experiments the controls reflect very common styles of (at least casual) mobile game controls.  \  \ We have included a reference to the work indicated by R2 towards the end of the literature review to show that the space of controls on mobile games is being actively explored. Though as noted in our rebuttal, this work is not directly related to the concerns of this paper. \  \ The reviewers asked why we did not conduct more qualitative analysis. We have added  in the literature review that in McGloin et al.â€™s study, though the manipulation of naturalness influenced experience, players did not perceive the different in naturalness as measured through a 13-item scale. We also note in the discussion of experiment 2 that qualitative questions about why tilt and slip were different were not asked because this was neither possible nor anticipated. \  \ We have also worked to remove all typos. \

Title: An Implicit Author Verification System for Text Messages Based on Gesture Typing Biometrics
Author list: Ulrich Burgbacher, Klaus Hinrichs
Abstract: Gesture typing is a popular text input method used on smartphones. Gesture keyboards are based on word gestures that subsequently trace all \ letters of a word on a virtual keyboard. Instead of tapping a word key by key, the user enters a word gesture with a single continuous stroke. \ In this paper, we introduce an implicit user verification approach for short text messages that are entered with a gesture keyboard. We utilize  \ the way people interact with gesture keyboards to extract behavioral biometric features. \ We propose a proof-of-concept classification framework that learns the gesture typing behavior of a person and is able to decide whether a gestured  \ message was written by the legitimate user or an imposter. Data collected from gesture keyboard users in a user study is used to assess the \ performance of the classification framework, demonstrating that the technique has considerable promise. \

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: In this work we introduce a proof-of-concept framework which is designed to verify the identities of users by their "typing" style on a gesture keyboard.
Summary of Changes: With regard to the reviews we have committed the following major changes: \  \ * We have removed the last paragraph of the discussion to get some  \   free space for two new aspects that we consider more important  \   after reading the reviews. \  \ * With regard to the concerns of R1 we have added a paragraph \   to the discussion that addresses how the findings of the study \   can be transferred to a real-life system. It reads: \  \   "To transfer the findings of the study to a real-life scenario \    it is important to investigate if a word gesture's signature \    depends on the surrounding word context. In addressing this \    concern, the text messages were designed to contain words \    within different surrounding contexts. Trying to identify in \    which context a word gesture was entered, the classifier makes \    a random decision (median EER of $50$\\,\\%). We conclude that \    within our framework the context has little relevance. \    This implies that word gestures which have been trained in \    the study can be used to verify novel sentences as long as \    models of more than $5$ of the contained words are available." \  \ * In addressing the comments of R3 we have added a brief discussion \   of the potential effect of the expertise of the subjects on the  \   verification performance: \  \   "The results of the study must be interpreted with regard to \    the fact that most participants, though proficient touch- \    screen users, were learning to use the keyboard over the course \    of the study. Only three users reported to use gesture typing \    habitually. The median EER from the single word classifiers of \    these users was about $6$ percentage points lower than the \    corresponding value for the less proficient users. This result, \    while preliminary, suggests that the classification might be \    more accurate for users who are familiar with gesture typing." \  \ * As suggested by R1 we have added one sentence to explain how the \   classifiers are combined in the last paragraph of the \   "System Overview" section: \  \   "In order to verify users by whole sentences or messages we \    compute the average a posteriori probability over all the \    word-based classifier outputs." \     \ * As R3 suggested we have removed the two claims \  \   "This $70$-$30$ ratio is commonly used in data mining." \   "[the EER] is often used as a single performance indicator \    of a biometric system" \  \ * We have added information about the time it takes to verify a \   user as suggested by R5. \     \ * We have replaced the rather unclear term "resultant argument" \   with "mean direction" with a reference of how it is defined. \  \ * We have changed some colors to ensure that the figures reproduce \   well in black and white. \

Title: Effects of Security Warnings and Instant Gratification Cues on Attitudes toward Mobile Websites
Author list: Bo Zhang, Mu Wu, Hyunjin Kang, Eun Go, S. Shyam Sundar
Abstract: In order to address the increased privacy and security concerns raised by mobile communications, designers of mobile applications and websites have come up with a variety of warnings and appeals. While some interstitials warn about potential risk to personal information due to an untrusted security certificate, others attempt to take usersâ€™ minds away from privacy concerns by making tempting, time-sensitive offers. How effective are they? We conducted an online experiment (N = 220) to find out. Our data show that both these strategies raise red flags for usersâ€”appeals to instant gratification make users more leery of the site and warnings make them perceive greater threat to personal data. Yet, users tend to reveal more information about their social media accounts when warned about an insecure site. This is probably because users process these interstitials based on cognitive heuristics triggered by them. These findings hold important implications for the design of cues in mobile interfaces.

And we specifically mentioned that this logic applies to layperson users. \ 2)	We changed the direction of the second hypothesis to reflect the more intuitive logic suggested by reviewers. \ 3)	The experimental conditions (three treatment conditions are shown, the control condition is omitted because of limited space) are better presented in Figure 1. \ 4)	All the measurement items (i.e., attitude, trust, perceived threat, behavioral intention, and power usage) are explained and clarified, with citations and references added as well.  \ 5)	For clarity and simplicity, we removed the redundant reporting of MANCOVA results and better explained our results with analyses of covariance (ANCOVA).  \ 6)	A new structural equation model including most of the variables was added to test the overall fit of our theoretical model with the data pattern obtained in the experiment.  \ 7)	We added all the missing citations and references and ensured that they conform to SIGCHI style. \ 8)	We changed the paperâ€™s title based on the revisions suggested by reviewers. \

Title: Selecting an Effective Niche: An Ecological View of the Success of Online Communities
Author list: Haiyi Zhu, Jilin Chen, Tara Matthews, Aditya Pal, Hernan Badenes, Robert E Kraut
Author emails: haiyiz@cs.cmu.edu, jilinc@us.ibm.com, tlmatthe@us.ibm.com, apal@us.ibm.com, hbadenes@ar.ibm.com, robert.kraut@cmu.edu
Abstract: Online communities serve various important functions, but many fail to thrive. Research on community success has traditionally focused on internal factors. In contrast, we take an ecological view to understand how the success of a community is influenced by other communities. We measured a community's relationship with other communitiesâ€”its â€œnicheâ€ùâ€”through four dimensions: topic overlap, shared members, content linking, and shared offline organizational affiliation. We used a mixed-method approach, combining the quantitative analysis of 9495 online enterprise communities and interviews with community members. Our results show that too little or too much overlap in topic with other communities causes a communityâ€™s activity to suffer. We also show that this main result is moderated in predictable ways by whether the community shares members with, links to content in, or shares an organizational affiliation with other communities. These findings provide new insight on community success, guiding online community designers on how to effectively position their community in relation to others.

Title: WADE: Simplified GUI Add-on Development for Third-party Software
Author list: Xiaojun Meng, Shengdong Zhao, Yongfeng Huang, Zhongyuan Zhang, James Eagan, Ramanathan Subramanian
Author emails: mengxj08@gmail.com, shengdong.zhao@gmail.com, xgjonathan@gmail.com, zhang_zhongyuan@nus.edu.sg, eagan@telecom-paristech.fr, s.raamanathan@gmail.com
Primary Affiliation 4 - Department/Schoo: Human Computer Interaction Lab, School of Computing
Abstract: We present the WADE Integrated Development Environment (IDE), which simplifies interface and functionality modification of existing third-party software without access to source code. WADE clones the Graphical User Interface (GUI) of a host program through dynamic-link library (DLL) injection, enabling modifications to (1) the GUI in a WYSIWYG fashion and (2) software functionality. We compare WADE with an alternative state-of-the-art runtime toolkit overloading approach in a user-study, whose results demonstrate that WADE significantly simplifies the task of GUI-based add-on development.
