Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We present the WADE Integrated Development Environment (IDE), which simplifies the modification of the interface and functionality of existing third-party software without access to source code.
Summary of Changes: We would like to sincerely thank the ACs and reviewers for your great effort and constructive feedback. All your questions and concerns are clarified below: \  \  \ â€¢	acknowledging the challenges of interfaces dynamics \  \ A section called â€œinterface dynamicsâ€ù was added to the end of the implementation section. \ While WADE demonstrates a promising step towards addressing the power and ease of use trade-off for runtime modifications, it is important to note that WADE is not without its limitations. The WYSIWYG modification of the GUI hierarchy in WADE only applies to the initialization state of the application. Interfaces, on the other hand, are often dynamic, with live code running that may change the interface from how it appeared at the moment it was imported into WADE. These changes to the application may conflict with the modifications implemented in WADE, leading to unstable modifications that do not behave as expected. Developers are advised to first get familiar with application behavior and identify potential runtime interface dynamics before using WADE for performing runtime modifications. \  \ â€¢	being more clear about current implementation \  \ The implementation of the modifications in the scenarios is discussed in the â€œDiscussionâ€ù section on page 4. More details can be found in the section â€œIntegrating WADE with the IDE and GUI builderâ€ù. Using the algorithm mentioned in this section, WADE can apply the changes made by a third-party programmer to the cloned GUI hierarchy, to the host application. All these modifications in the scenarios can be actually authored by â€œAdding widgetsâ€ù, â€œDeleting widgetsâ€ù, â€œProperty modificationâ€ù and â€œEvent handler modificationsâ€ù. To make it clearer for readers, we add some explanations to the â€œDiscussionâ€ù section on page 4. â€œThe only code she needs to write is the code specifically related to her functionality, which will modify the cloned GUI hierarchy and further apply these changes into the original application. The detailed implementation is discussed in the following sections.â€ù \ â€¢	discussing the ceiling or limitations of GUI builder metaphor \  \ To discuss the limitations of GUI builder metaphor, we add a subsection â€œLimits of the GUI builder metaphorâ€ù as follows: \ â€œWhile many of the modifications were easier to perform using a GUI builder, participants also found it less convenient when dealing with repetitive or looping tasks. For example, if a participant is asked to change 6 out of 7 labels to a different font type, it is easier to use a loop than perform the change manually multiple times. In such cases, command language is preferred as it allows easy programming of similar and repetitive tasks. This finding is consistent with the previous literature [8]. \ GUI metaphor delivers important benefits to learnability, memorability, and error prevention, but it can be inefficient for frequent users, particularly if the interface is not well designed and presents a long, complex form or a multi-step process [8]. For these cases, a command line interface may be far more efficient, but at the cost of requiring the user to learn command names and syntax, putting more demands on the userâ€™s memory and making more chances for errors.  \ This trade-off can be mitigated by combine the benefits of both approaches. For example, Inky allows sloppy command input and provides rich visual feedback to mitigate the cost on userâ€™s memory and make it less error-prone [8]. Sikuli, on the other hand, include visual images in the command to make it easier and more intuitive to refer to graphical elements [17]). To some extent, WADE follows the same approach by introducing GUI builder into Scottyâ€™s pure command line programming environment to improve the ease of use and robustness of the third party add-on development. However, our user study has revealed that there are room for improvement to best combine the advantages of GUI builder and command line programming to further improve the efficiency of third party add-on development while maintain its ease of use.â€ù \ â€¢	more appropriate positioning and clarity of contribution relative to nearby work \  \ We modify the paper to more appropriate position and clarify our contribution relative to nearby work according to Reviewer 3â€™s comments below. \ 1.	On p2, I think the submission is a bit unfair in its characterization of surface-based versus toolkit-based methods. \  \ In the â€œIntroductionâ€ù section, we cautiously add â€œto some extentâ€ù to say that the limitation of surface-based approach can be overcome by toolkit-based approach. In addition, we add the following text to explain the tradeoff of looking inside the application.â€ù Therefore, there exist a trade-off between generalizability, ease of use, and power (the ability to perform deeper modifications). While the previous approaches all have their advantages, additional solutions are still needed to better balance the power and ease of use for runtime modification of third-party software.â€ù \ 2.	On p4, questioning the robustness of pixel-based text recovery seems irrelevant since you do not actually use the text for anything. \  \ WADE can retrieve the original text label directly from the host applicationâ€™s internal structure and modify the context of text, like the changing label name scenario in the demo video. However, pixel-based approaches like Prefab have to perform one more step that is character recognition process. We would like to change the â€œpotentially unreliableâ€ù to â€œavoidableâ€ù in the â€œComparison with previous approachesâ€ù. It can show the direct and easy way of how WADE works as well as not question the robustness of pixel-based approaches. \ 3.	Whether on p5, or somewhere else, I think this submission probably needs to acknowledge the in-place editor used in Dixon et al's CHI 2012 whole-desktop Bubble Cursor. \  \ The technique used in the whole-desktop bubble cursor is totally based on the Prefab. We may not regard it as more related with WADE beyond Prefab. \  \ 4.	On p9, I do not think it's appropriate to raise the idea of testing new ideas in existing interfaces as an "Additional Usage Scenario" that was somehow suggested by a study participant. \  \ We agree with the idea of Reviewer 3 and decide to cut this entire subsection for the sake of other modifications. We also modify the parts that are a little repetitive to save space. \ â€¢	On page 4, paragraph 3, the authors discuss Facades [13].  This work came up in discussion at the PC meeting, and it was noted that Facades *did* permit the change of program behaviors via the widget replacement functionality. This is inconsistent with the way the work is presented right now. \  \ After checking the Facades paper again, we found this mistake and would like to remove this sentence â€œNeither does it support changing or adding program behaviors.â€ù in the section â€œComparison with previous approachesâ€ù. \

Title: Design Considerations for Parallel Performance Tools
Author list: Roman Atachiants, David Gregg, Kim Jarvis, Gavin Doherty
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Trinity College, The University of Dublin
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: Trinity College, The University of Dublin
Primary Affiliation 3 - Institution: Trinity College, The University of Dublin
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: Trinity College, The University of Dublin
Abstract: In recent years there has been a shift in microprocessor manufacture from building single-core processors towards providing multiple cores on the same chip. This shift has meant that a much wider population of developers are faced with the task of developing parallel software: a difficult, time consuming and expensive process. With the aim of identifying issues, emerging practices and design opportunities for support, we present in this paper a qualitative study in which we interviewed a range of software developers, in both industry and academia. We then perform a systematic analysis of the data and identify several cross-cutting themes. These analysis themes include the practical relevance of the probe effect, the significance of orchestration models in development and the mismatch between currently available tools and developers' needs. We also identify an important characteristic of parallel programming, where the process of optimisation goes hand in hand with the process of debugging, as opposed to clearer distinctions which may be made in traditional programming. We conclude with reflection on how the study can inform the design of software tools to support developers in the endeavour of parallel programming. \

Title: Understanding Multitasking Through Parallelized Strategy Exploration and Individualized Cognitive Modeling
Author list: Yunfeng Zhang, Anthony J. Hornof
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Dept. of Computer Science and Information Science
Abstract: Human multitasking often involves complex task interactions and subtle tradeoffs which might be best understood through detailed computational cognitive modeling, yet traditional cognitive modeling approaches may not explore a sufficient range of task strategies to reveal the true complexity of multitasking behavior. This study proposes a systematic approach for exploring a large number of strategies using a computer-cluster-based parallelized modeling system. The paper demonstrates the efficacy of the approach for investigating and revealing the effects of different microstrategies on human performance, both within and across individuals, for a time-pressured multimodal dual task. The modeling results suggest that multitasking performance is not simply a matter of interleaving cognitive and sensorimotor processing but is instead heavily influenced by the selection of subtask microstrategies.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This project pushes the boundaries of computational cognitive modeling by employing a computing cluster to explore a complex strategy and parameter space and to reveal the complexity with which humans multitask.
Summary of Changes: This submission improves the presentation of the paper and addresses the following comments from the reviewers: \  \ 1. We have reframed the paper to make it more relevant to the general CHI audience by mentioning how the task is similar to many other multitasking settings such as driving and how what we learned from this task could apply to these other multitasking settings.  (p.4, left column, bottom) \  \ 2. We have added references to relevant studies.  We referenced Gray and Boehm-Davis [5] on p.3 right column,  Janssen and Brumby [10] and Kieras and Meyer [12] on p.4 left column. \  \ 3. We explained how the 5 strategy dimensions were chosen on p.4 left column. \  \ 4. We discussed how these strategies could be relevant to other types of multitasking settings on p.4 left column. \  \ 5. We added some discussion about the learning effects in this experiment on p.2 left column. \  \ 6. We took to heart the observation of our strongest advocate, R1, that this work is necessarily complex and made extensive efforts to reduce the complexity of the presentation wherever possible.  We devised names for all of the microstrategies in the paper, and replaced all codes such as Microstrategy 3b with more semantically relevant phrases such as Track-Then-Eyes-To-Sound, and then used these new phrases in places of the codes in the graphs, dramatically reducing the need for readers to flip from page to page to interpret the content of the graphs.  We also reformatted the graphs to increase their legibility. \  \ We are delighted to have the opportunity to go far beyond the reviewers' requests for improvements.

Title: In Situ with Bystanders of Augmented Reality Glasses: Perspectives on Recording and Privacy-Mediating Technologies
Author list: Tamara Denning, Zakariya Dehlawi, Tadayoshi Kohno
Abstract: Augmented reality (AR) devices are poised to enter the market. It is unclear how the properties of these devices will affect individualsâ€™ privacy. In this study, we investigate the privacy perspectives of individuals when they are bystanders around AR devices. We conducted 12 field sessions in cafÃ©s and interviewed 31 bystanders regarding their reactions to a co-located AR device. Participants were predominantly split between having indifferent and negative reactions to the device. Participants who expressed that AR devices change the bystander experience attributed this difference to subtleness, ease of recording, and the technologyâ€™s lack of prevalence. Additionally, participants surfaced a variety of factors that make recording more or less acceptable, including what they are doing when the recording is being taken. Participants expressed interest in being asked permission before being recorded and in recording-blocking devices. We use the interview results to guide an exploration of design directions for privacy-mediating technologies.

Title: A Novel Knee Rehabilitation System for the Home
Author list: Mobolaji Ayoade, Lynne Baillie
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: Interactive and Trustworthy Technologies Research Group
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Interactive and Trustworthy Technologies  Research Group
Abstract: In this paper, we describe the design and evaluation of an interactive home-based rehabilitation visualisation system used by a wide variety of ages (users in our studies were aged from 47-89) to undertake rehabilitation in the home following knee replacement surgery. We present the rehabilitation visualization system and the results of a randomized controlled study in which we investigated the usability and feasibility of the system in the home. We found that our users were able to use the system successfully for their rehabilitation with improved rehabilitation outcomes after 6 weeks when compared to the current rehabilitation care. Finally we highlight the lessons learned which will benefit prospective designers of home rehabilitation technology in ensuring successful home evaluations in clinical rehabilitation.

Title: Modeling the Functional Area of the Thumb on Mobile Touchscreen Surfaces
Author list: Joanna Bergstrom-Lehtovirta, Antti Oulasvirta
Primary Affiliation 1 - Institution: Helsinki Institute for Information Technology HIIT, Aalto University and University of Helsinki
Abstract: We present a predictive model for the functional area of the thumb on a touchscreen surface: the area of the interface reachable by the thumb of the hand that is holding the device. We derive a quadratic formula by analyzing the kinematics of the gripping hand.  Model fit is high for the thumb-motion trajectories of 20 participants. The model predicts the functional area for a given 1) surface size, 2) hand size, and 3) position of the index finger on the back of the device. Designers can use this model to ensure that a user interface is suitable for interaction with the thumb. The model can also be used inversely--that is, to infer the grips assumed by a given user interface layout.

Summary of Changes: A professional proofreader checked the grammar and readability of the paper after other changes had been made. The introduction was condensed to better emphasize the generalizability and utility of the model. The Previous Work was re-organized to two sections: Kinesiology and Biomechanics, and Humanâ€“Computer Interaction. The former now shows the related concepts in kinesiology of the thumb functional area and explains why the existing models there cannot be directly applied to thumb input on touchscreens. The latter suggests there exists a need for this model in HCI and among the designers. To address generalizability, we also provide the anthropometric distribution of our sample. We obtained hand size data of Oulasvirta et al, and compared the model outcome in our examples. The generalizability and contributions were also discussed by comparing the model to designer's heuristics. \

Title: Modeling the Perception of User Performance
Author list: Max Nicosia, Antti Oulasvirta, Per Ola Kristensson
Abstract: This paper studies how users perceive their own performance in two alternative user interfaces. We extend methodology from psychophysics to the study of interactive performance and conduct two experiments in order to create a model of usersâ€™ perception of their own performance. In our studies, two interfaces are sequentially used in a pointing task, and users are asked to rate in which interface their performance was higher. We first differentiate the effects of objective performance (speed and accuracy) versus interface qualities (distance between elements and width of elements) on perceived performance. We then derive a model that predicts the amount of change required in an interface for users to reliably detect a difference. The model is useful as a heuristic for predicting if a new interface design is better enough for users to reliably appreciate the obtained gain in user performance. We validate the model via a separate user study, and conclude by discussing how to apply our findings to design problems.

Title: Searching for Myself:  Motivations and Strategies for Self-Search
Non-embedded fonts: Arial Times_New_Roman Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial,Italic Times_New_Roman,BoldItalic Arial,BoldItalic Helvetica,Bold
Author list: Catherine C, Marshall, SiÃ¢n Lindley
Abstract: We present findings from a qualitative study of self-search, also known as ego or vanity search. In the context of a broader study about personal online content, participants were asked to search for themselves using their own computers and the browsers and queries they would normally adopt. Our analysis highlights five motivations for self-search: as a form of identity management; to discover reactions to and reuse of user-generated media; to re-find personal content; as a form of entertainment; and to reveal lost or forgotten content. Strategies vary according to motivation, and may differ markedly from typical information-seeking, with users looking deep into the results and using image search to identify content about themselves. We argue that two dimensions underpin ways of improving self-search: controllability and expectedness, and discuss what these dimensions imply for design.

Title: Generating Implications for Design through Design Research
Author list: Corina Sas, Steve Whittaker, Steven P Dow, Jodi L Forlizzi, John Zimmerman
Primary Affiliation 2 - Institution: University of California at Santa Cruz
Abstract: A central tenet of HCI is that technology should be user-centric, with designs being based around social science findings about users. Nevertheless a repeated but critical challenge in design is translating empirical findings into actionable ideas that inform design, or generating implica-tions for design. Despite various design methods aiming to bridge this gap, knowledge informing design is still seen as problematic. However there has been little empirical explo-ration into what design researchers understand by such design knowledge, the functions and principles behind their creation. We report on interviews with twelve expert HCI design researchers probing the roles and types of design implications, and the process of generating and evaluating them. We synthesize different types of design implications into a framework to guide their generation. Our findings identify a broader range than previously described, addi-tional sources and heuristics supporting their development as well some important evaluation criteria. We discuss the value of these findings for interaction design research.

Title: Poverty on the Cheap: Estimating Poverty Maps Using Aggregated Mobile Communication Networks
Author list: Christopher Smith-Clarke, Afra Mashhadi, Licia Capra
Abstract: Governments and other organisations often rely on data collected by household surveys and censuses to identity areas in most need of regeneration and development projects. However, due to the high cost associated with the data collection process, many developing countries conduct such surveys very infrequently and include only a rather small sample of the population, thus failing to accurately capture the current socio-economic status of the country's population. In this paper, we address this problem by means of a methodology that relies on an alternative source of data from which to derive up to date poverty indicators, at a very fine level of spatio-temporal granularity. Taking two developing countries as examples, we show how to analyse the aggregated call detail records of mobile phone subscribers and extract features that are strongly correlated with poverty indexes currently derived from census data.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We describe and test a methodology for estimating poverty levels from mobile communication patterns in developing regions. Tools built upon these results would be cheap to implement and provide interpretable results in a timely manner.
Summary of Changes: The most important issue highlighted in the post-rebuttal reviews was making a convincing case for the paperâ€™s contribution to HCI research. To address this we have modified  the Introduction and Discussion sections so to emphasise both the impact on potential users of the methodology, on privacy of mobile phone users, which is an important theme in HCI, and also the fact that patterns of human interaction mediated by technology, and the social network represented by the data, is central to the analysis undertaken; which ties this work in with previous works appearing at CHI and other HCI venues. We have also rewritten some of the Related Work section in order to make this relation to other works clearer - note that many of the references in the blue part of the Related Work section have appeared in CHI, CSCW, ICWSM and UMAP, all of which are more or less HCI venues. \  \ In the Dataset Description section we have explained the difference in aggregation between our and previous work.  \  \ At the end of the Feature Extraction section we have argued that the latter three features are not simply alternative measures of overall usage, and relatedly, at the end of the Results section we argue that including all features in the presentation is a valuable exercise.  \  \ At the beginning of the Results sections we explain that correlation in the aggregate data is not to be expected given correlation in the individual data.  \  \ Finally, toward the end of the discussion section we discuss in more detail the issues of generalisation of results and exclusion of disadvantaged groups.

Title: Making Public Things: How HCI Design Can Express Matters of Concern
Author list: Carl DiSalvo, Jonathan Lukens, Thomas James Lodato, Tom Jenkins, Tanyoung Kim
Abstract: Science studies scholar Bruno Latour suggests that contemporary democracy is shifting from â€œmatters of factâ€ù to â€œmatters of concernâ€ù: contentious conditions entwined with everyday life. What is the role of human-computer interaction (HCI) design in this shift? In this paper we draw from five design projects to explore how design can express matters of concern by communicating the factors and consequences of issues.  In the process, we consider the role of design in contributing to the formation of publics and discuss an emerging orientation to publics in HCI design.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: This paper examines how design can articulate issues and give form to problematic situations. We describe this as a "public design orientationâ€ù.
Summary of Changes: In the process of making changes we focused on making stronger connections between the cases and the discussion, and writing up a more direct set of implications for both practicing designers and HCI design researchers. This required some substantial changes in the latter-half of the paper. These changes were the changes most requested by reviewers, so in focusing on them we hope to have satisfied, as best as possible, most of the issues raised. \  \ We did also address the comment that STS literature challenges distinctions between categories such as objective / subjective, rational / affective. We re-wrote those sections to communicate that the purpose of the design work was not to reinforce those distinctions, but rather to point out the messiness in the construction of those categories (as STS scholars we fully agreed with comment - it was simply poor communication on our part).  \

Title: Causing Commotion with a Shape-changing Bench  - Experiencing Shape-Changing Interfaces in Use
Author list: Erik GrÃ¶nvall, Sofie Kinch, Marianne Graves Petersen, Majken Kirkegaard Rasmussen
Abstract: In this paper we describe results from testing coMotion, a shape-changing bench, in three different contexts: a concert hall foyer, an airport departure hall and a shopping mall. We have gathered insights from more than 120 people, with regard to how users experience and make sense of the benchâ€™s shape changing capability. The paper applies McCarthy and Wrightâ€™s six different sense making processes (anticipating, connecting, interpreting, reflecting, appropriating and recounting) as an instrument to analyse peopleâ€™s experience with shape-changing furniture in the wild. The paper also introduces exploring as a seventh sense making process. Based on this analysis, the paper points to three relevant aspects when designing shape-changing artefacts for the wild, namely: 1) Affordance of shape-changing interfaces, 2) Transitions between background and foreground and 3) Interpreting physically dynamic objects.

Title: Stress and Multitasking in Everyday College Life: An Empirical Study of Online Activity
Author list: Gloria Mark, Yiran Wang, Melissa Niiya
Abstract: While HCI has focused on multitasking with information workers, we report on multitasking among Millennials who grew up with digital media--focusing on college students. We logged computer activity and used biosensors to measure stress of 48 students for 7 days for all waking hours, in their in situ environments. We found a significant positive relationship with stress and daily time spent on computers. Stress is positively associated with the amount of multitasking. Conversely, stress is negatively associated with Facebook and social media use. Heavy multitaskers use significantly more social media and report lower positive affect than light multitaskers. Night habits affect multitasking the following day: late-nighters show longer duration of computer use and those ending daily activities earlier multitask less. Our study shows that college students multitask at double the frequency compared to studies of information workers. These results can inform designs for stress management of college students.

Title: GestKeyboard: Enabling Gesture-Based Interaction on Ordinary Physical Keyboard
Author list: Haimo Zhang, Yang Li
Abstract: Stroke gestures are intuitive and efficient but often require gesture-capable input hardware such as a touchscreen. In this paper, we present GestKeyboard, a novel technique for gesturing over an ordinary, unmodified physical keyboardâ€”that remains the major input modality for existing desktop and laptop computers. We discuss an exploratory study for understanding the design space of gesturing on a physical keyboard and our algorithms for detecting gestures in a modeless way, without interfering with the keyboardâ€™s major functionality such as text entry and shortcuts activation. We explored various features for detecting gestures from a keyboard event stream. Our experiment based on the data collected from 10 participants indicated it is feasible to reliably detect gestures from normal keyboard use, 95% detection accuracy within a maximum latency of 200ms.

Title: Understanding User Adaptation Strategies for the Launching of Facebook Timeline
Author list: Pamela Wisniewski, Heng Xu, Yunan Chen
Primary Affiliation 1 - Department/Schoo: College of Information Sciences and Technology
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: College of Information Sciences and Technology
Abstract: This paper applies coping theory to understand user adaptation strategies to major interface changes on Social Networking Sites (SNSs). Specifically, we qualitatively examine 1,149 user comments posted to the Facebookâ€™s official Timeline blog in order to get a large and unobtrusive sample of real Facebook usersâ€™ perceptions about the launch of Timeline. Our data suggests a high level of stress associated with the transition to the new interface introduced by Timeline. We also found evidence which suggests that increasing usersâ€™ perceptions of control over major interface changes may help facilitate user adaptation to these changes. This study offers valuable insights to SNSs for mitigating user stress and facilitating successful adaptation during major interface changes.

We were able to address all of the revisions that we outlined in our rebuttal. Here is a brief description of our main revisions: \  \ â€¢ We revised the coding of loss of design/intended use, simplicity, and functionality.  After revisiting the data, it seemed more appropriate to group intended use and functionality together. Both spoke to the fact that Facebook changed the way users interacted with the site. Title: Towards a Closer Dialogue between Policy and Practice: Responsible Design in HCI
Author list: Barbara Grimpe, Mark Hartswood, Marina Jirotka
Abstract: Given the potent and pervasive nature of modern technologies, this paper lays out the complexities involved in achieving responsible design. In order to do this we will first compare an emerging policy-oriented programme of research known as RRI (Responsible Research and Innovation) with initiatives in HCI. A focus on the similarities and differences may highlight to what extent responsibility is already and successfully embedded within the concerns and practices of design and use, and what may yet need to be incorporated for responsible design. The paper then discusses the challenges of 'naturalising' the very ambitious programme of RRI within specific design activities and concerns, through the lens of four analytic concepts: reflexivity; responsiveness; inclusion; and anticipation. Finally, we make a case for a pragmatic, â€˜unromanticâ€™, but engaged reinterpretation of RRI for HCI.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We compare Responsible Research and Innovation, an emerging policy-oriented research programme, with HCI initiatives and make a case for a pragmatic, 'unromantic', yet engaged reinterpretation of RRI for HCI.
Summary of Changes: â€œTowards a Closer Dialogue between Policy and Practice: Responsible Design in HCIâ€ù  \ Paper number 2160 \ CHI 2014 \  \ Revision report  \  \ R3 questioned the merit of the paper by arguing that it lacks significant insights. We have clarified our contribution in the abstract, introduction and in our conclusions. We provide a systematic, nuanced comparison of the RRI agenda and HCI research and design (instead of hasty conclusions such as, â€˜RRI needs to be adoptedâ€™ or â€˜the RRI agenda is unrealisticâ€™ etc.). And we make a case for a pragmatic, â€˜unromanticâ€™ and yet engaged reinterpretation of RRI principles for HCI research and design. This way we also respond to R5 who was not sure what to take away from the paper, and what the core novel contribution is. \  \ This clarified line of reasoning and contribution is supported by our discussion of Lynchâ€™s concept of reflexivity. This was a central request of various reviewers: to include a discussion of his approach, and how it relates to RRI and design. This is now a crucial part of the â€œreflexivityâ€ù section and our conclusions.  \  \ We have included a methodology section that explains our case selection strategy, as requested by R2. \  \ We now draw many more, and clearer, conclusions for HCI than for RRI. But we also explain a few points where HCI can critically â€˜talk backâ€™ to RRI. In this regard we discuss the merits of unreflected tacit knowledge, and the concept of the â€˜provocative designerâ€™ (conclusions). \  \ We improved the structure of our paper, as required by R2. We completed the discussion of the perspectives, temporality and scope dimensions for all sections (e.g. in â€œinclusionâ€ù). We also rewrote our conclusions substantially and think that they are much clearer now. \  \ We have made much more explicit throughout the paper (introduction, conclusions, and in the middle) that â€˜responsible designâ€™ is a collaborative effort that requires rethinking and reorganisation of an entire ecosystem of stakeholders (e.g. funders, regulatory agencies) beyond the individual designer, and beyond a projectâ€™s termination (â€œinstitutional reflexivityâ€ù and â€œinstitutional responsibilityâ€ù). This answers R1â€™s concerns.  \  \ As promised in our rebuttal, we have elaborated on how to think of regulating in the wild. â€œAnticipatory governanceâ€ù is now discussed more explicitly in the section on anticipation and in the conclusions. Thereby we have also reacted to R3 (who had criticised that our statement about the poles of acceptance and rejection was banal). We now show more clearly in which sense technology regulation is a matter of user practice, and user agency, from the local to larger-scale community levels. To strengthen our point we referred to the â€˜slow technologyâ€™ movement, and in our conclusions we added a related discussion of â€œenvisioningâ€ù in design (Reeves). R2 had recommended that we include Reeves in our paper, so we think we found an effective way to do so.  \  \ We have included a paragraph on (supposedly) irresponsible design in the introduction, a point raised by R 1. We coupled this with an argument from standpoint theory (Haraway), which strengthens our case for a pragmatic, â€˜unromanticâ€™ and yet engaged understanding of RRI. Thereby we have also responded to R4 (include â€œfeminist standpoint theoryâ€ù, if possible). \  \ As requested by R1, we have clarified our stance on uncertainty. We regard uncertainty as a fundamental feature of reality (see the â€œanticipationâ€ù section and the â€œenvisioningâ€ù discussion in the conclusions) and also as one of the reasons why (ir)responsible design cannot be identified easily (see introduction). \  \ In the â€œreflexivityâ€ù section we have included a discussion of Harper et al. as requested by R1. \  \ We repositioned the â€œgroup reflexivityâ€ù argument (Moncur) â€“ R 3 had argued that we were â€œpicking hairsâ€ù, but we have made it clear now that this is (just) one type of reflexivity among others, and (just) one element within our broader pragmatic interpretation of the concept of reflexivity (conclusions). \  \ The â€œfour pillarsâ€ù repetition (R5) has been removed. \  \ Given the limited text space we had to take the following further decisions: \ - We could include only some of the additional literature suggested by R4 and R2, but we hope that the ones that we did include, and discussed, are now integrated well. Apart from the authors already mentioned we also included Rosner/Bean in the discussion o f (ir)responsible design, and how difficult it is to identify the latter (introduction). \ - In order to â€˜gainâ€™ text space for the necessary changes and amendments we removed some references from the original submission. First, there were those that we did not consider central to our line of reasoning (e.g. Douglas et al.; Stengers/Deutscher). Second, we removed the Knorr Cetina reference and the related paragraph (reflexivity section). R5 had argued that the latter would need further explanation. We agreed and decided that we rather remove the entire original paragraph instead of extending it. We also removed references that were already â€˜coveredâ€™ by others. For instance, Roco et al. is a reference to exemplify the relevance of the RRI discourse beyond Europe, but this argument is also well represented by Randles et al. or Schienke et al.

Title: Pervasive Information through Constant Personal Projection: The Ambient Mobile Pervasive Display (AMP-D)
Author list: Christian Winkler, Julian Seifert, David Dobbelstein, Enrico Rukzio
Abstract: The vision of pervasive ambient information displays which show relevant information has not yet come true. One of the main reasons is the limited number of available displays in the environment which is a fundamental requirement of the original vision. We introduce the concept of an Ambient Mobile Pervasive Display AMP-D which is a wearable projector system that constantly projects an ambient information display in front of the user. The floor display provides serendipitous access to public and personal information. The display is combined with a projected display on the user's hand, forming a continuous interaction space that is controlled by hand gestures. The paper introduces this novel device concept, discusses its interaction design, and explores its advantages through various implemented application examples. Furthermore, we present the AMP-D prototype which illustrates the involved challenges concerning hardware, sensing, and visualization.

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: We present constant personal projection as a novel pervasive display, including new interaction techniques, a prototype with various application examples, our lessons learned from the prototype's evolution and a small user study.
Summary of Changes: Related Work: We added WorldKit as recommended by 2AC and changed the last sentence of the first paragraph of Related Work to "Different to these works, \\ampd also supports passive usage of projected augmentations and multiple projected displays." to better differentiate AMP-D against related works in the field of personal projection (as recommended by 2AC). \  \ Evaluation: As promised, we added negative Likert-scale results as well as more critical answers to open ended questions as well as participants' additional application ideas. \  \ Novelty: We rephrased our contribution statement at the end of the introduction a little. \  \ Ambient aspect: We extended the "Pervasive and Ambient Floor Display" section by citing Pousman and Stasko's paper about ambient systems and briefly explaining why AMP-D can be called an ambient display according to their definition. \  \ As proposed, we added a citation to "Full 6dof pose estimation from geo-located images" by Arth, C., Reitmayr, G., and Schmalstieg, D to the "Limitations and Future Improvements" section. This paper explains how indoor localization can be accomplished using, for instance, indoor views of Google Street View and thereby presents a possible implementation for world-wide indoor localization. \  \ Video: We added text overlays to the elevator and traffic signal application scenarios saying that the interfacing was simulated. \  \ Added a subtitle to Figure 7. \ Added Acknowledgements.

Abstract: The negative aspects of smartphone overuse on young adults, such as sleep deprivation and attention deficits, are being increasingly recognized recently. This emerging issue motivated us to analyze the usage patterns related to smartphone overuse. We investigate smartphone usage for 95 college students using surveys, logged data, and interviews. We first divide the participants into risk and non-risk groups based on self-reported rating scale for smartphone overuse. We then analyze the usage data to identify between-group usage differences, which ranged from the overall usage patterns to app-specific usage patterns. Compared with the non-risk group, our results show that the risk group has longer usage time per day and different diurnal usage patterns. Also, the risk group users are more susceptible to push notifications, and tend to consume more online content. We characterize the overall relationship between usage features and smartphone overuse using analytic modeling and provide detailed illustrations of problematic usage behaviors based on interview data.

Thumbnail Image Caption: Smartphone overuse is an emerging social issue on technology use. We investigate how actual smartphone use is related to smartphone overuse through an exploratory data analysis of multiple datasets.
Auxiliary Material Descriptive (Read-me: As the reviewers and AC suggested, we decided to remove the descriptive figures that were not directly related to illustrating the main findings. In the Appendix section, we put these figures as well as other results that were not included in the paper. The name of the Appendix file is "chi14_addiction_supplement.pdf"  \  \ The following is a brief summary of the Appendix section: We begin with summarizing usage features that were used in this work. We then detail the descriptive statistics various usage features that are important to understand the usage differences and similarities. First, we report the session duration and inter-session duration distributions, and show the diurnal patterns of usage sessions. We illustrate more detailed information about top-ranked apps (i.e., top-1, top-2) and report the distribution of the number of unique apps. Second, we plot diurnal usage patterns of MIM and web browsing. Third, we report detailed information about internal and external sessions (e.g., CI values, p-values). \  \
Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Smartphone overuse is an emerging social issue on technology use. We investigate how actual smartphone use is related to smartphone overuse through an exploratory data analysis of multiple datasets.
Summary of Changes: [Revision Letter] \ Dear Coordinator of #2175 - \  \ We really appreciate your time and effort for shepherding our paper. We revised the paper as we proposed in the revision planning letter. We carefully considered reviewers' major concerns (particularly about improving its presentation). The following summarizes the revision work done since then.   \  \ 1. Improved introduction section (highlighting the key findings) \ 2. Tightened the related work & methodology sections \ 3. Changed the presentation of the result section  \ 4. Re-wrote the discussion section by summarizing the key findings and discussing their implications, including their relevance/impact in HCI and related fields \ 5. Made a separate analysis section for the regression and classification tests   \ 6. Proofread the manuscript with a native speaker.   \ 7. Created an Appendix section. \  \ Here's revision letter in MS word format:  \ https://www.dropbox.com/s/4fmu0zmq8lzzuro/revision_letter.docx  \  \ In the following, we illustrate more details about each revision work.  \  \  \ 1. Introduction  \ Reviewers commented that the key findings should be clearly delivered; and the result section also needs to be updated accordingly.  In our revision, we tightened the introduction part and re-wrote the summary of the findings as follows:  \   \ Our results uncover several usage patterns that are closely related to smartphone addiction. The risk group spent more time on smartphone use per day (risk group: 253.0 min vs. non-risk group: 207.0 min) than the non-risk group and showed diurnal usage differences (more usage in the morning and evening). For the risk group, usage sessions that were initiated by the push notifications were longer, showing the evidence that notifications acted as external cues for problematic usage. The risk group consumed significantly more online content that can provide instant gratifications (e.g., pastime, entertainment, information seeking). \   \ These findings were corroborated by the results of our analytic modeling and analysis of interview data. Regression analysis shows that the key factors of smartphone addiction such as interference, withdrawal, and tolerance were closely related to usage features. In addition, we use machine learning techniques to experiment with the prediction power of usage features and show that smartphone addiction can be accurately \ classified at the F-score of 0.87. The interview results provided more detailed instances of problematic usage behavior, such as loss of self-control when consuming online content (e.g., aimlessly seeking stimulating content from web/Facebook while in bed). Our key findings support the existing theories about technological addictions [11, 16, 10]. Repeated consumption of stimulating content may lead to addictive \ behaviors, and problematic behaviors are largely dependent on usage function rather than usage amount. \   \  \ 2. Related Work & Methodology Sections \ R1 commented that Related Work & Methodology sections can be tightened; and also some of the less clear sentences need to be fixed.    \  \ * In our revision, we shortened our discussion on Internet-related addiction work and tried to relate the prior work with mobile addiction.   \ * We explicitly stated relevance/difference of this work to the existing work, at the end of each sub-section in the background and related work section.  \ * We re-wrote a list of less-clear or long sentences that R1 commented (e.g., fixing grammar errors, removing â€œand so onâ€ù, explaining what instant rewards means). We updated the description on the work by Amesâ€™ and Harmonâ€™s as R1 suggested.   \ * R1 suggested us to reorganize Background and Related Work / HCI Research on Addictive Behavior: As R1 commented, we listed an example along with each category for easy of understanding.  \   \ The Methodology section was revised as follows:  \ * We tightened a few places with verbose description of data collection and analysis methodologies (as R1 and R3 commented). For instance, some verbose description of SmartLogger app was tightened.  \ * R1 commented that our participants were not entirely in their 20s, and the current description needs to be changed accordingly. We followed R1â€™s suggestion and updated the description as follows: we change â€œyoung population in their 20sâ€ù to â€œcollege students.â€ù  \  \  \ 3. Improving presentation of the result sections  \ We revised the result sections by following the reviewersâ€™ guidelines. As R1/R2 commented, we revised its presentation by tabularizing the relevant and important statistical results. We replaced the figures (displaying raw distributions) with the tables to accommodate the reviewersâ€™ comments.   \  \  * In Table 2, we presented the results about overall usage (i.e., aggregated usage, session-level usage, top-k app usage).  \  \  * Table 3: we presented the results about communication app usage (overall, MIMâ€™s usage amount/frequency, inter-app/notification usage/frequency, etc.)  \  \ Another concern raised by the reviewers was about delivering statistical test results. In the table, we clearly stated the following information: 1) mean value, 2) 95% confidence interval; 2) t-value; 3) exact p-value (two-tailed); 4) effect size (Cohenâ€™s d).    \ As the shepherd suggests, we will submit the supplement material that include some of the missing materials (e.g., raw distribution about usage features).   \  \ R2 has a concern with statistical significance with diurnal analysis. We found that statistical significance can be improved when the number of time segments is small (as Min et al. did [1]). The resulting p-values were adjusted for multiple testing using Bonferroni correction. Figure 5 in the revised version clearly shows that significant differences on usage time were found in the morning and evening time blocks. Overall, each time block has small to medium effect size (Cohenâ€™s d). It is likely that risk group users spend more time over the course of a day.  \  \ [1] Min et al; CSCW 2013, Mining smartphone data to classify life-facets of social relationships, Jun-Ki Min, Jason Wiese, Jason I. Hong, John Zimmerman.  \  \ * We revised â€œOVERALL USAGE PATTERN DIFFERENCESâ€ù section as follows. As R1 commented, we decided not to present â€œrawâ€ù distributions in the figures; accordingly, we removed the description part accordingly. We tried our best to illustrate the key features that we extracted from the dataset; e.g., improved explanation of entropy measure.   \  \ * At the end of each subsection, we have a small section that summarizes the key findings. We originally provided a brief summary of the results in the beginning of each section. But in the revised version, we think that putting together all the findings in a given section is more useful for reasoning about usage behavior relating to smartphone addiction.  \  \  (OVERALL USAGE PATTERN DIFFERENCES) \ Our results showed that the risk group users spent more time on smartphone use than the non-risk group (risk: 253.0 vs. non-risk: 207.0 min). The risk group users tended to use smartphones more frequently and to have longer usage sessions. Their app usage was more skewed to a small number of frequently used apps. In particular, significant differences were found on usage amount/frequency of the first ranked apps. Also, diurnal usage differences were observed, with the risk group spending more time on smartphone use in the morning/evening than the non-risk group. Despite such usage differences, significant differences were not found on the number of unique apps used (risk: 66.1 vs. non-risk: 65.5).  \  \ (Communication App Use) \ For mobile communications, our participants mainly used MIMs: its usage was over 60 minutes and 90% of over 400 notifications per day was from MIMs. While significant differences in overall MIM usage were not found, there were tendencies (the effect size > 0.2) that the risk group uses MIM longer and more frequently than the non-risk group. When dividing smartphone usage into internally/externally cued sessions, we found that 79% of usage was considered as external usage (e.g., MIM, Facebook). We found that the risk groupâ€™s usage time of MIM-initiated sessions was significantly greater than those of the non-risk group. This result confirms that MIM notification act as external cues for smartphone usage and can be considered one cause of problematic smartphone usage. \  \ (Web Browsing App Use) \ Our results showed that compared to the non-risk group, the risk group browsed the web more often, had different diurnal usage patterns, and tended to exhibit the content consumption behavior of seeking more stimulating content (e.g., visiting web portals, checking trending issues). Moreover, a few of the risk group participants excessively consumed possibly stimulating content on the online communities and exhibited unique surfing patterns to seek for stimulating content. \  \  \ 4. Added more discussions on findings, including their relevance/impact in HCI \ As reviewers commented, we worked hard to provide thorough and deep discussion about our findings by emphasizing their relevance and impact in the field of HCI.  \  \ Our exploratory data analysis revealed usage patterns relating to smartphone addiction. We found that the risk group spent more time than the non-risk group on smartphone usage. While the number of used apps was similar, the risk group showed a more skewed usage pattern on a few frequently used apps. In addition, significant diurnal usage differences were found. The risk group used smartphones for longer periods in the morning and evening. Overall, our participants mainly used smartphones for communications. MIM was the most frequently used app, followed by voice calls, SMS, and emails. They received a surprising number of MIM notifications per day (> 400). We found that the risk group spent more time on MIM-triggered sessions. This result serves as evidence that MIM notifications act as external cues for excessive smartphone usage. Another major usage was for consuming various kinds of online content. The risk group users spent more time on the web for consuming such stimulating content. \  \ According to our analysis, the overall difference in usage times between the risk/non-risk groups is not substantially large (< 50 minutes). In addiction literature, however, researchers concurred that excessive and problematic usage of technology is largely dependent on usage function rather than usage amount [11, 16]. For example, repeated usage that is intended for mood adjustment purposes (e.g., relieving boredom, stress, or depression) may form habitual usage (lowering self-control) and lead to addictive behaviors (losing self-control) \ [11, 16, 10]. \  \ Our regression results also confirmed that smartphone addiction is closely related to the content consumption function of smartphones. Our interview results provided a detailed evidence of addictive usage behaviors. The risk group lacked rational self-control, particularly when consuming stimulating content (e.g., aimlessly following web/Facebook links while in the bed). These findings contribute to existing scholarship about addiction scale development and problematic usage behaviors [15, 5, 22]. \  \ Smartphone usage has been studied thoroughly in the literature [8, 4, 21]. Our work supplements existing measurement studies [8, 4, 21] because we are reporting recent smartphone usage patterns (e.g., mobile instant messaging) and dealing with problematic usage behaviors, an emerging social issue associated with technology use. When compared with the usage statistics of the earlier datasets that were collected in 2009 [8] and 2010 [4], we observed significant changes in usage behaviors. We posit that much longer usage (224.7 min vs. 59.2 min [4]) may be due to the participant demographics and the network effect of smartphones and mobile instant messaging. Moreover, our work extends Oulasvirta et al.â€™s work [21] by examining real usage patterns from the perspective of smartphone addiction and showing the importance of externally cued usage behaviors. \  \ Our work contributes new knowledge about usage practices related to mobile communications [17, 3, 12]. We dealt with the latest trends for MIM use. As reported, we found that its usage is prevalent and can be indicative of addiction risks (e.g., causing negative impacts on an individualâ€™s personal and social activities). Thus, our results provide insights into understanding the impact of semi-synchronous communication channels, like MIM, on the social expectations related to constant connectivity [3] and interruption management practices [17]. \  \ Use of computing technology for promotion of health and sustainable behaviors has been of great interest to the HCI community [9]. In addition, addiction-related research has been growing recently [23, 26, 28]. Our results on usage analysis and automatic behavior assessment will be useful when designing mobile software that can moderate excessive use (e.g., visualizing smartphone usage, intervening usage with social support or pressure mechanisms, and gamifying smartphone use regulation) or enable intelligent parental controls (e.g., addressing a childâ€™s smartphone overuse). We believe that designing and evaluating intervention software would be an interesting avenue for future HCI research [7]. Our work can serve as a foundation for such research.  \  \ Similar to any cross-sectional and single-site study, the generalizability of this work may be limited due to the characteristics of our participant sample. However, an earlier measurement study partly affirms the generalizability of this work [8]; i.e., fine-grained usage features such as session time distribution exhibited consistent patterns across the datasets collected from different sites. Future studies should be conducted using different sites, demographics, mobile devices/platforms, and cultural backgrounds in order to explore these topics further and confirm the results. Moreover, the current analysis can be extended by investigating additional contextual factors such as location and transport modes, and other content categories such as social networking and mobile games. \  \  \ 5. Created a separate analysis section for the regression and classification tests   \ In our submission version, classification tests (machine learning) are located in the "discussion" section. And regression results are located in the "problematic usage behavior" section. As suggested in the rebuttal letter, we put these two parts together as a separate section before the "problematic usage behavior" section (i.e., at the end of quantitative analysis and the beginning of qualitative analysis).  As reviewers commented, we clearly stated the key features selected from multiple regression and classification results. Also, we explained that our goal with machine learning is to experiment with the prediction power of the features that we explored. The following is the excerpt from the revised version:  \  \ ANALYTIC MODELING OF USAGE BEHAVIOR \  \ Our results reveal quantitative features on usage between the risk and non-risk group. However, these results do not clarify how the usage features are associated with the self-report addiction level and how well they can predict the potential of smartphone addiction. We thus examined how much each usage feature contributed to the addiction scale through multiple regression analysis. We then demonstrate the prediction power of usage features with machine learning techniques that can automatically classify users into the risk/non-risk groups based on the usage data. \  \ Regression Analysis \  \ The key factors (or symptoms) in the Smartphone Addiction Proneness Scale include interferences with work/personal activities (interference), virtual world orientation (virtual), emotional alterations such as anxiety and irritation if smartphone use is impeded (withdrawal), and habituated usage without reducing usage amount (tolerance) [14]. Due to our limited sample size for regression analysis, we chose a set of representative features that could be used to characterize general usage behaviors including overall usage features (usage time/frequency, top-1 app usage time/frequency, top-5 app entropy, and usage time in 6-12/18-24 blocks) and category-specific usage features (MIM usage time/frequency, Web usage time/frequency, MIM/Web usage time in 6-12/18-24 blocks, external MIM session frequency, and aggregated MIM external session length/time). \  \   \ Table 6 summarizes the regression results. Overall, the usage time/frequency were highly related with smartphone addiction. Considering that the usage of instant messaging is dominant, we posited that its usage plays a critical role in problematic usage behaviors. Incoming MIM messages act as external usage cues for smartphone use. Those participants who felt more interference tended to have longer session sequence lengths of MIM initiated sessions. Moreover, web usage and external cues were related to the tolerance factor; consuming stimulating content on the web causes people to continue to use smartphones. \  \ These observations match with the well-known theories of technological addiction [11, 16, 10]. Repeated content consumption (message exchanges, web content) forms habitual usage (lowering self-control) and can eventually lead to addictive behaviors (losing self-control). External cues such as incoming messages, further reinforce a potentially addictive cycle. \  \  \ Classification Analysis \  \ We used machine learning algorithms to automatically classify whether a person belongs to the risk group. For model training, we considered all the features that we explored in the earlier sections. For each feature, we considered the basic statistics: mean, median, SD, and soft min/max (meanÂ±2SD). We used the classification models in Weka v3.6 such as J48 Decision Tree (DT), Naive Bayes (NB), Support Vector Machines (SVM). We reduced the number of features using the Information Gain filter and Rank-based search algorithms. To demonstrate the importance of feature categories, we tested the performance with different category combinations (see Table 7). The general set contained the general usage features such as usage time/frequency, top-k entropies, and sequence length. The temporal set included the diurnal usage features for aggregated usage and category-specific usage. The category set included the category-level usage features (no temporal aspects). The external set included all the usage features for the external sessions. The models were evaluated using 10-fold cross validation. The dataset was divided into 10 roughly equal parts. One part was left out for validation, and the rest were used for training. By repeating this for each part, the average performance of the classifiers were estimated. \  \   \ In Table 7, we report the best accuracy, precision, recall, and F-score values. We achieved the best performance when the category set was used with Decision Tree (F-score = 0.87). The ranked features in the best model included web usage time (mean, SD, median), SNS usage time (SD), SNS usage frequency (soft max, median), inter-MIM time (median), inter-browser time (mean, SD, soft max). In contrast, the performance was dropped when all the features were employed; ranked features include four general features, four category features, and two diurnal features. In addition, we examined the prediction power of each feature set. The performance of the general and temporal feature sets did not differ substantially, but the external feature set had the worst performance. To measure performance gain for each feature set, we trained the classifiers by excluding each set. As shown in the table, removing the category feature set resulted in a significant drop in performance, which shows its importance for classification. Moreover, the general features influenced the overall performance negatively. In summary, we found that investigating various category-specific usage patterns was critical, and our classification model allowed us to accurately classify whether a person belonged to the risk group. While the current work is mainly focused on communications and web browsing, our feature selection results indicated the importance of other features. Exploring other categories such as social networking and mobile games is part of our future work \  \  \ 6. Proofreading \ The draft was reviewed by the professional proofreader who fixed many of the grammar and style errors. The readability of the draft thus significantly improved.  \  \ 7. Appendix Section \ As the reviewers and AC suggested, we decided to remove the descriptive figures that were not directly related to illustrating the main findings. In the Appendix section, we put these figures as well as other results that were not included in the paper.   \  \ The following is a brief summary of the Appendix section: We begin with summarizing usage features that were used in this work. We then detail the descriptive statistics various usage features that are important to understand the usage differences and similarities. First, we report the session duration and inter-session duration distributions, and show the diurnal patterns of usage sessions. We illustrate more detailed information about top-ranked apps (i.e., top-1, top-2) and report the distribution of the number of unique apps. Second, we plot diurnal usage patterns of MIM and web browsing. Third, we report detailed information about internal and external sessions (e.g., CI values, p-values). \  \  \ 8. Final Remarks  \ Our team worked really hard to improve the quality of this paper. Please let us know if you have additional comments and suggestions about our current revision.   \  \ Again, we sincerely appreciate your time and effort for shepherding our work. I wish you a blessing New Year.  \  \ Sincerely,  \ Uichin Lee \  \

Title: HCI as a means to prosociality in the economy
Non-embedded fonts: Arial,Bold Times_New_Roman Times_New_Roman,Bold Times_New_Roman,Italic Arial Arial,Italic Helvetica,Bold
Author list: John Harvey, David Golightly, Andrew Smith
Primary Affiliation 2 - Department/Schoo: Human Factors Research Group, Faculty of Engineering
Abstract: HCI research often involves intervening in the economic lives of people, but researchers only rarely give explicit consideration to what actually constitutes prosociality in the economy. Much has been said previously regarding sustainability but this has largely focused on environmental rather than interpersonal relations. This paper provides an analysis of how prosocial HCI has been discussed and continues to be defined as a research field. Based on a corpus of published works, we describe a variety of genres of work relating to prosocial HCI. Key intellectual differences are explored, including the epistemological and ethical positions involved in designing for prosocial outcomes as well as how HCI researchers posit economic decision-making. Finally, emerging issues and opportunities for further debate and collaboration are discussed in turn.

Title: L.IVE: An Integrated Interactive Video-based Learning Environment
Author list: Toni-Jan Keith Monserrat, Yawen Li, Shengdong Zhao, Xiang Cao
Secondary Affiliation (optional) 1 - Ins: University of the Philippines Los BaÃ±os
Abstract: In this paper, we introduce L.IVE: an online interactive video-based learning environment with an alternative design and architecture that integrates three major interface components: video, comment threads, and assessments. This is in contrast with the approach of existing interfaces which visually separate these components. Our study, which compares L.IVE with existing popular video-based learning environments, suggests advantages in this integrated approach as compared to the separated approach in learning.

Title: Watching the Footwork: Second Screen Interaction at a Dance and Music Performance
Author list: Louise Barkhuus, Arvid EngstrÃ¶m, Goranka Zoric
Abstract: Interactive mobile technologies have become part of audience experiences of live performances in terms of both general media sharing and specific (sometimes official) extra content. At the same time, high bandwidth affords streaming of live events to mobile devices. We take advantage of these technologies in our high resolution, panoramic image video stream and study a scenario of audience members viewing the very same live event they are watching on a tablet. The video stream on the tablet is navigational and enables audience members to pan and zoom in the real-time video feed. We studied audience interaction and impressions in three performances of a dance and music show and found distinct uses of the second screen video stream. We emphasize that despite initial reluctance, the observed utilization of the technology opened up for new potential practices. Our study shows how working with perceived conflict in technology can still open up design space for interactive technologies.

Title: Partially Intelligent Automobiles and Driving Experience at the Moment of System Transition
Author list: Key Jung Lee, Yeon Kyoung Joo, Clifford Nass
Abstract: The current study (N = 49) took a user-centered approach to explore how level of automation (pedal automated, wheel automated or fully automated driving) and the interface modality (switching automation on or off via touch or voice control) in automated vehicles influence driversâ€™ perceived experience and performance. The results found that full or wheel automation in vehicles was perceived significantly more intelligent than pedal automation. Furthermore, drivers in the pedal automation condition reported greater nervousness when using the touch interface than the voice interface. This tendency was not found among drivers in the full and wheel automation conditions. Drivers who used the voice interface to control automated driving had fewer driving mistakes than those who operated the touch interface. Our findings have important psychological and practical implications for designing a user interface for automated vehicles.

Title: Distributed Analogical Idea Generation: Inventing with Crowds
Author list: Lixiu Yu, Aniket Kittur, Robert E Kraut
Abstract: Harnessing crowds can be a powerful mechanism for increasing innovation. However, current approaches to crowd innovation rely on large numbers of contributors generating ideas independently in an unstructured way. We introduce a new approach called distributed analogical idea generation, which aims to make idea generation more effective and less reliant on chance. Drawing from the literature in cognitive science on analogy and schema induction, our approach decomposes the creative process in a structured way amenable to using crowds. In three experiments we show that distributed analogical idea generation leads to better ideas than example-based approaches, and investigate the conditions under which crowds generate good schemas and ideas. Our results have implications for improving creativity and building systems for distributed crowd innovation.

Title: Understanding Quantified-Selfersâ€™ Practices in  Collecting and Exploring Personal Data
Author list: Eun Kyoung Choe, Nicole B Lee, Bongshin Lee, Wanda Pratt, Julie A Kientz
Abstract: Researchers have studied how people use self-tracking technologies and discovered a long list of barriers including lack of time and motivation as well as difficulty in data integration and interpretation. Despite the barriers, an increasing number of Quantified-Selfers diligently track many kinds of data about themselves, and some of them share their best practices and mistakes through Meetup talks, blogging, and conferences. In this work, we aim to gain insights from these â€œextreme users,â€ù who have used existing technologies and built their own workarounds to overcome different barriers. We conducted a qualitative and quantitative analysis of 52 video recordings of Quantified Self Meetup talks to understand what they did, how they did it, and what they learned. We highlight several common pitfalls to self-tracking, including tracking too many things, not tracking triggers and context, and insufficient scientific rigor. We identify future research efforts that could help make progress toward addressing these pitfalls. We also discuss how our findings can have broad implications in designing and developing self-tracking technologies.

Title: Exploring the Design Space of Gestural Interaction with Active Tokens through User-Defined Gestures
Author list: Consuelo Valdes, Diana Eastman, Casey Grote, Shantanu Thatte, Orit Shaer, Ali Mazalek, Brygg Ullmer, Miriam K. Konkel
Author emails: cvaldes@wellesley.edu, deastman@wellesley.edu, cgrote@wellesley.edu, sthatt1@tigers.lsu.edu, oshaer@wellesley.edu, mazalek@gatech.edu, ullmer@cct.lsu.edu, konkel@lsu.edu
Abstract: Multi-touch and tangible interfaces provide unique opportunities for enhancing learning and discovery with big data. However, existing interaction techniques have limitations when manipulating large data sets. Our goal is to define novel interaction techniques for multi-touch and tangible interfaces, which support the construction of complex queries for big data. In this paper, we present results from a study which investigates the use of gestural interaction with active tokens for manipulating large data sets. In particular, we studied user expectations of a hybrid tangible and gestural language engaging this space. Our main results include a vocabulary of user-defined gestures for interaction with active tokens, which extends beyond familiar multi-touch gestures; characterization of the design space of gestural interaction with active tokens; and insight into participantsâ€™ mental models, including common metaphors. We also present implications for the design of multi-touch and tangible interfaces with active tokens.

Title: Beyond Ethnography: Engagement and Reciprocity as Foundations for Design Research Out Here
Author list: Margot Brereton, Paul Roe, Ronald Schroeter, Anita Lee Hong
Abstract: This paper explores an emerging paradigm for HCI design research based primarily upon engagement, reciprocity and doing. Much HCI research begins with an investigatory and analytic ethnographic approach before translating to design. Design may come much later in the process and may never benefit the community that is researched. However in many settings it is difficult for researchers to access the privileged ethnographer position of observer and investigator. Moreover rapid ethnographic research often does not seem the best or most appropriate course of action. \  \ We draw upon a project working with a remote Australian Aboriginal community to illustrate an alternative approach in Indigenous research, where the notion of reciprocity is first and foremost. We argue that this can lead to sustainable designs, valid research and profound innovation. \

Title: Frenzy: Collaborative Data Organization for Creating Conference Sessions
Author list: Lydia B Chilton, Juho Kim, Paul AndrÃ©, Felicia Cordeiro, James A Landay, Daniel S Weld, Steven P Dow, Robert C Miller, Haoqi Zhang
Author emails: hmslydia@gmail.com, juhokim@mit.edu, pandre@cs.cmu.edu, felicia0@cs.washington.edu, landay@cs.washington.edu, weld@cs.washington.edu, spdow@cs.cmu.edu, rcm@mit.edu, hq@eecs.harvard.edu
Abstract: Organizing conference sessions around themes improves the experience for attendees. However, the session creation process can be difficult and time-consuming due to the amount of expertise and effort required to consider alternative paper groupings. We present a collaborative web application called Frenzy to draw on the efforts and knowledge of an entire program committee. Frenzy comprises (a) interfaces to support large numbers of experts working collectively to create sessions, and (b) a two-stage process that decomposes the session-creation problem into meta-data elicitation and global constraint satisfaction. Meta-data elicitation involves a large group of experts working simultaneously, while global constraint satisfaction involves a smaller group that uses the meta-data to form sessions.  \  \ We evaluated Frenzy with 48 people during a deployment at the CSCW 2014 program committee meeting. The session making process was much faster than the traditional process, taking 88 minutes instead of a full day. We found that meta-data elicitation was useful for session creation. Moreover, the sessions created by Frenzy were the basis of the CSCW 2014 schedule. \

Contribution & Benefit Statement (Mandat: Frenzy is a time-saving tool for conference session-making which allows organizers to incorporate many peoples' expertise in parallel to collaboratively solve the constraint of grouping papers thematically into named sessions.
Summary of Changes: Many changes were made as outlined in my rebuttal.  \  \ The three biggest changes are to the  \ Related Work, Discussion and Data Analysis Section. \  \ In the Related Work, I removed the justifications of our own design and made room for a more appropriate and historical review of systems and research that Frenzy builds upon, notable Grudin's Groupware and Social Dynamics article.   \  \ In the discussion section I outline three of the three techniques Frenzy uses that are critical to enable the collaborative community process. To make room for this, I shrank the previous discussion section which was just full of somewhat meaningless quotes. I selected only a few of the more salient ones and put them in their own subsection of the Data Analysis section. \  \ I added a more rigorous presentation of the logistic regression showing the concrete benefits of the meta-data our system collected. \  \ Additionally, all the screenshots are retaken and annotated better, typoes are fixed, I put names of anonymized people and events back in the paper (references to CSCW PC mostly) I clarified terms and language. I cut redundant explanations and non-essential examples to make extra room where needed.

Title: Protibadi: A Platform for Fighting Sexual Harassment in Urban Bangladesh
Author list: Syed Ishtiaque Ahmed, Steven J. Jackson, Nova Ahmed, Hasan Ferdous, Md. Rashidujjaman Rifat, A.S.M Rizvi, Shamir Ahmed, Rifat Sabbir Mansur
Author emails: sa738@cornell.edu, sjj54@cornell.edu, nova@northsouth.edu, webtonmoy@yahoo.com, ne.rifat@gmail.com, rizvi22222@yahoo.com, Shamir253@yahoo.com, zaquesvb@yahoo.com
Primary Affiliation 4 - Institution: Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology
Primary Affiliation 5 - Institution: Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology
Primary Affiliation 6 - Institution: Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology
Primary Affiliation 7 - Institution: Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology
Primary Affiliation 8 - Institution: Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology
Abstract: Public sexual harassment has emerged as a large and growing concern in urban Bangladesh, with deep and damaging implications for gender security, justice, and rights of public participation. In this paper we describe an integrated program of ethnographic and design work meant to understand and address such problems. For one year we conducted surveys, interviews, and focus groups around sexual harassment with women at three different universities in Dhaka. Based on this input, we developed â€œProtibadiâ€ù, a web and mobile phone based application designed to report, map, and share womenâ€™s stories around sexual harassment in public places. In August 2013 the system launched, user studies were conducted, and public responses were monitored to gauge reactions, strengths, and limits of the system. This paper describes the findings of our ethnographic and design-based work, and suggests lessons relevant to other HCI efforts to understand and design around difficult and culturally sensitive problems.
